title: LEE L. LANDES DIES; S.I. ADVANCE EDITOR
description: Lee L. Landes, managing editor of The Staten Island Advance, daily newspaper, from 1955 to 1965, and a leading Staten Island civic worker, died Wednesday night of cancer in Staten Island Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 18 Emerson Avenue, Emerson Hill, S. I.

description: JERUSALEM, May 2Secretary of State Kissinger today began talks with Israeli leaders that he hopes will eventually lead to a compromise troop separation agreement with Syria on the Golan Heights.

description: A $1,000 New York City bond issued in 1924 and redeemable on June 1 of this year has been presented to Controller Harrison J. Goldin With a demand that payment be made, as the bond specifies, in Gold Coin of the United States of America.

title: N.L.R.B. ACCUSES MINING COMPANY

title: Haigon Nixon's Order, Refuses Questions of Watergate Panel

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW AN INCREASE
description: Price gains continued yesterday In the corporate bond, market in recently offered utility and industrial obligations. The taxexempt, sector, for the second consecutive day, gave a good account of itself insofar as new offerings were concerned. In the Government market, which was digesting terms of next week's $5.6billion Treasury refinancing that were announced on Wednesday, trading was quiet and prices somewhat mixed.

title: Article 2  No Title

Bell investors became discouraged when the team failed to obtain the University of Penneylvania's 70,000seat Franklin yield as a playing site. The Bell will play in100,000seat John F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Poorer Lands See Start Toward New Era as U.N.Session Ends

title: Knowledge of Plumbers Denied Again by Kissinger

title: Mitterrand Gain Reported In French Presidency Poll
description: PARIS, May 2 (UPI)The latest poll on the French presidential election shows the Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, gaining 2 percentage points to stand at 44 per cent. Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the Finance Minister in the outgoing Cabinet, polled 31 per cent to place second, and Jacques ChabanDelmas, the official Gaullist candidate, fell to a distant third with only 17 per cent of the vote.

title: Nixon Strategy Viewed as Seeking Divisions
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 President Nixon has reaped the first harvest of his latest Watergate strategy. Simply stated, according to White. House of ficials who participated in the decision to make public edited transcripts of Presidential tape, recordings, that strategy is to divide on partisan and ideological grounds. Divide the Rouse Judiciary Committee, which is weighing impeachment. Divide the Congress, which will ultimately determine the President's fate. Divide the body politic, which will influence the decisions in Washington.

title: Chile: The Bishops Speak
description: In lowkeyed eloquence, a statement by Chile's Roman Catholic bishops to the military junta enumerates the churchmen's concerns: The climate of insecurity and fear, rooted in acctisations, and false rumors; rising unemployment and job dismiasals for arbitrary or ideological reasons, with wage earners bearing an excessive share of sacrifice; forced reorientation of the school system; lack of legal safeguards for personal security; peremptory arrest; long detentions without trial; the use of torture; scant possibilities for legal defense.

title: Red Smith
description: PARIS, Ky., May 2The three men who sit up nights with pregnant horses on Claiborne Farm were paying strict attention to the mare Face the Facts on March 29, 1971, as they had been for more than a month. Face the Facts is a lady of quality and always was. In her racing days she won stakes on both coasts, running to a track record Santa Anita, and when she retired to stud she behaved as a lady should, producing nothing but winners, Her first three foals, Issue, Actual and Bicker, were all by the millionaire Round Table. Bicker, best of the three, was destined to win four stakes and earn almost a quarter of a million. Now Face the Facts was in foal to Damascus, horseoftheyear in 1967, when he won the Preakness and Belmont Stakes after finishtrig third in the Kentucky Derby. Trouble was, she should have given birth way back on Feb. 27.

title: Films and Music Portray African Art
description: WASHiNGTONIt is common ground, With just about everyone that modern art, was reinvigorated before 1914 by contact with socalled primitive art. Picasso, Matisse and Braque ate only three of the artists and Les Demoiselles d'Avignon only one of the paintings on which this view is based. It ??? incontrovertible. But many people also believe that the invigoration in question involved contact with what were then called the dark gods: deities that battened upon fear, cruelty, ignorance and superstition and manipulated them for their own ends.

description: Among the myriad and diVarse materials that have been used for artistic purposes in all the known civilizations of the earth, the one that hat retained an Undimmed aura of mystery and romance is the metal that his excited the moat extravagant dreams of avarice and power: gold. The ruthless quest for gold is so integral apart of the history of the European discovery and conquest of the Americas, for example, that it is difficult at airs to detach our interest in ancient objects made of gold from the bloody chronicle of pursuit and explottation that still haunts he imagination and troubles conscience.

title: Cost of Sequestering Jury

Gross, a former state Republican chairman, sequestered for 32 days, United States District Court records show. The bill includes $21,678 for jury pay at $20 a day for each of the 12 jurors and six alternates, $26,135 for meals and ladging, and $3,053 for transportation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CINCINNATI, May 3 (UPI)The director of operations for the new World Football League said today in United States District Court that the signing of National Football League stars to future contracts benefited his league in number of ways. Henry Parker, testifying in the case against the W.F.L. filed by the Cincinnati Bengals of the N.F.L., was asked by a Bengals attorney, John Lloyd, what way the new league would gain in the 1974 season by the future signings. I think in a number of ways, Parker said. One, it shows people that our clubs are willing to spend sizable sums of money. Two, it shows players we will have in the future, and three, it adds credibility to the league.

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3At 9:29 A.M., Tony Bardaro Walked into Tommy Trotter's auxiliary office on the back side of Churchill Downs and promised that the man whose horses he trains WOuld pay or. $3,500 entry fee for Buck's Bid in the Kentucky Derby. One minute later, entries closed. This happened yesterday but Tommy Trotter, putting together his first Derby as racing secretary; Lynn Storie the baliplayer who turned square and became president of the Downs; Bob Gorham, the reformed golf writer who is resident manager, and everybody else connected with this 100yearold cavalry post are still offering silent prayers of thanksgiving. Buck's Bid was the 23d and last horse named for the race, making it unnecessary for management to work some owners over with a rubber, hose until they scratched their runners.

title: The Special World of The Artisan
description: The object that an artisan creates is shaped by his head as well as his hands.He has the choice14 changing it as he creates it by adding to it or by taking away from it, The object is only finished when, the artisan believes that he has finished it. And then there is the excitement of moving;on to his next creation. In The Special World of the Artisan, we are given a real sense of the love and care which go into every step of each process and the resulting happiness the finished form brings to him.

title: Loyalty to a President or loyalty to the law?
description: Senator Sam Ervin has proposed that the Attorney General be taken out of the Cabinet and that the Justice Department betaken out of the executive branch. Senator Robert Byrd has proposed that the Federal Bureau of Investigation be taken out of the Justice Department Former Supreme Cotirt Justice Arthur Goldberg has proposed that the White House counsel be taken out of the White House and his fiinctions transferred to Justice. Ramsey Clark has suggested that the Justice Department be taken out of politics, by such measures as requiring that the Attorney General or his Deputy and three Assistant Attorneys General be of different political party than the President, and he would prohibit recent campaign managers or candidates for high political office from serving in high Justice Department positions. Former United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour (echoing a proposal made a few years ago by Prof. Isidore Silver) has proposed splitting the differencetwo Cabinet departments, one headed by in Attorney General who would serve the President as personal and political adviser; the other, a Department of Law Enforcement headed by a Chief Prosecutor who would serve the ideal of nonpartisan law enforcement. Lloyd Cutler, distinguished Washington attoniey, has a plan for a permanent special prosecutor outside the Justice Department and Senator Alan Cranston has introduced legislation that would have a commission look into this possibility. Other reformers look toward European models where the Attorney General is responsible not to the executive theAttorney General is a political officer charged with legal duties. Thus during the controversy in the eighteenthirties over the national bank, President Jackson wanted his Attorney Genera to designate certain banks as depositories of United States funds and, when the Attorney General balked, reportedly remarked, Sir, you must find a law authorizing the act or I will appoint an Attorney General who will.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW Dash of Optimism Awakens Stocks
description: The stock market broke out of its doldrums last week as prices mostly advanced in moderate trading.

title: Circumnavigating Long Island In a 12 Foot Sailboat
description: KHEELING in the green seawater which had poured over the gunwales of my tiny, stormtossed sailboat, bailing, and sailing for my life through choppy seas and gusty southwest winds off Montauk Point, 120 miles from City Island in the Bronx where my sailing trip began, I had no time to recall the warnings of my friends. It's not that I hadn't been warned that I'd never make it all the way around Long Island in a 12foot boat. Of course I had. And the cliche is that at perilous times like this you do recall the warnings, and you hate yourself for having ignored them. But the fact is, and I'm sorry to have to disillusion the Cassandras of this world, no such thoughts entered my head.

title: Play Ball, Girls!

They will work in a managerial organization: a government agency, Federal, state or iocal; a business, school or university, or a hospitaand even a small business employinga few hundred persons is by any historical standard, a large organization and requires a good many managers and defined management structure.

title: Getting Even With Portugal's Gestapo
description: LISBONIt took the form of a coup. But with a bit more than a week gone by, what's happened in Portugal is beginning to seem like a revolution. Institutions that dominated the Portuguese for nearly 50 years have disappeared. The dictator. The habit of silence. And the mechanism that kept it all in place: the secret police which, despite a change of name, is still known to the Portuguese as the Pide.

title: A very special meaning
description: In 1948, before television had become a great factor in American life, the noted British anthropologist Geoffrey Gorer wrote of the comics that they are one of the few important bonds (the films being another and the Presidential elections a third) uniting all Americans in a common experience. This may be the reason that the White House has spent some time in recent months corresponding flatteringly with comicstrip, artists.

title: Ghildren's Books Spring 1974
description: Robert Cormier's fourth novel, written for teenagers but a strong read for adults, is a story with a highly serious message not only about the usurpation and misuse of power but about power's inevitable staying. The Chocolate War is masterfully structured and rich in theme; the action is well crafted, well timed, suspenseful; complex ideas develop and unfold with clarity. title: Of women writers and writing about women
description: Among women intellectuals who came to adulthood in the 1930's and 1940's Elizabeth Hardwick and Simone de Beauvoir share a strong interest in the subject of women and their fate in the modern world. Both writers addressed themselves to the question of female creativity long before this became a fashionable tellectual pursuit. Beauvoir drew on her fsrmal training in philosophy to produle her classic, existentialist The Second Sex. Hardwick came to the subject of women through her interest in literature. Intellectually she was molded by the world of the Partisan Review. It was a world.that had a high belief in the perfectly written essay, nonconformist leftwing politics, serious attention to literature, and curiosity about Mass culture. It has given us three of our most important contemporary women intellectuals: Mary McCarthy, Diana Trilling and Elizabeth Hardwick herself.

title: In a Man's Time
description: At once a journal of sorts, a hymn to life and an attempt at selfdefinition, In a Man's Time records Peter Marin's effort to locate himself in a world frequently made treacherous by a multitude of lost souls and false gods. Marin, formerly a director of an Aperimental day school in California and coauthor of a book on drug use, is intent on capturing not the age but how it feels to move through it. The journallike strUcture of the work, with dated entries covering almost every day from July to September of 1972, permits Marin an immediate access to the stuff of experience he feels a novel would not give him, But despite the choppiness of its diary form, the book demands to be read as a unified, coherent work of imagination: like most novels, it has a point of view, a tone and cluster of themes that run throughout and hold it together.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It was pointed out in the story on dividends that the market of thi late 1940's is similar to today's market in many respects  low priceearnings ratios, for example, and high current yields DividendsMarket Tonic?, April 14).

title: Two novels
description: In  the Springtime of the Year is a book like a handmade quilt It is traditional, wellgtitched, moves slowly towards completion, and is intended, at least partially, as a comfort against the cold. It speaks of home truths, of rituals, of longestablished ways of life and of a sense of sharing. Like a quilt, too, it is somewhat abstract, somewhat geometrical concerned less with departures from the norm than with the pattern of things, a phraie which recurs with variations throughout the book. Unlike quilts, however, it is of a genus currently unfashionable; one way of saying this is that it is written in a romantic mode, in which absolute goodness is both possible and meanrngful, rather than in the prevelant 20thcentury ironic mode, in which it is not.

title: Tales with a look of gold
description: A lady asked me once pointblank, Do you like forgetmenots? The question stunned me, for it had never crossed my mind to find them objectionable. Would a person deliberately damn a forgetmenot? Come to think of it, the same thing must apply to fairy tales. They appeal, of course, especially to children, who take time to attend such human pleasures. But a tale of en chantment is not in itself childish unless, as I hate to believe, one elects to groW up to the other world of disenchantment, no fairies in it, no Rapunzels with goldenhait.no happy endings.

title: 42% in Gallup Poll Respond Negatively To Nixon TV Plea

title: There's the Devil to Pay
description: Here are nine books written and published with young people in mind. All of them concern a current popular interest in the occult. This may turn out to be one of those short gold mines, and writing prospectors ought to be warned that by the time their claims are staked the kids could be up to something else: rationalism on its return fare; unsmiling empiricism locked in the lab. After all the new scientific cultists will demand, how can you read books by grown people who say they believe in ghosts and devils and aren't kidding or, just as unsettling, are? The reasons behind the occult rage have been well explored. We know the times are particularly insecure; that institutional religions are casting down old hollow figures, Iving to strengthen their base; that parents, unruled, become mere tall children appealing for assurance of immortality to their own offspring who in turn, lost, light up and go to the devil. A species under the sort of pressure ours endures is bound to invent gods and their opposites and worship them fervently or put them on the shelf, depending upon the times, the weather, the wars, the kings. Fallen on evil days and when religion and government are about the same, we get cathedrals and witches. In our own difficult times, the state aecular, we aregetting, one hopes black.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The ice for Ron Hairis has never been smooth. Some hockey players glide through their careers as if the ice were always downhill. But for Ron Harris the ice has been bumpy and slow and always uphill, At the age of 31, he's a muscular 190 pounds, with a chest that resembles a keg of dynamite, but he's only 5 feet 10 inches and National Hockey League coaches prefer their dfifensemen to be taller. He's not really fast enqugh to be a right wing. He's not really skillful. But hockey isn't always a game of skill. It's tisually a game of toil, a game of perspiration and persistence. Of all the New York Rangers who will oppose the Philadelphia Flyers in today's decisive seventh game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series, penhaps none toils more than Ron Harris, known as Harry to his teammates. Ask the other Rangers to describe him and in variably they'll say, Harry's an honest hockey player. It's a tribute to perspiration and persistence. No team ever has enough honest hockey players. Harry is proud to be one.

title: The two apartments shown here, like the two shown in this space last week, were designed and furnished for under $5,000 which is considered a minimum sum for achieving good design in a small apartment. In each case, the owners were able to keep within their budgets because they did a great deal of the work themselvespatching plaster, paintag, laying carpeting, covering walls with fabric and actually making some of the furnishings.
description: This apartment is so tiny, says architect Dale Booher, that 1 was tempted to move out. Instead he had two entire walls mirrored, one in the 12by18foot living room and another in the 7by10foot dining room. Installing the mirrors ($1,000) and building the two whiteenameled sofas ($500 each) were the only projects Mr. Booher did not do himself. He did design the sofas, however, which have removable arms. One is used aft a bed when his young daughter visits. The feltcovered platform bed in the living room provides extra seating (mattress, $80; frame materials, $100). The architect also covered the walls with felt ($1.25 a yard) and laid carpet squares in both rooms ($300 using 25centsasquare carpeting from the five and ten). Two kilim rugs (the geometric one between the sofas was $150; the one under the dining table was $300) are bright accents in the predominantly charcoal gray and white rooms., Baskets and folding tray tables from Azuma add other color accents. The dining room (at left) had originally been a bedroom. One wall was mirrored to give a sense of space. To mask the doors that open to the kitchen and the bathroom, Mr. Booker built the floortoceiling screen covered in red vinyl that is reflected in the mirror. The table is a butcherblock top on a metal base ($200); the dining chairs were $35 apiece.

title: Television,
description: Occasionally just Occasionally; I make an effort to attend one of those panel discussions about tele vision that seem to be en prevalent around town. A recent example was sponsored by the New York chapter of the National, Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. With an audiente overflowing into the aisles of a large hotel ballroom the forum tackled the subject of Bolder Themes in Television. The moderator was David Susskind, unflappable and genially liberal but coldly persistent when cornered on a touchy issue. The panelists were, in alphabetical and seating order, Eugene Accas, vice president for network relations of a large advertising agency; Norman Lear, writerproducer for his own very successful Tandem. title: Book Ends
description: Last Hurrah. At the National Book Awards ceremony, which included an aboveaverage amount of comedy (see The Guest Word), a sad note was sounded by Maurice Natanson, winner of the award in religion and philosophy. Mr. Natanson alluded in his acceptance speech to the imminent demise of Northwestern University Press, the publisher of his book, Edmund Husserl: Phiosopher of Infinite Tasks. We talked to Joy Neuman, acting director of the press, who said it was indeed sothat the press will be phased out as soon as manuscripts currently contracted for are processed. The reason given by the university was money, but Mrs. Neuman observed. The amount of money needed to keep it going is not significant in terms of their overall budget. If there had been interest in keeping the press going they could have done it. Longterm projects Northwestern was engaged in Included the definitive complete edition of Herman Melville's works, of which six volumes have been published, and a series in phenomenology and existential philosophy, which included Mr. Natanson's book. The resigned hope is that other presses will take over these projects, as well as Northwestern's other books. Mrs. Neuman summed up: This was really a tragic and unnecessary move, detrimental to the future of the university presses.

The beginning of his second fouryear term coincides with the opening today of the Paulist General Assembly at Mr. Paul, the Paulist notitiate in Oak Ridge, N. J.

title: AP Delay May Affect rocks Project
description: LIMERICK, Pa.  A deadlock between two Fediral agencies involving the proposed Tocks Island dam has turned a decision on the licensing of a nuclear power plant in Limerick, 21 miles west of Philadelphia, into a critical test of the National Environmental Policy Act.

title: ITALY HAS DEBATE ON VEGETABLE OIL
description: ROME, May 4  A food scare is on here, the villain being colza oil, a vegetable fat pressed from rapeseed.

title: Bus Driver, 65, Recalls His Career
description: After 38, years and over two million miles, Michael Ryfun maneuvered his Greyhound bus into the gate at the Port Authority Building, at Eighth Avenue and 40th Street, for the last time. Then, having returned from a 454mile roundtrip between New, York and Boston, four hours each way, Mr. Ryfun, who was just 65, climbed down from the bus and retired.

title: Mementos From the Fast
description: Reminiscing, is pretty much an adult pleasure. Watch out! If you find yourself harking back fondly to the Beatles or The Days When the City Streets Were Safe or even the Vietnam war, you're probably beyond the pale and on your way toward middle, age. The older you get, the more you like to talk about your own childhood. This can create problems in a room full of adults where everybody wants to talk about his own childhood and nobody.

title: The $2Billion Battle for Big Record Stars
description: HOLLYWOOD  There's a new show business celebrity around town, He's a 31yearold businessman named David Geffen, regularly seen these days escorting Cher Bono (of the recent team of Sonny & Cher).

title: Frank R. Schwengel, 88, Dies; Chitirman of Seagram & Sons
description: Frank R. Schwengel, board chairman of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc. since 1957, died yesterday at his home on Artillery Lane, Scarsdale, N. Y. His age was 88.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, has leased for 25 years 215,000 square feet of office space in the Celanese Building, 1211 Avenue of the Americas.The transaction, one of the largest of the year, involved an aggregate rent of more than $50million and options for approximately 100,000 square feet of additional space.The new space will be occupied by most of the bank's trust divisions and the Chase Investors Management Corporation, N.Y., in the second quarter of 1975. It consists of the 33d through 37th floors in the 45 story building, which was completed last year and contains a total of 1.8 million square feet. The building is about 75 per cent rented.The lease was negotiated by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the bank's holding company. The move will affect about 630 employes at the bank's downtown headquarters, One Chase Manhattan Plaza. A spokesman for the bank said that the move would open up space in the headquarters building that is needed for other divisions. The move will involve the executives of the trust department, the pension trust services and individual trust services.

title: Belger and Klotzer Star In Relays
description: Mark Belger won his second gold watch of the meet and Ron Klotzer of Union, NJ., produced the only record yesterday in the ninth annual New York, Relays at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: Joan Foster Is Bride
description: Miss Joan Stuart Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gordon. Foster of Summit, N. J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Frederick William Schneider 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schneider Jr. of North Caldwell, N. J. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony in Calvary Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. John McGovern, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Through Malnutrition, Wasting Human ResourcesBabies
description: The proven reserves of a nation's human resources are babies. Yet, when some babies and their mothers are hungry and malnourished, part of the resource is being wasted, and that, according to recent staff report from the Senate's Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs, is what is happening in the United States.

title: Metuchen Unites to Oppose Burger King
description: METUCHEN The people of Metuchen; proud of their Comniernitier smalltown atInosphere, pleasant homes and treeshaded streets, are united in their opposition to a proposal to build a Burger King restaurant in their town.

description: Capobianco Directing All Over

title: Toilet Tissue Treasured
description: LONDON (Canadian Press)Britons are running thin on the bathroom essential  toilet paper. In parts of the country, toilet rolls are in such short supply that supermarkets have introduced the rule that a customer must spend at least $10 on other goods before being eligible to buy one roll.

title: Klein Environment Plan A Regional Issue
description: HAUPPAUGE  Long Island officials said last week that the message contained in Suffolk County Executive John, V. N. Klein's environmental report, in which he proposed a tough new environmental code, was applicable not only to Suffolk and Nassau counties but to other areas as well.

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4Horse players are pious people with reverence for the articleS of their,. faith, and a sacred tenet in their dogma is the helief in horses for Courses. It Is a fact that some thoroughbreds take to cerfain tracks as some men prefer particular blondes; and in Cannonade's short racing life he has shown a distinct fondness for the Sports tobaccdbrown bridle it patch at Churchill  Downs. After runnidg. The Times 14 times around Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga and finishing everywhere from first to fifth, he came down here last November and rushed past 10 horses to win the Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes. In five more starts in Pennsylvania, New York and Florida, he could win only once until he came back last Saturday for the Stepping Stone Purse.

title: Old War Posters Will Be Auctioned
description: MAPLEWOODA collection of original World War I posters will be auctioned here today, with the proceeds going to the Scholarship Fund of the Columbia High School Home and School Association.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The number of state officials and legislators who have accepted free railroad passes for travel within New Jersey continued to climb this year, despite the risk that such largesse could be considered politically embarrassing when publicly disclosed and despite the fact that fewer and fewer trains are operating.

title: Margit j. Roos Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Margit Josephine Roos to Richard Cate Collins has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Roos of Nashville and New York. Mr. Collins is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Deaver Collins, also of Nashville.

title: GUN POSSESSION Is FOUGHT A NEw
description: The State Commission of Investigation, which his been looking into the quarrel between the polic:e and the judiciary over who is respopsilole for the scarceness of jail or prison Sentences for the illegal possession of handguns, issued an interim report yesterday blaming the whole criminal justice system for that situation.

title: Child to Mrs. Garfield
description: A daughter was born on April 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Garfield of Fort Lee, N. J., at the Englewood Hospital. The child has been named Rosanne Hope. Mr. Garfield is controller of the New York City Housing and Development Administration.

title: College Fund Fete To Honor Ewbank
description: WEST LONG BRANCH A testimonial dinner honoring Weeb Ewbank, former coach of the New York Jets and now vice president and general manager of the team, will be held June 12 at the Old Orchard Inn in Eaton town. Proceeds from the event will go to the Monmouth College Fund.

description: Reacting to the Watergate scandais, four New York Democratic gubernatorial candidates have begun what is likely to become trend In politics=full disclosure of their campaign finances periodisally during the campaign.

title: Seattle Boating Festival Paced By Washington's Varsity Crew
description: SEATTLE, May 4  When it's not raining here that is cause enough for celebration.

title: The Nation
description: The wage and price controls program, established in August, 1971, to try to halt inflation, was allowed to lapse at midnight last Tuesday with the economy in its worst price spiral in more than two decades. The end of controls set off still more increases.

title: SelfProtection
description: A savings program is one of the most accepted forms of selfprotection. The Federal Government, in cooperation with employers, organized labor and banks, offers two of the most popular financial selfprotection programs  the payrollsavings and the bondamonth plans for the ownership of United States savings bonds.

title: A Child in Prison Camp
description: In, the antiJapanese panic of World War II, Canada, emulating the United States, swept up its 22,000 West Coast residents of Japanese descent and put them in harsh inland internment centers, on the stupid assumption that even though most of them were Canadian citizens, they might aid the enemy.

title: The New American City
description: ATLANTA. THIS is Instant City. Downtown Atlanta has been builtin the last 10 years. What you see in the mileandahalf of Atlanta's business heart is what you get: a concentration of totally new office toweri, hotels, shopping facilities, landscaped streets, plazas and parks that are a product of the sixties and early seventies  an incredibly unified achievement in an unbelievably short time, when other cities were struggling with piecemeal renewal.

title: The second term is usually worse
description: If there were axioms in political history, this would be one: that although all first Presidential terms are difficult, most second terms are worse. The eight years of Jefferson's Administration were no exception.

title: GAIUS W. WERWIN
description: Gaius Warner Merwin, a retired patent licensing representative fo rthe Western Electric Company, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 78 years old and lived in Hancock, N. H.

title: Hope Tassie Bride Of H. J. Scherck 3d
description: Miss Hope Tissie and Henry J. Scherck 3d were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Aquinas Institute in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Michael Sheeran.

title: Sabbath Brought to Aged
description: For four young seminarians from the Rabbi Isaac Eichanan Theological Seminary of Yeshiva University, the biblical injunction that thou shalt honor the face of the aged, Leviticus XX, 32, is a call to action.

title: Cambodia Gives More As Rebels Press Siege of Base
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 4 (AP)Insurgents kept up the shelling of besieged Longvek camp today, forcing Government troops to give up Mara ground, the Cambodian command said.

title: Livingston College: Image a Key to Survival
description: PISCATAWAY  Livingston College, the urbanoriented, experimental division of Rutgers University, is in trouble. Admissions are sagging, and the suspected cause is a poor public reputation allegedly spawned by unfavorable publicity tinged with racial overtones.

title: Lost children and found kingdoms
description: Okay, you kids, get back to the television set, where you belong. These are my books, see. Well, you can look at them for just a minute while I go upstairs and get the glockenspiel. I want to try out the tunes for these songs in The Mooncusser's Daughter. Plays are always better with songs in them, and this is a pretty funny one. Tell me where is patience mustered is the opening line of one song. Mmm. I like the old mellow one for Come Unto This Rockbound Coast a lot better; it was in the Grade VI music book, but this is bouncier. It's a really funny play. A Mooncusser is a wrecker. This one has a guilty conscience named Caliban living in a cave below his lighthouse. His daughter, Sympathy Bilkanohor, is coming home from dancing school for the first time in years; at the seine time, a gang of crooks are trying to get Caliban's treasure, a rare book, away from him. The only person who can get it is one who has never told even a white lie. Our friend William Shake

description: NEWMARKET, England, May 4 (Reuters)Nonoalco, an Americanbred colt owned by Madame Maria Berger won the English 2,000 Guineas run over onemile here today, by 1 lengths.

description: DES MOINES (AP)  Tom steines, who lost a leg in Vietnam, and then, following severe infection and high fever, became permanently deaf, was once admittedly embittered but is now leading a happy and useful life.

title: 128 ARE DISMISSED IN DISPUTE AT PAPER
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.; May 4 (UPI)  The Kansas City Star dismissed today 98 pressmen and 30 mailersa total of 128 employeesin a dispute over the discharge of another pressman, The police escorted the workers from the building, and the morning edition was printed by supervisors and nonunion personal.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 4Sammy James of Miami, driving a 38foot Bertram, Whittaker Moppie, powered by two 482cubicinch Mercruisers, captured the 11th annual Sam Griffith Memorial offshore powerboat race today.

description: LAKEPORT, N. Y., May 4 (AP) A Madison county couple were assaulted by three young men and then bound and robbed of $3,000 in jewelry in their Oneida, Lake home yesterday, the state police said today. The victims were William DeFurio, 61 years old, and his wife, Mary, 57, of the Town of Lenox.

title: MRS.EDWARD NEWMAN
description: Mrs. Christine Newman, widow of Edward L. Newman, ar insurance executive who died in 1956, died Thursday in Brooklyn, nursing home. She was 89 years old and lived at 333 Martens Street, Brooklyn Mrs. Newman Was a former executive vice president of E. L. & D. J. Newman, Inc., an insurance brokerage concern.

title: Admiral Is Named to Direct U.S. Naval Forces in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) Vice Adrn. Hai 1d E. Shear, a native of Shelter Island, L. I., has been nominated by President Nixon to receive a fourth star and to be commander of naval forces in Europe, the Pentagon said.

title: The Best of All 25 N.B.A,'s
description: As one of the few old dodderers who've been to all 25 annual National Book Awards, I can say that this year's was the best of them all. It wasn't just that we had a streaker at the closing ceremony, and a standup comic accepting. Thomas Pynchon's award, and Peter Orlovsky orotunding Allen Ginsberg's acceptance remarks; that all contributed, but principally there was, throughout the preceding week's activities and at the ceremony itself, an unaccustomed air of camaraderie among the publishers, authors, reviewers, agents, and booksellers who make up what is called the book world. The thousandhead reception that followed the awardbestowing positively overflowed with good nature, laughter, and bonhomie.

title: A pledge kept
description: It is not just the fact that life was simpler in the pioneer days. Philosophies were simpler, too, not so pocked withqualifications, not so regularly challenged by alternatives and the bottom line was a whole lot less remote. It was easier to be good then; also, perhaps, easier to be bad. Or at least badness was easier to define and recognize.

title: Brilliant Syrnphony in C by City Ballet
description: The beginning of any New York city Ballet season often produces some of the finest performances of that engagement. The burden of maintaining 40 or more ballets in the active repertory has not over taxed rehearsal hors; and time exists to polish classics of the repertory such as Symphony in C, now over 25 years old. The work was given Friday evening at State Theater for the first time this saeson.

title: ELDERLY IN FLORIDA GET BREAK ON TAXES
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 4 Gov. Reubin Askew signed into law yesterday a bill providing that fiveyear residents who are 65 years old and older, and people of any age who are permanently disabled and who own their homes, shall be exempt from paying taxes on the first $10,000 of the assessed value of their properties.

title: W.H. Taft Weds Mrs. Julia Vadala
description: Mrs. Julia Ann Vadala, deputy assistant secretary for human development in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, was married in Washington yesterday morning to William Howard Taft 4th, executive assistant to the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Food: Zucchini
description: Alphabetically, zucchini is at the bottom of the vegetable list, but this most versatile squash should be near the top of anyone's compendium of what's what out of a garden. Its potential is phenomenal. The recipes in this issue for zucchini in a style of Provence, zucchini with tomatoes, fried green zucchini, zucchini stuffed with meat and pignoli and Parmesan zucchini, simply hint at the possibilities of this little green squash.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets swept a doubleheader with the San Francisco Giants last weekend at San Francisco behind the pitching of Jon Matlack and some revived hitting. The Giants visit the East this week for three televised night games in Shea Stadium tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday beginning at 8:05.

title: Record Price for. Camera
description: LONDON (AP)Preus Photos of Horten, Norway, paid a record $24,255 for an 1861 Thomas Sutton wetplate panoramic camera made by T. Ross of London, auction offitials at Christie's announced. They said the highest previous price for a camera in a Christie's auction was $1,848.

title: First Hand Lesson in Government
description: ORADELL  Three junior high school students visited the Legislature in Trenton recently and, although they had some incisive comments about their experience, they gave the lawmakers generally high marks.

title: TireBusters Battle Clock, Back Woes And They Love every Minute of Misery
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va.Out on the track, Richard Petty and Bobby Allison were burning up the asphalt and hardly anyone was aware of Jim Shults or Cliff Timberman  except Richard Petty, and Bobby Allison. Shults and Timberman are tirebusters, part of a team responsible for putting the correct tires with the correct pressure and the correct balance on the stock cars Richard Petty, Bobby Allison and all the other. Grand National stars drive to win hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: PLAN ON RETARDED FOCUSES ON GAMES
description: MANSFIELD, Conn.A cowl'. trywide effort, financed by the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation, to get parents and others more actively engaged in games with mentally retarded people, has ben inaugurated at the Mansfield Training School here by Mrs. Eunice Kennedy Shriver.

title: And Now From the Folks Who
description: WHENEVER I'm near Kperna, that pretty little French town that lies at the heart of the Champagne district, I usually stop to see my friend Joe D'Argent and, to find out what's new in the grapesqueezing business. Monsieur D'Argent, to give him the dignity he deserves, is not only the head man in an organization called Le Comite Intkirofesonnel du Vin de Champagne a sort of trade association of all the great champagne makers, but he also happens to be the mayor of his village in the suburbs of Epernay. He is a gentleman, bearing a resemblance to Charles de Gaulle, unfailingly polite, almost never perturbed.

title: Solutions for Plant Diseases
description: PLANT diseases may be caused by fungi, bacteria, viruses, nematodes, and by various environ mental conditions such, as excess or lack of water or nutrients, air pondtion, weather conditions, and chemical injury. Many diseases flourish in a wet season and control must be started be= fore symptoms appear. Choice of resistant varieties and various sanitary measures reduce the need for chemical protection.

title: Cosmos Goach in LineUp For Opener. With COttiets
description: The New York Cosmos open their North American Soccer League season against the Baltimore Comets at 3 o'clock this afternoon on familiar note: Injuries have forced their News coach, Gordon of Bradley, to see action and diSoccer rect the defense. Bradley, who has come to the rescue of the, team time and again, will insert himself in the lineup at fullback because Werner Roth has aggravated an old injury on his right leg. The game will be played at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

description: More than 30 experiinental heater companies  Shakespeare players, parlor gropers, freelance jugglers, mummers and general, layabouts  paraded down Broadway in a fantastic caravan yesterday to begin the city's celebration of Off Off. Broadway stage.

title: Secret boundaries between branches of government
description: Herman Wolkinson has a lot to answer for. In 1949, this otherwise obscure official in the Justice Department wrote several papers for The Federal Bar Journal entitled Demands of Congressional Committees for Executive Pipers. These reflected the atmosphere of Truman's war with Congress, and were aimed especially at investigating Committees like that of Homer Ferguson, on which young William Rogers was serving as counsel. Though the papers never became official documents in that Democratic Adthey obviously made quite an impression on Rogersso much so that, when he bad changed sides and joined the Justice Department himself, the Wolkinson papers, only slightly recast, issued froni Herbert Brownell's department as an official explanation of the Eisenhower Administration's refusal to let.

title: ACCUSED STUDENTS DENIED A REVIEW
description: A threeman panel of Columbia University has refused to review disciplinary charges against five undergraduate students, posing a new problem in academic governance at the university.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 4 A report by California's Auditor General has heightened a dispute over profitmaking, and the quality of care in statesupported prepaid health plans for MediCal recipients.

title: C.I Held in Nixon Threat
description: SEATTLE, May 4 (AP) A 21yearold Fort Lewis soldier was arrested here last night by the Seattle police and a Secret Service agent for allegedly threatening the life of Presiden Nixon the Soldier, Whose name was not realeased was taken to the king country Jail.

title: Clare jordan Married
description: Miss Clare M. Jordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Jordan of Passaic Park, N.J., was married Here yesterday aftetnoon of William F. Treanor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Treanor of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Eugene Solan. The bridegroom is a member, of the New York law firm of Cox, Treanor & Shaughnessy, of which his father is at partner.

title: Ballet
description: The National Ballet of Canadat ends its twoweek season at the Metropolitan Opera Rouse today, although it will return for three weeks later in the summer.

title: Surprise of May
description: May always surprises us. It comes with such haste, it seems, and with such abundance. Only yesterday we were admiring bloodroot blossoms and wind flowers and hepaticas. This morning we were surprised to see the shadblow, like shimmering, lacy puffs of rare beauty in the woods. We turned our backs for an hour and came back to find apple trees like enormous pink and white bouquets, loud with bees. And before dusk the lilacs will be scenting the air.

title: Nixon Opens World's Fair in Spokane
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 4 President Nixon opened Expo 74, a world's fair dedicated to the environment, with an appeal today for international coopeiation to achieve world peace and a fresh new environment for all nations.

title: New Zealand Chief Ailing
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 4 (UPI)Prime Minister Norman E. Kirk is suffering from acute pleurisy but the condition is under control, a Government spokesman said today. Mr. Kirk, who is 51 years old, entered a hospital for treatment of varicose veins of both legs on April 9 and developed respiratory trouble after his release.

title: Bridge
description: The experts who bit the headlines lire generally those who invent systems or conventions, who ma* psychic bids, who bring homevirtualIY hopeless contracts, orrwho exerciseimagination in some other fashion. But these are not the primary qualities that make a championwhat is needed is sheer grinding accuracy.

description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, May 4An odd couple has taken the lead in these early days of open political life in Mozambique.

title: J. E. Bernstein to Wed Miss Susan F. Kaplow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kaplow of Long Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Frances Kaplow, to Jonathan Efrem Bernstein, a certified public accountant with the metropolitan office of Arthur Young & Co.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Tel Aviv tonight to begin the second round of his Middle East shuttle diplomacy with expectations that Syria and Israel would soon curb their military activity on the Golan Heights to facilitate his efforts to conclude a troop separation agreement between them. Then, under conditions of heavy security, he was driven to Jerusalem for talks with Premier Golda Meir and other Israeli officials. [1:8.]

title: DRAFTEES PRESS DUTCH MINISTRY
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands Dozens of pickets, mostly longhaired, wearing army fatigues and armed withbanners and pamphlets, have been gathering on Mondays outside the Defense Ministry here. Delegations have met with ministry officials to discuss complaints or to hand over petitions.

title: Farmers Market
description: When the definitive history of urban renewal is written it could be titled How to Do Everything Wrong. has been a painful way to learn how to do at least few things right. For many communities, it is much too late. History and amenity have been bulldozed out of the hearts of cities because they had the misfortune to be old, look messy and occupy cheap land. The temptation was too great to tidy it all up at an equally tidy developer's profit.

title: State Price Controls Urged by Hospital Association
description: PRINCETONNew Jersey hospitals have called for the implementation of statelevel price controls on the nation's healthcare industry. In so doing, the state's 144 healthcare institutions have recommitted themselves to what has been termed an attitude of fiscal restraint.

title: Watergate Prosecutor Is Up for A Promotion
description: Senator Sam Ervin announced unexpectedly last week that he wants the Senate Judiciary Committee to launch an investigation of the Justice Department's conduct in the original Watergate prosecution. Such an investigation would be a direct challenge to President Nixon's impeachment defense, which asserts the full vigor and integrity of the departnient's work on the case.

title: Oil Concerns Plan To Reduce Outlets
description: MINEOLATwo major oil companies are cutting back sharply on the number of outlets on Long Island and retailoring those they plan to maintain.

title: Additional Suspects In Robbery Attempt At Bank Are Hunted
description: NEW HAVEN, May 4The police, who captured three suspects in a bank robbery yesterday in which two police officers were wounded, one of them critically, today searched for:. other participants in the holdup.

title: It's Spring, So Play Ball (or Go Fly a Kite)
description: RUMORS that spring has arrived have been confirmed by several scientific observation; (1) all the bicycles ln the House have flat tries; (2) a bravo tulip appeared a window box on our block: and Was prompty stoned to death with empty soda pop cans; and (3) another penguin is playing third base for the, Mets,

title: 15State Alarm Issued for 2 Fugitives From Brooklyn's Detention
description: A 15state police alarm was issued yesterday for two inmates who escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention for. Men on Friday night by sawing through the steel bars of an eight floor window and lowering themselves to the ground on a rope of blankets knotted with twine.

title: Susan J. Wallin Married to John White
description: Miss. Susan Jane Wallin, program director of ZBM Television in Hamilton, Bermuda, was married yesterday afternoon to John Harrison White, managing director and vice president of Advertising Associates Compton, Ltd., in Hamilton. The Rev. Barber L. Waters performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Memorial United ??? Church in White Plains.

description: ENGLISH F. A. CUP FINAL

title: Invasions of Privacy Decried
description: TRENTONA leading critic of governmental invasion of privacy has charged that New Jersey is lagging in providing safeguards against the misuse of computerized information.

title: Picture Books.
description: While it was probably not a raving beauty who first said Looks aren't everyting, it could have been a lover of picture books. Few are more serious about their reading than the very young. They care how a dragon breathes fire. They notice that the boy's sock is blue on page 14 when the author said it was green on page 6. The story in a picture book maybe as short and simple as a song lyric but, like Mt Everest, it must be solidly there to be read and reread, to be enriched with illustrations, to guissantee that the book it graces is more than just another pretty little thing.
