description: PITTSBURGH, May 4 (UPI) Dave Parker's tworun single highlighted a three run fifth inning rally today that gave the Pittiburgh Pirates a 43 triumph over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Last 2 Escaped Convicfs Are Apprehencledb In jeitsey
description: CAMDEN, May 4 (UPI) Cold, wet and hungry, the last two of 10 inmates who attacked a guard and escaped through a window at the Camden County Jail Annex, have been recapturedr And are being held here under tight security.

title: Grasping Is Victor On Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 4 (AP)Grasping won easily and Ground Song won by an eyelash today as the 5yearold mares captured the divisions of the $25,600 Brentwood Stakes at Hollywood Park.

title: CURB ON FIGHTING ON GOLAN HEIGHTS SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: JERUSALEM, May 4 Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Tel Aviv tonight to begins the Second round of his Middle East shuttle diploinacy with expectations that Syria and Israel would soon curb their military activity on the Golan Heights to facilitate his efforts to conclude a troop Separation agreement between them.

title: The World
description: On what he himself said was the most difficult of his five journeys to help achieve peace in the Middle East, Secretary of State Kissinger last week began the negotiations he hopes will lead to disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces, still warring on the Golan Heights.

title: Extensive: Cleanup Brings Back Mirine Lifeto the Miami River
description: MIAMI, may 4Miami River, once heavily polluted, smelly and devoid of marine species, Ls alive again.

title: June Graves, A. T.Enos 4th Plan Nuptials
description: Miss June Harriet Graves, a portfolio assistant with Smith, Barney & Co., an investment concern in New York, and Alanson Trask Enos 4th of Bernardsville, N. J., a banking officer in the special: loan department of the National Bank of North America here, plan to be married in August.

title: Headliners
description: At her trial, she said she did it to save her marriage now that Edith, Irving has been released frOm a Swiss jail, she wants a divorce from her husband, CliffordofIheHowardHugheshoax. Mrs. Irving served 14 months of a twoyear sentence for fraud and forgery, arising fram her part in the Hughes biography. She plans now to resume a painting career to repay her sher of more than $1.3million against participants in the hoax.

title: Woman Fighting to Marry Civility Dead Prisoner
description: In the spring of. 1971, Peter Butler, who was in Attica State Prison completing the fifth year of a life, sentence for murder, wrote a letter seeking advice from, William M. Kunstler,  the flamboyant lawyer kown for his defense of radical causes.

title: A preppie at Harvard
description: Fortunately, listing my prejudices against this type ofbook will still leave me with some space to say how much I enjoyed it. At a time when a steady bookreader may be at the point of l'obbyhrg for legislation that would prevent writers from writing any more about their adolescences or marriages  and one advantage of the publishing industry's centralization, my research has shown, is that a New York City ordinance might do the trick  Peter S. Prescott has presented a reminiscence based on (and partly consisting on a diary he kept from the summer he left Choate to the summer he completed his freshman year at Harvard. That can only add to my fear that future archeelogists may come to the conclusion that this society consisted almost entirely of highly selfanalytical writers; all of whom started out a bit awk ward with girls.

title: Rep. Hutchinson to Oppose Immunity for Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The senior Republican on the House Judiciary Committee says he will oppose any effort to grant immunity to witnesses at the impeachment hearings, even if it means many major Watergate figures may not be heard.

title: MILES STANLEY, 49 LABOR LEADER, DIES
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 4 (AP)Miles C. Stanley, president of the West Virginia Labor Federation since 1957, died yesterday in a hospital here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

title: Cheers for Claudine
description: THERE are a number of unusual things about Claudine, the sometimes triumphantly funny new film at the De Mille and Fine Arts Theaters. It's about being black, about being/ poor, about being on welfare, and about trying to make economic and etnotional ends meet withdut being forced by the system to cheat. The most unusual thing about Claudine is that it seems to take family life seriously, something done by very few films these days, perhaps because the situation comedies on television have given family life such a bad naineycan imagine some exceptionally impressionable child of the televition generation growing up to think he had been deprived because his house had never rocked with canned laughter.

title: Calley Sentence Upheld
description: President Nixon has decided against any further reduction of First Lieut. William L. Caney Jr.'s 10year sentence for the murder of Vietnatnese civilians at My Lai. Details on Page 13.

title: LEADERS TO MODIFY POWER TAKEOVER
description: ALBANY, May 4Governor Wilson and the legislative leadership have agreed to restrict legislation that as presently drafted would allow the power authority of the State of New York.to take over an unlithited Dumber of Consolidated Edison Company plants, according to legislative sources.

title: Adirondack Branch Of the Penn Central Found Recoverable
description: An aerial survey has shown that the Penn Central's abandoned Adirondack Branch, which the state wants to acquire, remains intact along almost all of the 118mile line.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a homeowner who has been making energy conservation improvements for five years, the article Energy Conservation Is a Snap [April 7] was interesting as a comparison with my own efforts. But I found several misleading points.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRICES WERE RAISED on a wide variety of goods following the lifting of price controls. Copper went up 12 cents a pound, steel price increases ranged from 5.7 per cent to 9.5 per cent and cigarettes rose 70 cents thousand. In contrast, Gulf Oil cut gasoline prices by 3 cents, and Hormel reduced the price of meat products by 7 to 14 per cent . The Senate rejected a proposal give the Administration authority to reimpose wage and price controls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Upon taking office, President Nixon inherited two disastersone at home, the other abroad. At home: campus rioting, black rebellion, crime, drugs, skyjacking in epidemic proportions. Abroad: a devastating war in Southeast Asia, with 500 of America's flower of manhood dying every day and on a collision course with two of the world's foremost militarY powers Red China and the Soviet Union.

title: Alison Pearl Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pearl of Hewlett, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Pearl, to Robert H. Gale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gale of Great Neck, L. I. A wedding in October is planned.

title: The Sets Schedule
description: MAY 7. Hawaii; 9, Pittsburgh; 12, at Cleveland; 15, Toronto; 17. Boston; 20, Baltimore; 22, Minnesota; 24, Houston; 25, at Philadelphia; 28 Los Angeles; 20, at Denver; 31, at Golden Gaters.

title: Nancy Seligman Engaged to Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald, D. Seligman of Merrick, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Seligman, to Dr. Harry coldmark, son of Mr. and Mrs, Abraham D. Goldmark of New York.

title: By John CuMemo
description: After.mass, the newsboys would have their stacks of Sunday papers piled up at the bottom of the broad stone steps leading down to the sidewalk from old St. Mary's, competing for our patronagein the good old free enterprise way. My father read The Chicago Herald & Examiner and The Rockford Morning Star, so we kids were assured of their comic sections; but unless we could also persuade him to buy The Chicago Tribune, we could not follow the adventures of 'Terry and the Pirates, Smilin Jack, Di& Tracy and Little Orphan Annie. Even though Dad disliked The Tribune for being antiRoosevelt, be would usually indulge us; then we could keep the Sunday boredom at bay until the good radio shows started in the evening, lying flat on our stomachs on the living room rug, with the color comics of three newspapers spread out before us. Believe it or not, we had no difficulty keeping in mind from week to week the continuing adventures of several dozen heroes on land (Joe Palooka), sea (Don Winslow of the Navy) and air (Smilin Jack), and in the past (Prince Valiant), present (Gasoline Alley) and future (Flash Gordon and Buck Rogers, 25th Century A.D.).

title: Steps Up Drive to Discredit Accusations by Former Counsel to President
description: WASHINOTON, May 4 The White House, stepping up its campaign to discredit John W. Dean 3d, made public today, a 32page, memorandum, charging the, former counsel to president Nixon with misstatements in his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee.

title: A Planner of Lisbon Coup Tells How Officers Toppled a Regime
description: BRAGA, Portugal, May 3In the officers canteen at Eighth Infantry headquarters, three lieutenants sat watching televised summaries of the May Day celebrations.

title: The Wind, Fickle and Shifty, Tests Builders
description: Architects and engineers, after battling for years to reduce the effect of the wind on the structural integrity or, their buildings, have begun to fight for the haplessand sometimes hatlesspedestrian.

title: Food Program Is in Economic Squeeze
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, LI., The energy crisis, spiraling food costs and the shift of welfare cases to the Federal Supplemental Security Income have combined to strain the Long Island Council of Churches food distribution program to almost a breaking point.

title: Wit and Watergate Spike an Evening Of McKuen Poems
description: Rod McXuen, who gave the first of two concerts on consecutive evenings Friday at Avery Fisher Hall, is probably best appreciated in a concert setting. Set down on the page, his poems invite unfortunate comparisons with real poetry reality being defined as pretensions to high art. And in his more recent ventures as a composer of classical music, his earnest banalities prove more embarrassing than anything else.

title: Home Improvement
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions entire Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page. BERNARD GLADSTONE

title: If Weeds Are A Problem.
description: THERE are many tools available to the home gardener to battle the weeds that rob his plants of moisture and light and provide a hiding Place for popotentially harmful insects, and diseases.

title: Hein Is Retiring From A.F.C. Post
description: Mel Hein, a famous figure in football for five decades, will retire as supervisor of officials for the American Conference on May 31, the National Football League an,nounced yesterday. He is 65 years old.

title: James Barnett to Marry Sharon Barber
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alden G. Barber of Basking Ridge, N. J. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Lee Barber, to James William Barnett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Z. ??? of Charleston, S. C. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Red Sox Bow New Rules Give N.F.L. Coaches Little to Kick bout
description: Among those Most affect, ed by pro football's nevi/Nies changes, the coaches are generally in favor while the kickers are suspicious., The coaching reaction is surprising because the new sudden death period to break tie scores and the rules about field goal attempts are going to put them on the.spot and subject them secondguessing, when:their decisions backfire.

title: The Year a Star was not Born
description: During the 1940's, writerdirector Preston Sturges was sitting pretty in wood, an irreverent genius celebrated for his unique blend of savage wit and screwball comedy. Today, his brilliant, fastpaced ftimefrom The Great McGintr.to The Lady Eve to Sullivan's Travels to The Miracle of Morgan's Creek to Hail the Conquering Heroare considered classics of the cinema.

title: Gould Stars But Adelphi Wins Meet
description: BROOCKVILLE, L. I., May 4 Joe Gould of Queens College threw the javelin 227 feet 4 inches for a meet record today in the 22d, annual Collegiate Track Conference championship.

title: A Film Grows in Brooklyn
description: In 1957, Martin Davidson, a tall, friendlyfaced young man, graduated from Tilden High School in East Flatbush. He went to college to become a lawyer because he would get to talk a lot. But after a year he quit and turned to show business.

title: Recital
description: Barbara Ford, sopranop and Dennis Zeigler, clarinetist, made their joint debut here particularly pleasant by assembling an unusual and attractive program. It was given at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night, and although the two, artists each had solo opportunities, most often they were performing together.

title: Pro Transactions
description: MINNESOTA (AL)Traded Dick Woodson, righthanded pitcher, to New York Yankees for Mike Pazik, righthanded pitcher, and cash. Optioned Dan Fife, righthanded pitcher, to Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. Recalled Dave Golfs, righthanded Pitcher, from Tacoma. Purchased Bill Butler, lefthanded pitcher, from Tacoma.

title: Future Social Events Tickets to the following events may be, obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:
description: Whitney Gala to Go Fop May 8The 18th Annual Gala of the Friends of the Whitney Museum is taking its cue from the American pop art exhibition there. Nearly 500 guests, Friends and their friends, will take over the second floor for their high fashion ball amid a background of the lively pleasures, visual and gastronomic, of mass culture. Tablecloths of primary colors and pop art prints from the museum's collection will parallel the menuPopsicles, hot dogs, doughnuts, Crackerjack and Fritos. But, as forewarned is forearmed, the majority of patrons will attend dinners beforehand in private homes. A nonprofit gala, just for sheer celebrationhas to be with tickets, by invitation.

title: Auction Will Benefit Montclair Academy
description: MONTCLAIR  Antiques and fine art will be auctioned at Montclair Academy next Saturday. Proceeds from the auction, which is sponsored by the academy's Parents and Alumni Associations, will benefit the school.

title: len Loves Challenge of Her Nearly Impossible Job
description: TRENTONIn the last 14 months, she has resigned her Assembly, seat, run in the Democratic pritnary for Governor (and lost), been catapulted to the forefront of the women's movement in New Jeraby and accepted an appoiunent to the hot seat in the Governor's cabinet: Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.

title: Power to the person
description: A woman who has been leading aboutthe Liberation Army's devotion to The People writes to ask, Who are The People? Am. I, she wonders, one of The People, and if not, does that make me an enemy of The People or, worse, one of The Unpeople?

title: Stamps U.S. Goes All Out U.P.U
description: Stamps U.S. Goes All Out U.P.U scroll in ink and color done in the early 1A00's, when the noted Japanese Ulrlyoe artist, was intrigued by figure placement. The work has five women, each symbolizing one of the Five Feminine Virtues  reading, entertaining, domesticity, art and writing:

title: E. R. Murphy Weds Mrs. Joan Clarkson
description: Mrs. Joan LeRoy Clarkson, widow of Robert L. Clarkson Jr., was married yesterday afternoon to Emmett Robert Murphy, an insurance broker. The Rev. Howard Lowell of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal. Church in Locust Valley, L. I., performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L.1.

title: 30 Decorators Revive a MAnsion
description: BERNARDSVILLE  I really don't know how many rooms there are; I never counted them, said Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting in describing Upton Pyne, a longvacant stone mansion here that has been transformed into a glittering showcase for the work of 80 New York and New Jersey designers.

title: Balloons and Birds Open Expo
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 4 Hot air balloons were lofted. Three thousand homing pigeons were released. Bands played. Fireworks exploded. Exactly 1,974 footlong rainbow trout were dumped into the river. And as mallard ducks paddled amid the pomp and celebrities, a miniWorld's Fair devoted to environmental issues opened its gates here today for a sixmonth run.

title: Rich DogShow Centennial Planned in Memphis
description: To Celebrate, the 100th anniversary of dog shows in the United, States, the Memphis kennel. Club s staging the Centennial shoW in the Tennessee city on News June 2. of We are planning one of the Dogs richest dog shows ever held in America, said Jim Vaughters, the chainnan and a lieutenant in the Memphis Police Department. We are giving $2,000 for best in show and $500 for each group. That means, the winner's owner, goes home with at least $2,500. If he wins a cash award in the breed, it, will be, even more. For example, there's $100 for the best Great Dane, Basenji and bichon frise.

title: Turkey Restoring Democracy After Military Rule
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 28 In a world where military coups are commonplace, Turkey is trying something unusualrestoring democracy after almost three years of a militarybacked Government.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: New Corporate Bonds

title: Cornell's Varsity Eight Outrows Princeton, Yale
description: DERBY, Conn., May 5The Cornell varsity crew, possibly a growing giant, won the Carnegie Cup here today on the Housatonic River by 2 lengths. Princeton was second, just ahead of Yale.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Financial Troubles Beset Libraries At Coast Schools
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5The University of California Libraries, which include the noted collections at the Berkeley and U.C.L.A. campuses, are having financial problems, and university officials say that they may adversely affect the quality of the system's graduate schools.

title: Buying of Schwarz Adds To Weber's Toy Empire
description: ZURICH, Switzlrland, May 3 Bravo for private Swiss venture capitall says Hans BaerZuridi banker, doting father, and an unabashed customeradmirer of Franz Carl Weber, the celebrated Swiss toy empire that has just bought F. A. O. Schwarz.

title: INJURED FUGITIVE HELD IN BROOKLYN
description: One of the two fugitives who fled from the Brooklyn Hpuie of Detention for Men on Friday night was captured last night in a Brooklyn Hospital where he WAS being peaticrlor, a broken, heel apparently, suffeted braescape, the police said.

title: Stolen Property Display Is Planned by Police
description: Nearly $1.3million in stolen property recovered by the Police Department last month will be put on display Wednesday and Thursday at the department's former headquarters building at 240 Centre Street in an effort to identify its owners.

title: MONTACU HANKIN SR.
description: Montagu Nankin Sr., an antiquarianbook dealer since 1920, who specialized in hunting and fishing books, died yesterday at his home, 6 Pembroke Road, Summit, N.J. His age was 82.

title: Eight Are Killed in Delhi In MoslemHindu Clash
description: NEW DELHI, May 5Eight persons were killed and 50 injured today in a clash between Hindus and Moslems in a densely populated district of Delhi. IThe police opened fire to disperse a rioting mob, which had burned several shops and buildings.

title: Grievance Procedure Is Set Up in U.S. Prisons to Curb Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Bureau of Prisons has established a new grievance procedure for inmates of. Federal institutions that is expected to check the flow of prisoners lawsuits into the already overburdened Federal courts.

title: STEEL GROUP PLANS SOUTH KOREAN PLANT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May. 5 The Pohang Iron and Steel Company; South Korea's largest steel manufacturer, announced over the weekend a $99.9million contract for construction of a cold rolling mill at the port city of Pohang by a consodium consisting of Wean United, Inc., of Pittsburg VoestAlpine of Austria, and Siemens A.G. of West Germany.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In a protest over telephone facilities at the Manhattan Men's House of Detention, some 80 inmates refused for 40 minutes yesterday to return to their cells after lunch.

title: Goalie and Clock Stop New Yorkers
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5With nowhere to go but home, the Rangers had all the time after today's loss to assess their failures aaginst the Philadelphia Flyers, the first expansion team in the National Hockey League to win a playoff series from an old line club.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Tom Seavejr's Survival by Legs Unless an athlete is a runner, the legs often are ignored. Until the legs go. Then their importance is appreelated briefly but forgotten again. It's too easy to think of Henry Aaron swinging a bat with his arms, of Joe Namath passing a football with his arm, of Jack Nicklaus driving a golf ball with his arms, of George Foreman, punching with his arms. But their arms are merely an extension of the strength and balance in their legs. Tom Seaver was reminded of that recently and painfully, Tom Seaver of the New York Mets is baseball's premier pitcher. He'll be on display tonight against the San Francisco Giants as baseball's highestpaid pitcher with a $170;000 annual salary. But when the season began, he wasn't earning.his money in his first.four starts, he not only failed to win, he failed to pitch effectively. In his fourth start, he was knocked out in the sixth inning by the Pittsburgh Pirates who had accumulated six runs on 12 hits, When you're Tom Seaver, that's only supposed to happen to other pitchers. Manny Sanguillen's home run in that game also is only supposed to happen to other pitchers.

title: Stars, Down 20, Hope Return of Beaty Will Foil Nete Defense Tactics Tonight
description: The Utah Stars, trailing New York, 20, in their American Basketball. Association championship series, will be counting on the return of Zelmo Beaty to try and combat the Nets cheating defense tonight in game No. 3 at Salt Lake City.

title: Newspaper Talks Halted; News to Try Automation
description: Contract talks between the printers union and the city's three major daily newspapers btoke down at 12:30 A.M. today. The Daily News announced it would try to introduce the use of automated typesetting processes tonight.

title: Cambodian Battalions Protest for Back PaY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 5 (Reuters)Two Cambodian, battalions that said they had not been paid for four months staged a demonstration outside the presidential palace today.

title: Declines in Deaths From Nine Leading Diseases Show a Surprising Trend
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Death rates from heart disease, stroke and seven other leading killers of Americans declined during the last two decades, but no one knows why.

title: 500 Companies at Peaks, But Investors Had Losses
description: The nation's 500 largest industrial corporations set new profit and sales records in 1973 while investors in these companies took heavy kisses, Fortune magazine reported yesterday, according to United Press International.

title: Chicagoans End Season
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra ended its 197374 New York season at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with a program consisting of Mozart's Haffner Symphony, Elgar's Enigma Variations and Stravinsky's Le Sacre du Printemps.

title: Six Die in London Fire.
description: LONDON, Monday, May 5 (AP)Fire swept through two apartment houses in Clapham in South London early today, killing six persons and injuring at least 10, authorities said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Voters in France chose Francois Mitterrand, Socialist, and Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a conservative, as the two contenders for the presidency. Jacques ChabanDelmas, the candidate of the Gaullist party, which has governed France for 16 years, ran a weak third among 12 candidates. Because neither Mr. Mitterrand nor Mr. Giscard d'Estaing received a majority of the vote, there will be runoff election May 19. [1:8.]

title: First Lady of City Remains Woman Without Pretension
description: Mary Beame stood fingering the heavy, flowered curtains in the sitting robin at Gracie. Mansion and gazed wistfully across the sunlit lawn Where pink and yellow tulips, deep  purple violets and red azaleas  were in bloom. The sounds of children rollerskating and playing ball in the park beside the mansion, the songs of birds and the hum of nearby traffi could all be heard inside the room.

title: Major Bills in Legislature
description: ABBREVIATIONS: PrPassed; 0Defeated; CCommitive n by Gover FFloor; KKilled; Ssigned; V!letoeo; AAwalting actiornor; BNeing dratted or negotiated; NNot yet Introduced.

title: House Democrats to Vote On Reforming Committees
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Democrats vote this week on whether to accept proposals to reform the House committee sntem for the first time in 28 years in hopes of making it more responsive to public needs.

title: Cora Ehrenclou Bride of Robert Rowell
description: Miss Francisca Cora Ehrenclou was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert S. Rowell, a landscape designer and artist of Nicasio, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Bucks Square Series
description: BOSTON, May 5Wayne Emhty played the role of Red. Auerbach, his old friend and onetime boss of the Boa ton Celties, today.

title: F.T.C. Investigating Salons and Schools
description: A widespread investigation is under way by the New York region of the Federal Trade Commission of the various types of concerns involved in socalled futureservice contracts. These include health spas, reducing salons, karateJudo schools, correspondence schools and those that provide computer  training and truck  &Wing courses.

title: A.E.C. Workers Strike
description: PADUCAH, Ky., May 5 (UPI)  About 900 workers went on strike today at the Atomic Energy Commission's gaseous diffusion plant, one of Paducah's largest industries. Local 3550 of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union struck after failing to settle a wage dispute and reach a new contract to replace one that expired last midnight.

title: KISSINGER URGES ISRAELIS TO MAP A NEW TRUCE LINE
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 5 Secretary of State Kissinger flew here today after urging Israeli leaders to drair up a new ceasefire line that he could propose to Syria when he returns to Damascus on Tuesday in his continuing search for an agreement on the separation of Syrian and Israeli forces.

title: City Ballet: Weekend of Stimulation
description: A weekend spent with the New York City Ballet is like a weekend in the country. Well, it is nearly like a weekend in the country. At, least, it is as near as a hardpressed dance critic is likely to get to a weekend in the country this season.

title: Get That Done
description: On March 21, 1973, John W. Dean 3d informed President Nixon that one of the original Watergate defendants, E. Howard Hunt, was blackmailing the White House. With numerous diversions, the President's response threaded consistently through their subsequent 103minute conversation.

title: Fikes Is a Hot Runner; He Runs a 3:88.3 Mile
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP)Denis Fikes of the University of Pennsylvania ran a 3 minute 58.3 second mile today in the Quakers' 12547 track victory over Cornell.

title: GEN. RIG WARNS WATERGATE CURE MAY BE EXCESSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, suggested today that excesses and distortions in investigating Watergate scandals might lead to the cure being worse than the illness.

title: Oil Company Shareholders Quiescent As Dividends Lag While profits Soar
description: Oil company profits have soared in the past year, and every motorist knows that the price of the product is up, top. But the prices of oil compally shares are down, and the industry's dividend payments are lagging behind traditional levels.

title: Continued Rise in Interest Rates Seen
description: While several major banks moved their prime lending rates lest week to a record 11 per cent, the consensus among bankers appears to be that the upward movement in interest rates will continue to be fed by inflation for some time to come.

title: Barbara Byron Becomes Bride
description: Miss Barbara Ann Byron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Byron of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Burt Farber, assistant to the president of Harvard University. He is the son of Mrs. Sidney Farber of Carnbridge, Mass., and the late Dr. Farber.

title: PROGRESS IS NOTED IN PAPERS TALKS
description: Progress was reported last night in contract negotiations between the printers union and New York City's three major daily newspapers in an effort to avert a confrontation threatened for tonight at The Daily News.

title: Bronx Man Is Charged In Theft of 25 Taxis
description: A 20yearold Bronx man was arrested Saturday night on charges of stealing taxis and operating them to pick up passengers.

title: Colombey  lesDeuxEglises Reports 193 Out of 218 Vote in Wide Spread
description: COLOMBEYLESDEUXEGLISES, France, May 5 A dark brown granite Cross of Lorraine  as forbidding, gigantic and austere as the man it memorializes, Charles de Gaulletowers from its hilltop where he lived for 36 years, where he died and is buried. The second and final rites for de Gaulle were said today at Colombey's ballot box.

title: DR. HYMAN HERSHRERG
description: Dr. Hyman Hershberg, a general practitioner for 50 years, died Thursday in Monteflore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 84 years old and lived at 2080 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Bloodwater: A Buena Costa County Mystery by John Crowe (Dodd, Mead, $4.95).

title: DE GUSTIBUS

Percy, Republican of Illinois, said today that he was moving to ward a decision to run for President in 1976, but that he would make no announcement before this year's Congressional elections The Senator, when asked whether he woo leaning toward a Presideritial candidacy or away from one, teplied: I wouldsal it's go.

Franklin, imprisoned in Southern Yemen or 16 months on espionage charges. title: In China, Funeral Wreaths Tell of the Politically Living
description: HONG KONG, May 5 China's political leadership is aging, so it is not surprising that state funerals seem to occur with relative frequency in Peking. For China watchers, these events are of more than morbid interest, for the published lists of those who send wreaths and those who mourn often seem to contain hints on the political status of the quick as well as the dead.

The suspects, all between 18 and 30 years old, were released on bond on their own recognizance.

title: Money Game a Puzzle to Campaigners With Big Contributors Ruled Out
description: One of the problems with keeping big money out of political campaigns is how to replace it with little money. The track record for most candidates in tapping the little man New York for campaign contributions is poor. Political A case in point is Notes Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. His supporters sent out 200,000 letters to Democrats throughout the state appealing for contributions. The cost of the computerized mailing was $49,521. The returns? About $15,000 for a net loss of about $34,000. Other fundraising Mail campaigns have had similar problems in the past.

description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., May 5There was a bar mitzvah party yesterday in this village, once known only as the melting pot for fortunes, and the occasion represented Something of a coming of age for Tuxedo Park as well as for David Haber, the 13yearold boy in whose honor it was given.

title: HAROLD HASWELL, 61, A RACINO,
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 5 (AP)Harold M. Haswell, director of racing at Saratoga Harness, died today at Saratoga Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: Bostwick Retains Court Tennis Title
description: Jimmy Bostwick of New York retained the world open court tennis championship yesterday by defeating Howard Angus, the British challenger, 7 sets to 5, in the finale at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club here.

title: Suspect, 24, With Toy Gun Shot After Subway Holdup
description: A stakeout team of Transit Authority policemen yesterday shot a man who was wielding what turned out to be a toy gun in a robbery of a subway token booth in the Bronx. It was the second shooting incident by a police team involving a suspect with a toy gun at a subway booth in two days, and the first had occurred just two blocks away.

title: A Governor Goes to Europe
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 5 (AP)Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. left for Europe last night for a nineday factfinding tour to study offshore drilling and refinery operations, a spokesman said. Aristotle Onassis, the Greek industrialist and shipowner, has been seeking to build a refinery in the state.

title: GEN. HAIG WARNS WATERGATE CURE MAYBE EXCESSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, suggested today that excesses and distortions in investigating Watergate scandals might lead to the cure being worse than the illness.

title: Nothing, to Hide
description: I met with Mr. Dean on Sept. 15, and he gave me no reason at that meeting to believe any others were involved. Not only was I unaware of any coverup, but at that time, and until March 21, I was unaware that there was anything to cover up.

title: Quintuplets Born in France
description: NANCY, France, May 5 (Reuters) A 26yearold woman gave birth here today to quintuplets. The four boys and girl, born 10 weeks prematurely, were placed in an incubaton The mother, MarieFrance Micheli, has one other daughter, aged five. The father is a construction foreman.

title: Books of The Times Captain Cook's Enchanted Isles
description: THE LIFE OF CAPTAIN JAMES COOK 131 J. C. Beaglehole. 760 pages. Illustrate Stanford University Press. $18.50.

title: Briscoe Landslide Perils Mrs. Farenthold's Career
description: HOUSTON, May 5 Candidates hoping for, a rebellion against incumbents were disappointed in yesterday's political primdries in Texas:

title: DR. MILTON JABUSH
description: Dr. Milton Jabush of Lakewood N. J., a diplomate of the American Board of Family Practice, died Saturday when his plane crashed at Myrtle Beach, S.C. He was 50 years old.

title: T.B. Morgan Weds Mrs. Strawbridge
description: Mrs. Mary Rockefeller Strawbridge, younger doughter of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Mrs. Mary Clark Rockefeller, was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas B. Morgan, press secretary to former Mayor John V. Lindsay from 1969 to 1973.

title: City Of Newark Termed MailFraud Capital of U.S.
description: NEWARK, May 5This city has become a center for mail frauds in which the unwary are being bilked of millions of dollars a year through advertisements promoting workathome schemes, weightreduction gimmicks, substancei promising prolonged bridegroom strength and sexual stamina, and miracle cures for illnesses.

title: Cosmos Drop Opener to Comets by 32
description: Blame the fullbacks, the halfbacks, the weather, the photographers or the noise the kids made in the stands, but please, don't blame the Baltimore Comets for the loss they handed the New York Cosmos in their seasonopener yesterday at Randalls Island.

title: GROMYKO IN SYRIA FOR A 3DAY VISIT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5 Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, arrived in Damascus today and said he intended to discuss with Syrian officials a settlement for the Middle East problem, particularly the disengagement of forces on the Golan Heights.

title: Mrs. Hilda Wise, Daughter Of Governor Lehman, Dies
description: Mrs. Hilda Jane Lehman Wise, daughter of Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and the late Governor and Senator, died Saturday at her home, 180 East End Avenue. She was 53 years old.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Winston 500 Is Captured By Pearson
description: TALLADEGA, Ala, May 5 (AP) David Pearson held off repeated challenges today and won an exciting Winston 500 stock car race in the rain. Three persons were hurt during the race in a pitroad accident.

title: Students Try Revolution in Fire Fighting
description: MARINETTE, Wis., May 5  Thick black smoke billowed over parts of this small, northern Wisconsin city this weekend as dozens of major fires burned furiously.

title: Coalition of Black Trade Unionists Plans to Bring Political and Labor Force to Bear in Fall Elections
description: DETEOIT May 5 This weekend may have marked the end of the beginning and the beginning of the real action for a potentially formidable new force in national politics and the labor movement, the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists.

title: Pennsylvania Ballet's Burana Spreads Its Fire to Audience
description: It is a singular pleasure to watch dancers with distinctive personalities in addition to welltrained bodies, dancers who approach everything they do with zest. The Pennsylvania Ballet has its own special corner on those qualities, and Saturday, at Ole Brooklyn Academy of Music, ft received a correspondingly enthusiastic and affectionate response.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the Rational Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

description: LAH TURKIYE (Prudential), Genoa May 25; sails from Port Newark, N.J.

title: State's First DrugData Center Gets Grant of $40,000
description: RIDGEWOOD, May 5The state's first druginformation center, at Valley Hospital in Ridkewood, has received a $40,000 grant to extend its services to the 125 hospitals and more than 11,500 physicians practicing in the state. The center maintains a library with informillion about the availability, identification, interaction, side effects and adverse reactions of both American and foreignmade drugs.

title: Austrians Advance in Cup Tennis
description: VIENNA, May 5 (AP)Peter Pokorny of Austria defeated Jeff Simpson of New Zealand, 61, 62, 911, 63, today and Austria reached the quarterfinals of their European Zone Davis Cup competition. It is the first time since 1936 that Austria has advanced that for in cup play.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Communist Party Etnerges As Strongest in Portugal
description: LISBON, May 5The Communist party has emerged from clandestine existence, prison and exile to become the strongest and bestorganized political force in the new Portugal being shaped after a military coup overthrew the rightwing authoritarian government 10 days ago.

title: Duke U. Students Learn Interviewing Techniques of 'Oral History' to Record Lives of Ordinary People
description: DURHAM, N.C.On Sept. 271900, The Daily Examiner Navasota, Tex., reported the death of Morris Carrington, a local, black leader of an in tsurgent political movement.

title: MITTERRAND TOPS VOTING IN FRANCE; TO FACE GISCARD
description: PARIS, Monday, May 6Voters yesterday chose Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and Valery. Giscard d'Estaing, a conservative, as the two contenders for the presidency of France.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9.

title: TV: A Special on Ailey
description: Adding to an outstanding list of television dance programs, WNET/13 tonight at 8 o'clock is offering Alvin Ailey: Memories and Visions as the Public Broadcasting Corporation's Special of the Week. As a production of the Soul! series, the hourlong presentation was produced by Ellis Haizlip and Alonzo Brown Jr, and directed by Stan Lathan, whose more commercial credits include Several episodes of Sanford and Son and the film documentary Save the Children.

title: Stars, Down 20, Hope Return of Beaty Will Foil Nete Defense Tactics Tonight
description: The Utah Stars, trailing New York, 20, in their American Basketball. Association championship series, will be counting on the return of Zelmo Beaty to try and combat the Nets cheating defense tonight in game No. 3 at Salt Lake City.

title: Tired of It, Grocer Kills Armed Intruder
description: Carters General Storeit's the only store for a quartermile around in its Ozone ParkSouth Jamaica neighborhood of pleasant frame, homes. It sells groceries, beer and soft drinks. It sells newspapers, too, but the two men who came in at 9:23 P.M. Saturday probably never noticed the headline of the Muhanimad Speaks issue on display: The Judgment Nears.

title: Fiyers Beat Rangers, 43, Gain Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5In the confusion of a tumultuous, final minute, the New York Rangers today let an Next Year slip by them as the Philadelphia Flyers scored a 43 victory and Moved to the championship round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Fetters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In an April .12 editorial The Times took the view that limiting the amount of money it is perinissible to earn while still collecting Social Security was a grossly unjust provision. Onthe contrary, I believe the limitation of Social Security payments to those who have retired or partially retired Makes sense.

title: Arts Fund, in Policy Shift, To Flow Equally in State
description: The record budget for the arts approved by the Legislature and awaiting Governor Wilson's signature is designed to spread culture through the state as it never has been before and also to supply more state funds than ever before for support of major cultural institutions.

title: Christine Buck Wed To Howard Kissel
description: Miss Christine Mary. Buck, a violinist, was married here yesterday aftemootkito Howard Kissel, entertainment editor and movie critic for Women's Wear Daily. Rabbi Dan Isaac performed the ceremony in the roof garden of 2 Beekman Place.

title: 2 CONVICTED ARABS EXPELLED BY GREECE
description: ATHENS, May 5 (AP)Two Paleitinian guerrillas convicted of having killed five persons and wounded 55 during a grenade and pistol attack at Athens airport last year were expelled from Greece today and put aboard an airliner bound for Libya.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on colonialism, subcommittee on Pacific Ocean territories10:30 A M.

title: PLAN TO HELP MILLS LAID TO DAIRY AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) A top official of the nation's largest dairy cooperative planned to raise $2million to elect Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas to the White House in 1972, according to statements filed in court.

title: VITO TAMULIS
description: NASHVILLE, May 5 (AP) Vito C. Tamulis, who pitched for the Brooklyn Dodgers from 1938 to 1940, died today of a heart ailment at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was P2 years old.

title: DANCE VISIT ENDED BY PENNSYLVANIANS
description: A sense of adventure accompanies an emerging ballet coinpany like a persistent shadow. With time, the successful ones achieve poise, which marks the beginning of their maturity. The Pennsylvania Ballet, wearing its poise proudly, concluded its short season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News. Summary and Index, Page 37

title: PORTUGAL URGES: A TRUCE IN AFRICA
description: LISBON, May 6The ruling military junta appealed today or a ceasefire in Portugal's African territories.

title: Who Carl Vote?
description: Two years ago, only 55 per cent of Americans voting age participated in the Presidential electionwhich meant, incidentally, that President Nixon, despite his landslide, was elected by only about onethird of the nation's potential voters. The rate of participation was so low because nearly 40 million Americans voting age and otherwise qualified failed tb register.

title: THE NEWS ORDERS IN LABOR DISPUTE
description: The Daily News pearly today ordered its printers to leave its building on 42d Street and Second Avenue in a dispute over the use of automated typesetting processes, after publication of the paper had been delayed fore several hours.

title: WILSON DOUBLES AID FOR COLLEGES
description: ALBANY, May 6Governor Wilson has abandoned his plan for aid to higher education, accepting the approach put forward by the Legislature and agreeing to double the appropriation he had called for only last week.

title: Morristown High School Closed After Racial Fight
description: MORRISTOWN, May 6Classes at Morristown High School were canceled shortly after noon today following clashes between black and white students. Eight students were injured, but all were released from hospitals after treatment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This letter is prompted by the sickening spectacle pictured in the May Times of a group of public officials smirking happily over the signing of a New Jersey bill to repeal the 1962 covenant with respect to Port Authority expendituresi in the masstransit field. Public credit depends in a large Measure on the good faith of government at all levels. That responsible officials can gleefully dishonor a state's commitment can only be destructive of public credit. The 1962 covenant was embodied in concurrent legislation adopted by the two states and reads: The two states covenant and agree with each other and with the holders of any, affected bonds that no pledged revenues shall be applied  for any railroad purposes whatsoever other than permitted purpreposes

title: E.E.C. UNIT BACKS ITALY ON IMPORTS
description: BRUSSELS, May 6The executive commission of the Common Market will propose tomorrow that the nine members approve as a unit the bulk of the restrictions on imports announced by Italy last week. The measure, which covers 42 per cent of Italian imports, mainly consumer goods, requires importers to make sixmonth, interestfree deposit of 50 per cent of the value of the goods imported and goes into effect at midnight tonight.

title: U.S. Charges Housing Bias In Williamsburg Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Justice Department today filed a civil, suit charging the Shefa Developmnt Corporation and its president, Jichak Schwartz, with violating the 1968 Fair Housing Act by refusing to rent apartments to Puerto Ricans in two 30unit buildings at 190 and 200 Ross Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Congress Approves Funds For Alcoholism Treatment
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The House by a vote of 301 to 17 completed Congressional approval today of a bill authorizing $374million for treating and preventing alcoholism.

title: U. S. Got. and Agency Bonds (Prices in 32d of a Point, composite bill vields in basis Points.)
description: U. S. Got. and Agency Bonds (Prices in 32d of a Point, composite bill vields in basis Points.)

title: 11% Prime Uniform
description: A prime lending rate of 11 per cent was made virtually uniform by commercial banks around the country as the move was joined by such leading banks as the Bank of America and the First National City Bank. Details on Paga 70.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that it had formally signed a contract with Saudi Arabian Airlines for delivery of two L1011 Tristar jetliners. Lockheed's original letter of intent with Saudi Arabian Airlines had been subject to the obtaining of suitable financing by the air carrier. The purchase price of the two Tristars $48million.

title: TAPE GAPS LINKED TO PITCH OF VOICE
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The pitch of voices and the onoff controls qn the President's taping system produced a large number of the unintelligible sections on the tape transcripts published last week, the President's counsel, J. Fred Buzhardt, said today.

title: TIMES HEADS LIST IN PUBLISHER POLL
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., May 6 (AP)  Publishers responding to a survey by Edward L. Bemays, public relations counsel, have again placed The New York Times at the top of a list of nehtopapers that best meet the journalistic standards of thelate Thomas Gibson, Adolph S. Ochs and Joseph Pulitzer. Mr. Gibson was, publisher of The Rocky Mountain Herald, Mr. Ochs of The New York Times and Mr. Pulitzer of the New York World.

title: MORD RETRACTS CAPITAL TV SHOW
description: An exclusive twopart con, versation program with James W. McCord the convicted Watergate burglar, wits withdrawn from broadcast by WRCTV in Washington at Mr. McCord'ii request last week because his lawyers felt it might be in violation of an order by Judge John J. Sirica of the United States. District Courf.

title: Felipe Alou Retires
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 6 (UPI) Felipe Alou, the eldest of three brothers to play major league baseball, said pesterday he was retiring following his unconditidnal release by the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Monthly Oil Payments Up $1 Billion Over Year Ago
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reuters)  Commerce Secretary Frederick Dent said today that United States payments for oil imports were now running more than $1billion a month above yearago levels.

title: A.E.C. IS CRITICIZED ON BREEDER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Environmental Protection Agency held today that the Atomic Energy Commission had ??? in a draft statement to make an adequate appraisal of the environmental impact of its longterm program to develop a breeder reactor for widespread commercial use by electric utilities.

title: Harvard Shell Is Eastern Sprint Choice
description: Harvard's unbeaten varsity crew was seeded first yesterday for the Eastern sprint championships on Saturday at Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester, Mass, The other seeded crews were, in order: Wisconsin, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cornell, Pennsylvania and Northeastern.

title: Lapp Decathlon Leader
description: BROOKVILLE, Li., May 6 Rich Lapp of New York Tech was the leader after five events in the second annual C.W. Post college decathlon. He has scored 3,154 points, 23 more than Tony Corso of C.W. Post.

title: HOUSING SYMPHONY PLAYS WITH SPIRIT
description: In what promises to become an annual occasion, the Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra gave its second formal spring concert in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. The usual habitats for this Municipal syinphony, now in its third season are the lawns and halls of public housing, Sing. Sing prison the parks, the streets or wher: ever the city's residents might care to gather for a session Of classical orchestral music.

title: Cordero Gets Plaudits But NO Big A Winners
description: Angel Cordero was back on the job at Aqueduct yesterday, after having ridden Cannonadd to victory in the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs last Saturday, anti finishing fourth At the in the Century at Hollywood Park Race in. California on Tracks Sunday. When lie came out for the first race on a colt called Pancho Jay, Cordem was roundly greeted by many in the crowd of 20,716.

title: Rise in Forest Budget Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, and two House members urged today that more money be spent on growing timber in the national forests to help provide lumber and plywood for building homes. Speaking at a meeting of the National Forests Products Association, they said the budget for the Uited States ??? Service wasvgenerally ??? low.

title: Contenders in France
description: PARIS, May 6After close to 30 year in public life, Francois Mitterrand; who led the field in the presidential election yesterday, winning a place in the runoff vote May 19, is still something of a mystery to many Frenchmen.

title: 3 on a Cruiser Rescued At Sea by Coast Guard
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 6Three men aboard a 26foot cabin cruiser whose engine broke down a mile and a half at sea were rescued today after a 12hour search by Coast Guard ships and a helicopter.

title: Britain and Soviet Union Sign Pact on Cooperation
description: LONDON, May 6 (AP)Britain and the Soviet Union signed today a 10year pact to develop economic, scientific, technological and industrial cooperation, Government sources said.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Lunchtime Concert Series Swings Into Bryant Park
description: The mooning saxophones and rising brass accents of bigband music inaugurated a lunchtime serves of cultural events in Bryant Park yesterday.

title: Often Victorious Brandt Enters a Somber Period
description: I shouldn't say this, but I have the feeling it may be the beginning of the end for us, a high West German official said a couple of weeks ago.

title: Peron Will Visit Soviet Aide Announces in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, May 6President Juan Domingo Per6n of Argentina will visit the Soviet Union later this year, probably in September or October, his personal delegate to Moscow announce today.

title: Tracks for Conrail
description: Acting in the public interest, the Interstate Commerce Commission has recorded its fundamental disagreement with the drastic plans for abandonment of Northeast railroad trackage recommended by the Department Transportation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice directed the city to halt implementation of a law that authorizes rent increases of up to 4 per cent a year, to compensate landlords for higher labor costs, in rentcontrolled apartments here. The law is on the verge of repeal by the City Council, whose General Welfare Committee approved repeal on April 30. In light of this expression of intent by the Council's committee, this court feels that a preliminary injunction should issue, Justice Nathaniel T. Heiman ruled.

title: N.C.A.A. Supports Two Senate Bills
description: MISSION, Kan., May (UPI)The N.C.A.A. Council announced today its endorsement of two bills in Congress that would affect participation by amateur athletes in international competition.

title: Grant's Sales in April Up
description: The W. T. Grant Company said its sales in April were 0.7 per cent higher, totaling $143.1 million compared with $142.1million in the same 1973 month. In three months through April sales were 2.5 per cent lower to $370.5million from $380milion.

title: People and Business
description: New regulations for banks that trade in municipal securities were urged yesterday by John R. Evans, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, May. 7. 1814
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, taking responsibility for negligence that allowed an East German Communist spy to become a member of his staff, took the unexpected step of tendering his resignation to President Gustav W. Heinemann. He asked that Foreign Minister Walter Scheel be named to fill; his place until Parliamentelects a successor. A spokesman for Dr. Heinemann said that the President had accepted Mr. Brandt's letter of resignation without insisting that he remain in office. This means that Mr. Scheel will automatically become Chancellor today. [1:8.]

title: Horowitz to Give Recital In Cleveland on Sunday
description: Vladimir Horowitz, who last played in public six years ago, will emerge again for a recital at Severence Hall in Cleveland Sunday afternoon.

title: TWO NEW OIL DEALS MADE BY ABU DHABI
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3 (AP)The Persian Gulf Arab emirate of Abu Dhabi has signed two new sales deals for crude oil with American companies, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey has reported.

title: Guard and Escaped Bank Robber Hurt In Bid to Free Inmate During Funeral
description: NEWARK, May 6An escaped bank robber was wounded and a corrections officer was pistolwhipped today in an abortive attempt to free an inmate, of Trenton State Priscin who was attending his grandfather's funeral here.

title: Milk Producers Group Fined $5,000 for Nixon Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, May 6An Eastern milk producers group, the Lehigh Valley Cooperative Farmers of Allentown, Pa., was fined $5,000 today after pleading guilty to allegations that it illegally, gave $50,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: ICELAND'S COALITION SPLITS ON INFLATION
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 6 (AP)One of the three parties in Iceland's leftist coalition Cabinet withdrew today in protest over the Government's antiinflation policies.

title: ARTHUR DONOW
description: Arthur Donow, a public accountant, who was controller of the Nassau County Public, Welfare Department from 1930 to 1950, died Sunday of a heart attack in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in Port Jefferson, L.I., and in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Donow graduated from Pace College.

title: White Sox Bow, 54, To Tigers
description: Dick Sharon, a pinchhitter, drove in the tying run with a grounder in the seventh inning, then stole second and scored on a single by Jerry Moses to give the Detroit Tigers a 5.4 triumph over the Chicago White Sox last night at Tiger Stadium in Detroit.

title: Valery Giscard d'Estaing
description: PARIS, May 6Watery Giscard d'Estaing, Who at age 48 could become one of France's youngest Presidents, has frequently been likened to John F. Kennedy.

title: ROYALTY BIDDING ON OIL LEASES SET
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Interior Department said today that it would make a smallscale test of royalty bidding in its September offering of oil leases for two million acres of seabed off the coast of Louisiana.

title: College President Named
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., May (AP)Donald A. Gordon, 40 years old, of Santa Barbara, Calif., will become president of Pine Manor Junior College July I. He was principal of Abbott Academy in Andover, Mass., now merged with Phillips An dove/.

title: Escapades Shows. Dance's Pleasures And Its. Problems
description: Yon Martin, a member'of Miss Miller's Chamber Arts Dance Players, prepares for a solo. The Niork up to this point has been a happy blend of lyrical,. sometimes almost wistful, solos and anecdotally funny group dance, very much in the spirit of Gwendolyn Watson's music, which has suddenly come to a pause. The puzzled dancer pretends exasperation as taped voices  supplant the expected Music, but he begins, to dance.

title: New Coach Sees Army In New Light
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 My biggest surprise here is that West Point is more like a school than a milithy academy. That was Homer Smith's observation today just about four College months after he was hired as the Sports new head footNotes ball coach at Army.West Point is kids with books under their arms going to class and taking exams just like at other colleges. I haven't seen a parade yet but I have seen a lot of chemistry books.

title: Devotees of Crumb Share Chamber Unit's Showcase
description: The Chamber Music Society of the American Symphony Orchestra ended its sixcontact series at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night with a curious, inconsistent program.

title: Heiress in Art Theft a Social Rebel
description: LONDON, May 6Last Octaber, Bridget Rose Dugdale stood before a judge after a jury had found her guilty of a theft of paintings from her wealthy parents. The judge, Sir. Hugh, Park, gave her a suspended twoyear sentence and set her free, sayfrig:

title: Leftists to Back Peron Despite Rebuff
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 6The Peronist left wing, in a major statement published today, vowed to remain within the Peronist movement despite the rebuff received from President Juan Domingo Perlin last week at the May Day celebrations here.

title: BYRNE SIGNS LAW ON VOTE FINANCING
description: TRENTON, May 6 New Jersey today became the first state to enact a law providing public funds for the campaigns of candidates for Governor in the general election.

title: Kennedy Library Plan Scaled Down Greatly
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 (AP)  The longdelayed John F. Kennedy Library, once envisioned as a massive complex dominated by glass pyramid, is being redesigned because local residents complained it would be too grandiose.

title: Team Tennis Opens With Flair
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6In an atmosphere of bedsheets and banners, luckynumber scorecards, spectators shouting without being reprimanded, substitutions and playbyplay statistics, World Team Tennis arrived on the professional sports scene tonight.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 (UPI)The fate of Flip Sal, the horse that broke down Saturday in the 100th running of the Kentucky Derby, may not be known until Wednesday at the earliest.

title: New President Is Elected For Building Trades Group
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The executive council of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the. American Federation of Labor and Council of Industrial Organizations unanimously elected Robert A. Georgine today as, president of the department.

title: Bears Chambers Cited
description: CHICAGO, May 6 (UPI) A defensive lineman, Wally Chambers, was named today as recipient of the Brian Piccolo Award for 1974 and received a trophy from two teammates, Dick Butkus and Jim Osborne. Osborne won last season's award, presented to the Bears rookie who best exemplifies the spirit of Brian Piccolo, a running back for the Bears who died of Cancer.

title: City Police Force Gets Its First Woman Mountie
description: Mary and Herman are not your usual kind of police team, but for the next month they'll become a familiar patrol pair in a corner of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx.

title: Sweetened Sugar
description: Under the spur of supply shortages in many parts the world, the price of sugar is soaring again in commodities markets. Yet the United States, with the capacity to grow much more sugar than it does, is still paying domestic producers to hold down their output.

title: Selling Pushes Farm Products Down
description: Waves of selling swept all key commodity futures exchanges yesterday, forcing potential buyers to hide and observe the first rule of their tradenever buck a trend.

title: Cougars Top Toros, Win W.H.A. Series
description: TORONTO, May 6 (UPI)Secondperiod goals by Bob Liddington, Jan Popiel, Bob Sicinski and Darryl Maggs powered Chicago to a 52 victory over the Torontb Toros tonight and clinched the World Hockey Association semifinal playoff for the Cougars, four games to three.

title: A vertisin Prerniums Gaining
description: Shortages or no shprtages, the Premittm Show was bigger than ever yesterday as it opened its fourday stay at the New York Coliseum with about 1,050 exhibitors and 24,298 registrations.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: After Gaullism?
description: The first round of France's Presidential election has brought the Gaullist era to an end. More than 80 per cent of the nation voted for changeafter sixteen years Gaullism. A halfdecade after General de Gaulle's departure from office, it is evident that his long years of personal rule failed to leave behind a party capable of carrying on in his name. In estimating what comes next, there is only one certainty a close race between Socialist Francois Mitterrand and Independent Republican Valery Giscard d'Estaing in the runoff on May 19.

title: BURR LINDEN CHASE
description: Burr Linden Chase, who retired in 1962 as board chairman of Silver Burdett Publishers, division of the General Learning Corporation, Morristown, N. J., died Friday at his home in Madison, N. J. He was 82 years old.

title: Nixon Accused of Hindering Aid to Mentally
description: DETROIT, May 6 (AP) Policies of the Nixon Administratiori have hindered morel than they have helped in the delivery of services to those suffering from mental illness, Dr. John P. Spiegel of Brandeislhealth University, presidentelect of the American Psychiatric tion, charged today.

title: PRESIDENT YIELDS IN MOVE TO QUASH JAWORSKI'S WRIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 6President Nixon backed down today from his opposition to the Watergate special prosecutor's subpoena for tapes and records of 64 White House conversations by indicating through his lawyers that he was wjlling to reach an accommodation With the prosecution.

title: U.S. JUDGE WEIGHING] GALLEY'S BOND PLEA
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 6 (AP) A Federal judge took under, advisement today a ruling on whether William L. Calley Jr.,1 now a civilian, should remain free on bond.

title: Princess Margaret Receives Beames At WaldorfAstoria

title: The Screen: Mann's 'Lost in the Stars':The Cast
description: Except for Kurt Weill's score, which remains one of his loveliest, everything about the Maxwell "Anderson-Weill musical play, "Lost in the Stars," seems to have aged badly in the screen adaptation that opened here yesterday at selected theaters.The film is the eighth and last presentation in the American Film Theater's first subscription series. It's also by far the worst, but since the A.F.T. offerings included one fine film, "The Homecoming," one recording of a fine production, "Three Sisters," and a number of superlative performances, including that of Alan Bates in "Butley," the A.F.T.'s initial season shouldn't be judged to have been as much of a failure as were some of its parts."Lost in the Stars," based on Alan Paton's 1948 novel, "Cry the Beloved Country" (which was filmed in 1952), was first done on Broadway in 1949 and then revived in 1972. From the way that Daniel Mann has directed this film version, it seems to be a work completely dependent upon the conventions of the stage.In the theater we accept illiterate characters who sing Broadway-type lyrics and we pretend that the lyrics are poetry. We also accept startling narrative coincidences because, after all, the stage is so small that the most unlikely people might well bump into one anotherand often do when dancing.Mr. Mann has apparently had no idea how to create an equivalent reality in a film that appears to have been shot mostly on exterior locations meant to simulate those in South Africa, where the story is set. One result is a kind of aimlessness that pervades the film. The camera doesn't seem to know quite what to do when a character bursts into song over a real washtub in a real backyard. It seems almost embarrassed, as you might be if the person next to you in the subway suddenly launched into a full-throttle "Some Enchanted Evening."Thus the music and the lyrics that are supposed to be in the service of the drama are constantly upsetting it, making it look fabricated and false. This is too bad, since I suspect there is still a lot of power to be gotten from Mr. Paton's story of the old black country preacher, a man of orderly faith, and his search through the Johannesburg slums for the son who has become a murderer.For reasons best known to the film makers, they've pretty much dropped the original idea of the reconciliation between the black preacher and the wealthy old white bigot whose son was the victim of the murder. Even if that optimistic conclusion was dropped as smacking too much of 1949 liberalism, it still is dramatically more effective than the nothing ending that "Lost in the Stars" now has.The performers do much better as singers than as actors, and because Brock Peters, who plays the old preacher, has given good performances in the past, I assume his uneasiness here must stem from the aimlessness of the production as a whole.None of the actors come off well, and that includes Melba Moore as the poor ghetto girl, Clifton Davis as the black boy who goes wrong and Paul Rogers (so fine in "The Homecoming") as the bigoted white landowner."Lost in the Stars" is a very bad movie but it does contain the Weill score. The music almost compensates for the foolishness of the images, the lyrics, the drama and the point-of-view, which, in spite of the ending, recalls the "ain't-black-folks-noble?" philosophy evident in so much well-meaning theater of 40 to 50 years ago. Tote dat barge. Lift dat bale. A card at the beginning of the movie identifies the time of the story as "The Recent Past." That isn't enough to get the movie off the hook.

A spokesman for Dr. Heinemann said that the President had accepted Mr. Brandt's letter of resignation without insisting that he remain in office. This means that Mr. Scheel will automatically become Chancellor today. [1:8.]

title: Dave Anderson
description: Frustration is like other intangibles. It's usually difficult to put a price on it, But for followers of the New York Rangers, the price of frustration is $5million. That's approximately the amount they have contributed to the Madison Square Garden box office in the last eight years for the frustration of watching Stanley Cup games. The ticket buyers deserve a refund. The last time the Rangers won the Stanley Cup was in 1940 when a German army helmet meant Adolf Hitler; now a German army helmet means the Philadelphia Flyers fan club for Dave Schultz, the heavyweight champion on skates. That's how long it has been. Two generations. In that time three New York teams that weren't even organized in 1940 have won the championship in their respective sportsthe Knicks, the Jets and the Mets. But the Rangers continue to skate on a treadmill to frustration that to their followers is really worse than the one the team was on all those years when it didn't even qualify for the playoffs. Now the frustration includes a $15top for the Garden playoff games.

title: Sketches of the Winners of the 58th Pulitzer rizes in Jou lism, nd the
description: Cultural anthropoligist finished The Denial of Death toward end of 1972 Sought to show that fear of life and fear of death are mainsprings of human activity. The 49yearold author of eight books said in an interview last year in Psychology Today that, although he had been an atheist, I think the birth of my first child, more than anything else, was the miracle that woke me up to the idea of God.  Shortly after book's publication by Free Press Division of Macmillan, was, stricken with cancer and taken to hospital in Vancouver, B.C., where he had been teaching at Simon Fraser University. Of death he had written, I think one does, or should try to, just hand over one's  life, the meaning of it, the value of it, the end of it. Born Sept. 27, 1924, in Springfield, Mass. A. B. from Syracuse in 1950  Served in U.S. Embassy in Paris, but returned to Syracuse for doctorate  Died last March Survived by widow, Marie, and three children.

title: Super Milers Reunion To Mark Bannister Feat.
description: On May 6, 1954, at the Iffley Road Track in London, a slim, sandyhaired, 25yearold Oxford medical student named Roger Bannister ran the world's first mile in under four minutes, On the 20th anniversary of that event yesterday, plans for a reunion bringing together most of the world's greatest milers of the last 20 years were announced here by Sports Illustrated magazine and the National Art Museum of Sport.

title: 43 Triumph Sparked by Maddox Double
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 7 Elliott Maddox, one of the Yankees new faces of 1974, lashed a runscoring double in the 12th inning tonight, giving the Yankees a 43 victory over the Texas Rangers and helping them overcome the sloppy base running of Thurman Munson, the slipshod fielding of Jim Mason and the uncommonly ineffective pitching of Sparky Lyle.

title: Hot vs. Clean Air
description: If there is a surefire way to obscure the complexities of the energy problem, it is to present them through the simplicities of selfserving argument This is what the American Electric Power System has done in demanding crippling amendment of the Clean Air Act.

title: Dance The Royal Ballet
description: It is all unfair. Institutions, by calendar count; grow old as quickly as the people watching them. But institutions, at least the right institutions, are forever renewing themselves and are, as a consequence eternally young. Last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Britain's Royal Ballet started one of its regular New York seasons, but this time celebrating its first visit to these shores 25 years ago. And only the company seems to have gotten younger. It is as welcome as the flowers in May.

title: 135,000 Visit Expo 74
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 7 (UPI)Warm and sunny spring weather, and a Presidential visit combined to bring more than 135,000 visitors to the Expo 74 site during the fair's first weekend of operation. Expo's general manager, Peter Spurney, said opening day and Sunday attendance exceeded expectations and predicted that the fair's total attendance after; six months of operation could, hit the five million mark, or higher.

title: National Kinney Sets an Offer For All Shares of Uris Building
description: The National Kinney Corporation initiated yesterday a tender offer for all of the shares of the Uris Building Corporation in which it already has 56 per cent interest. Kinney will pay $15 share for 3.5 million Uris common shares and $19.327 each for 310,349 Uris warrants, for an estimated total cost of $60million.

The Southern city was a prime candidate for an N.F.L. expansion team and the 26 owners need to revise their plans when they next meet here in June.

Mr. Brandt's decision appeared to be final, but for the time being, he said, he will not resign as head of the party. [1:1.]

Amid t the tumult there was a twominute bell at 1:28 P.M. and then the final bell at 1:30 marked the end of trading in the most spectacular potato futures contract in the history of the exchange.

One form by which the 139,000 department employes are rated annually by their supervisors contains reueated references to he, his, or himself while making no references to females.

description: NEWARK, May 7A jury of eight women and four men tonight found Albert Chavies guilty of murder in the first degree for his role in the assassination of a Black Muslim minister, James McGregor Shabazz, last Sept. 4.

title: Red Smith
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Ed Garvey, the George Meany of professional football, took part in a conference today on the economics of professional sport. What's to confer? a caller asked. Every (expletive deleted) in the game has a milliondollar contract already or can go get one, from the World Football League, can't he? Garvey said that wasn't exactly the point. We asked some economists and other people not involved in pro football to come in and help evaluate the reserve system, he said, and to discuss the economics of pro sports in general. It's sort of a freeforall.

title: Conductor Brings to Light Blacks Symphonic Works
description: Black music? Of Coursethe blues, spirituals, and all that jazz. Paul Freeman knew all about: it, or thought he did. But Mr. Freeman, who is conductor in residence of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, discovered to his astonishment not long, ago that there is a threecenturyheritage of firstrate symphonic music by black composers. He has set out, to make it known.

title: League of Women Voters Votes to Let Men Join It
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 The League of Women Voters agreed today to end its longstanding policy of barring full membership to men. The vote, by a margin of better than 2 to 1, came after a long and often bitter debate over whether women have enough selfconfidence to work equally with men.

More than 250,000 acres of the Everglades have been burned since January. The new lire is in a remote, section of the swamp. Officials said unless the fire was checked quickly, it would burn out of control.

Neal, who headed the Watergate coverup investiation last year when Archibald Cox was the special prosecutor, has returned to the prosecution team as chief trial lawyer, it was announced today. title: The Peace Chancellor
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt's resignation is a loss not only to West Germany but to the world. Despite skepticism at home and abroad, his Ostpolitik brought a provi sional settlement between East and West in Central Europe a quartercentury after World War II; and it won him the Nobel Peace Prize. His effort to accelerate the unification of Western Europe and to improve its strained relations with the United Stateshis Westpolitikwas of equal importance, even if less successful. His halfdecade of service as West Germany's first Socialist Chancellor since the 1920's helped take the world a long stride toward peace.

S. have come to realize that a revolution has taken place in Latin Americathat military junta takeovers there (Brazil, Uruguay, Bolivia, Ecuador and Chilewith others brewing) can be equated with revolution? And, can he believe that with our Pentagon military might and supplies, and the economic leverage of our multinational corporations, we honestly could deal with Latin America as equals  and partners?

title: Gaullist France Comes to an End

If nothing else the quest for a new President touched off by Georges Pompidou's death proved that Gaullism could not long endure without its namesake and inventor.
