title: U.S. Rests Casein TrotFix Trial
description: Shaken by the defection of its star witness, the Government rested its case yesterday in the racefixing trial of 13 harness drivers and nine codefendants.

title: SENATE TO QUERY JUSTICE OFFICIALS ON COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today in executive session to begin fullscale hearings into the Justice Department's failure to unravel the Watergate coverup in the summer and fall of 1972, Senate sources said.

title: The G.O.P. Disengages
description: Dean Burch, counselor to President Nixon, overreached himself two weeks ago in a speech to the Republican National Committee, a speech that he said he had cleared with the President. Mr. Burch, now the chief political guru on the White House staff, told his fellow Republican leaders that they had to sink or swim with Mr. Nixon because his roles as President and as party leader are. indistinguishable.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and India, Page 45

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The, net profit of petroleum companies cannot be correctly stated in the simple terms as presented by the oil companies and in your newspaper. The actual net profits are considerably higher than publicly announced. This comes about as a result of accounting rules and the tax laws. Percentage depletion is permitted as a deduction against beforetax income thereby reducing the tax and the aftertax income. The accounting rules call aftertax profit net profit, but this is misleading.

title: Most Active Stocks Wednesday, May 8, 1974
Bar Association Loses Its Fight To Avoid Paying Realty Taxes
description: ALBANY, May 8The State Court of Appeals today ruled that the Association of the Bar, of the City of New York and the Exploreri Club must pay realestate taxes to New York City.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, May 8 (UPI)The Israeli military command said that three Israeli soldiers were wounded in artillery clashes in the Golan Heights area today.

title: You Could Almost Say He Was Born With a Ladle in His Hand
description: We can quote chapter and verse about the works and world of Georges Auguste Escoffier, the man who is to the Gallic table what games are to Hoyle: But somehow, in the course of our labors in the world of food, we had never heard of Edouard Nignon, another of the titans of French cooking.

title: Black Senator, in Georgia Indicted for Tax Evasion
description: ATLANTA, gay, 8 (UPI)A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted State Senator Le roy R. Johnson, one of the South's most powerful black politicians on four counts of evading $44,339.92 in Federal income taxes.

title: Red Sox Top Yanks, 40, On 5Hitter
description: BOSTON, May 8Bill Lee, a lefthanded pitcher who eats up the Yankees like Sesame Street's Cookie Monster gobbles cookies, began correcting tonight some of the injustice he had talked about shortly before Boston defeated the Yankees, 40.

title: FORD ADDING $163 TO ITS 74 PRICES; ES, ASSAILS RISE
description: DETROIT, May 8The Ford Motor Company announced today price increases averaging $163 on its 1974 cars and trucks to offset in part unprecedented cost increases. The rises amount to $113, or 2.4 per cent, in the sticker price, and $50, or 1.1 per cent, for options that have become standard equipment.

title: ROONEY BILLBOARDS BEING INVESTIGATED
description: Howard M. Pack, president of Seatrain Lines, Inc., which operates a shipbuilding enterprise in the former Navy Yard here, expressed surprise yesterday at being the target of a new investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: Boys Clubs Cole Gets Group's Hoover Award
description: The Boys Clubs of America presented their Herbert Hoover Memorial Award yesterday to Albert L. Cole, chairman of the organization's board and former general manager and vice president of Reader's Digest, in an awards dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel attended by 1,500 people.

title: Subway Thief Gets 7 Years
description: Clarence Farrell, who pleaded guilty to robbing a Bronx subway change booth, was sentenced yesterday to a sevenyear prison term. Mr. Farrell was arrested, last Oct. 24 at a Manhattan train station after Ili& jumped over a turnstile to avoid paying the fare. The police allegedly found 293 tokens in his pockets and after investigation he was charged With the arinepobbery of the IRT change booth at East 219th Streets in the Bronx. In that robbery, $304.20 was taken in cash. Justice Donald Zimmerman of Bronx Suprerhe Court ilronounced sentence.

title: FUTURES PRIM FOR GRAINS CLIMB
description: Despite the prospect of record crops of wheat and corn, prices of both grains sharply yesterday, continuing the strength they showed on Tuesday.

title: RECORD HARVEST FOR MEAT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The nation's farmers are expected to harvest a record 1.6 billion bushels of winter wheat this year, up 27 per cent from the former record, set in 1973, the Agriculture Department estimated today.

title: News and Printers Resuming Talks as Paper Continues to Publish
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator in the newspaper dispute, asked the two sides last night to meet with him today for resumption of contract negotiations.

title: Respect For The Rules
description: BOSTON, May 8When Willy Brandt resigned as Chancellor of the Federal German Republio, he gave the briefest of official explanations: I accept the political responsibility for negligence in connection with the Guillaume espionage affair. title: Trading in Stock Halted
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended yesterday trading in the securities of American Export Industries, Inc., and American Export Lines, Inc., formerly known as American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc., until May 17. The suspension in trading was initiated because the companies failed to comply with reporting provisions of the S.E.C. Act, resulting in a lack of current information to the public.

title: PAPER LOSES EFFORT TO VOID REBOZOSUIT
description: MIAMI, May 8 (1.IPI)United States District Judge Joe.Eaton refused today to dismiss a $10million libel suit filed by President Nixo0 close friend Charles G. Rebozo, against The Washington.:Post.

title: FREDERICK G. HORN
description: Frederick G. Horn, an associate professor emeritus of accounting at New York University's College of Business and Public Administration, died yesterday at Ramapo General Hospital, Spring Valley, N. Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Pearl River N. Y.

title: Impasse on 5% OTB Tax Holds Up City. Fiscal Aid
description: ALBANY, May 8An impasse over where a 5 per cent surcharge on bets placed at offtrack betting facilities will be imposed is delaying final approval by the Legislature of the full fiscal package for. New York City. The package is designed to close an $818million gap in the city's budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: Carolinian Seeking Ervinr Seat Avoids Runoff Primary
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 8State Attorney General Robert Morgan emerged today as the Democratic nominee to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Sam J. Ervin Jr.

title: Companies Expected to Have Trouble Getting Outside Directors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8Large corporations are going to have an increasingly difficult time getting outsiders to serve on their boards, according to a number of prominent businessmen who met here this week.

title: REA OFFICER DENIES HE MISUSED FUNDS
description: Tom Kole, president of REA Express, Inc., issued a statement late yesterday in which he denied that he had ever used corporate funds for personal investment purposes.

description: Kenneth B. Wackman, vice chairman of, the Talcott National Corporation, a large factoring concern, died Tuesday evening at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Allocation of Gas For May Increased By 10.4% for Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The Federal Energy Administration announced today a 10.4 per cent increase in daily gasoline supplies for May, virtually eliminating the prospect of any nationwide shortage this month.

description: OTTAWA, May 8The minority Liberal party Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was toppled today when it lost a confidence vote in the House of Commons over its budget policies.

description: WASFIINGTON, May 8The House Interior Committee all but completed today the final draft of a bill that would curb some., Of the, Avorst abuses of surfaceruining for Coal by imposing the first \Federal environmental regulation on the booming strip mine industry.

description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Thursday, May 9 (Reuters)Premier Olafur Johannesson announced early today that Iceland's Parliament would be dissolved and new elections held June 30 as a result of the splitting of his coalition Cabinet over hoW to fight inflation.

description: FRANKLIN LAKES, May 8Hal Corizzi, the only basketball coach in Ramapo Regional High School's existence, has coached his final season.

description: HAMILL, S. D.The calves had to be pulled this yearliterally winched out of their Mother's womb.

title: Every Effort Vowed in Move to Reopen Morristown H.S. After Racial Clashes
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 8 Education officials here said today they would make every effort to resume the normal class schedule on Monday at this affluent commuter town's high school, which has been closed most of the week because of fighting between black and white students.

title: Consumer Chief Reports Plea to Go Easy on a Beame Contributor
description: Elinor Guggenheimer, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday that Irving Goldman, the Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and a major fundraiser id Mayor Beame's election campaign, had asked her to go easy on a Beame campaign contributor whose company was under investigation for alleged codsumer fraud.

title: TV Musicians Refuse to Work As Talks on Contract Bog Down
description: In what is termed by the union a withholding of services rather than a strike, the American Federation of Musicians has stopped, work at the three television networks and at a number of independent production companies. Hal Davis, president of the union, said the action was taken because negotiations for a new contract had reached an impasse after the old twoyear contract had expired April 30.

description: The Combustion Engineering stock market debacle yesterday demonstrated once again that many institutional investors act on the herd instinct rather than on dispassionate analysis of a stock's worth.

title: DROPS CONTINUE ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices continued to tall or the American Stock Exchange and the overthecountermarket yesterday as investors remained cautious about possibilIties of improvement in the economy in this country and showed fears of Canadian tax increases.

title: Kansas City Star Strike
description: KANSAS CITY, May 8 (UPI) Editions of The Kansas City Star with reduced amounts of news and display advertisement and no classified ads were printed again today by supervisory personnel and other employes in the absence of pressmen.

title: Chicago Tribune. Calls on Nixon To Quit for WellBeing of Nation
description: CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI)The Chicago Tribune, long regarded as one of the nation's stanchest Republican newspapers, called today for President Nixon to leave office for the sake of the Presidency, the country and the free world.

title: Smith, Newcombe Advance in W.C.T.
description: DALLAS, May 8Rod Laver, whose steely nerves and penchant for the big shot had carried him to the top of professional tennis, again failed in his quest for the World Championship of Tennis title tonight.

description: High Tides Around New York

title: Nixon Opponents Accused of Using Repulsive Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)A top White Hotise aide charged tonight that tactics were being used by those who wished to drive the President from office.

title: Borge to Open School Stage
description: The new 450seat theater at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be opened tomorrow evening with performances by Victor Borge, the star of Comedy in Music, and Marylyn Mulvey, soprano. Mr. Borges daughter, Rikke, is 1973 graduate of the school. The pieshape theater was designer by Donald Oenslager.

title: Man Robs Queens Bank And Dies Later in Bar
description: A 55yearold man held up a bank yesterday and collapsed and died a few minutes later while drinking at a Queens bar, the police reported. The man had walked up to a teller at the bank in Elmont, set down a paper bag he said contained a bomb, and fled with $2,400, the police said.

title: Jesuit at the White House Defends Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Dr. John McLaughlin, the Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, held an extraordinary news conference today to deny charges by Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader, and other Republicans that, as Mr. Scott put it, the Watergate transcripts portrayed deplorable, disgusting, shabby, immoral performances by the President and his aides.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 8 (AP)Joseph Wheeler, owner the Virginia Ambassadors of the World Football League, said today if he could not get more investors for the franchise by Friday he would have to sell the club. Wheeler said a group in Orlando, Fla., had expressed interest in buying the franchise after meeting with him last night.

title: COOKTREADWELL ASKS SUSPENSION
description: CookTreadwell & Harry, Inc. a 65yearold Memphis Insurance agency and underwriter, requested yesterday suspension of trading of its common stock on the overthecounter market afterlearning of material misstatements of results of its operations in 1972.

Figures Include only transactions etiocted by NASDAQ marketmakers but may include some duplication where marketmakas traded with each other.

title: Ford Denies Citroen Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that, thete was absolutely no substance to reports that it might aid the Citroen Motor Company, in its present troubles. The New York Times reported yesterday that there were rumors in Paris about this possibility.

title: The Other Lawyers
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren observed the other day that the parade of attorneys accused of Watergaterelated crimes has weakened confidence in the legal profession. Starting at the top, the President faces possible impeachment and the former Vice President has been disbarred in Maryland.

title: MOZAMBIQUE ENDS POLITICAL SILENCE
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, May 8Like Lisbon, this capital of Portuguese Mozambique has been humming with political talk since the coup that ended nearly half century of political silence. But the discussion here is note about how to create democratic government in Portugal. The question is, How can Portugal continue to govern at all in this African land? There has been no answer from Lisbon.

description: Major League Baseball and Standings

title: WITNESSES SUPPORT STORY ON RONCALLO
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 8Government witnesses in the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo supported testimony today given by William F. Cosulich, the head of an environmentalengineering concern in Woodbury, L. I. Mr. Cosulich had testified that threats were used to obtain a $1,000 campaign contribution from him in 1970.

title: Black Vote for Wallace Is Put. At 2025% in Alabama Primary
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 8 Gov. George C. Wallace apparently picked up as much as 25 per cent of the black vote in Alabama yesterday.

title: Basketball Merger By Next Season?
description: Amalgamation of the stronger American Basketball Association teams into an enlarged National Basketball Association may be achieved by next season through a series of highly private negotiations, Federal court actions and external forces, according to Informed sources in both leagues.

title: Also Slays HimselfWaited in Lobby to Attack Couple
description: A 32yearpld airline flight attendant returning home with her date early yesterday was shot to death in the lobby of her East Side apartment building by a rejected suitor who then used his pistol to kill himself, the police reported.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The May wheat futures contract, which once sold as high as $6.36 a bushel, dropped sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday to close down the 20centsabushel limit at $3.41. On Wednesday, the delivery closed at $3.61.

title: $125,000 Offered for Tennis Slam
description: A $125,000 bontis was offered yesterday to any woman who scores a grand slam of tennis.

title: A Strange Nomination
description: Richard Nixon's nomination of Earl J. Silbert to be U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia has predictably set off a Senate Judiciary Committee investigation of the Justice Department's original handling of the Watergate matter. Mr. Silbert directed the Watergate inquiry until the appointment of Archibald Cox as special prosecutor, which raises the question why Mr. Nixon would nominate a man whose confirmation hearings were bound to rake over the coals of Watergate and the coverup.

title: PORTUGAL IS BACKEDI BY TRADING GROUP
description: GENEVA, May 9Portugal's partners in the sevennation European Free Trade Association expressed outspoken support today for moves toward the reintroduction of democratic processes by the country's new ruling junta.

title: Burns Beats Siderowf in NorthSouth
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 9 (AP)The Canadian amateur champion, George Burns won the first three holes on the back nine and went on to a 2and1 victory over the British amateur champion, Dick Siderowf, today in the raindelayed quarterfinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: MORTIMER MAY DIES; A ZIONIST LEADER, 81
description: Mortimer May, a former president of the Zionist Organization of America, who had beeft an executive with the May Hosiery Mills of Nashville for 50 years, died Wednesday in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 81 years old and formerly lived, in Nashville.

title: At the Polls
description: Of this week's scattered primaries, the most portentous was in Alabama, the most revealing in Ohio. Gov. George C. Wallace's unprecedented thirdterm nominationwith twothirds of the total vote in a field of five Democrats must be seen as a sure sign of his continuing political importance in spite of the crippling attempt on his life. It will reinforce Mr. Wallace's hope of playing a major role in the Presidential politics of 1976.

title: N.Y.U. to Drop Varsity Baseball
description: New York University announced yesterday it would drop varsity baseball at the end of this season. At the same time the school's president, Dr. James M. Hester, said junior varsity basketball would be brought back next year for the first time since the spring of 1971, when intercollegiate basketball was dropped because of financial troubles at the school.

title: Spring Potpourri on Forum's Screen
description: Lighthearted is the word for Spring Potpourri, the collection of 13 short subjects that arrived yesterday at the Film Forum. And true to the label, the wares of these avantgarde film makers are varied, even though they are not preponderantly effective in executing their largely humorous or satiric themes.

title: Democratic Coalition Aid Likely to Go to Samuels
description: Howard J. Samuels is favored to win the liberal New Democratic Coalition endorsement tomorrow in the first major test of strength in the Democratic gubernatorial race.

description: XENIA, OhioPresident Nizon promised massive Federal aid to help rebuild this city ok 25,000, which was halfdestroyed by a tornado a month ago.

title: April Wholesale Index Up 0.7% Despite a Drop in Farm Prices

The measure would require legislative passage before it could be put into effect. The State Labor and Industry Commissioner, Joseph A. Hoffman, said was time for workers and employers to bite the bullet because the fund was in perilous, condition.

description: WASHINGTON, May 9The Republican leader in the House, John J. Rhodes of Arizona, said today that President Nixon should think again about resigning. His statement was part of mounting pressure against Mr. Nixon within his own party.

title: Campaign of Fear

Stewart Jr. has turned back the latest effort of the United Federatidn Teachers to dominate or disrupt the election process.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)Haskins & Sells, one of the nation's biggest accounting firms, has won a $1million contract to recommend improvements in the office of the Controller of the Currency in the first outside review the agency's 110year history, the Treasury said today.

title: White House Extends Tours
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The White House announced today that tourists visiting time would be extended an additional two hours on Satur days during the summer months to accommodate the expected increase in vacation crowds. Starting. Saturday, June 1, and until Aug. 31, the visiting hours will be extended from 10 AN. until 2 P.M. Normaily the building closes at noon. The White House is normally open from 10 A.M. to noon daily from Tuesday to Friday.

title: Rev. Dr. John Meister, Led Presbyterian Seminary Unit
description: The Rev. Dr. John W. Meister, director of the United Presbyterian Connell of Theological Seminaries, died Tuesday in the Medical Center at Princeton, N. J., after a brief illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Titusville, N. J.

title: Red Smith
description: Forgettable though it was, the 100th Kentucky Derby was hardly forgotten before an, item was published reporting that Bill Shoemaker's California attorneys were talking about going to court over vicious and damaging material in Run For The Roses, an informal history the race by Jim Bolus of The Louisville CourierJournal. (Hawthorn Books, Inc., $14.95.) The book says that after misjudging the finish line, easing Gallant Man for an instant and losing the 1957 Derby to Iron Liege by a nose, Shoemaker tried to lie out of it, The lawyers say he didn't lie. The fact is, he not only of admitted his error, but after the death of Gallant Man's owner, Ralph Lowe, the jockey established and paid for a trophy to be awarded annually in Lowe's memory for high sportsmanship, thus making sure his mistake would be recalled publicly every year.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: PATTERSON, N. Y.On your way to the East Branch of the Croton River in Patterson; N. Y. you halt at a Texaco truck stop, and after a blazing hot cup of black coffee and a gray hamburger, you buy an eighttrack Glen Campbell tape and push on west along the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: Tropicana to Pay Dividend
description: The directors of Tropicana Products, Inc., have voted to declare the company's first dividend. Ten cents a share will be paid on June 10 to stockholders of record May 20.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I share the view stated in your April 29 editorial Promise of the Sun that solar energy is a promising energy source. It is virtually inexhaustible and is inherently clean. We at the A.E.C. agree completely that this energy source must be developed to help meet the nation's energy needs. We would also agree that the several applications of sotar energy are likely to begin to contribute to our energy supply at different times.

title: BONN SEEN COOLER ON EAST BLOC TIES Brandt's Heir is Expected to Place Greater Emphasis on Western Relations
description: BONN, May 9A close associate of Helmut Schmidt, who is expected to be elected Chancellor of West Germany next week, said today that the new leader would place far less emphasis on developing relations with Communist countries than Willy Brandt did.

title: 4 Drivers Cleared In Saperfeda Trial
description: Charges against four harness drivers accused of fixing superMeta races at New York tracks were dismissed by Judge Gain G. Judd yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: Notes on People
description: A Brooklynborn widow whose son a Lithuanian seaman, tried to defect to the United States in 1970 by leaping from a Soviet trawler to the deck of a Coast Guard cutter, is herself being blocked in her efforts to leave the Soviet Union, it, was reported in Moscow. Sergei Kovalev, a dissident physicist said, that Mrs. Marija Sulsklene had had her applications to leave rejected twice and that officials had frustrated her efforts to travel from Lithuania to Moscow to go to the United States. Embassy.

title: Shubert Fund Directors Refuse Lefkowitz Request to Step Aside
description: The directors of the Shubert Foundation have refused a request by the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, to yield control during litigation over the alleged misuse of milllions of dollars of foundation funds.

title: 2 Men Hide in a Bank And Rob It in Morning
description: Two robbers who apparently spent the night in a Queens bank escaped before opening time yesterday with more than $73,000 after holding nine arriving employes at gunpoint and forcing, an assistant manager to open a vault.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Widen State Use of Shale Revenue
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill that would permit Colorado, Utah and Wyoming to use oilshale revenues for a wide range of public services.

title: State High Court Finds Insurer Liable For Bills of a Child Sick Since Infancy
description: TRENTON, May 9The State Supreme Court, reversing a lowercourt ruling, held today that an insurance company must pay the insured medical costs for a 5yearold child who has suffered from cystic fibrosis since infancy.

title: 150 Years of London's National Gallery
description: LONDONUnderstatement, is alive and well here, where the 150th anniversary of the opening of the National Gallery on May 10, 1824, has been marked by an official publication headlined Failure & Success that lingers for the first half of its length on 20 masterpieces that might have come to the National Gallery but for one reason or another got away.

description: Beaths

title: Senate Watergate in Inquiry into $100,000 Hughes Donation
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The Senate Watergate committee voted in closed session today to recall Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's chief of staff, in its investigation of a $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard R. Hughes.

title: RedFaced in Albany Overestimating Its Own Power Forced G.O.P. to Call Off Vote on Con Edison
description: ALBANY, May 9The jaded people who watch; or take part in the life of the Capitol were treated to a rare public event last night: the sight of the Republican majority party suddenly realizing that it had overestimated its power. The wielding of power is the ultimate art among the professional politicians gathered in the legislative session here, and the Senate majority leader, Warren M., Anderson, had to suffer the embarrassment of reversing his course and putting aside the Consolidated Edison issue as the Democrats watched gleefully.

title: Jersey Bill on Repliers To Editorials Blocked
description: TRENTON, May 9 (UPI)The State Senate blocked legislation today that would have forced newspapers tb print public replies to editorials.

title: Jersey Senate Backs Safe Rodino District
description: TRENTON, May 9A Democratic Congressional redistricting bill that carves out a safe new district for Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. and assures the defeat of at, least one incumbent New Jersey Republican passed the state Senate here this afternoon by a vote of 21 to 17.

title: Times Reporter Receives Award Of Columbia Journalism Alumni
description: Peter Kihss, a reported for The New York Times, received an award last night from the Columbia Journalism Alumni Association because, the association said, for 40 years he has personified the best traditions of the Graduate School of Journalism and of, the profession itself.

title: Lampoon Says Gatsby Is Muzak to Its Era
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 (AP)The Great Gatsby took top honors in the Harvard Lampcon's 34th annual Movie Worsts Awards and was cited for making the, Jazz Age look like the Muzak Era.

title: Protectionism in Europe
description: PARIS, May 9The recent protectionist action taken by Italy to shore up her shaky finances has distressed many Europeans, created another crisis within the European Economic Community and generated new fears about a world economic, slowdown. The Common Market, a customs union in which goods are supposed to move freely, found the Italian move particularly distressing as dealing a blow at the community's basic principle of free trade

title: Joseph J. Biunno Dies, A Lawyer in Newark, 60
description: NEWARK, May 9 (AP)Joseph J. Biunno, a senior partner in the Newark law firm of Lum, Biunno & Tompkins; died today at Mountainside Hospital. He was 60 years old.

description: Prof. Daniel C. Boughner, an authority on Ben Jonson and his contemporaries in English letters, died Wednesday at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 65 years old and, lived in Brooklyn.

title: HUMPHREY GIVES WORLD FOOD PLAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed a world food action program today to lead the world back from the precipice of famine.

description: Nicely, demonstrating that necessity can be the mother of inventive programing, Boston's WGBH has gathered together a 13part science series for public television. Nova, presented on Sundays at 7:30 P.M: on the Public Broadcasting Service, is a budgetconscious pastiche, a, bit uneven around the edges but oftenand especially in recent weekssolid and impressive.

title: LACHMAN LEAVING BOARD TO TEACH
description: Dr. Seyniour P. Lachman, the president of the Board of Education, said yesterday, that he would leave the board on June 30, when his current term ex pires, to become a City University professor.

description: BOSTON, May 9The start of tonight's game between the Yankees and Boston was delayed several minutes because a pheasant was flitting around the field and neither the players, the umpires or the ground crew could catch her.

title: Governor Picks EGovernor
description: SALEM, Ore., May 9 (UPI)Gov. Tom McCall has appointed former Gov. David Cargo of New Mexico to the Oregon Motion Picture Promotion Committee. Mr. Cargo recently moved to Lake Oswego and set up a law practice in Portland. During his two terms as Governor,. he created a motion, picture commission to attract movie and television productions to New Mexico.

title: McLuhan McLuhan McLuhan
description: TORONTOThe Nixon tapes end the transcripts afford a maximal confrontation between oral and written media. The oral favors secrecy and confidentiality, just as print fosters diversity of interpretation. Is it perhaps significant that we use the word bugging for auditory surveillance in order to express distaste? The activity of the psychoanalyst is also oral exploration of our unconscious; do we call this invader of our privacy a shrink for the same reason? Is there some deep conflict between the visual and the auditory in our essentially literate and visual world?

title: Wilson Urgedto Tellof Finances In LieutenantGovernor Years
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes called on Governor Wilson yesterday to make a complete disclosure of his finances and the activities of his former law firm during the 15 years that he was Lieutenant Governor.

title: PRICES MAIN ISSUE IN CANADIAN RACE
description: OTTAWA, May 9 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the leaders of the two principal opposition parties focused on inflation today as the main issue of their campaigns for the national parliamentary elections on July 8.

title: 6th Rikers Fugitive Seized, 3 Others Are Still at Large
description: One of nine inmates who escaped from the Bikers Island prison complex last Monday night was recaptured yesterday in a South Bronx tenement at 547 Cauldwell Avenue, near East 149th Street. Five others were quickly recaptured, and three are still at large, the police said.

title: 400 Elderly at City Hall Protest Dismissal of Musical Director
description: About 400 elderly people lemonstrated yesterday at City FAR to protest the dismissal rf a social worker who had been their musical director. Richard Hill, 31 years old, last week became a victim of the city's budget problems. He was notified that provisional employes were being dismissed. Two weeks earlier, according to. City Councilman Morton Povman, Queens Democrat, the Social Services Department had considered offering him the position of director of musical programs for all of the city's enters for the elderly.

title: No Exit for Mr. Trudeau
description: Prime Minister Trudeau appears to owe the fall of his Liberal party Government to what he calls the scourge of inflation. Prices in Canada have gone up 10.4 per cent in a year, the same intolerable rate as the climb in the United States.

title: Music: Helps and Thorne
description: A program of American music in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night juxtaposed two American composers born in the nineteentwenties with Charles Ives, born hundred years ago. Robert Helps and Francis Thorne were the contemporaries, though, as is almost always the case, they were not more modern than Ives.

title: Fonda Back in Hospital
description: Henry Fonda reentered Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday for an adjustment on his pacemaker implanted last Friday. The hospital said last night that it would take about a day or two before the 68yearold actor could be released. His scheduled performances in Clarence Darrow in Detroit and Denver have been canceled, but the producers of the show said they hoped he would resume his role in Los Angeles on Mal 27.

title: A State Ban on Horsemeat Sale Is Scratched in Assembly Vote
description: ALBANY, May 9With some legislators voting neigh and others disturbed by the debate as they ate sandwiches, the Assembly tonight defeated a bill that would have banned the sale of horsemeat for human consumption. The measure was offered by Joseph. M. Margiotta, Republican of Uniondale, L.I., who conceded that his main argument was not based on health reasons but on the fondness of the suburban equestrian set for their pleasure horses and their concern at the rising cost of horsemeat on the hoof. They get very emotionally upset, he said, at the thought that their pets might be devoured. The subject produced a long debate with most legislators trying fo top one another with humorous obserlations But one Brooklyn Democrat, Mi chael Pesce, noted that various cultures, including. Italians from Bari, Italy, savored horsemeat.

title: A Home for Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a measure that would give the Vice President an official residence in Washington for the first time. The house is on the grounds of the United States Naval Obsetvatory on Massachusetts Avenue, in northwest Washington. It has been used for 40 years as the home of the Chief of Naval Operations. The house is occupied by Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, who will retire as Chief of Naval Operations July 1.

title: Strong Brazilian Drama of Misery
description: Out of materials as timeless as mysticism, faith and the profound burdens of the human condition, the Brazilian director Ruy Guerra constructed a film as unsparing as its initial imagethe sun that parches the earth where his characters play out their wretched lives.The film, "Os Fuzis" ("The Guns") was made 11 years ago and is being shown today and tomorrow at noon and midnight at the First Avenue-Screening Room.Set in drought-stricken northeastern Brazil, where misery and religion, intensified by the remorselessness of nature, border starvation and fantasy, the film employs a relatively small canvas to make broad statements. Embraced within the canvas are a single town, a handful of soldiers sent to guard from the passive, hungry populace a food shipment owned by one man; a nubile girl, a lone truck driver and a swelling legion of impoverished migrants in the train of a mystic with a sacred ox embodying the promise of the miracle of rain.Building slowly and at times in a manner difficult to comprehend until the cohesion of Mr. Guerra's design establishes itself, the director moves through his introductions and the surface of thingsglare, enervating heat, shaded and squinting eyes, dust and sweatinto his characters as individuals and then beyond them to comment on and question the nature of mankind.His vision of life is sharp, saddened, suffused with awareness of futility and failureof men, governments and faiths. It is no accident that the voice of the mystic resounds through this film with hoarse agony.

title: Yankee Records
The Hearings Begin
description: I don't need to stress again the importance of our undertaking and the wisdom, decency and principle which we must bring to it. We understand our high constitutional responsibility. We will faithfully live up to it. Peter W. Rodino Jr., Chairman, House Judiciary Committee

description: DALLAS, May 9Jan Kodes got the last laugh on Ilie Nastase and Bjorn Borg stunned Arthur Ashe in surprising quarterfinalround results of the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis tonight.

title: Cancer Regressions Puzzling Experts
description: BALTIMORE, May Rare, but documented, spontaneous regressions of cancer seem to be whispers of nature, hinting at something important about the cancer process, a scientist said here today, but he and many others agreed that the whispers remain cryptic.

description: TRENTON, May 9 (UPI)The State Senate blocked legislation today that would have forced newspapers to print public replies to editorials.

title: Nets Seeking To Wrap Up Title Series
description: The good news is that the New York Nets will have a chance to wrap up the American Basketball Association championship in front of their home fans tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, when they face the Utah Stars with a 31 lead in the fourofseven game final series. The game, which will start, at 8:05 P.M., will be broadcast by WHN radio.

title: About New York
description: Last Monday morning, Murray Polner, the editor of the quarterly Present Tense, got on the IRT subway at the Main Street station in Flushing, and saw a woman lying on the floor of the car. She was motionless, her head against the bottom of a seat, and another woman was ministering to her.

title: Portuguese Unions to Form Federation
description: LISBON, May 9The military junta has agreed to let Portugal's unions form a labor confederation as part of what is described as a transformation of the country from a Fasciststyle corporate state into a democracy.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, May 9The building is a relic of the Newark riots of 1967, a former furniture factoryshowroom whose back half was gutted by fire seven years ago and, many surrounding structures, never repaired.

title: Canada's Trudeaumania Is Dissolved by Inflation
description: MONTREAL, May 9 years ago, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, a brash, colorful intellectual who had caught the fancy of Canada and even some of the world beyond, won a landslide victory on a wave of Kennedystyle adulation known as Trudeaumania. Today, unable to piece together a House of Commons majority for his Government's annual budget proposals, the Prime Minister reluctantly made the ritual request for the dissolution of Parliament and the call for what he somewhat testily referred to as an election that I am sure the people do net want. The dramatic change in his these resulted not from any repudiation by the Canadian people, but rather from a parliamentary imbalance that had become increasingly unworkable. The immediate that led to the Government's defeat in the House was the economy. The cost of living in March was 10.4 per cent higher than its level of a year earlier and the opposition parties maintained that Mr. Trudeau was not doing enough about it. But ever since the 1972 election, in which he lost ground, calls for a vote ch. no confidence had been a regular feature of the Parliament in Ottawa, with hooting and jeering and bitter heckling interrupting many of the debates. Earlier this spring, the Prime Minister conceded to an interviewer that although I want to stick around, that may not be a matter of choice.

title: Expo 74: From Pleas to Save Nature To Sales Pitches for Vehiculer Fun
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 9Jim and Maggie Lent, honeymooning here from Stevensville, Mont., liked the Soviet exhibit and the gondola ride over the waterfalls best. I think the United States Pavilion has the best of message, said Vern Hedman, a retired railroad worker from Whitefish, Mont. It makes people think of course, I don't know for how long. Joe Pasqua], a Castro Valley, Calif, tax consultant, said he did not go through the Mormon exhibit because I saw people coming out of there talking to themselves and I don't need that.

title: Y. U. to Drop Varsity Baseball
description: New York University announced yesterday it would drop varsity baseball at the end of this season. At the same time the school's president, Dr. James M. Hester, said junior varsity basketball would be brought back next year for the first time since the spring of 1971, when intercollegiate basketball was dropped because of financial troubles at the school.

title: BONN SEEN COOLER ON EAST BLOC TIES
description: BONN, May 9A close associate of Helmut Schmidt, who is expected to be elected Chancellor of West Germany next week, said today that the new leader would place, far less emphasis on developing rebatons with Communist countries than Willy Brandt did.

title: Dornres Won't Hitch His Future to Stars
description: Marty Domres, the Baltimore Colts quarterback and a renowned athlete for Columbia, 1966 through 1968, spurned an offer yesterday from the New York Stars of the World Football League. Domres, 27 years old, signed a new contract with the Colts for a substantial raise and said that in today's hectic pro football market, A player who doesn't maximize his earnings is a bad businessman who doesn't belong in this profession.

title: Connally Linked to Phone Calls For a Friend Under U.S. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 9John B. Connally, while Secretary of the Treasury, telephoned the Justice Department repeatedly to express his fear that Jake Jacobsen, his longtime friend, was being unfairly treated in the department's investigation of a Texas saving and loan scandal, according to authoritative sources.

title: Britain's Steel Output Up
description: LONDON, May 9, (UPI)Britain's steel output in April averaged 547,300 ingot tons a week, 8.9 per cent higher than in March when steelmaking throughout the country was affected by the miners strike the stateowned British Steel Corporation announced today. However, production still fell 10.7 per cent short of the April, 1973 figure.

title: GEN. EARL BRANNON JR.
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9 (AP)  Brig. Gen. Earl W. Brannon Jr., U.S.A.F., retired a physician who served on the medical support team for the first United States manned space flight, died last Friday. He was 53 years old.

title: BUTENKO ENDS FIGHT FOR SPYING RETRIAL
description: NEWARK, May 9John W. Butenko, convicted 10 years Butenko, convicted 10 years Union, gave up his fight for a new trial in Federal Court here today and was given a 12year suspended jail term.

title: ALBANY VOTES BILI ON ACCESS TO DATA
description: ALBANY, May 10The Sen ate today gave final legislative approval to a freedom of infor mation bill that mandates for the first time that official rec ords of all state and local governments be open to scrutiny by the press and the public.

title: Stakes Historic for North Sea Oil Rig
description: ABOARD SEA QUEST DRILLING PLATFORM, North Sea, May 3Every so often this huge floating oil rig anchored in 420 feet of frigid water pitches slightly, but the 70 men who live and work on board pay no attention. The sea is calm today and the men are accustomed to much worse.

title: RIFTS REPORTED IN BONN COALITION
description: BONN, May 10New political uncertainties have begun to appear in the aftermath of Willy Brandt's surprise resignation as chancellor Monday night.

description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 10 (UPI) Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former Governor of New York, said today that the American people will not condone the attitude of President Nixon as disclosed in the transcripts of White House conversations.

title: BIG BOARD TO HALT CHADBOURN TRADING

This applies to the common stock; 46 cumulative convertible preferred stock and the 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due March 15, 1989.

title: Vinyl Chloride Parley Told, of Danger to Workers
description: Workers exposed to vinyl chloride, a widely used chemiCal in the plastics industry, face an increased risk of developing blood, liver and respiratory, abnormalities as well as dying from a variety of cancers, the first international meeting on the chemical was told yesterday.

description: No one is better than Claes Oldenburg at the allAmerican subject, the Standing Mitt With Ball, for instance, which appears in several sizes and guises in his new show at Leo Castelli's (4 East 77th Street). But it is important that Mr. Oldenburg was born in Stockholm of Swedish parents, lived in Oslo for three years when he was in short pants and has inherited from his father a diplomat's awareness and apartnessa professional's ability, in other words to size up an unfamiliar situation in no time at all.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has reported a record of boxoffice receipts for the company as a result of its threeweek season at the. Mark Hellinger Theater from April 15 through May 4. Total receipts were $106,042.83. Anticipated receipts had been $100,000.

Toward the close of the session, court reform has moved to the legislative bargain basementwith no genuine sales.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (Refuters)  Spurred largely by strong gain in automotive sales, retail sales rose 1.4 per cent; or $617million to a seasonally adjusted $44.41billion in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

Whatever such bartering repreented in economic exploitalion of North American Indians by European traders, the explosion of creativity that resulted within tribes from copst to coast was yet another expression of the highAly developed esthetic sensilility of these peoples.

description: NEWARK, May 10A former pilot for Robert Vesco flew the financier's multimilliondollar Boeing 707 here today from Panama, and said he had taken the plane without Mr. Vesco's knowledge and consent at the direction of a judge of the New Jersey Superior Court.

description: Allegro Brillante, which the New York City Ballet gave for the first time this season on Thursday night at the State Theater, is not one of George Balanchine's major works. Yet it is not a minor ballet either. Perhaps it is actually major Balanchine in miniature.

description: Said yesterday that the Watergate affair had put, America in a grave situation and urged prayers that both the House Judiciary Committee and President Nixon would take the right steps.

description: Dick Ruthven and Mac Scarce combined on a fourhit pitching effort last night in Veterans Stadium as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 32.

title: EXTORTION ALLEGED AT RONCALLO TRIAL
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 10A second businessman testified in Federal District Court today in the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo that an Oyster Bay official had told him he would lose town business if he did not make additional political contributions.

title: TRADING IS QUIET IN COMMODITIES
description: In quiet, preweekend trading yesterday most commodity futures contracts closed without significant changes. Silver futures showed strength that some traders attributed to uneasy buying because of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings. At times of uncertainty some speculators like to bold silver and other metals. Platinum also rose in quiet trading.

title: Art: Nevelson Still Shines
description: Almost two decades have passed since the American sculptor Louise Nevelson exhibited the first of her blackpainted wood constructions in a series of unforgettable exhibitions at the old Grand Central Moderns Gallery in New York. These exhibitions were like nothing else one had encountered at that time crowded, mysterious environments in which the visitor was held spellbound by shadowlike structures rising from the floor, hanging from the ceiling and covering the  walls in a profusion of poetic invention. One felt transported to another worlda world in which the language of constructivism had been absorbed into the imperatives of a dreamand it was only later, when the first shock of these encounters had diminished a little, that one could discern the many separate sculptural conceptions that contributed to the dramatic effect.

title: Old Mets Top New Cubs, 72
description: CHICAGO, May 10They've got so many new guys, Yogi Berra reflected today, nodding toward the Chicago Cubs, the most heavily traded team in baseball, that we don't know how to pitch to them. In fact, I don't even know their first names.

title: TV: Place in the Country
description: Leave it to the British, for another of those original, stimulating television series, this time a 13week, 30minute, tour of historic homes and estates that couldn't be more engrossing and charmingly picturesque. Each Saturday at 9, WPIX, Channel 11, is airing A Place in the Country, directed and produced for Thames Television by Robert Fleming and sponsoredhence the local showingsby British Caledonian Airways. Tonight's chapter, the second, is Waddesdon, the Rothschild digs in Buckinghamshire.

Rebozo, President Nixon's close associate and confidant, has reportedly told the Senate Watergate committee that he accepted a $50,000 contribution from a Florida grocery executive that he believed was intended for the President's reelection campaign of 1972.

description: NEWARK, May 10  Fiftyeight candidates are vying for nine City Council seats in the, municipal elections on Tuesday. Four of the seats are at large, and there is one representing, each of the city's five wards.

description: GREAT NECK, L. I.  The 16 women range in age from 36 to 63. They have college degrees, an impressive list of professional, civic and volunteer credits, husbands and a total of 37 children.

title: Judge Who Will Give the Ruling Thinks Calley Will W in Appeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 10The Federal judge who has agreed to hear the challenge of former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of his conviction for the murder of civilians at My Lai said today that he believed Mr. Calley would win.

title: Improving the Prisons
description: Two recent public decisions underline the timidity and shortsightedness which hamper the development of enlightened corrections policies in the United States. Albany, the Legislature seems determined to kill a plan to establish a twoyear degreegranting college for approximately 200 inmates of the state prison system, Washington, the Federal Buregu of Prisons has adopted a halfhearted measure for adjudicating certain types inmate grieyances within the Federal prison system.

title: Contract Aivards
description: The Chrysler Corporation received a $49.1 million Army contract for M60 combat tanks, it was announced yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Top dairy cooperative leaders tried to raise $300,000 for President Nixon's campaign within hours of a White House meeting on milk price supports in March, 1971, according to secret Senate testimony.

title: DANISH HEAD WINS CONFIDENCE VOTE
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 10 (AP)  The minority! Liberal party Government of Premier Poul Hartling emerged at dawn today from a marathon 20hour session of Parliament with an unexpected vote of confidence that assured it of at least four more days in office.

title: Peak Level Pushes Rates Down in Credit Arena
description: The First National City Bank, New York City's largest, raised its base rate on corporate loans to a record 11 per cent yesterday in the wake of a general rise in, moneymarket interest rates. Other major banks quickly swung into line.

title: U.S. AGENCY FIGHTS BAR'S FEE SCHEDULE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 10The United States Justice Department contended in an antitrust suit against the Oregon, I State Bar yesterday that the bar's legal fee schedule denies the public the right to com petitive pricing.

title: People and Business
description: Norman Jaspan, who heads the management consulting concern of Norman Jaspan Associates, Inc., believes that kickbacks, bribes and conflicts of interest have become a dominant factor in business. And he has gathered some statistics to back up this view.

title: The Press as Cloak and Suitor
description: Nowhere is the admiration of Henry Kissinger more apparent than in the blurblike superlatives of his press clippings. The Merlin of American diplomacy the name that made foreign policy famous, says Newsweek. One of 56 Secretaries of State, Time thinks he has a chance of being remembered as the greatest in U.S. history. To Murrey Marder, the experienced diplomatic correspondent of The Washington Post, he may well be the biggest, peimanent, loating foreign policy establishment in our history.  It has been written in The New York Times that weare indeed living in the age of Pax Kissingerus. Such coverageplus his stunning diplomatic successhas helped to make him America's most admired man, as measured by the Gallup Poll.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suffolk County officials disclosed yesterday that a proposed $600million sewer project may have to be redesigned, or even referred back to voters, because the lowest bids on part of it were considerably higher than What the county could afford.

title: BENJAMIN TABANKIN
description: Benjamin. Tabankin, who retired in 1969 as owner of the. Home Utilities Fuel Oil Company of Irvington, N. J, which he founded, died yesterday in a nursing home in West Orange N. J. He was 80 years old and lived at 53 Stockman Place, Irvington.

description: The National News Council dismissed yesterday charges brought by the Mobil Oil Company against the ABCTV news documentary OilThe Policy Crisis without a hearing and with the statement that the March 20 broadcast was well within the bounds of robust opinion journalism.

description: PARIS, May 10France's pre: idential contenders, Frangoi Mitterrand and Valery Giscar !d'Estaing, debated pretty muci to a standoff tonight in th first live television encounte Of a distinctly Americanstyl election campaign.

description: New York City's largest bank, the First National City Bank, yesterday raised the prime rate that it charges its most creditworthy customers to 11 per cent, a record. Other major banks quickly fell into line. Page 39.

Isn't fact, dangerous to grant Mother a celebratory day on Which she is heaped with all the gratitude flowers and candy, can express?

title: Town Supervisor Strikes Back At Purchase Secession Threat
description: HARRISON, N. Y., May 10Supervisor John Passidomo of the Town  of Harrison, faced with threats of secession, by residents of the section known as Purchase, has replied with threats of his own.

title: Business Group Predicts Climb In Jobless and More Price Rises
description: The consultants assessment was distinctly more bearish than that of Government forecasters, who usually are optimistic, and was even more restrained than some private forecasts. HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 America's captains of industry were told by their own experts today to expect a stagnant economy in 1974, a sharp rise in unemployment and continued price increases.

title: Remectia, Talking Picture Favored at Big A Today
description: Some 10 days ago many people were disturbed by a proposal to run the centennial nef the Hentqcky Derby in two sections. To their satisfaction, however, the Derby last Saturday had a safe 23 entrants, and Cannonade led all the others home, with no incident, in a nonsplit event.

title: Dance: Royal Ballet
description: Kenneth MacMillan's new Royal Ballet spectacular, Manon, was, given at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night With an almost complete turnabout of cast in its principal roles. The Manon was Jennifer Penney; her lover, Des Grieux, was Wayne Eagling, and her brother, Lescaut, was Nicholas Johnson, making his New York debut. Lescaut's mistress was danced by Lesley Collier.

title: House Panel Expected to Consider a New Subpoen,
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The House Judiciary Committee will consider next week issuing new subpoena for tapes of some of President Nixon's Watergate conversations, according to wellplaced Congressional officials.

title: Market Place. Investor Profile At Con Edison
description: The typical owner of Consolidated Edison common stock is a woman in her middle or late years who lives in New York City or Westchester. She has about 100 shares of the Big Board's mostbattered stock, which in the three weeks since the company omitted the secondquarter dividend has dropped nearly 60 per cent in value.

title: FRED WEISSMAN
description: Fred Weissman, publisher of the International Insurance Monitor, at 150 West 28th Street, for the last 28 years, died Thursday, at Mount Eden General Hospital in the Bronx. His age was 72, and he lived at 170 West Kingsbridge Road.

Rockefeller, Secretary of State Kissinger and Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, was acquitted yesterday on all five counts of a Federal indictment charging him with evading income taxes.

title: Malcolm Rebuts Charge Of Poor Tombs Security
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm conceded yesterday that the Manhattan Hous'e of Detention for Men had serious sanitation and noise problems, but he disputed state charges of inadequate security at the prison, known as the Tombs, and called other criticisms unjustified or out of date.

title: WINE TALK Burgundy's Origins: A Baffling Matter
description: If you think the wines of Bordeaux are a confusing subject, consider for a moment the wines of Burgundy. The famous vineyard, Clos de Vougeot, for instance, has about 125 acres of vinesand 60 owners. Le Montrachet, considered the greatest of all French wines, comes from a Burgundian vineyard of 19 acres with eight major and several minor owners. The Marquis de Laguiche, who owns nearly a quarter of the vineyard, produces eight barrels of the wine in a good year.

title: CAPITAL IS ASTIR
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The White House sought tonight to stem a torrent of rumors by declaring that President Nixon was up to the battle and had no intention of resigning.

title: Notes on People It's Her Day and Now Her Year
description: Just in time for Mother's Day, which is tomorrow, the Mother of the Year was named yesterday. She is Mrs. Russell Stewart Marriott, of Kensington, Md., and she was chosen from 52 nominees representing the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Mrs. Marriott, the District of Columbia nominee, has three grown sons and seven grandchildren.

title: WIVES EMOTIONS LINKED TO CANCER
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 Women who suffer from cancer of the reproductive tract tend to rate high in emotional selfcontrol, idealism and sense of responsibility,. a psychiatrist said today.

title: Francis Leads Advance in Match Play
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. L, May 10  Heavy rains this morning caused a 90minute interruption in the first round of the 26th annual William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament, but did not disturb the beautiWily manicured Seawane Club course or the play of little Gene Francis.

description: ClosedEnd Funds

title: U.S. Nain'es Envoy To Qatar, the 4th To Area Recently
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 President Nixon today nominated a United States Ambassador to Qatar. It was the fourth appointment ofan envoy to a Persian Gulf oilproducing state in the last two weeks.

title: ABC Joins News Competition With Plans for A.M. America
description: ABCTV has disclosed plans to enter the early morning network competition next January with a twohour daily program of news, entertainment and information to run opposite NBCTV's Today and the CBS Morning News. The program, A.M. America, will be scheduled from 7 to 9 A.M. and will have its premiere Jan. 6, 1975.

description: Tickets matching the number win 32,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win 5225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225: Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25 Tickets with all five cumbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third anli fourth or the fourth and fifth win 52,50.

title: 51% in Harris Poll Feel That Nixon Broke Law
description: The Louis Harris Poll said yesterday that a majority of those asked in a recent survey said that they felt that President Nixon would be found to have broken the law, United Press International reported.

title: Books of The Times A Landscapet of Birds
description: Sometimes we need reminders that the whole country is not going down the drain economics and politics notwithstanding and that there is still left an abundance of beauty in our natural wonders, even such mundane natural wonders as a beach or swamp and even artificial natural wonders like wildlife sanctuaries and parks. These two bird books are salutary reminders of the beauty that is around us, even though neither is designed as such. One is a practical book for the novice or experienced bird watcher, The Habitat Guide to Birditig, by Thomas P. McElroy Jr. The other, Roger Barton's Confessions of a Bird Watcher, is a sort of diary of birds seen and places visited in the search for birds.

title: Jackson, Ilere, Says Oil Industry Needs To Be Accountable
description: Senator Henry M Jackson said yesterday that unless the oil industry was properly managed and directed it could destroy other businesses and place the country in a terrible, terrible foreignpolicy position.

title: Macon's 'MachineGun Mayor Wants to Run for Higher Office
description: MACON, Ga.  The first thing Mayor Ronnie Thompson wants to get cleared up is that story the press keeps repeating about him blazing away at a sniper with a submachine gun.

title: SugarProgram Extension Obtains Tentative Backing
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) The House Agriculture Committee rejected today a move to suspend sugar imoprts from Venezuela and then tentatively approved a fiveyear extension of the Government's sugar control program.

title: G.O.P. Leader Calls on Beame To Back Bill Giving Con Ed Aid
description: ALBANY, May 10Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, tonight urged Mayor Beanie to back strenuously a legislative solution to the financial problems of Consolidated Edison, implying that without this support the measure could die here next week.

title: 3 Notable Buildings Face Wrecker's Ball
description: Lower Manhattan is about to lose three of its few remaining architecturally notable preWorld War I office buildings.

title: U. S. ENERGY PLAN FOUND TOO COSTLY
description: If the United States tries to meet all its energy needs from domestic sources by 1980 the goal of the Nixon Administration's Project Independence  the price of all forms of energy could be driven as high as the equivalent of 312 a barrel of oil, according to group of economists and energy experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: S.E.C. SETS A DATE FOR A JOINT TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Securities and Exchange Commission today fixed May 17 as the effective date of the consolidated tape plan for reporting lastsale transactions on national stock exchanges and the overthecounter market.

title: Dr. Rubin Pfeiffer, 69, Of Dewitt Clinton, Dies
description: Dr. Rubin Pfeiffer, who retired last September as chairman of the language department of Dewitt Clintoni High School, died here Thursday. Ile was 69 years old and lived at 3824 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: EXOFFICER CITED BY NADJARI JURY
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, yesterday announced the indictments of a former narcotics division detective and a convicted heroin trafficker on charges of conspiring to harbor fugitives and obstruct justice.

title: 4 Freed Drivers Reinstated, But Tracks Keep Them Out
description: The four harness drivers against whom charges had been dropped in the Government's racefixing trial received temporary licenses yesterday to go back to their jobs as trainers and drivers.

title: SemiFree D.C.
description: The voters in the District of Columbia have overwhelmingly ratified a Congressionally approved homerule charter that gives Washington a form of government providing more self determination than its citizens have enjoyed in a century. The new arrangement stops far short, however, of giving the nation's last colony full independence.

title: Bail Denied Copter Pilot
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 (UPI)A Federal judge refused today to order bail for a young Army private accused of commandeerling a helicopter Feb. 17 at Fort !Meade, Md., then crashlanding the craft on the White House lawn. Pfc. Robert K. Preston had sought bail.

title: REBOZO IS LINKED TO A $50,000 GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close associate and confidant, has reportedly told the Senate Watergate committee that he accepted a $50,000 contribution from a Florida grocery executive that he believed was intended for the President's reelection campaign of 1972.

title: 2 Schoolboys Get Wrestling Awards
description: WESTBURY, L. I. May 10James Earl and John Orr have been selected as recipients of the George M. Levy and the Roosevelt Raceway wrestling scholarship awards. Earl, a senior at Valley Stream Central High School, was selected as winner of the Levy award, and Orr, a senior at Massapequa High School, will receive the Roosevelt Raceway award. Each scholarship is worth $500.

title: Military Intelligence Head In Argentina Forced Out
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 10 (AP)The head of Argentina's military intelligence, one of President Juan Domingo Per6n's strongest political foes, has been forced to quit by the Government.

title: Mariner Starts on Path To America's Cup Trials
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., May 10Mariner, the second of two new yachts built for defense of the America's Cup this summer, was commissioned today at, the United States Merchant Marine Academy, and she will be out sailing tomorrow on Long. Island Sound. So, perhaps, wilt her rival, Courageous, if they can put her back together again at Cityisland.

description: spedal to The New To Voles

title: Howe, 46, Is Named A.W.H.A. AllStar
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 10 (AP)Gordie Howe was named today to the 1974 World Hockey Association Allstar team, beating out the scoring champion, Mike Walton, for the right wing spot.

title: Nuclear Unit Shut Down
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 10 (UPI)  A malfunction at the Tennessee Valley Authority's Brown's Ferry nuclear plant has forced the shutdown of one unit, the Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday. No radioactivity was released and no personnel at the plant near Athens, Ala., were exposed to radiation, the A.E.C. said.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 1,100 Union Carbide employes in Piscataway have walked off their jobs in a contract dispute. The workers, members of Local 8891 of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union, set up a picket line at the plant after a marathon negotiating session had failed to produce a settlement.

title: Remedia, Talking Picture Favored at Big A Today
description: Some 10 days ago many people were disturbed by a proposal to run the centennial of the Kentucky Derby in two sections. To their satisfaction, however, the Derby last Saturday had a safe 23 entrants, and Cannonade led all the others home, with no incident, in a nonsplit event.

title: World Production of Oil Reached Record in 73
description: LONDON, May 10 (Reuters) The world oil output and consumption reached record levels last year despite the embargoes and production cutbacks imposed in the last quarter, according to the British Petroleum Statistical Review.

title: Business Briefs
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced yesterday that effective immediately it was raising prices on its cigarette and little cigar brands by 70 cents per thousand. Reynolds produces Winston, Salem, Camel, Doral and Vantage cigarettes and Winchester little cigars. The increase to the wholesaler, which follows simiar rises by Lorillard and Morris, comes to 14 cents a carton.

title: For Mother's Day, Notables Give Some Verbal Bouquets
description: Paul O'Dwyer, President of the City Council, said she did a lot to help me get rid of an inferiority complex.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10The White House sought tonight to stem a torrent of rumors by declaring that President Nixon was up to the battle and had no intention of resigning.

description: The Americans spacecraft Mariner 10 has been aimed successfully for a revisit to the planet Mercury Sept. 21, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., announced yesterday.

title: Naval Official to Retire
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 10 (UPI)  The director of the NavalUndersea Center, Dr. William B. McLean, inventor of the Sidewinder missile, announced yesterday that he would retire June 30, ending 30 years of service to the Navy.

title: VIETCONG SPURN TALKS IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10A breakdown occurred today in the last remaining forum for negotiations between the Vietcong and the South Vietnamese Government. The two sides were thus left without regular talks for the first time since the Paris agreement was signed 15 months ago.

title: 19 Are Vying for Job Of Running District 2
description: Stiff civility was the rule as members of Manhattan's Community School Board 2 and Mrs, Rhoda S. Lansky, the district superintendent, Sat edgily side by side recently behind the long table on the gymnasium dais. But their faces were often clouded or set with anger.

title: CONVICT ON COAST ADMITS KIDNAPPING
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 10 (AP)  Ruchell Magee, San Quentin convict, pleaded guilty today to a charge of aggravated kidnaping stemming from the Marin County courthouse raid in August, 1970, in which judge and three abductors were killed.

title: Judge Expects to Decide Soon In the Bloomfield Tenure Case
description: NEWARK, May 10Superior Court Judge Melvin Antell said today that he expected to render his decision before the end of May in the Bloomfield College facultytenure case.

title: Powerful Quake Reported In a Populous Area of China
description: BOULDER, Colo., May 10 (UPI)  A powerful earthquake rumbled through a densely pop ulated region of central China today, the National Earthquake Information Service reported.

title: Kissinger Believes SyrianIsraeli Decision Is Near
description: JERUSALEM, May 10Secretary of State Kissinger told Israeli officials tonight that he might know by next Tuesday whether he could bring about an agreement by Syria and Israel to separate their, troops on the Golan Heights during his current Middle East trip, now in its 13th day.

title: ARTHUR C. FIELDS, A BOOK PUBLISHER
description: Arthur C. Fields, an indespendent publisher who was widely respected for the pains he took in editing and marketing his books, died of a heart attack Thursday at Glen Cove (L. I.) Community Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L. I.

title: MAIIEll SAYS UNIT AIDED NIXON IN 56
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10In 1956, Howard R. Hughes paid, most of the cost of a secret agent operation, staffed by former Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, that thwarted an attempt by Harold E. Stassen to have Richard M. Nixon removed from the Republican Presidential ticket, a witness testified in Federal Court here today.

title: EDWARD NEINKEN
description: Edward Neinken, who retired five years ago as treasurer of the Champion Pants Company, which was taken over by the KayserRoth Corporation at 640 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn, His age was 74, and he lived at 20 Fifth Avenue.
