title: MOSCOW HOPEFUL OF VISIT BY NIXON
description: MOSCOW, May 10Despite the uproar in the United States caused by publication of the edited Watergate transcripts, the Kremlin has just enthusiastically told the Administration that Moscow is still looking forward to President Nixon's visit in the second half of June.

title: Sabre Wins Preliminary Jump Class
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 10Sabre, an unknown 5yearold brown gelding from Allentown, Pa., proved a talented mudder today when he won the first two preliminary jumper classes in the opening session of the threeday Children's Services horse show.

title: Rangel Asks Opium Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) Alleged shortages of opiumderivative drugs in this country prompted Representative Charles. B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, to call today for an investigation by the General Accounting Office. There is a great deal of similarity between our recent problem in obtaining needed information on the alleged oil shortage from the oil industry and this situation he said.

title: SpanishAmericans Far Behind In Report on Income and Status
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The e'conomic and social status of persons of Spanish origin is far behind that of persons designated as whites, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

title: S.D.R. PACT REACHED FOR MONEY REFORM
description: PARIS, May. 10The major. Western powers have agreed, on some technical points for nonetary reform, including the ntroduction of a new type of Special Drawing Right that could be useful in recycling money from oilproducing and exporting nations back into Western economies, it was disclosed here today.

title: LI.R.R. Trains Stalled By Short Circuit Here
description: A short circuit caused by a piece of pipe faljing from a train engine inside Penn Station yesterday evening stalled three citybound Long Island Rail Road trains outside the station and delayed outbound trains by up to an hour.

title: Addiction Unit Drops Political Question
description: The city's Addiction Services Agency said yesterday that it would end its practice of asking officials of drugtreatment programs whether they had political influence or connections they could use on the Board of Estimate when their contracts were up for approval.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Vesco's 707 Jet. Spirited To Jersey at Court Order
description: NEWARK, May 10A former pilot for Robert Vesco flew the financier's multimilliondollar Boeing 707 here today from Panama, and said he had taken the plane without Mr. Vesco's knowledge and consent at the direction of a judge of the New Jersey Superior Court.

title: Group to Protect Public In Insurance Bankruptcies
description: TRENTON, May 10 (UPI) The state has created an association of insurance companies to protect the public by paying off claims when a company goes bankrupt.

title: Prentice's 65 Leads Golf By 2 Strokes.
description: RALEIGH, N. C. May 10 (AP)Jo Ann Prentice posted the lowest competitive round of her life today, a sevenunderpar 65, to take the firstround lead in the $35000 American Defender golf tournament.

title: Doubts Grow in Congress That Nixon Can Stay On
description: WASHINGTON, May 10President Nixon's Republican support continued to deteriorate today in a capital rife with rumor of resignation and absorbed by doubts about the President's chances of riding out the Watergate crisis.

title: Syrians and Israelis on Golan Fight for 60th Successive Day
description: TEL AVIV, May 10For the 60th consecutive day, Syrian and Israeli forces battled today along what was once a ceasefire line.

title: Coast P.T.A. Opposes Busing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 (UPI)The California Parent Teachers Association has become the 12th state P.T.A. to urge a United States constitutional amendment against involuntary school busing.

title: Station Wagons Recalled
description: DETROIT May 10 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it would recall 1,020 currentmodel Ford and Mercury station wagon's to find 290 that may have been equipped with trailer hitches designed for use on cars.

title: PRESIDENT GIVES 10.3BILLION PLAN TO SPUR HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, May 10President Nixon announced today an emergency program that would provide up to $10.3billion of additional mortgage money to help stimulate the stagnant private housing market.

title: S.E.C. IS CRITICIZED ON ITS JOB PRACTICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  The communications arm of the United Church of Christ has accused the Securities and Exchange Commission of refusing to end discriminatory employment practices in the securities industry.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Press Gag in Zebra Murder Cast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10A judge's order that sought to limit the news that could be reported about three defendants in the socalled Zebra murder cases was overturned tonight by the state Court of Appeals after a special hearing.

title: Liddy Guilty of Contempt of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 10One of the original Watergate burglary defendants, G. Gordon Liddy, was found guilty today of two counts of contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions last, July 20 before a House subcommittee.

title: Outcome of Italian Divorce Vote Uncertain as Campaigning Ends
description: ROME, May 10Campaigning ended tonight for a referendum to be held Sunday and Monday on repeal of, threeyearold divorce statute.

title: Dave Anderson The Yankees BackDoor Policy.
description: In the new headquarters of the New York Yankees near Shea Stadium, the office of the president has a back door.

title: MICHAEL V. CREEDON
description: Michael V. Creedon who retired in 1962 as assistant to vice president of Western Union in New York, died Thursday at his home in Westport Point, Mass., at the age of 75.

title: COMSAT RATE CUT OF 20% PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission announced today agreement by its Common Carrier Bureau and the Communications Satellite Corporation to reduce by 20 per cent all Comsat rates except those for the new domestic satellites.

title: Ash Lowers BudgetDeficit Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Rdy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, disclosed today that the deficit in the budget fox the fiscal year ending June 3C would be slightly lower than last January's estimate but that the deficit in the new fiscal year would be a little larger. In a speech to the City Club of Cleveland, the text of which was released here, Mr. Ash said hopes for a significant reduction in spending in the new fiscal year were simply baying at the moon.

title: JOSEPH T. CANTRELL
description: Joseph T. Cantrell, a carriagebuilder who was an early maker of wooden station wagons for automobile bodies, died yesterday in a nursing home in Huntington, L. I. He was 98 years old and lived at 12 Dewey Street in Huntington.

title: Following Dog's Nose, Police Uncover Explosives in Subway Locker
description: Brandy, the Police Department bomb section's German shepherd that sniffs out explosives, helped yesterday to uncover a pipe bomb, two guns and other explosive material in Times Square subway lockers.

title: Lauda Fastest in Trial
description: NIVELLES, Belgium, May 10 (AP)Niki Lauda of Austria, driving a Ferrari, set the fastest time in today's opening trials for Sunday's Belgian Formula One Grand Prix. Lauda was timed in 1 minute 14.14 seconds for the 2.3mile track.

title: L.I. BANK IN DEAL FOR MIDWEST BIT
description: Formal agreements have been signed by the Colonial Commercial Corporation of Valley Stream, L.I., for a major interest in the Welfare Finance Corporation and its major subsidiary, the National Finance Merger Company of CinNews cinnati, Colonial said yesterday. This interest was gained when creditors of Welfare and National, which are operating under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, accepted a plan of arrangement for funding the bankrupt companies debt.

description: BOSTON, May 10If tonight's pulsating National Basketball Association championship round playoff game proved anything, it may have been that the Milwaukee Bucks are even more obstinate than the Boston Celtics.

description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 10 (AP)George Burns played fiveunder par golf to beat Skeeter Heath, 4 and 3, and move into the final of the annual North and SOuth amateur tournament against Danny Yates, a 3and2 winner over Marty West.

title: WNET IS DENIED EXTRA STATE AID
description: ALBANY, May 10  Legislative sources reported tonight that WNET (Channel 13), the New York City educational television station that has displeased a number of legislators with its political programs, has been denied a lastminute request for additional state aid.

title: Delaware Captures Conference Tennis
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., may 10 Delaware University, th'e defending champion, defeated Hofstra, 63, today to win the MidAtlantic Conference tennis championship at Lakeview Indoor Tennis, Club.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: BERNARDSVILLE, May 10  Chris Hallinan is young man who is going places in a hurry. The Bernards High School longdistance runner, though just 16 years old, is one of the top schoolboy runners in the country. Chris, a 5foot10incht 140pounder, ran a mile in 4 minutes seconds in an indoor dual meet at Lawrenceville in February that gave him, the fastest time in the nation by a high school sophomore. Additionally, he has clocked a 9:09.3 twomile, which ranks second in the United States for 16yearolds.

title: Coup's Echo in Spain
description: MADRID, May 9Day after day the newspapers and televiI sion broadcasts have given detailed, often enthusiastic accounts of Portuguese crowds chasing the secret police, of political prisoners released from jail News and of exiles reAnalysis turning to f r enzied welcomes. Not since the Allies defeated Hitler have the Spaniards been so seized with the drama of a foreign event, and with its conceivable application to themselves.

title: PRICES AGAIN FAIL ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices fell again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market following another increase in the bank prime lending rate to a record 11 per cent.

title: Colombian Jetliner Hijacke4 $300,000 Ransom Demanded
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 10 (AP)Hijackers flew a Colombian jetliner to the eastern city of Cali last night and demand ed $300,000 for the return of, the plane and the 85 people on board, sources at the airport in Bogota said.

title: Foyt Is Favored for Pole In Safer Indy Qualifying
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 10On a presumably safer track in presumably safer cars, about 25 drivers are expected to try for the pole position tomorrow for the Indianapolis 500. Except, of course, if it rains, which is also expected.

description: NEW DELHI, May 10Primei Minister Indira Gandhi met opposition leaders today and sought to resolve thel threedayold nationwide rail way strike.

description: Dr. Kenneth W. Riland, an osteopathic physician here whose patients have included President Nixon, former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, Secretary of State Kissinger and Chief Justice Warren E, Burger, was acquitted yesterday on all five counts of a Federal indictment charging him with evading income taxes.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10The House Ways and Means Committee, trying to simplify tax returns, wants to repeal three of the most popular deductionsfor gasoline taxes, medical insurance premiums and dividends on stocks.

description: The Marathon Oil Company said yesterday that it was reducing the price of gasoline by 4.3 cents a gallon, effective today. The company said that a market analysis indicated that Marathon dealers and customers were in an unfavorable competitive position.

description: California doctors and their spouses have more surgical operations than other professionals and their spouses in the same socioeconomic bracket, according to a Stanford University study published yesterday.

description: The Federal Power Commission was petitioned yesterday to stop Consolidated Edison from continuing construction of the proposed pumpedstorage hydroelectric plant on Storm King Mountain.

title: Stage: Italian Festival
description: A new Off Broadway undertaking called the Festival of New Italian Plays has opened at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 MacDougal Street (4779894), with interesting results. A company largely of ItalianAmerican actors and directors is presenting English versions of eight plays thrdugh July 30 to stress achievements in the Italian theater. Sponsoring the festival, which also includes Monday readings of prose and poetry, are the Italian Ministry of Tourism and Entertainment and the Italian Institute of Culture of New York.

title: Newcombe, Borg Gain, W.C.T. Final
description: DALLAS, May 10Professional tennis braced for another history  making event when Bjorn Borg, a 17yearold Swede, reached the final of the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10President Nixon announced today an emergency program that would provide up to $10.3billion of additional mortgage money to help stimulate the stagnant private housing market.

description: Jefferson said he was a farmer, Franklin said he was a printer and I think of myself as a teacher. This was the description given of himself by Lawrence Arthur Cremin, the Frederick A.P. Barnard Professor of Education at Columbia University, who was named the seventh president of Teachers College yesterday.

title: Treatment for Glass May Enhance Defrosting guallties
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 RCA scientists are working on a highly technical treatment of glass that may some day make possible completely transparent defrosters for automobile windown and windshields. Patent 3,811,855 will be granted May 21 to David E. Carlson, Kenneth W. Hang and George F. Stockdale of the technical staff at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N. J., for what is called a method of treating a glass body to provide an iondepleted region therein.

title: ArabFrench Group Weighs a Venture Banking in City
description: PARIS, May 10M. M. Abustatdi president of the Union slea Banques Arabes et Francaises, one of the giant Arab, French banking groups, said today he was talking with several Anierican banks to set up a commercial and investmentbanking venture in New York.

title: i Suit for $1Million Charges Doorman Beat Up a Boy, 8
description: A $1million suit was filed in State Supreme Court here yesterday on behalf of an 8yearold boy who, the suit charges, was beaten by the doorman at Jimmy's Restaurant, 33 West 52d Street, last April 8.

title: WEEDEN & CO. SHOWS WIDER MONTHLY LOSS
description: Weeden & Co., Inc., a brokerage house specializing in thirdmarket transactions, reported yesterday that it had a net loss in April of $556,000 against a $145,000 deficit in the yearearlier month.

title: Gunmen in Ulster Kill 2 Patrolmen After a Police Raid
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 10 (Reuters)  Two policemen were shot dead by three gunmen on the outskirts of Belfast tonight, police officials said.

title: Concert: Mehta's Flair
description: On paper the program of the Thursday night Philharmonic concert, conducted by Zubin Mehta, looked peculiar. Not one but three overtures by Carl Maria von Weber started things off. But considering that the Turandot Overture and the Abu Hassan Overture run only about three minutes each, and also considering that they turn up with the infrequency of, say, impeachment hearings, there was a valid excuse for playing them one after the other. As for the early Peter Schmoll overture, it is a more conventional nine minutes in length.

title: On Road in Mozambique The Danger Signs Grow
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, May 10The road between this port city and Lourengo Marques, the capital 800 miles to the south, provides some clues as to why the Portuguese junta has been rebuffed and is facing a spreading war after proposing a ceasefire to the rebellious Mozambique Liberation Front.

title: Theater Summit to Study Problems at June Congress
description: The First American Congress of Theater (FACT), a summit conference of the professional theater, will take place at Princeton University from June 2 to June 6.

description: WASHINGTON, May 10President Nixon's Republican support continued to deteriorate today in a capital rife with rumor of resignation and absorbed by doubts about the President's chances of riding out the Watergate crisis.

title: Inquiry Clears an ExCity Aide Of Interest Conflict on New Job
description: Paul Levine, a former Economic Development Administration official who negotiated a job with the S & S Corrugated Paper Machinery Company while residents in the Northside section of Brooklyn fought the plant's expansion, has been cleared of any criminal wrongdoing.

title: Recreational Vehicles Lag
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (Reuters) Shipments of recreational vehicles in March were only half what they were the year before, reflecting consumer worries about gasoline shortages, the Recreational Vehicle Institute said yesterday. The Institute said there were 45,500 recreational units shipped in March, down nearly 50 per cent from the 88,000 shipped the preceding March.

description: BRISBANE, Australia, May 10 (Reuters)Tony Mundine, the British Commonwealth middleweight boxing champion, beat Don Cobbs of the United States tonight,. when Des Crabbe, the referee, stopped the fight in the sixth round. Mundine smashed Cobbs with a right to the jaw at 2 minutes 23 seconds into the sixth round and sent him crashing to the canvas.

title: Gimbel Deficit. Is Widened

Sales in the quarter also declined to $162.7million from $167.3million.

title: Celtics and Bucks Battle for Title Today
description: MILWAUKEE, May 11Exactly seven months after they opened their National Basketball Association schedules the Milwaukee Bucks and the Boston Celtics will end their long seasons tomorrow afternoon in a game that will determine the league championship.

title: Kerr on 'Bad Habits and 'My Sister, My Sister'
description: TAKEN together, the two long oneact comedies that make up Terrence McNally's Bad Habits offer a sort of philosophy. In the first, Ravenswood, a doctor who is con fined to a wheelchair because his wife once pushed him down a flight of backstage steps at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia counsels other married couples (and one couple, Hiram and Francis, who are not precisely married) by urging them to indulge their deepest desires, whatever those desires may be., Smoking, for instance, may be bad but not as bad as not smoking. Trying to kill one's wife by attacking her with a remotecontrol lawnmower may be a reasonable act, given the fact that she once ran over him with a golf cart. And so on. Couples are ready to leave the sanitorinm when they fully realize that they can live together because nobody else would put up with us. Behaving naturally is the best way to get along.

That is why investigators now are as interested what is not in the transcripts as what is there.

title: Future Social Events
description: A DemiPointi Dybbuk May 15There'll be a dybbuk with a difference in =home Robbins's new ballet of the same name that will have a benefit preview as part of the celebration of the New York City Ballet's 25th anniversary spring gala at the New York State Theater. Leonard Bernstein, as his birthday gift, will conduct the music he wrote for the balletthe first BernsteinRobbins collaboration since West Side Story. A dybbuk, you remember, is the KaballistJudaic medieval version of the soulsquatter that also plagued Christians of the same period. However, the dancing dybbuk falls in love with the girl he possesses, which not only gives him a chance to display his virtuosity but also to make the sacrificial choice to return to limbo. You'll have a chance to receive a complimentary drink at a reception in the lobby if you buy gala tickets from $4 to $35. If you feel sufficiently expansive to be a patron ($50, $100 and $125), you'll attend a Russian supper and dance on the promenade. Mrs'Barbara Bellin Kahn is

description: To the Editor: At a time when there seems to be less official concern over environmental quality in the United States, it is encouraging to see that some other countries are still giving priority to a decent environment.

description: STILLWATER, Olda., May 11  President Nixon, who was reported to have told his family last night he would not resign as long as one Senator supported him, told a friendly crowd in Oklahoma tonight that he had no intention of giving up.

title: Suddenly, Real Ploys About Reat People
description: THE Circle Repertory Theater Company, an unprepossessing secondfloor walkup theater on Broadway and 83d Street (geographically, about as Off Off Broadway as you can get), past year become the chief provider of new American plays to the New York commercial theater. After short runs in the company's 100seat home theater, three Circle productions have'moved Off Broadway to become critical and popular successes.

title: Ballet: Royal Swan Lake
description: When Britain's Royal Ballet wants to be tremendous it can be tremendously tremendous. Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House it gave the first performance of its newly revised production of Swan Lake, and it went like a dream. I have never seen the conipany dance better, I have never seen a better production of Swan Lake, and I have never seen any Swan Lake better danced. On this kind of form the Royal Ballet must be the greatest machine for out and out dancing in the world today.

title: York College Plan Near'ing Approval
description: Approval of a new street system in the York College urban renewal area in Jamaica, Queens, is expected to be given by the City, Planning Commission within 10 days, John E. Zuccotti, the commission's chairman, said last week.

title: Bridge
description: Only a mall pinority of serious bridge players are gamblers, whether they make their living from the game or not. Technical interest, and satisfaction of the urge to compete, are sufficient for them without introducirig a monetary element. The American Contratt Bridge League has a regulation against betting on tournament results: It cannot be enforced, but it is rarely violated.

description: Plans for a $4.5million bus terminal and roof parking space in the heart of the shopping district in Flushing, Queens, will be taken up at a public hearing by the City Planning Commission on Wednesday, May 29 at City Hall.

title: A Night Out on London Town With the LatterDay Druids
description: They do every year, the cheery and gentle English Druids will soon be parading up Parliament Hill in Highgate, North London, to celebrate the summer solstice, beginning with a midnight vigil on the night of June 2122. In their white robes, blue tabards and goldenwreathed headdresses, the Druids encircle the ancient and somewhat mysterious monument called the Stone of Free Speech and go through some quiet pageantry, prayer, riciting of verse and tossing of flowers. Visitors are perfectly welcome, either to watch or to take a minor role in the ceremonies, and the time to be on hand is 12:40 A.M. on the 22d. Druids consider that 1 A.M. is the real midnight, accurate time. The vigil goes on until dawn, at about 4:45 A.M., when a little festival commences, one of eight ceremonies every year that mark the changing angles of the sun or recall other ancient Druidic holidays.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: In May, 1972, a threejudge Federal panel declared that the New Jersey election law relating to party affiliation and voting in primary elections was unconstitutional. The results of this change are not yet fully understood, and the League of Women Voters would like once again to clarify the present law before this year's primary elections on June 4.

title: The American Condition
description: Like the country today, it is hard to say what The American Condition is really all about. Throughout the book, there are the smokes of an important attack upon bureaucracy as a threat to freedom. But when and how and even to what end that attack is launched becomes lost in other crash efforts to rush us through the Development of Western Thought, a revised introductory economics, and a reevaluation of the efficacy of politics. The result is a treatise that, again like thecountry, is full of good things in plethoric confusion, but may well have lost its sustaining purpose.

title: Miss Porter Bride Of T. D. Mann. Jr.
description: Miss Susan Terhune Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Jones Porter Jr. of Abadan, Iran, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Dewey Mann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mann of Scotch Plains, N. J., and Harwich Port, Mass. The Rev. Charles Todd Newberry 3d, a Presbyterian minister and cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: A New incarnation Brightens Firebird By the City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet's current Firebird is the third version George Balanchine has made of the Stravinsky ballet and, in its present incarnation, dates from the City Ballet's 1972 Stravinsky Festival. Yet even this version, given at the State Theater Friday night for the first time this season, has been modified since then in its details.

title: Blacks for Wallace (!)
description: Last week's Democratic primaries in North Carolina and Alabama brought both good news and bad. The good news was that the era of racial politics in the South may be ending; the bad news was that the first beneficiary may be Gov. George Wallace of Alabama.

title: Hoboken Offers Quick Tests for Fuel Adulteration
description: HOBOKEN While driving his car the other day, Eugene Ferretti suddenly heard abnormal noises emanating from fits engine. He had a full tank of gasoline, his car always performed well and there was no apparent reason for the illsheartening sounds.

title: SIX KILLED, 35 HURT AS BUS HITS TRUCK
description: CHARLESTON, Mo., May 11 (AP)Six persons were killed and 35 injured today when al Greyhound bus sideswiped a truck that had overturned earlier, the police said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Northeastern United States survived the energy crisis this last winter with relatively minor inconvenience, so minor in fact that the memory of long lines at gasoline stations and the threat of a shortage of heating oil or natural gas may have already dimmed. Nevertheless, the crisis is by no means over. It began well before the Arab oil embargo, and whether a cutoff of oil from the Middle East is reimposed or not, our short supply of energy  in all forms  promises to get worse.

title: Hampton Jitney Fought at Hearing
description: RIVERHEAD  Opposition from a competing line and a legal question may stall the hiempton Jitney, a proposed bus service between Amagansett and Southampton, before it gets on the road.

title: WALLACE DEUEL, REPORTER, DEAD
description: CHICAGO,, May 11 (AP)Wallace R. Deuel, a former foreign correspondent of The Chicago Daily News who was well known for his wartime dispatches, died yesterday at the age of 68.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 11 (Ap)George Burns took step toward his goal of a herth on rieit year's WalkerCup team by defeating Danny Yates, 4 and 2, today in the 36hole final of the North and South amateur golf tournament. The Port Washington, L.I., golfer gained a threehole lead in the morning round, raised it to five after two holes iii the afternoon and then had to stave off a belated threat by Yates, an Atlanta insurance man Burns carded a 73, one over par, for the first 18 holes over the Pinehurst country Club No. 2 course, against 78 for Yates. In the afternoon, Burns was four over par, leaving him five over for 34 holes.

description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 11 (Reuters)  Syrian and Israeli forces were locked in heavy artillery fighting on Mount Hermon tonight, a Syrian military spokesman said.

description: The resignation of Willy Brandt as Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, in the midst of spy, scandal, marked the climax of an'extraordinary political odyssey and at least a sharp, caesura in career that has had a deep impact on Germany.

description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11Navy's lacrosse team rallied for five goals in the fourth quarter today to de feat Army, 127. Bob tieSimone led the Middies fourthquarter surge with three goals, while the Navy defense held Array scoreless over the final 15 minutes.

The pamphlet, which was devised by three youths, explains the steps that residents can take to modernize commercial and residential, areas.

title: Mitterand's Son Reported Object of Assassination Try
description: SAINTDENIS DE LA REUNION, Sunday, May 12 (Reuters)  Socialist party sources on this Indian Ocean island said today that gunmen had tried to assassinate the son of the French presidential candidate, Francois Mitterrand.

title: Education as a reflex of politics
description: The Great School Wars eases quietly into a ferociously angry subject. We are only five years away from the divisive and violent New York City school strikes which established the power of the United Federation of Teachers (U.F.T.), released terrible antiSemitic and antiblack energies and finally broke the quest for power of the independent school district at Ocean HillBrownsville. And as we look about New York today, it is impossible not to read in the condition of the schools and of the city itself the failure of education to rescue the, poor from poverty or, as the saying goes, to open the doors of opportunity to every American. Cautiously, Diane Ravitcha  fellow of the Institute of Philosophy and Politics of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University  affirms her faith in that American dream despite a detailed narrative which suggests, if anything, that education in New York has fairly consistently failed those who needed it.

title: Celler Charges Delays By Impeachment Panel
description: Former Representative Emanuel Celler, 86 years old, said that if he were still chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, the impeach ment investigation would have been faster.

title: AID TO CON EDISON URGED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Beame urged the Legislature yesterday to come to the rescue of Consolidated Edison immediately, expressing fear that failure to take some decisive action might jeopardize an orderly, continuous source of power supply to our city.

description: Miss Catherine Wilkinson Carstens, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Ferdinand Carstens of Darien, Conn., and Paul Martin Tymniak, son of Mrs. Martin Tymniak of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert. Nelson Back in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Noroton, Conn.

title: The Peaceable Kingdom of John Burroughs
description: I could not live in a palace, but in a but I am as well suited as a turtle in a shell. John Burroughs (18371921)  to Slabsides from New York City, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to Bear Mountain Bridge, then Route 9W north. West Park is about six miles beyond the MidHudson Bridge. Cross the railroad bridge and take the next left onto Floyd Ackert Road, between Marcel's restaurant and a ceramics shop. Burroughs Drive is on the left at the top of a hill, after the post office and railroad tracks and a white clapboard house on the right. The sanctuary begins at Burroughs Drive.

title: Chess Match Draws Don't Count They (Til They Add Up to Victory)

title: 3 Islands Off Puerto Rico Ruled Free of Screwworm
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Screwworms have vanished from three islands off Puerto Rico in the wake of assaults on the fertility of native screwworm flies, an Agriculture Department spokesman has said.

title: Criminals. At Large
description: With all the junk being is sued in paperback mysteries, it is a pleasure to find a superior species. A salute to the new series written by Ralph Dennis: the first two titles areATLAN; TA DEATHWATCH and THE CHARLESTON KNIFE'S BACK IN TOWN (Popular, 95 cents each). The heroes are a private eye named Hardman (hard man, get it?) and his sidekick, a black colossus named Hump. The jacket says something about sex and violence. Forget this cheap comeon There is plenty of violence but very little sex. What we do get is expert writing, plus good plotting and an unusual degree of sensitivity.

title: Belger, Willie Smith Star As 10 Meet Marks Fall
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 11The new $170,000 Tartan allweather track was unveiled today at, the Glenn Loucks Memorial Games and the schoolboy athletes promptly assaulted the meet's record book.

description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters)The Justice Department has filed an antitrust action against the Oregon State Bar for maintaining schedule of minimum legal fees.

title: Hard Choice for France
description: The neckandneck runoff for the French presidency between Socialist Francois Mitterrand and conservative Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing naturally has both candidates bidding for the 15 per cent of, the vote that went to Gaullist candidate Jacques ChabanDelmas in the first round. As the biggest bloc of floating votes now, it could be decisive. But there are other critical factors that will influence the outcome.

title: Bronx Man Seized in Slaying
description: A Bronx man known to the police as a major narcotics violator was arrested yesterday for stabbing to death a 31yearold man on March 8. The suspect, Leroy Nickey Barnes, 41 years old, of 3333 Henry Hudson Parkway, in the Riverdale section, had been indicted for homicide along with Curtis Mollette, 36, of 930 Grand Concourse, who was arrested on April 24. Both men were charged with killing Clifford Haynes of 976 Simpson Street, the Bronx, on March 8.

title: Who Drew the Moustache on the Presidential Image? Not TV News ty, JOHN J. O'CONNOR.
description: ON Sept. 13, 1952, Richard M. Nixon used television, in the famous Checkers speech, as a successful instrument for political survival. On April 29, 1974, Richard M. Nixon returned once again television for political survival, this time bypassing the Congress of the United States to take his case for the Watergate transcripts directly to the people. In the context of a TV presentation, his speech was successful. Th'e onscreen image was forceful and controlled. Beyond that, however, the prospect of broader success still twists.

description: To talk about problemsolving or decisionmaking within a national environment means examining many complex cultural forces. It means trying to measure the impact of these forces on contemporary life, and also coming to grips with changes now taking place.

title: 20 years after Brovvn: Negro progress and black rage
description: The first time I ever walked through the Atlanta airport was in 1962. I was a Northern black working for the State Department. It was my first trip to the deep South and the sounds of white Southern voices were strange and threatening. The mores of the region were foreign and I liked little of what I had read about it. It was late in the evening when I got to Atlanta and I had a severalhour wait for my connection to Birmingham. The airport was fairly empty except for a few family groups scattered here and there and a group of young white men who were in and around the bar. The young men wore rough clothes and talkedaccording to my Northern earthe language of the deep South. I was alone and uneasy, if not afraid. I was struck then by the irony of being an employe of the American people and yet feeling like a lost and threatened alien in my own country.

title: Byrne to Receive. Seton Hall Degree
description: SOUTH ORANGE Governor Byrne will deliver the principal address and receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at Seton Hall University's commencement next Saturday.

title: Into the bell jar world of unreality
description: Mundome  the title is a grammatically impossible juxtaposition of the Latin words for world and self  is an extraordinarily pure novel, pure as the contained landscapes inside glass paperweights in which the snow falls endlessly on minute figures, preserved from dust and decay by the absence of air. It is a novel singularly free from designs upon the reader; it tells its story, but unlike the similarly hypnotic Ancient Mariner it appends no sermon. Like its central characters, it asks only that it be allowed to express itself without being meddled with.

title: The World
description: Despite more than two weeks of intense negotiations, involving not only Secretary of State Kissinger but also Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko as gobetweens, the efforts to achieve a creasefire between Israeli and Syrian forces are far short of a breakthrough. Egypt's President Anwar elSadat said the two sides were barely in the starting block.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: A proposal that the United States adopt the metric system of weights and measures has been defeated in the House of Representatives; the arithmetic was 240 to 153. Debate on the bill was not without humor. Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, a critic of the bill, at one point challenged Representative John W. Davis, a proponent, to convert two inches into metric, quicklike. The Democrat from Georgia replied, about 50 millimeters, thought about it a moment, and then said he was wrong. He was right. Representative John B. Anderson, Republican of Illinois, said that failure to pass the measure would place the United States with Trinidad, South Yemen and Tobago as countries that have not converted to the metric system. Failure to pass the bill, one that has been stalled in Congress for 100 years, was due in part to concern over the cost of conversion.

title: North Dakota Paper Runs 52YearOld Baby Picture
description: FARGO, N.D. (AP)  A baby who was born on a New Year's Day more than 52 years ago finally had her picture published in a local paper recently.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Joe Robbie hasn't learned by his mistakes. His acid manner contributed to the defection of Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiick from the Miami Dolphins to the World Football League for the 1975 season. Now the principal owner of the twotime Super Bowl champions is alienating Don Shula, pro football's most respected coach. For more than two weeks now, Robbie and Shula haven't spoken to each other following a bitter exchange at the team's annual awards dinner. The confrontation at the Fontainebleu Hotel on April 26 developed when Shula was late appearing on the dais. The coach had waited for his wife Dorothy to arrive at the cocktail reception. Impatient to begin, Robbie stormed down from the dais.

title: Lawn Diseases and Solutions
description: AWNS are an important part of the landscape. Unfortunately, while striving to achieve the ultimate in lawn beauty, the home gardener often predisposes his turf to more severe disease development than if he ignored it. The reason, some maintenance practices that produce lush, dark green lawns also favor the growth of fungi which cause lawn diseases. But, disaster is not necessary. With proper planning and management, attractive lawns can be nurtured that are not prone to disease development.

title: Disintegration
description: The authority of the President of the United States is visibly disintegrating. Instead of the master stroke that Mr. Nixon apparently envisaged, the disclosure of the edited transcripts of his Watergate conversations has proved a disaster for him. Before the preliminaries of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry could get started on Thursday, leaders of his own party in Congress and longtime supporters in the press had already expressed dismay at the quality of the President's thinking and leadership as disclosed in the transcripts.

title: Book Ends
description: Spokespersons. The publishers publicity men and women who sometimes act as water bearers to slake the incessant newsthirst of columns such as this one are usually identified, if at, all, as, a spokesman. So we are happy to lift the veil of traditional anonymity and announce that four spokespersons have recently broken out on their own. The first is Isabelle Holland, formerly of Lippincott, who has a new novel coming out called Kilgaren, to be published by McKay. Not only that but she has another slated for the fall called Trelawney. Then there is Lynn Caine, who is still publicity woman with Little, Brown, and who has written, Widow, an account of her own life after her husband's death. Ironically, Mrs. Caine's book came about because of one of those TV shows she's always hustling to get her authors on. She appeared on a Barbara Walters Not for Women Only show and received offers from four publishers to write a book. One of the watchers was Sherry Arden, publicity woman at Mdrrow, who wooed Mrs. Caine at lunch, along with Joni Evans, an editor there; the book went to Morrow. Mrs. Caine says she feels schizophrenic these days, promoting other authors books aswell as her own (when an author asks her about her book she firmly says, No let's talk about your book). Yes she's going on a coasttocoast publicity tour and her bosses have given her time off. Still another former publicity woman turned writer is Marcia Seligson, whose The Eternal Bliss Machine will be out in paperback this June. Lastly, there is Carol Hill of Random House, whose novel Let's Fall in Love was reviewed here April 14. Note to the F.C.C., I.R.S., S.E.C. and the F.B.I.: this department was not taken out to lunch by any of the aforementioned women prior to this mention. Except Lynn Caine, who refused to talk about her book.

Some of its essayists (like Rode), and its novelists and playwrights (Florencio Sanchez, Quiroga, Onetti) had achieved international fame. One of the best Latin American avantgarde painters was the Uruguayan born Joaquin TorresGarcia. Even the best of the tango singers, Carlos Gardel, was bom there. Today the former Switzerland of South America is looking more and more like its sad sister. Paraguay, and has joined the, Banana Republic Club. (Umguayan weather is too cold to permit the growing of bananas but that is only a detail.) A recent movie, State of Siege, documented in the most chilling way what had happened to that proud republic. title: The Man From Peoria: Will Anything Play?
description: WASHINGTONPeoria, that humming industrial town in the heart of the Illinois farmlands, was a symbolic capital of President Nixon's Middle America. Will it play Peoria? John D. Ehrlichman, then the President's domestic policy chief, used to respond to secondguessers here. ,, Peoria is the center of a Congressional district that went 2to1 for Richard Nixon in 1972. But it typifies, too, the audience of The Chicago Tribune, a bible of Midwest Republicanism, which published every word of the White House Watergate transcripts and demanded last week that Mr. Nixon leave office, or be removed.

title: An Inquiry Into The Human Prospect
description: The literature of the Apocalypse, which has grown into quite a substantial corpus in the last five years, has especially prided itself on the width of its conceptual grasp. Nothing is separate from anything else, the ecologists have told us: fish in the sea are affected by farmers in Missouri, and no solution which ignores the connections can hope to succeed. Yet many of these same writers, dogged in their pursuit of DDT through the, food chain, have been surprisingly timid about, similar inquiries into the political implications of environmental control. To the extent they have discussed politics at all, most of the environmental writers have either urged more government regulation of the evil corporations, or issued goodhearted appeals for vague new ethics of cooperation and 150 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $1.95.

Mr. Adams has occupied so large a place In the development of American photography that its history, at least since the nineteenthirties, could scarcely be written wahout ample consideration of his manysided accomplishments. Although trained originally as a concert pianist, he has been exhibiting and publishing his photographs since the twenties. In 1932, the year that he was giyen this first oneman show at the DeYbung Museum in San Francisco, he founded th'e Group f/64 with Edward Weston, Willard Van Dyke, Imogen Cunningham, Sonia, Noskowiak and Henry Swift, and four years later he was given a oneman show at Alfred Stieglitz's An American.

title: What's Doing in VIENNA
description: FESTIVALVienna will live up to its billing as the music capital of Europe during the Vienna Festival from May 25 to June 24. This year is the 150th anniversary of Anton Bruckner's birth, and his nine symphonies will get sturdy airings from the Vienna Philharmonic under Karl BOhm, the Berlin Philharmonic under Herbert von Karajan, the Vienna Symphony under Carlo Maria Giulini and other ensembles. The historic Theater an der Wien will offer guest appearances by Milan's Piccolo Teatro, Brussels Royal Opera, Osaka's Bunraku Theater, Cracow's Stary Teatr and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. All this will be shored up by nightly performances at the Vienna State Opera (Staatsoper), while the Vienna Folk Opera (Volksoper) imports the Harkness Ballet and performs opera in German along with operettas like The Merry Widow, Gypsy Baron, Land of Smiles and Die Fledermaus. Pay heed! Not seeing an operetta in Vienna is like not seeing the Eiffel Tower Paris the Colosseum in Rome.

title: Clarke's Play Keeps Flyers In High Gear
description: Deadlocked, 1 to 1, in their fourofseven Stanley Cup final series, the Philadelphia Flyers and the Boston Bruins move today to the Spectrum for the third game.

title: Members of Ethics Board Consider Reopening of Goldman Case
description: Members of the city's Board; of Ethics are considering re opening the case of the ap: pointment of Irving Goldman as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

title: Racing Buffs Work at Dangerous, Nonpaying Jobs
description: They had come 150 miles, some of them, to stand on a bank of earth at Station 2; some with their backs to race cars traveling 140 miles an hour, only 20 feet away, and with nothing beAbout tween them and disaster but quick Motor reflexes.

title: Margaret M. Morrison Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Harris Morrison of Concord, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Maxwell Morrison, to Jeffrey Winslow Hamilton, a member of the Concord Academy faculty in Concord, Mass.

title: Two Port Groups Open Drive For Funds to Improve Channel
description: By WERNER BAMBERGER

title: Elizabeth King kans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Madison King to John Nicholas Griffin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward William King of Kingsport, Tenn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Albert Griffin Jr. of Towson, Md.

title: MacGregor Bids Business Be Active in Election Year
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 11Clark MacGregor, director of President Nixon's reelection campaign in 1972, told a group of prominent bankers and corporation heads today that if the American business community sits on the sidelines in this election year, the next Congress will have lopsided majorities hostile to the business point of view.

title: Liebling Press Session Attended by 1,300 Here
description: The third annual A. J. Liebling CounterConvention, a sort of springrite catharsis for the press, opened yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel. It attracted 1,300 people, mostly journalists, who spent the day attending panel discussions and catching up on the gossipleft hanging from last year's convention.

title: 5 Projects For Sewage Get Priority From State
description: ALBANY  Five sewage treatment plants in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are among 166 priority water pollution control projects throughout New York State that are slated for funding in the next two fiscal years, according to an announcement by the Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, MAY 12, 1974
description: Two American officials flew to the Golan Heights to inspect the area around the town of El Quneitra, in southwest Syria, whose fate has become a major issue in Secretary of State Kissinger's efforts to bring about SyrianIsraeli troop separation agreement. Joseph J. Sisco, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Harold J. Saunders, the National Security Council's expert on Middle East, spent four hours in the El Quneitra area. They were accompanied by Lieut. Gen. Mordechai Gur, the Israeli chief of staff, who has strongly argued on security grounds against the return to Syria of the three hills surrounding El Quneitra, which is now ghost town. [1:1.]

title: A WellRounded Musician
description: Howard Roberts plays music chairs all by himself as he switches from conductor, to composer to singer to trumpet player, to arranger and to musical director.

title: Crockett's 9Second Feat Sets World Record in 100
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. May 11Ivory Crockett, a slightly built 24yearold Southern Illinois graduate, shattered Bob Hayes's 11yearold world record in the 100yard dash tonight, running the distance in 9 seconds.

title: What's New in Art
description: What's New in Art

title: 2 5 Years in Battle for Rightsi Fund's Lawyer Seesvictory
description: Jack Greenberg ticked them miles, a long road with many off: Ocala, Fla.; Oklahoma City; Topeka, Kan.; Little Rock, Ark.; Greensboro, and Raliegh, N.C.; Albany, Ga.; Meridian, Miss.; New Orleans; Montgomery, Selma and Birmingham, Ala.; Detroit; Chicago; San Francisco; New York.

title: NO Matter How You Slice It, It's Pie
description: WAYNEThere are fourandtwenty pie choices at the Four and Twenty piesonly bakery in the modern Wayne Hills Mall here.

title: Old Stereographs Of Jersey on View
description: LINCROFTAn unusual exhibit of early stereographic views of New Jersey will be on display at the Monmouth County Park System Visitor Center from Tuesday through June 20. Entitled Through Two Lenses, the show is being produced by the Monmouth Museum with a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Port Industry Seeks to Reduce Guaranteed Wage for Workers
description: The port's stevedoring industry is seeking a 30 per cent reduction in the guaranteed annual income paid to dock workers here, saying the cost of the provision is driving cargo to other ports.

title: Music: New Composers; Chamber Group Plays Post1960 Works in Program Presented by John. Watts
description: John Watts'sworthy Composers Theater has offered a May Festival of 10 concerts Of contemporary music this spring at the Washington Square Methodist Church, and on Friday evening the group presented the first of two free chamberorchestra programs to end the series.

title: Mites: Europe for The BudgetMinded
description: EVEN though the dollar is in better shape this year than last (as much as 20 per cent stronger in some countries), rampant inflation in Europe is going to make things tough for the lowbudget traveler.

title: PopcornA Bagful of Profits
description: LOST NATION, Iowait's twice as old as Christianity. Early Americans sold it in bunches. Others wore it. It was once a sign of goodwill. A tobacco firm markets it. Gordon Dahl just buried some. Cattle eat it. Hogs eat it. And so do some people.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor. Bevis Hillier would be happier, he says, if The Grand Acquisitors by John Hess, did not read so much like a Nuremberg denunciation of the Metropolitan Museum's director Thomas Hoving. Notwithstanding, Mr. Hillier has piled Ossa on Pelion by writing a review (April 7) as venemous, unbalanced and misleading as the Hess book itselfno mean achievement.

title: Houdini of the Hamptons
description: Hoodini Of the Hamptons

title: A Few Specific Growing Pointers For the Vegetable Gardener's Big Crop
description: Warm soil and air temperature are the signals to set out tomato seedlings. Those who rush planting find that cool nights (below 55 degrees) will cause blossoms to drop or not set, and cold soil will halt tomato growth.

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER EXTENSION OF G.LBILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Stopgap legislation to extend educational allowances for Vietnam era veterans for two years is expected to be considered by the Senate next week.

title: Mr. Ford: He Is Now His F'arty's Leader
description: WASHINGTONMr. President, er, that is, Mr. Vice President  The young California politician was embarrassed by his mistake, but he need not have been: Republicans across the nation have already elevated Vice President Ford to one niche normally occupied by the President. In but title he is now the leader of the Republican party.

title: Angry Hill, Melnyk Share Houston Golf Lead at 137
description: HOUSTON, May 11 (AP)Dave Hill, still angry from the treatment he received at this event a year ago, hammered out a fiveunderpar 67 and moved into a tie with Steve Melnyk for the second round lead today in the raindelayed 5150,000 Houston open golf tournament.

title: News of the Stage
description: Joseph Papp, the ubiquitous founderproducer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, is bringing Liv Ullmann, the Norwegian actress, to New York !next season in Ibsen's A Doll's House. He has also persuaded Ingmar Bergman, Sweden's directorwriter, to direct Ibsen's Rosmersholm for him during the 197576 season.

title: Responsibility for a Sacred Trust
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In the debate over impeachment, it has been argued on behalf of President Nixon that an impeachment proceeding, as well as any resultant trial in the Senate, must be conducted as an ordinary criminal trial in order to assure the accused of fair play and substantial justice.

title: Too Easy to Be Art?
description: sINCE the kind of painting known as PhotoRealism emerged in the art world three or four years agoemerged, that is, as a movementit has received few hosannas, As the radical wing of what has seemed to be a general realist revival, it has been dutifully reported by some critics, often with sincere attempts to discern its merits. But it has so tailed to attract an intellectual following that, for want of a friendly criticism to argue with, even hostile criticism seems to be more or less in abeyance now.

title: Golan Heights Settlers Are Sometimes in the Way
description: JERUSALEMIn the midst of a Syrian artillery barrage last week, the Israeli Philharmonic began an outdoor concert, attended by several Cabinet ministers, in Haruv, the 17th and newest civilian settlement to be established on the occupied Golan Heights since the 1967 war. The orchestra played for about 10 minutes but finally was forced to quit and head for underground shelters.

title: Museum Cancels Program
description: The Brooklyn Museum has had to close down a special arts education program for schoolchildren from four local school districts because the museum did not get the funds that it thought had been promised by the Model Cities Administration.

title: LILCO May Gain From Con Ed Bill
description: LILCO May Gain From Con Ed Bill

title: Split Acorn: Chris Evert And Special Team Score
description: A pair of thrilling stretch runs that resulted in triumphs for Special Team and Chris Evert entertained the crowd of 35,919 at Aqueduct yesterday. These respective successes occurred in the Acorn Stakes for 3yearold fillies, a race that was so popular with owners and trainers that it had to be run in two divisions.

title: Dido and Aeneas Return to Greece, Singing
description: LAST summer the Greek island of Corfti was host to its first festival. It was organized more or less at the last moment by Michael Sisk, general director, John Carignan, Jr., music director, and Thomas Schippers, artistic adviser, so that for two weeks in July it offered performances largely by small music, dance and theater groups.

title: League of Person Voters
description: For a half century the League of Women Voters has been a force for good in American politicstirelessly prodding, admonishing and educating the electorate and the elected in their civic responsibilities.

title: Son to the Lovetts
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Lovett of Greenville, Wilmington, Del., on April 25 in the Wilmington General Hospital. Mrs. Lovett is the former Miss Dorothy dehaven of Stamford, Conn. The child, the couple's third, has been named Robert Abercrombie 2d, He is a grandson of Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense in the Truman Administration, and Mrs. Lovett of Locust Valley, L.I The child's father is with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.

title: Peter Blair Jr. Fiance Of Sally Sprague Lee
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Lee Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., and Prouts Neck, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Sprague Lee, to Peter Heyliger Blair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blair of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Music Are We All Trapped in Bluebeard's Castle?
description: GEORG SOLTI somewhat upitaged the Metropolitan Opera when, on May 1, he came to Carnegie Hall with his Chicago Symphony and a concert performance of Bela Bartoks Duke Bluebeard Castle. It so happens that on June 10, during the course of its 1974 June Festival, the Metropolitan Opera will be giving, for the first time in its history, the Bartok opera (along with another oneacter, Puccini's Gianni Schicchi). A staged performance of an opera is, of course, always preferable to a concert version, so the Metropolitan Opera will have the advantage in at least that. But, with all due deference to the fine Metropolitan orchestra, it is safe to say that those players will not be able to duplicate the blazing incandescence that Solti and his virtuoso orchestra brought to the score.

title: He Knows More Ellington Than Duke Himself
description: WHEN Duke Ellington and his orchestra spent a week at the University of Wisconsin in July, 1972, holding master classes, conducting workshops and giving several concerts, a key member of the Duke's entourage was a slim, 20yearold pianist, almost totally blind, who was referred to by the Duke as If you have any questions about my music, Ellington told students at his master classes, just, ask Brooks Kerr.

title: Turnout Is Low in School Votes
description: In the aftermath of last week's school board elections, Long Island officials appeared pleased that fewer budgets were defeated than in last year's elections, but they indicated disappointmentand even surpriseat the comparatively low voter turnout.

title: MRS. W. D. ANDERSON
description: Mrs. Carolyn B. Anderson, secretary for the last three years of the Corporation of Tufts University, died Friday of a stroke in Lawrence Memorial Hospital in Medford, Mass. She was 36 years old and lived in Medford. Mrs. Anderson was the wife of Wilbert D. Anderson.

title: After an inflation of errors a depletion of theory
description: Walter Heller is a man of renowned cheerfulness; he is sure to be remembered happily by history as the ebullient architect of United States economic expansion during the midsixties, a proud and exhilarating time for him and his profession. But Heller was not very cheerful late last year on the eve of his ascension to a pinnacle of the profession, the presidency of the American Economic Association. The former chief economic adviser of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson noted at the association's annual convention that it had been an infamous year for economists, that they were caught with their parameters down and had to go back to the drawing boards.

title: Home Improvement
description: GOOD paint job should last at least four or five years on the outside of most housesbut this will only hold true if three basic rules are followed: (1) A top quality paint designed for the surface over which it will be applied is used. (2) The directions on the label are carefully followed as to mixing, thinning and application techniques. (3) The surfaces to be painted are carefully cleaned, sanded, primed and otherwise prepared so as to insure a good foundatiOn for the new coat.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Here and Now: Guest is Albert Shenker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, Channel 4, 9:30 A.M.

title: Thomas Lyon Child Is Fiance Of Miss Barbara Joy Rushmore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rushmore Jr. of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Blooming Grove, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Joy Rushmore, to Thomas Lyon Child, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richards Lyon Child of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Stamford, N.Y.

title: Movies A World with No Secrets
description: MON SQUARE, SAN FRANCISCO: An attractive young couple rclandestine loversweave and out of the crowd, having hat seems to be an innocent, banal conversation about Christmas presents. A man with a hearing aid and a shopPing bag trails after them. High above AI square, another man watches them Vinugh an exotic telescope. Finally, third man enters a large van where tape recorders are playing fragments the conversation.

title: Arts Society Cites Montclair Student
description: MORRISTOWN  Mrs. Clark V. Daly of Basking Ridge was installed last week as president of the New Jersey chapter of the National Society of Arts and Letters.

title: People and Business
description: Secondgrade pupils at Gould Avenue School in North Caldwell are going into the candyselling business. They are being capitalized by a $25 loan from the Midlantid National Bank of Newark, one of the state's largeit financial institutions.

title: The Region
description: Following painful tradition, the New York State Legislature struggled to adjourn last week with significant legislation still await ing lastminute resolution: The bills would bring about form virtually eliminate IraEdison Company  which claims to be on the verge of bankruptcy  through the purchase of two of the utility's plants, were still being some campaign spending recanny decontrol for apartments and provide funds to help New York CRY halaace its $12.2billion budget. And efforts to ease the financial pressure on the Consolidated.

description: Miss Janet Brett Sawyetydaughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Preston Sawyer of Dultbury, Mass., and John L. Merrill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merrill Jr, of Kennebunkport Me., were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist in Duxury. The Rev. Lewis H. Mills and the Rev. Montague Pearse officiated at the ceremony.

title: The Region
description: After three months the Connecticut General Assembly session has come to a close. The lawmakers considered 1,390 bills, some inconsequential, some significant, and adopted 450. It was, by all accounts, a prosaic session. The legislators did, however, place restrictions on campaign funding, passed a record budget of $1.38billion and, for the second year in a row, cut taxes.

title: Lynn Broquist Sets. July 21 Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harry P. Broquist of Nashville have an nounced the, engagement of their, daughter, Miss. Lynn Marie Broquist, to. Seymour Nelson Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Miles of New York and Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Gap Project Aided by an Upsala Student
description: EAST ORANGE  Those persons visiting the Delaware Water Gap this summer will hear the recorded words of an Upsala College student, Robert D. Hamlin of Livingston, who has researched and written a geological history of the gap.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Assails Strike Leaders
description: NEW DELHI, May 11The Indian Government adopted a tough stance against railway union leaders today, the fourth day of the nationwide railroad strike.

title: UMass Eight Captures Dad Vail Trophy
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11The University of Massachusetts oarsmen won the varsity heavyweight championship for the second straight year by less than a length in the 36th annual Dad Vail regatta on a fairly calm Schuylkill in sunny weather today before a crowd of 20,000.

title: Joan Weinberg Wed
description: Miss Joan Carol Weinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Nathan Weinberg of Pleasantville, N. Y., was married yesterday morning to Lieut. William Ernest Thompson 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. John Whallon, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony in St. Bede's Chapel in Greenwich, Conn., which was formerly part of Rosemary Hall.

title: 5Year Detention of a Russian In Asylums Evokes Controversy
description: MOSCOW, May 11When in 1969, a bluntspoken former Soviet army general tried to defend a group of Crimean Tatars charged with antiSoviet activity, he was arrested, officially ruled insane and sent to a mental hospital.

title: The Riches Of Jean Renoir:The Riches of Renoir
description: ON Sept. 15 Jean Renoir will be 80 years old. It is thus unlikely that this giant among directors will work on any more films. This makes all the more special the appearance here this week (at the First Avenue Screening Room) of his most recent production, the limpid, lovely, rollicking, four-part movie titled "Le Petit Thtre de Jean Renoir," commissioned five years ago for French television but just now having its commercial debut in Manhattan.From the opening sequence in which Renoir, in his first appearance on screen as himself, greets us, the audience, as he stands beside his miniature theater where the stories will unfold, and from the very first scene in the first story ("The Last Christmas Dinner"), in which two cranky Santa Clauses fight for territory outside a posh restaurant, until the bow of the actors that concludes the program, "Le Petit Thtre de Jean Renoir" unfolds with the kind of breathtaking effect that I associate with Hitchcock's "Frenzy" and with Buuel's "Tristana" and "The Discreet Charm of The Bourgeoisie."These films have nothing in common except that they are the works of superlative artists working in modes that they have been mastering for more than five decades. I'm perfectly aware that age doesn't automatically enrich a talent. It has a way of eroding all but the most profound talents, especially those of filmmakers who always are under particular stress to be responsive to the mass audience that, ultimately, allows the filmmaker to continue working. It's a terrible business, really. Compromises must be effected. So many that finally it becomes a triumph of sorts just to secure the necessary financing, to get a movie into production and, eventually, into a theater. After all that wear and tear, who can have the discipline of purpose to remember the film itself?Fine old moviemakers are very rare, largely, I suspect, because we  you and I  have a way of looking at each new film much in the manner that we peruse the front page of a daily newspaper. If it doesn't report some ghastly disaster, some startling development in science, some scandal, we're inclined to throw it aside. We've seen it before.Impatient critics and movie-goers in 1967 dismissed Charlie Chaplin's charming, 1930-esque comedy, "A Countess from Hong Kong," with Marlon Brando and Sophire Loren playing extensions of Chaplin, because it didn't measure up to what they wanted that year (which included "Elvira Madigan" and "In Cold Blood," to name just two of 1967's major hits).If the filmmaker lasts into old age, the results can sometimes be as remarkable as "Bonaparte and The Revolution," Abel Gance's extraordinary reworking of his 1927 silent epic, "Abel Gance's Napoleon," which was shown at the New York Film Festival several years ago. At the age of 82 Gance re-edited "Napoleon," added sound to those sequences that were still without it, and shot additional, material, to make a new epic film as well as an epic commentary on the evolution of films. (I understand that both "Abel Gance's Napoleon" and "Bonaparte and The Revolution" may soon be available for commercial distribution in this country, which is, to put it calmly, about time.)The pressure on theatrical film directors is the sort that can reduce strong men to jellies composed of flabby flesh, fear and avarice. Roberto Rossellini, who will be 68 this year, has survived and grown only by turning his back on theatrical films entirely, working instead on a series of educational films, financed by TV interests, that allow him to be as idiosyncratic as he wants. Had Rossellini eared that much for the high life, he'd probably be directing Mafia movies today for Dino De Laurentiis, or for some lesser equivalent.All of which makes the longevity and the richness of the careers of Hitchcock, Buuel and Renoir so rare. Attention must be paid, particularly at this moment to Jean Renoir.By some poetic chance, "Le Petit Thtre" is both a cause for celebration and an act of it. It is nothing so grand as a retrospective of the entire career of the man who made, among other masterpieces, "Rules of The Game," "Grand Illusion," "Picnic on The Grass," "The Southerner," "The Diary of A Chambermaid," "The River," "The Golden Coach" and "French Can-Can."It is a small film composed of three separate comedies plus a between-acts song sung by Jeanne Moreau, playing a solemnly untalented Parisian music hall performer, circa 1900. Yet the whole thing is so effortlessly composed, so wise and so full of the concerns that make each Renoir film memorable, it vividly evokes the spirit of the remarkable man we can still honor in his lifetime.The form of the film, a familiar sort of television device, has a special aptness for Renoir's career. Renoir, the host, introduces each story with a few words, at which point the camera moves from the director and crosses the tiny footlights of his miniature stage, where the stories are played. Life changes to theater which changes to life which changes to theater, until, at last, the people in Renoir's last little comedy have to walk to the apron of the stage and bow to us to return us to our own world.This Renoir fondness for theater is, I propose, less the philosophical expression that some critics would have you believe than it is a kind of polite recognition of life's most awesome, most banal riddles. What is real? Is everything a hopeless mess directed by someone with absolutely no interest in us? Renoir, I'm sure, doesn't know, nor if he thought he did, would he presume to say.None of the three little comedies is quite as simple as it might seem. "The Last Christmas Dinner," about two Parisian clochards, an old man and an old lady whose make-up as derelicts is as artificial as the sets they inhabit, is the sort of fairy tale in which a character can say that "Christmas is our most successful clich" and then the sketch goes on to prove it."The Electric Waxer" is a modern "opera" about a furiously foolish housewife who loves her parquet floors more than she loves her husband or, as she says: "Trust my floors to a maid? I'd rather die!" Which, eventually, she does. The marvel is that Renoir manages to cover much of the same ground about the "new Paris" covered by Godard in "Two or Three Things I Know About Her," without once slipping into the attitude of the shocked polemicist.He's hugely amused without being cruel or bitter, or, for that matter, unconcerned.The final sketch is Renoir returning to Marcel Pagnol country, the sun-filled, verdant Midi where a wealthy old landowner must come to terms (which he does) with the wife he loves and her young lover, who's his best friend. Renoir's love of nature is bursting out all over this sequence, but it has less to do with foliage than with people, with the troubled but flexible old man (Fernand Sardou), his beautiful, all-too-desirable bride (Franoise Arnoul), the conscience-stricken lover (Jean Carmet), and the nice, clumsy young maid (Dominique Labourier), who doesn't care who knows that she eavesdrops and who dreams of being a courtesan on the order of Messalina. She is, of course, the least likely Messalina anyone might imagine, but Renoir, and the rest of us with him, have a special fondness for the enormity of the dream.That, I think, is one of the enduring qualities that illuminate Renoir's little theater, his world. Nothing in it is ever inconsequential.

title: Consumer Center Opens in Brooklyn
description: A new consumer information and assistance center has been opened in Brooklyn as part of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's program to bring consumer services directly to neighborhoods where people are often victimized by questionable liminess practices and are least likely to complain.

title: Westerners Discern a Weakened Israeli Defense Force
description: Heavy losses in officers, shortages in technical personnel and a command structure shaken by con: troversy have weakened, according to some western experts, the Israeli Defense Force since it ended the:: October war on a note of triumph 60 miles from Cairo.

title: The New Elton John Won Have to Be a Clown Television
description: LONDON.

title: CARD DEALER HEED IN SLAYING AT CLUB
description: A 31yearold card dealer at a Chinatown gambling club was charged with murder yesterday in the shooting Friday night of a Chinese gang leader whose body was found later that evening wrapped in a brown paper bundle at the club.

title: Bishop William M. Wilborn Of Church of God in Christ
description: ALBANY, May 11 (AP)Bishop William M. Wilborn, head of the central New York region of the Church of God in Christ for 39 years, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 74 years old.

title: Wiretap in Store Is Upheld by Judge In a Coast Lawsuit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11. A Federal district judge here has ruled that Federal wiretapping statutes permit employers to tap employes telephone conversations if they go through a company switchboard.

title: Jones, Hahn, Staub Help Swan Pick Up His. First Victory
description: CHICAGO, May 11The New York Mets survived another afternoon of low comedy in Wrigley Field today, defeated the Chicago Cubs again by 63 and won sole possession of a small prize: fourth place in the Eastern Division.

title: Osprey Eggs Transplanted
description: BARNEGAT  The New Jersey osprey, known locally es the fish hawk, may get a new lease on life if an experimental eggtransplant program conducted by the state's Division of Fish, Game and Shellfisheries is successful.

title: Resignation Has Its Problems Too
description: As recently as a month ago, the idea of President Nixon's resignation as a way out of Watergate seemed to have little support among either his longtime supporters or his critics. The accelerating reaction to the edited White House transcripts has evidently transformed that position, But there are still legal and political problems to be faced if Mr. Nixon should abandon his declared opposition the idea and indicate that he is now ready to go.

title: Recordings
description: SINCE few Americans have ever taken art and its potential powers very seriously (black music, white music  who cares, so long as it's not that classical junk), it should come as no surprise that scholars of American music and of black culture have only recently begun to notice and to care for the fact that black composers have been creating in the field of classical symphonic music for a couple of centuries. What a shock. How quaint. Is it good? Can it save the symphony? Has the civilrights movement gone too far? say some folk.

title: Ann M. Alexander Wed to W. E. Poist
description: The marriage of Miss Ann Marie Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Radcliffe Alexander of Bethlehem, Pa., formerly of New York, to William Elbert Poist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Elbert Poist of Hanover, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Parents Await Ruling on Plea to Regain Children Taken From Them by Juvenile Court
description: DES, MOINES, IowaDarlene Alsager stared at a large color photograph taken around Christmas, 1968, of her six young children, four of whom cave not slept in their parents house for nearly five %years.

title: The House Of the History of Dreams
description: House of the History of Dreams rocks grew and withered and grew again. Men looked in mirrors and toyed with the direction of the light of the sun, they learned to write and to give names to the stars and the planet Venus.

title: School Integration Order of 54 Did Much, but Much Is Undone
description: It was cloudy and warm that spring Monday in Washington, May 17, 1954. On Capitol Hill, the ArmyMcCarthy hearings stalled over President Eisenhower's refusal to disclose his private conversations. In London, Churchill was calling for a negotiated peace in IndoChina.

title: Firemen Free Hand 01 Boy From Grinder
description: Firemen from Brooklyn Rescue Company 2 yesterday spent two hours cutting apart a meat grinder that caught the left hand of a 12yearold boy in an East Flatbush butcher shop.

title: Paperbacks Best Sellers
description: 1 THE GREAT GATSBY, by F. Scott Fitzgerald. (Bantam, $1.50.) The peerless, haunting evocation of the twenties and a man's doomed attempt to buy his lost dream.

title: Bonnie Brower Married
description: Miss Bonnie Kay Brower and William Kirby Whyte were married yesterday evening in the Presbyterian Church of Westfield, N. J., by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Christian. The parents of 943 couple are Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Brower of Westfield and Mr. and Mrs. William G. Whyte of Washington. The bride is a politica) researcher with the National Association of Manufacttieers in Washington, wher'e her husband is on the sales staff of the Ford Motor Con pany.
