title: New Hampshire Dunned
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 11 (AP)  Concord has sent the state a bill for $1,776, beginning a campaign against providing nonemergency services for the state. The bill is for the use of city policemen in last week's search of the state prison.

title: Court Hearing Set in Vesco Jet Removal
description: NEWARK, May 11A New Jersey Superior Court Judge today ordered all parties involved in the removal of a Boe ing 707 jetliner owned by Robert Vesco, the fugitive fii nancier, from a Panamanian airport into his courtoom Monday in an effort to ascertain whether any international laws had been violated by the flight.

title: Miss Ennis Captures 6Mile Run
description: Viaffles and honey beat out spaghetti and butter as a training food by a slight margin yesterday as Doreen Ennis, representing the Nutley (N. J.) Track Club, won the third annual minimarathon in Central Park, setting a course record of 36 minutes 45.6 seconds.

title: A Rock Road To Ramace, And a Home Qn Park Ave.
description: Ava Fichtner de La Sabhare Farrow and David Weir Bated each other profusely when they met. She thought he was a somewhat strange garage mechanic, which he wasn't He thought she was inclined to be bossy, which she was, and is.

title: LISBON APPEALS TO REBELS AGAIN
description: LISBON, May 11The military junta, which is due to give way in a few days to a provisional government, issued new appeal today to guerrilla movements in Portugal's African territories to lay down their arms.

title: But what if people live to be 100 or more?; Slowing the clock of age
description: Mrs. Anna Olinger has no real explanation for her age of 103 years. I suppose it's just that I've managed to change with the times, she told an interviewer not long ago. Born in 1871 in rugged part of eastern Kansas, she went to college in Michigan (and was, in fact, one of the first women to attend Michigan State University), married Presbyterian minister and a few years after his death in 1921 became associate director of the Presbyterian student center at the University Kansas in Lawrence. Still living in a house on the edge of campus, she belongs to two women's groups and a literary club, attends church and occasionally gardens. I'm the busiest woman in town, she said. I can't wait to get up in the mornings.

title: Red Smith
description: Inflation is a fact of life in intercollegiate athletics as well as in the supermarket, and $200,000 is a sizable sum. That is why Notre Dame has abdicated authority over its own affairs and let Roone Arledge of American Broadcasting Company tamper with its 1974 football schedule for the greater glory of his network. Hungering for an extra slice of the television pie, the university pefmitted ABC to switch its game with Georgia Tech from Saturday afternoon, Nov. 9, to Monday night, Sept. 9. Not for the first time, a proud lady has been reduced to taking in laundry. When times are hard and costs soar, $200,000 covers a multihide of sins.

title: A torte to be proud of
description: Blueberries as big as the end of your thumb, real sky blue and heavy.. That's the way Robert Frost described them in Blueberries. They are the second biggest berry crop in this country (strawberries are the first); they are fine just as they come from the bush or the pint basket, and the first ones should be up from the Carolinas in the next week or so. Cooked, they can represent one of the prides of native American cuisine. Take this blueberry torte, for instance.

title: Paperbacks
description: The Circus of Dr. Lao was first published in 1935, and a gorgeous embarrassment it must have been back then. This blinking neon paperback edition from Avon headlines it as A classic novel of the supernatural  a breathtaking voyage of terror and wonder. The cover illustration, a Peter Max style billboard advertisement for hell, homes in on that enormous Chariots of the Gods?, Morning of the Magicians constituency. Satyrs, gorgons, sphinxes, mermaids, unicorns, dramatis personae from a 17thcentury map of Terra Incognita. But this is just salesmanship, Barnum promoting, say, St Luke's Gospel: * * ! See Water ChangedYESinto Wine!** Certainly Charles G. Finney's novel has symbolioalmythological sofas and end tables and hassocks enough to furnish a threering allegory. But The Circus of Dr. Lao is not an allegory. It's another kind of classic. A classic American joke, featuring the special, outrageous hyperbole that characterized Nineteenth Century American humor. Finney has made a baroque headstone to mark the last remains of TwainBierceMencken saradonic journalism.

title: HOW THE TRAFFIC STOPPED AT EBOLI
description: ROME, May 11Italy was all but cut in two this week by a rebellion in the poor traffichub city of Eboli, 50 miles southeast of Naples, where demonstrators blocked northsouth rail and road connections for days.

title: :Jane Fawcett Is Brid
description: Miss Jane Mitchell Pawcett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mitchell Fawcett, was married yesterdayafteronoon to Stephen Arm e Cornunale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Comunale Jr. Both families are of Akron, Ohio, where the Rev. George Ross Charity Ball Cotillion and is a member of the Junior League of Akron. Her father is president and chief executive officer of the Mohawk Rubber Company in Hudson, Ohio.

title: AirQuality Standards Are Set For Proposed Convention Center
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration gave tentative approval yesterday to the $200million convention center planned to be built on the Hudson River, provided that several conditions are met to assure compliance with airquality standards.

title: roubled Italy Back From the Brink?
description: ROME  Among the world's 10 leading industrial nations, Italy is renowned for producing small cars with responsive engines, welldesigned shoes and business machines, fancy fabrics and cheap refrigeratorsand the biggest debts.

title: Mrs. George Harron of the Save Lucy Committee in front of the large wooden elephant in Margate. Scaffolding is because much restoration still needs to be done.
description: MARGATELucy the Elephant, a 93yearold historic landmark made of tin and lumber, will be reopened for the summer tourist season. The partly restored Lucy is far from an ordinary pachyderm, for, not only is she almost a century old, but she also is 65 feet tall and weighs 90 tons.

title: Miss Joan Bell Wylie, Richard Minich Wed
description: Miss Joan Belle Wylie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Kelso Wylie of Rye, N.Y., and Richard Alan Minich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Minich of Buffalo, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Joseph P. Bishop of the Rye Presbyterian Church jn the garden of the church.

title: New England Can Take 15,000 More Freshmen
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 11 (AP)New England colleges and universities have room for at least 15,000 freshmen, according to the New England Board of Higher Education.

title: CUNY Meet Again Won By Queens
description: Joe Gould, a senior, won four events yesterdiy to lead Queens College's track team to its fifth consecutive. City University track championship at its Flushing, Queens, field.

title: Foyt Posts Fastest Time In Indy 500 Qualifying
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May IIRain and a rules controversy today helped A. J. Foyt, a threetime winner of the Indianapolis 500, stake a tentative claim to the pole position for the 58th running of the 500 on May 26.

title: A Swedish Wunderkind In Spotlight
description: DALLAS, May 11I was just thinking, John Newcombe said today, reflecting on the saga of 17yearold Bjorn Borg, he's calling his parents after his wins and I'm calling my children.

title: Dance Canada + Nureyev = S. R. O.
description: WITH four major companies in town, together with a number of fringe events, the dedicated dance enthusiast just could not go right the other week. To see the local premiere of Karen Kain in Giselle at the Metropolitan Opera House meant missing the opening of the Pennsylvania Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Whether you went to the Martha Graham Company in its last week or New York City Ballet in its first week, it still meant you missed something. Talk about an embarassment of riches.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: April 30Nets 89, Utah 85. May 4Nets 118, Utah 94. May 6Nets 103, Utah 100 (o't). May 8Utah 97, New York 89. May 10Nets 111, Utah 100 (Nets won championship series 41).

title: Allen W. Hamill 3d Is Fiance Of Miss Susan Pinkney Foster
description: Raymond C. Foster Jr. has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Pinkney Foster, to Allen William Hamill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamill Jr. of Houston. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mrs. Foster. A wedding in September is planned.

title: ITALIAN CANVASS IRKS PROTESTANTS
description: ROME  An official canvass to obtain information on Protestant churches in Italy has caused an outcry in the Protestant community ever what it terms the Government's police mentality.

title: Poll Shows Impeachment Move Was Backed Before Tranacripts
description: WASHINGTON. May 11A public opinion survey taken a month ago on whether President Nixon should be impeached shows that, even before the, release of the edited transcripts of the President's Watergate conversations, a majority believed, that impeachment proceedings should be begun against Mr. Nixon.

title: The World
description: Leadership in the Atlantic Alliance is undergoing severe tests. France has faced a period of uncertainty since the death of President Pompidou, Britain is still recovering from the labor troubles that brought the downfall of Prime Minister Heath, mid most European nations face the, disturbing pressures of the oil crisis and rampant inflation. There were new shocks last week. West Gertitdn Chancellor Willy Brandt resigned dering a spy scandal, Canada's Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was forced to call a midterm election. In Portugal, the new junta was having difficulty trying to install democracy in a country debilitated by a halfdictatorship.

title: 2 000 Go to Teen Arts Fete
description: TRENTON  Rarely does the New Jersey State Museum become such a hive of activity as it did last week, when it was the scene of the annual State Teen Arts Festival.

title: Amnesty Amendment May Be Attached, to Resolution Restoring Lee's Citizenship
description: WASHINGTON, May 11An obscure move to restore the citizenship of Gen. Robert E. Lee, mired for years in Congress, is suddenly taking on new importance as a potential vehicle for granting amnesty to Vietnam war resisters.

title: JAMES A. COLE
description: James A. Cole, coowner with his wife of the Dornwald German Shepherd Kennels in Pound Ridge, N. Y., died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 74 years old and also lived in New York.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number win $2500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or lest four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win,$25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, The Second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth Win $2.50.

title: Some People Find Inflation Delightful
description: WASHINGTON  Quiz: Name the state in the United States that had the largest increase in per capita personal income last year.

title: An Ambulance for Ailing Cars
description: LEBANONHouse calls by doctors have become almost a thing of the past, but 20yearold Dave Graham of 9 1iigh Street may have started a new trend. He goes to the residences of ailing automobiles.

title: Playing with tops
description: ACROSS

title: Chinese Long Shot Runs For 12 Days, Loses $10,000
description: If Bongung Dong had bet the horses, instead of touting them in an aborted newspaper called The Chinese Racing Daily, he might not have lost $10,000 in two weeks.

title: A Nautical Rolls Royce With StockCar Options
description: The challenge was disarmingly blunt: Design an oceangoing multihull yacht fast enough to compete in the toughest oneman and twoman ocean sailing races. Yet, she must handle easily and provide cruising accommodations for four to six persons when not racing.

title: POLICE CHIEF FIGHTS FOR JOB IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, May 11  Police Chief John Inman is preparing a court fight to retain his job while Mayor Maynard Jackson makes it clear that he no longer wants him as the top administrator for the department.

title: Osteopathic Group To Hold Meeting
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Association of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons will hold its 73d Annual convention in Pittsburgh from Thursday through next Sunday. Some 1,500 persons associated with the osteopathic profession are expected to attend a series of business sessions and clinical lectures at the Pittsburgh Hilton. Hotel, according to Dr. Michael Sutula of Union, president of the association.

title: Church Membership Is Shown in New Map
description: The most comprehensive countybycounty survey of church membership in the United States two decades was made public last week, and included a large color map showing what amounts to a detailed Christian geography of the nation. Compared to a similar study two decades ago, the current report showed that the percentage of church membership grew from 45.8 per cent of the piipulation to 49.6 per cent in 1971.

title: Contrast Marks Vote in 2 Cities
description: NEWARK  Mayor Kenneth A., Gibson's bid for reelection here, plus balloting that will establish a new, form of government in Paterson, are the focal points of several municipal elections on Tuesday.

title: A Classic Case of HighPowered Lobbying
description: ALBANYThis is the story of how to paraphrase the civics textbooks a bill did not become a law.

title: Girl Furnishes Lilliputian World
description: PARAMUS  The handiwork of a local 13yearold girl is gathering crowds at display booths at many of the flea markets and antique shows in this area.

title: Maria Braden, A.P. Reporter, Is Bride of Joseph Henry Clark
description: Miss Maria Braden, a reporter with The Associated Press in Lexington, Ky. was married here yesterday afternoon to Joseph Henry Clark, who is with Scruggs & Hammond, Inc., landscape architects and planning consultants in Lexington. He is a son of Mrs. Arvil Clark of Paducah, Ky., and the late Mr. Clark.

title: An adult in a child's world
description: If The Story of Harold has In it a space that remains unfilled, one may still say these rare things of it: it is cleanly original; it is engrossing vertically and on its surface; it has imagination to spare; it is sometimes very funny; and, in its naturalseeming, storytelling way, it is about almost everything important that goes on between people. I can't remember ever reading a novel with so serious a flaw that I enjoyed so fully.

title: Congressional Unit In State Designates Saltzman as Unifier
description: New May 9The New York State Congressional delegation, in a characteristically divided action, selected New York City businessman today to promote delegation unity.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Young
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harrison Hurst Young Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ruth Young, to Paul Martin Deringer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Watts Deringer of Allentown, Pa. Mr. Deringer and his fiance plan to be married Sept. 7 in All Saints Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: Mom, Dad Call Miss Kuykendall's Shots
description: Kathy Kuykendall isn't the youngest professional athlete in the country, but she's the only fulltime pro who is accompanied, year round, by her parents. In fact, Kathy's father, W. J. Kuykendall, gave up his, job in Houston, and her mother, Anna, retired from teaching tennis so that they wouldn't miss a stroke when Kathy joined the women's professional tennis tour last year at the age of 16.

title: Gage Does 221 In Hammer Throw
description: FRESNO, Calif., May 11 (UPI)Tom Gage of the New York Athletic Club beat the defending hemmer throw champion, George Frenn, with a heave of 221 feet 5 inches today in the 47th annual West Coast Relayi.

title: Fashion
description: The camisole craze hit the beaches of St. Tropez last summer; this summer it will be beside the pool, on the terrace in the moonlight from Nantucket to Monterey. Camisoles as fashion range from tops to be worn with long, full skirts to just a hint of the shape in camisolebare evening dresses. But fashion's joke on itself is that camisoles are, once again, being sold as underwear. A little warm, perhaps, but greatgrandmother would have approved.

title: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries, into some unfinished news events.
description: Last summer, a law took effect in Arizona banning smoking in most indoor public places and providing for fines of up to $100 for violators.

title: Door Again Slams Shut on Housing
description: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP

title: Stuart, Wilbur, Charlotte: A Tale of Tales
description: Stuart Little is small in size only, has the adventurousness, the great purpose and the indomitable spirit of a classic figure, and his story, funny and tender and exciting by turns, will be read, reread, and loved by young and old.

title: A Few Signs of Spring and Other Good News
description: FOLLOWUP on two items for those who, tell us we leave our readers hanging on precipices: In New Orleans, the moratorium on destruction of old buildings in the central business district was passed by the City Council five to two, with a good saucing of lively local politics.

title: Last of the .400 hitters
description: ?? admirable were the ball suspended from a string. But here's a ball humming at him at 90 miles an hour, very much like a bullet, and he's 42 years old, and craack! Reality manifest: all of the world compressed and exploding. The flight of the ball was effect, the running of the bases consequence, but all that would be done was done in that instant, the event entire. That ball was, as they say, gone. And so was Ted Williams.

title: Institute Planned. On Social Studies
description: NEW BRUNSWICK New Jersey socialstudy teachers and supervisers will have an opportunity to use new high school materials in anthropology, geography and sociology through a National Science Foundation institute at Rutgers University.

title: Veronica Mallory, Nurse Here, Is Married to Michael B. Stubbs
description: The Old Lyme (Conn.) Congregational Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Veronica Mallory to Michael B. Stubbs, son of Mrs. Merrill Stubbs of Essex, Conn., formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Stubbs.

title: Penal Rights Suit Filed
description: BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI) The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a class action suit charging the Maryland penal institution at Jessup with sex discrimination.

title: Music in Review
description: Listening to Sharon Bennett sing at her debut recital in Town Hall on Monday night was a consistent pleasure. An Eastman School graduate and currently a member of the Hamburg State Opera, Miss Bennett rejoices in a securely focused coloratura soprano of exceptionally pure tonal beauty, a fully developed technique and even a respectable trill.

title: Three Alternate Rail Freight Routes Are Proposed for State
description: NEWARKAn Interstate Commerce Commission planning group is urging the development and improvement of three alternate throughfreight rail routes across New Jersey so that the New YorkWashington mainline trackage can be devoted more and more to highspeed passenger service.

title: Aged in the Wood: The Stave Churches of Rural Norway
description: 0 N a stormy night, lightning flashing among the tombstones, carved, snakes and dragons peering down from the portals, the brooding structure might seem a setting for a Hitchcock film. It is actually church at Heddal, southwest of Oslo, and the largest of the 32 stave churches ]eft of the hupdreds that once dotted the Norwegiah countryside.

title: A master of gorgeous and perverse surprises
description: There was ample reason to expect The Decay of the Angel to be a failure. There was a candid,. suspicion abroad in the West that Yukio Mishima's final work might appear no more than a gesture, a literary ritual as incomprehensible to us as his laststand and certainly grandstand act, committing suicide to stop the rush of history.

title: M.P.Goodbody, Miss Holly Cole Marry in South
description: Miss Holly DuBose Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Norton Cole of Birmingham, Ala., was married in Birmingham yesterday to Michael Pim Goodbody, son of Carl Spitzer Goodbody and Mrs. Erich Gunter Heckes, both of Sarasota, Fla.

title: NO, AMER, SOCCER LEAGUE
description: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE

title: The Dybbuk Is Not Fancy Free
description: WHEN Jerome Robbins and Leonard Bernstein worked on West Side Sory, a modernday variation on Romeo and Juliet, in 1957, there were some who thought it woulet be another Kiss Me, Kate. It was the time of the updated Shakespearean musical.

title: Great Expectations
description: Great Expectations

title: Dining Out in jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and low as superb.

title: James Sturdevant of NBC Cameraman, Dies in Crash
description: HONOLULU, May 11 (AP)James Sturdevant, television news cameraman, was killed in a traffic accident here today. He was 48 years old.

title: Poverty Aide Here Seized as Loan Shark
description: The police said the arrests resulted from tips provided by an associate who said he was kidnapped on April 28 by two of the men and driven to a remote spot near Kennedy International Airport, where they allegedly tried to kill him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Widening rent stabilization. [Point of View by City Councilman Leon A. Katz, April 14] is no strategy for solving the city's housing problems.

title: Tenants In Arverne Get Aid From City
description: The 342 families living in the Arverne limitedprofit housing development on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, threatened with backtoback increases of 25 per cent in the maintenance charges they pay for their apartments, have received a tax abatement from the, city that promises to cut in half the amount they will have to pay this year and next.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Dave Schultz of the Philadelphia Flyers, before his team met the Rangers in the Stanley Cup semifinals, said he hoped it would be the Rangers because they have a reputation for choking in the playoffs.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, MAY 12, 1974
description: International Two American officials flew to the Golan Heights to inspect the area around the town of El Quneitra, in southwest Syria, whose fate has become a major issue in Secretary of State Kissinger's efforts to bring about SyrianIsraeli troop separation agreement. Joseph J. Sisco, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Harold J. Saunders, the National Security Council's expert on Middle East, spent four hours in the El Quneitra area. They were accompanied by Lieut. Gen. Mordechai Gur, the Israeli chief of staff, who has strongly argued on security grounds against the return to Syria of the three hills surrounding El Quneitra, which is now ghost town. [1:1.]

title: II Boom
description: To achieve It Boom, the silk workers of Rimaldi, a tiny Piedmontese village, have first to experience Ii Bust. This seems ominously possible when the Silkworms are attacked by a dysfunction that cancels their output. But it becomes inevitable when the villagers are afflicted with a social anthropologist on a foundation grant. D. S. Roggenbuck descends on Rimaldi for a sixweek blitz to study the mechanism of productive and counterproductive forces; and the dynamics of interpersonal relationships and group pressures during a period of severe tension in the life of a rural community. During his catastrophic stay in the field, Roggenbuck unbalances every interpersonal and intracultural relationship in the ancient village, which he sees as a type of Middletownintransition. The anthropologist's hip daughter, Janine, is in closer harmony with the ancient vibes than her dad, but she is outnumbered. The Topkinses tell the Rimaldi story with wry humor tinged with pessimism. As the town's stanchest, conserver of ritual and custom says, before he drops dead: It is bad to let the world in. After the cottage industry comes the Colonel Sanders franchise.

title: HAL MOHR, WINNER OF 2 OSCARS, DIES
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 11 (AP)  Hal Mohr, a cinematographer who made the first sound film, The Jazz Singer, starring AI Jolson, died yesterday at a hospital here, He was 79 years old.

title: The Republican
description: NEW YORKJust 18 month'sagb, even the liberal Eastern Republican establishment was only too willing to forget any antagonism to Richard NiXon and latch on to his coattails in the 1972 elections. In this year's elections, the reaction to the President among Republicans from Maine to New Jersey is shaping up as Richard Who?

title: New Housing for Brooklyn
description: Construction of a 991unit housing complex, considered by political and civic leaders to be a major component in the revitalization of the downtown Brooklyn area, should begin this summer, the state's Urban Development Corporation said last week.

title: COLUMBIA U. MAKES JOURNALISM AWARDS
description: Tom Stundza, a reporter for The Gary (Ind.) PostTribune, has been named the recipient of Columbia University's 1924 Paul Tobenkin Memorial Award for a series of articles on discrimination in the Gary community.

title: Soviet Assails U.S. On Water Report; Denies Health Peril
description: MOSCOW, May 11A Soviet health official has attacked as deliberate slander American reports that some tourists had picked up intestinal parasites from drinking Russian tap water.

title: Penn Wins Heptagonal Track Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11Nine meet records were broken and one was equaled as the University of Pennsylvania won its fourth consecutive Heptagonal outdoor track championship today on warm, sunny Franklin Field. Penn scored 84 points to runnerup Navy's 79.

title: Numismatics
description: LL signs seem to point to a continuation of the steady, sometimes spectacular, upward spiral of interest in foreign coin collecting. ReOorts appealing in this space over the last year or so have charted this spiral in terms of dollars  everincreasing amounts of dollarsspent at major auctions by collectors (in some cases, investors would be a more apt term) Who unhesitatingly pushed prices to new highs in their determination to get items with great pricegrowth potential.

title: Illinois Impeachment Unit Asks Court to Reverse Ban on Its Ads
description: CHICAGO, May 11The Illinois Impeach Nixon Committee asked the United States Supreme Court yesterday to reverse a decision that permits a ban on advertisements callsing for the impeachment of President Nixon. The ban was imposed by the Chicago Transit Authority.

title: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:
Calendar of Motor Sports Events for This Coming Week
description: Volunteer flagmen, who had been helping a driver who spun off the course recently at Lime Rock, Conn., scrambling to safety on hearing a warning whistlemore cars were coming.

title: 2 Feared Dead as Boat Tips at Horseshoe Falls
description: A small outboard motorboat carrying two men capsized in the Niagara River last evening and was swept over Horseshoe Falls.

title: Kenneth Miller, ExEditor On Philadelphia Inquirer
description: LINWOOD, N. J., May 11 (AP) Kenneth Miller, a former assistant managing editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer died yesterday at the Linwood Nursing Home. He was 63 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey state police were searching for four of six inmates who escaped from the Atlantic County Jail in Mays Landing by cutting through bars and crawling out an air duct: Two of the six, Men were captured within hours of the breakout Friday. According to Undersheriff Edward F. Cartier, the inmates all were awaiting trial for crimes ranging froin armed robbery to murder.

title: Train Whistle Guitar
description: A fundatitental point of departure for evaluating Albert Murrays first published novel, Train Whistle Guitar, is to place it in the context of a continuing national debate on the quality of Negro lifein Americi In his books of nonfiction, Murray castigates the very terms of the debate since on one side are documents such as The Moynihan Report and Stanley Elkinss Sambo thesis, which claim black culture and family lifeeither don't exist or that they are negative, even pathological when measured against the middleclass, mainstream norms these social Scientisternanufacture from their statistics. The counter arguments to this view are selfdefeating hepause usually they are Couched in the same socioloffical abstractions and therefore, never get to the rbot of the issue. Murray will accept the findings of neither side because he knows better than to believe in the dehumanized stereotype produced by these lines of reasoning. Train Whistle Guitar, in one sense, is ainagnificent rebuttal to these views; in it Murray evokes his climatic sense of life: as against the tennhiological abstractions and categories derived from procedures.

title: Navy Plans'to Trim Jobs Of 482 Civilians Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Navy says that by June, 1975, it will eliminate the jobs Of 482 civilians in various headquarters around the world and transfer 572 military positions to ships and aircraft units that it says are undenstrength.

title: Conference Planned On Pharmaceuticals
description: Conference Planned On Pharmaceuticals

title: Not only is boxing suicidal, it is murderous.
description: A louseridden and neglected vagrant died a few months after he was found huddled against a hotel boiler. He had been a worldchampion boxer.

title: Mexico Out to Get Tax Dodgers And End Tradition of Evasion
description: MEXICO CITY.The Mexican Government is campaigning to stamp out one of the country's oldest and most respected traditionstax evasion. We started with propaganda to create a tax consciousness in the, country, a senior official said. Now we're applying pressure and eventually we'll have to send some people to jail. In posters, films and radio and television advertisements, the Government is trying to convince Mexicans that the country's development depends on the proper payment of taxes. God gives us water, one advertisement proclaims, but He doesn't put it in pipes.

title: Publishers Tell I.T.U. Dispute Can Be Resolved by Negrotiations
description: Spokesmen for The Daily News and The New York Times told officers of the International Typographical Union yesterday that they believed their work stoppage contract dispute with local printers could be resolved through negotiation rather than continuing confrontation.

title: WEICKER WEIGHTS 4 FOR U.S. ATTORNEY
description: HARTFORD, May 11  A special Federal Attorney, a Federal, public defender and two lawyers in private practice are under consideration for nomination as United States Attorney in Connecticut, according to Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: Democrats in Nebraska Battle Over Second Place on Ticket
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 11A bitter fight over the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor in the Nebraska primary election Tuesday could affect the national political future of Gov. J. J. Exon, a conservative Democrat who seems certain to win the party's nomination for a second twoyear term.

title: Goldie Ahearn, 75, Is Dead; An Early Boxing Promoter
description: OLNEY, Md., May 11 (UPI)Goldie Ahearn, a wellknown sports promoter, died today at the age of 75 of a heart attack.

title: Eleanor Toby, R. G. Gundeck Have Nuptials
description: Miss Eleanor McNeal Toby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Toby of Greenwich, Conn., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard George Gundeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gundeck, also of Greenwich.

title: Gardens
description: REMEMBER last spring when the price of gold jumped to $128 an ounce? Not having much gold on hand at the time, that didn't bother me a bit.

title: Bette, Syrop Betrothed
description: Mrs. William Syrop of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bette M. Syrop, to Barry A. Sheiber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Sheiber of Brooklyn. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Syrop.

title: REVIEW IS SOUGHT ROSENBERG CASE
description: A committee to reopen the Rosenberg case, composed of persons who contend that Ethel and Julius Rosenberg were unjustly convicted and executed for Soviet espionage in 1953, is being formed here.

title: Aerial Spraying Fought On Island
description: NORTHPORTFinal preparations by the state for the aerial spraying of thousands of acres of land in Suffolk County with the insecticide Sevin are moving forward amid opposition to the program on Long Island.

title: British Football
description: International Matches

title: AROUND THE
description: Before all the bulb flowers fade, take notes and score the spring's display. If there were some color combinations and varieties that pleased, make a note to grow them again.

title: Headliners
description: Ramsey, Clark has announced that he will seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New York. His campaign will test not only his personal appeal but also how well he can finance a campaign based on severely restricted indhcidual contributions. It could be tough going. By accepting only contributions of $100 or less, Mr. Clark says he hopes to raise $500,000 before the September primary. At this early date, donations total more than $66,000. Of this, $22,000 came in response to newspaper ads and the rest to letters and fundraising gatherings. Past Senatorial contenders have spent as little as $30,000 but as much as $1million before primary day. Mr. Clark says that even if he doesn't reach his fiscal goal he will stay in the race. If he does, he will have to defeat at least former Rep.Allard Lowenstein; and if he does that, he will face incumbent Republican Jacob Javits.

title: Bergen 4H Clubs Plan Animal Show
description: PARAMUS  Bergen County 4H Clubs, in conjunction with the Mad Menagerie 4H Club, will hold their third spring Rabbit and Cavy (guinea pig) Show at 254 Concord Drive on May 25. The show will be open to all youngsters, regardless whether or not they are 4H members.

title: Disputed Measure On Abortion Advances
description: three months of pregnancy.

title: Wesselmann: The Mockery Has Disappeared
description: THE three early works by Tom Wesselmann in the Whitney reprise of Pop art are, in that context, rather comely. They are brightly painted tableaux mimicking the interior of the Average American Home, as dictated by the media. Though not large by present standards, the most ambitious of them is about 8 feet by 7 feet and projects some 4 feet from the wall. Some of the furniture and such significant accessories as toilet paper and telephones are real, whereas the female inhabitants are little more than silhouettes.

title: Peter Boggs to Wed Gail McPherson
description: Miss Gail McPherson, a greatgranddaughter of AndrewCarnegie, the industrialist and philanthropist, plans to be married Aug. 3 to Peter Lavison Boggs, who was a fellow student at Washington College: in Chestertown, Md.

title: TIGHT SUPERVISION IS SET IN ELECTION
description: There will be special police details keeping order, some deputy state attorneys general, a team of community relations workers from the United States Department of Justice, and a State Supreme Court justice standing by to adjudicate in case of dispute.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR long decades, until 1972, the American harvest was taken for granted, a routine affair that stirred little political or economic interest. Often it was harvest of inconvenience, an unwanted abundance of wheat or corn or soybeans, subsidized, stored and eventually sold at cutrate prices to underdeveloped and needy nations like India.

title: Vive le France
description: To give you an idea of the size of the France, a ship's officer said, it is the only ship in the world where you can travel with your wife and your mistress with the assurance that they will never meet.

title: War and Effervescence
description: FALAISE, FranceIt is years since there has been so much political effervescence and uncertainty in the West. At the start of 1973 the North Atlantic world seemed to be progressing under firm and sensible leadership. Now this illusion has been swept away.

description: ROMEThe Italians vote today on whether to repeal their divorce statute. In the referendum, they will be coming to grips with the fundamentals of their society.

title: SAMUELS BACKED BY COALITION VOTE
description: The New Democratic Coalition endorsed Howard J. Samuels for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination yesterday in the first test of strength in the race.

title: Harvard Crew Wins Sprint Decisively
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 11  Alan Wardwell Shealy, the stroke oar and the catalyst of the Harvard varsity crew, was in a mean mood as his shell lined up for the start of the Eastern sprint championship on Lake Quinsigamond at 5:15 this afternoon. We resolved we were going to blow them out of the water, Shealy said later. And the Harvard boat did.

title: Tennis Stars Enjoying Cadillacs, Bank Accounts
description: DALLAS; May 11  The eight Cadillacs were lined up in front of the Ramada Inn in a splashy show of luxury, like oil wells advertising wealth.

title: N.Y.A.C. Is Upset By Undine Crew
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 11The Undine Barge Club of Philadelphia upset the. New York A.C. in the intermediate four with coxswain event of the Knickerbocker regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach Lagoon today, The Schuylkill River crew was stroked by Phil Healey of Haverford School. Undine led from the start although Frank Pisani, the New York A.C. stroke, was off the line at 40.

title: BIAS A KEY TOPIC IN NEW ZEALAND
description: AUCKLAND, New ZealandBeneath a blackboard with homily for the day and the Ten Commandments in a whitewashed clapboard church hall in Ponsonby, one of the poorest suburbs of Auckland, New Zealand's largest city, members of the Polynesian Panther party meet regularly to plot revolution.

title: ARMS RACE SEEN IN INDIAN OCEAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 11 (Reuters)  Plans to convert Britain's Indian Ocean island of Diego, Garcia into a fullfledged United States naval and air base will almost certainly prompt the Soviet Union to seek a similar installation in the area, a panel of United Nation appointed experts on military issues warned yesterday. It foresaw another arms race as a result.

title: Expos Defeat Cards, 31, On Bailey's 2Run Homer
description: MONTREAL, May 11 (UPI) Bob Bailey clouted a tworun homer and Steve Renko completed his first game of the season today as the Montreal Expos defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 31, in a nationally televised game.

title: Colombia Hijacking Ends; One of Gunmen Is Killed
description: BOGOTA, COLOMBIA, May 111 (UN)  Policemen and a pilot throwing karate chops today captured three hijackers who had commandeered an Avianca Airlines Boeing 727 jet And took it on an erratic 19hour journey over the Andes, demanding a ransom of $400,000.

title: U.S. and West Germany Sign EnvironmentalControl Pact
description: BONN, May 11 (UPI)West Germany and the United States have signed an agreement expanding cooperation in environmental control.

title: ExGov. Ogilvie to Aid Percy
description: CHICAGO, May 11 (UPI) Former Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie was named today by Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, to a key post on a committee that will help decide whether the Senator runs for President in 1976.

title: 96th Street Development Set

title: Pro Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (AL)Lost Angel Marmoset, second basemen, for three Months with torn cartilage In left knee.

title: The Welcome Migrants
description: The migrant birds come back from the South and our mornings are full of song. The migrants are in our dooryards, our meadows, our parks and woodlands, mating, nesting, preparing to raise their broods. Our spring and summer will be full of birds, making life more colorful, more tuneful, less overrun by insects. Next fall, when the frosts have touched the roadsides, they will go south again.

title: Thousands Flock to 9th Ave. Festival
description: Ninth Avenue blossomed yesterday with food stalls, handcraft bazaars, big crowds and burgeoning pride for the weekend celebration of its culinary and cultural diversity.

title: The Interior Decorator Who Missed Her Calling
description: This is really the story of poor little Dutch girl who comes to America to manyher fiance, is jilted by him and, by dint Of talent and hard work, becomes a famous interior decorator and the author of the largestselling original paperback book ever published.

title: A Bronx Owner Finds Fuel Costs Dashing His Hopes
description: How much am I worth?

title: A Troubled Morristown Assays Clash at School
description: MORRISTOWN  Students, parents and faculty members attribute last week's disorders at Morristown High School to a variety of shortcomings ranging from racial tensions and inadequate class schedules to a lack of discipline and overcrowding.

title: Andrea Schick Engaged
description: Jerome Schick of Upper Montclair, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Andrea Orin Schick, to William Paul Saks of Caldwell, N. J., son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Sacks of Morris Plains, N. J. The future bridegroom changed his surname. Miss Schick is the daughter also of the late Mrs. Schick. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyde Wins Marathon
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., May 11 (AP)Peter Hyde, 20 years old, of Sparta, N.J., won the Chamberlain Valley marathon today in 2 hours 22 minutes 45 seconds. Hyde is a student at Williams College, Williamstown, Mass.

title: Paperbacks Of the Month
description: Last year Kurt Vonnegut celebrated his 50th birthday with this giant brainwash, clearing his head by throwing out acquired ideas and, in the course of it, liberating characters from some of his previous books (Slaughterhouse Five, Mother Night, and so it goes). His object in Breakfast of Champions was to tell of the final collapse of Dwayne Hoover, a rich Pontiac dealer who goes berserk in late middle age, shooting up everyone and everything in sight, including his own son. This he accomplishes with a sharp eye for contemporary lunacies and the style of a writer who can make despair hilarious. An explosive meditation, Nora Sayre called it, that ranks with Vonnegut's best.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Daylight Saving Time
description: ZIM NEW YORK (Zim), Barcelona May 23; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

description: The official record of stark abuse in the exercise of Presidential power has brought forth its first concrete legislative response: a bill introduced in the Senate halt the arbitrary use of a national security pretext for invasion of privacy.

description: Jim Slaton, the easygoing righthander who at the end of last season was considered the Brewers most improved pitcher, evidently continues to improve.

title: Photography
description: ONE thing that Ansel Adams, Richard Avedon and Aaron Siskind have in common is that all three are virtuoso performers with the camera. That is about the only thing they have in common, except the pure accident that all three are currently having exhibitions in New York.

title: AcidBurning Plan Shifted
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 11 (UPI) The Air Force anjounced yesterday that it had decided to destroy 2.3 million gallons of herbicide orange, an acid, at a remote site rather, than to burn it in the United States as originally proposed.

title: Letters: A Demand For Singles. Power
description: I write this letter as a single individual who enjoys traveling and objects to the single supplement, charge. This supplement, at times, makes the cost J.:of a room for two people the same es for one.

title: Music: Imago Mundi
description: During the Baltimdre Symphony's playing of George Rochberg's Imago Mundi at Carnegie Hall Friday night, this listener's thoughts kept darting back to a performance given by the New York City Ballet in the spring of 1963. That performance was the premiere of Bugaku, a ballet with choreography by George Balanchine and music by Toshiro Mayuzumi.

title: Sea Data Gathered for Floating Atoum Plant
description: NEWARK  The Nuclear Age is showing its face more and more these days along parts of the South Jersey coast.

title: The Change of Government in Portugal Awakens Fears, and All of Africa Is Watching
description: LOURENCO MARQUESAfter nearly a century of dormancy enforced by Portugal's dictatorship, the 300,000 squaremile territory of Mozambique Is abruptly beginning to change, like the chrysalis of some obscure African insect. And the whole of Africa, southern Africa especially, is waiting anxiously to see what will hatch.

description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1 P.M.

The Mets begin a sevenday home stand with Friday's game. WORTV (Channel 9) will televise both games while WHN radio (1050) will carry the playbyplay.

title: Wallace Is Fighting to Control Party
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11 The illusion of harmony between Gov. George C. Wallace and his old foes, in the loyalist wing of the state Democratic Executive Committee, evaporated this week when it became clear that each side was still competing for control of the state party machinery.

description: Any suggestion that some form of amalganiation between the American and National Basketball Associations is imminent, or closer than it has been, is not realistic, according to Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the N.B.A.

description: GLASSBOROLike many of the 12,000 students who attend the state college here, Joe and his friend, Ed King, don blue jeans every morning and journey to class.

title: Dignified Bicentennial Sought
description: TRENTON Alarmed by the prospect of New Jersey being inundated with commercial souvenirs that attempt to exploit the state's observance of the national bicentennial, the New Jersey Bicentennial Celebration Commission has adopted a firm policy against what it regards as exploitation of the country's 200th birthday.

title: Hawaiians Phone Early to Mothers Because of Strike
description: HONOLULU, May 11Mother's Day came early to Hawaii because of a telephone strike.

title: Poverty Agency Closing
description: DETROIT  An air of anxiety and bitterness hangs over this city's antipoverty agency as it grinds slowly to a halt.

title: Subtle Performance Of Modern Works By New Arts Group
description: Perhaps the performance of 20thcentury music is not so badly off, considering the proliferation of chamber groups presently devoting themselves to the cause. The New Arts Ensemble, which played in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night, is a relatively new group now in its third season, six young Eastman School graduates currently in residence at Belknap College in New Hampshire.

title: Flamboyant Nassau District Attorney Enjoys Limelight
description: MINEOLA, L.I.Some people call him the Aganot just because his name is Calm, but also because of his long and powerful reign as a District Attorney pledged to keep Nassau County a sanctuary of decency.

title: You will never see anything like that again
description: Between Cannes and New York, on the last leg of her 93day roundtheworld cruise, there was a streaker on the S.S. France. As dignified couples crowded the dance floor in the SaintTropez night club on the evening of April 5, a retired Canadian school teacher shed her blue pants suit and undergarments and ran across the room. Two ship's hostesses gave chase and subdued her. Men in black tie and women in long gowns, having just dined on caviar and tole gras, were doing a sedate twostep as their digestive juices flowed, when the raw shape of the seventies disrupted this timeless scene of shipboard elegance. Like thewitches in Macbeth, the streaker was a premonition, a brief but unequivocal announcement that the age of the ocean liner was past and the France's glory days were numbered.

title: Mrs. de Brossard Wed to E. L Cave
description: Mrs. Pauline Winn de Brossard of New York and Brookville, L. I., was married at home here yesterday to Edward Lee Cave, senior vice president of Sotheby Parke Bernet. The noon ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dennis Wagner of the Park Avenue Methodist Church.

title: Manhattan Takes Triangular Track
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 12  Jim Nathaniel, a freshman, won three events and anchored the winning 440yard relay team to help Manhattan defeat Rutgers and Fairleigh Dickinson in a track meet at Rutgers Stadium. The Jaspers had 115 points while the Scarlet scored 76 and F.D.U. 9.

description: Mrs. Laura Smith Oliver, widow of George S. Oliver who was copublisher of two Pittsburgh newspapers, The GazetteTimes and The ChronicleTelegraph, died yesterday in Rosemont, Pa., where she had been living. She was 90 years old.

title: Conference Urges Governments to Act On World Problems
description: After six days of deliberating the world's most pressing environmental and social problems, a conference of about 60 leading scientists, legal scholars and economists has concluded that their first task is not so much to find specific technological solutions as it is to figure out ways to mobilize the world to take action.

title: ISRAELI COALITION LIKELY THIS WEEK
description: JERUSALEM, May 12Labor Minister Yitzhak Rabin is expected to complete negotiations this week on the formation of a new coalition government embracing two smaller parties that would give him a narrow majority, with 61 seats in Israel's 120seat Parliament.

title: Guider
description: JUST PLAIN ANDY At the end of the 19th century, Andrew Carnegie, one of the world's richest men, wanted a home that was the most modest, plainest and most roomy house in New York. He got it. The Carnegie mansion, on Fifth Avenue at 91St Street, was completed in 1903 with 64 rooms, three basement levels, four stories, airconditioning  and  purified water. There, the steel magnate could and, did entertain those types the rich entertain: American Presidents, Mark Twain; Rudyard Kipling, Ignace Jan Paderewski, Marie Curie and Booker T. Washington.

title: Women Who Want Important Campaign Roles
description: Drop by any campaign headquarters and you'll see them stuffing envelopes, typing letters, answering phones and carrying coffee cups.

title: Cincinnati's MayorElect Quits In Federal Investigation of Vice
description: CINCINNATI, May 12  The City Council has finally accepted the resignation of Gerald N. Springer, 30 years old, who was to have become Mayor of Cincinnati on Dec. 1

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said in Damascus that he and Syrian leaders had gone from the general to a detailed and cornplete examination of all issues in a SyrianIsraeli agreement on troop separation, but that an accord still eluded them. Although he has narrowed the difference between. Syria and Israel during his 15 days in the Middle East, the unresolved issues may prove too formidable in the period Me: Kissinger has allotted himself for achieving the agreementroughly this week. [1:8.]

title: Horowitz Plays Again, Flabbergastingly
description: CLEVELAND, May 12Why, you'd never think he was 69he plays like a 20yearold, a woman in the audience remarked during Vladimir Horowitz's recital here this afternoon. One would have liked to ask the awed listener precisely which 20yearold she had in mind. Mr. Horowitz, making another of the returns to the recital stage for which he has become renowned, put on a typically flabbergasting Horowitzian show, in which there were many moments that perhaps no living pianist could equal.

title: American Film Festival Opens at Hilton Tomorrow
description: The 16th annual American Film Festival, the largest regularly held convocation of nontheatrical movies in the world, will begin sessions tomorrow at the New York Hilton. Sponsored by the Educational Film Library Association, the fiveday program will be attended by film makers, distributors and educators in the audiovisual field.

title: Governor of Puerto Rico Savs the Ills of South Bronx Wasteland Spread to His Island
description: Puerto Rico's Governor has reported to more than 20 United States foundations that the continuing twoway flow of Puerto Ricans means that the island's problems cannot ultimately be resolved without the solution of some of the problems of, for example, the South Bronx.

title: Jo Ann Prentice Is Victor in Golf
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 12 (AP)  Heavy rain caused cancellation of the final round of the American Defender golf classic today and Jo Ann Prentice was declared the winner with a sevenunderpar 137 for 36 holes.

title: City's Correction Chief Asserts He Lacks Power to Name Aides
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm said yesterday that, under Mayor Beanie, he did not have the power to select his own top personnel and that this policy had created a difficult situation for him in his department.

title: Stage: Grand Musical
description: Op the heels of a brilliant Bloomers, the uptown Equity Library Theater is closing its season with Man With a Load of Mischief, an almost unflawed English rose of a musical. Somebody should pin one on the door of the theater, on 103d Street at Riverside Drive (CH 4.1482). For that matter, a law should be passed that this delectable show, which played Off Broadway seven years ago, should run at least all summer.

title: Red Smith
description: The man the police found lying in a Brooklyn street was registered simply as unknown derelict in emergency in Kings County Hospital. When Charles Gellman heard about that, he felt like punching somebody. In the nineteenthirties, Doc Gellman punched people for pay under the name of Chuck Halper, but now he is executive director of Jewish Memorial Hospital at Broadway and 196th Street. Now instead of punching somebody, he called his friend, the director at Kings County. I want him over here, said. If he's able to make it by taxi, I'll pay for the cab. Otherwise I'll send an ambulance.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Sri Lanka, Short of Food, Faces an Economic Crisis
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 6  At dawn hundreds of people wait in bread lines. Elderly men and women pick through garbage. Thieves harvest vegetables and rice in the countryside.

title: ERVIN TO ASK DELAY IN REPORT BY PANEL
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 12 (UPI)  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that he planned to ask the Senate Watergate, committee, of which he is chairman, to delay its report to the (full Senate until impeachment proceedings are completed by the Congress.

title: City Is Mending Streets and Brightening 6th Ave.
description: The greening of Sixth Avenue? Skeptics may snort, but that's how the city's Transportation Administration describes its ambitious renewal program between Canal and West Fourth Streets on a milelong stretch of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue).

title: Storm Causes Flooding And Power Disruptions
description: A storm moving across the metropolitan area last eveting dumped;more than half an inch of rain on the city and caused some flooding and power disruptions in the suburbs.

description: ATHENS, May 12(Reuters)Former Vice President Agnew arrived here today for a private visit to Greece.

title: Jewish Women Urged To Press Family Role
description: Fifteen hundred Orthodox Jewish women, ending their 9.9th annual convention yestpfday in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, heard Calls for the strengthening of the family unit as the foundalion of Jewish religious life.

title: Helping Millions
description: The United Fund of Greater New York is conducting its sixth annual appeal among companies, labor unions and government agen, cies and the people who work for them. Their contributions to the United Fund will benefit 425 agencies whose services help nearly four million people annually. Recently compiled statistics project the number of peciple that seek aid from United Fund agencies. For example, 1,298,424 persons are treated in United Fund hospitals, convalescent homes and institutions for chronic illnessi and 1,144,551 persons avail themselves of United Fund neighborhood houses, clubs and summer camp facilities.

title: Liberals Astray
description: By the time that the LaFolletteMonroney Legislative Reorganization Act passed Congress in 1946, it had been the subject of intense public controversy and of innumerable articles and editorials. For more than a year now, a committee of ten House members drawn equally from both parties has been at work on a reform proposal thatso far as the House of Representatives is concernedwould be as far reaching and as desirable as the LaFolletteMonroney Act. But in a Congress and nation preoccupied with Watergate, this committee has done its work silently and unnoticed.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 12Matt Bolger, the Rutgers baseball coach, was settling down to watch Rutgers play Colgate in football last November. Suddenly, at the opening kickoff, it happened, and Bolger thought to himself: There goes the baseball season.

title: THOMAS MLEOD, HEADED STERN'S
description: Thomas W. MacLeod, former president of the Stern Brothers department store and civic and Charity leader here, died Saturday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was J75 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: PETER HILTON
description: Peter Hilton, president of Corporate Diversification, Ltd., business consultants, and for many years head of the Hilton & Riggio advertising agency, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and Dorset, Vt.

title: Beaths
description: BALDWINLeslie A., at Greenwich, Conn., May 10, 1974, husband of Abbie Fairchild Baldwin and father of Mrs. Walter Pierson, Jr. and Mrs. Edward H. Morgan, Funeral and interment private.

title: Walk, Steal and Single Top Nets
description: CHICAGO, May 12When they look back on it, the New York Mets may decide that they achieved, only a couple of tiny things in icecold Wrigley Field this afternoon: On a spot check by the umpires, they confirmed that the pitching mound was 10 inches above the ground, where it belongs. And Willie Mays got in some batting practice for his appearances this summer in oldtimers games.

title: Aeros Beat Cougars to Lead by 10
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)Prank Hughes's unassisted goal at 15 minutes 48 seconds of the third period gave the Houston Aeros a 32 victory over the Chicago Cougars in the opening game of the final World Hockey Association playoffs tonight.

title: CABLE UNIT HITS INCBSTV REPORT
description: The National Cable Television Association, in a formal complaint to the Federal Communications Commission, has charged WCBSTV, New York, with violating the fairness doctrine when it broadcast a report on a speech that was critical of payTV by cable and then denied the cable interests a chance to reply.

title: China Says South KoreanS Attackedm Her Fishing Boats
description: HONG. KONG, May 12 (UPI) China charged today that South Korean fishing vessels had intruded into her territorial waters and rammed Chinese fishing boats operating in the East China Sea:

title: Franklin National Moves To Assure Its Liquidity
description: The Franklin National Bank, one of New York's major comnercial banks, received a pledge of financial support from the Federal Reserve System yesterday and announced a series of proposed actions of its own to bolster its financial position.

title: Dissident Periodical Is Revived in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 12  The (Chronicle of Current Events the underground newsletter that was once the focal point of the Soviet dissident movement, ha: been revived here 18 months after a crackdown by the secret police forced it to halt publics, Ition.

title: A Time to Celebrate
description: Looking back now on Brown v. Board of Education, we know that in just twenty years we have become different country. Chief Justice Warren's opinion is the voice of a simpler age; when we had faith in the uplifting power of education and social reform. We have been bruised by experience since then, and we understand that the issues of race and pov:eity are much more complicated, more intractable, than we imagined.

title: TV: MiniDocumentaries From ABC
description: Last night on the American Broadcasting. Company, immediately following Part 1 of the film Ice Station Zebra, Sarah Vaughn began singing, and the television scene shifted to a quietly effective minidocumentary on black female singers. The presentation was part of a series called Americans All, one of the more interesting innovations in commercial programing this last season. The series is under the aegis of ABC News and is produced and directed by Howard Enders. Its purpose is to describe the contributions of ethnic and racial minorities to American culture. The treatments vary in length, up to 18 minutes, depending on how far the preceding program falls short of the next hourly mark. The arrangement has obvious advantages. Wirees the network from having to stuff films and plays into time slots that end precisely on the hour or halfhour. At the same time, the network wins, Brownie points for public affairs. And the mass audience, which generally has kept tuned in for the minidocumentaries, gets some valuable information about the world outside its Windows.

title: Books of The Times
description: ELIZABETH ALONE. By William Trevor. 336 pates. Viking. $7.95.

title: Morristown High Reopens Today, Guarded by Police
description: Policemen will be patrolling the halls today as regularly scheduled classes resume at Morristown High School, the scene of racial disturbances last week. School officials foresee an excellent climate for the reopening.

title: BUSINESS INPUT ON TRADE SOUGHT White. House, on Assumption Bill Will Pass, Plans Elaborate Network NEARLY 600 INVOLVED Businessmen Will Get Calls in Advance of Any Talks on Lifting World Barriers
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Almost 600 businessmen will be receiving telephone calls from the Government this week to confirm or request their willingness to be part of an elaborate new network of governmentindustry relations in advance of negotiations with other countries on trade barriers.

title: Proposal for Human Colonies in Space Is Hailed by Scientists as Feasible Now
description: A conference of physicists, astronauts and space flight technologists discussed last week the likelihood that it is now possible and, in fact, desirable to establish selfsufficient human colonies in space.

He walked 27,153 meters in two hours and then went on to break the 30kilometer record with a time of 2 hours 12 minutes 58 seconds.

It's a daydreamer's kind of view, for soon the trees blur into a background that hosts the images of the mind. And Dr. Singer is a daydreamer, always has been.

description: Ma Bell will offer $500million of debentures this week, and the triple Arated undertaking will be watched closely for clues to the course of rates. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company offering is expected Thursday.

title: About New York
description: He sat in his office, eyes hooded, skin the color of a walnut, looking remarkably like David Frye's impression of President Nixon. Some people insist he is the worst guy in town, but across the room was a photograph. To Roy, With Prayerful Good Wishes  Terence Cardinal Cooke, it said on it, and nearby were all the old plaques, testimonials and photographs. In one, he whispered into Joe McCarthy's ear, while the late Senator, his hand across his mouth, respectfully listened. He was Roy M. Cohn, of course, and as always he was busy. Once, the old plaques say, he was the scourge of Godless Communism, and a defender of the American way of life. Now, although he is an enrolled Democrat, he may be the Conservative candidate for District Attorney, or perhaps even Senator. Mr. Cohn has always thought big.

title: Miss Furtseva Off a Soviet List; Questions Raised on Her Future
description: MOSCOW, May 12  Yekaterina A. Furtseva, Minister of Culture and politically the most prominent woman in the Soviet Union, has apparently been passed over for renomination to the Supreme Soviet.

title: Anthony Imperiale

title: Screen: Pale Flower' Proves Triumph of Style
description: To see one of Masahiro Shinoda's films, it seems, is to bear witness to a triumph of style over substance. Whether it is one of the director's samurai films, such as "the Assassin" or "Sasuke Against the Wind," which played here last year, or one of the yakuza  gangster filmssuch as "Pale Flower," which opened yesterday at the Regency Theater, the result is the same.One comes away with the memory of a well-defined pictorial style, moody, black and white, given to depicting people in the shadowy perimeters around cores of light.The stories are another matter. And "Pale Flower," a 1964 film being shown here for the first time, shares with some of Mr. Shinoda's other works some vexing characters, some unintentional vagueness and a set of subtitles that probably could have been more illuminating."Pale Flower" is an existential work, chiefly occupied with the rather remote relationship between a gangster (Ryo Ikebe) released from prison after serving time for murder and a mysterious young woman (Mariko Kaga), who lives for such kicks as high-stakes gambling, fast driving, drugs and witnessing the murder that sends the gangster back to jail again."Pale Flower" is a film that has been likened to Jean-Luc Godard's memorable "Breathless." At least, it is no more than a pale imitation.

title: Topeka Again Facing Desegregation Battle
description: Twenty years ago the city of Topeka, Kan., gained unwanted fame when it was listed at the head of the five cases grouped under Brown v. Board of Education in the historic desegregation decision.

title: Coalition Backing Enhances Samuels, Unity Theme
description: A typically noisy and untypically harmonious New Democratic Coalition convention in a Manhattan high school last Saturday will unquestionably have significant impact on the race for the Democratic nominations for Governor, United States Senator and other statewide offices. In the gubernatorial race, the endorsement of Howard J. Samuels, coupled with upstate support that he already had, virtually guaranteed him a place on the Sept. 10 primary ballot and enhanced his argument that he has the best chance of unifying the party and heading off a party  splitting primary fight. That has been the principal thrust of Mr. Samuels's appeal to the sofarundeclared Democratic leaders of New York City, Buffalo and Albany who in past campaigkis have been labeled as bosses by Mr. Samuels but who could guarantee his nomination with their support.

title: Original Celtic Formula Works
description: MILWAUKEE, May 12In a series that was so even it went the full seven games, needed overtime twice and shattered the advantage of the home court, one ingredient resurfaced today for the Boston Celtics in their victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

description: PARIS, May 11West German economic policies more favorable to business are being predicted following the resignation of Chancellor Willy Brandt last week and the designation of his successor, Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt.

title: Abortion Advocates Protest
description: CINCINNATI, May 12 (UPI) Wearing masks and feigning pregnancies, 35 advocates of women's liberation staged a protest in favor of abortion for two hours today outside St. Peter in Chains Roman Catholic Cathedral in downtown Cincinnati. The demonstration, which was jeered by persons arriving for mass, was organized by local members of the National Organization for Women to protest a campaign to reverse the United States Supreme Court's decision last wear legalizing abortions.

title: GENERAL IS GRIM ON MOZAMBIQUE
description: NAMPULA, Mozambique, May 12The No. 2 man in Lisbon's junta expressed pessimism tonight about Portugal's ability to hold on to Mozambique.

title: New combe Beats Borg for W.C.T. Title
description: DALLAS, May 12John Newcombe capped a remarkable return to the top with a determined fourset victory over Bjorn Borg today for the $50,000 first prize in the World Championship of Tennis.

title: Fittipaldi Wins 2d Grand Prix

Richardson, who resigned as Attorney General because of a dispute with President Nixon over the Watergate scandal, said today that he thought the chances of Vice President Ford's becoming President before 1976 were a little better than even. Mr. Gibson, the first black to be elected Mayor of a major eastern city, has been described as square, bland, patient and persistent.

title: On Fighting Inflation
description: PHILADELPHIAInflation and unemployment are settling into a repetitive and distressing pattern. Our mixture of public resignation and official ineptitude finds parallels that were once confined to banana republics and underdeveloped countries. The nearfuture outlook remains grim: more unemployment, more inflation, An escalating stagflation confronts us. Despite labor's restraint, the current wage pace of more than 7 per cent a year remains too high for a flat price trend. One can understand Mr. Meany's consternation at recent events and his summons for a new round of 10 per cent pay hikes. Predictably, they will he largely dissipated in a new bout of, inflationand unemploymentif they are granted A figure closer to a 4 per cent annual advance would be a prerequisite to stability.

description: BOSTON, May 12 (AP)An entire rack of the paperback book section of the main store of the Jordan Marsh Company has been filled with copies of the White House transcripts. The rack is labeled Mystery.

title: The Awesome Task
description: As the House Judiciary Committee conducts its hearings to determine whether there are sufficient grounds to impeach the President, the focus of attention and debate should be solely and sharply on the evidence by which Richard Nixon's past conduct will be judged. Under such circumstances, any speculative counting uture votes in Congress demeans what Representative Edward Hutchinson, the committee's ranking Republican, has rightly called that awesome task. Equally offensive would be the continuation by the White House of the public relations campaign that reached an alltime low in the labored theological defense of the Watergate transcripts by Dr. John McLaughlin.

title: CHICAGO TRIBUNE BACKED ON NIXON
description: CHICAGO, May 12The Chicago Tribune has been deluged by the greatest inpouring of mail and telephone calls in half a century since the publication Thursday of its blunt editorial saying Richard Nixon was no longer fit to be President and should resign or be impeached, These statements by readers have shown that many Midwesterners still felt the President should not be attacked. But a majority applauded The Tribune's stand.

title: Candace Leeds Wed in Town Hall
description: Miss Candace Leeds, assistant director of Town Hall and producer of its Interludes series, was married married yesterday morning to Robert Wagenseil Jones, an architect. The Rev. Allan L. Egly, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony on the stage of Town Hall, where a reception was held.

title: Enriched Chicken Feed
description: No public or private agency has yet been able to determine who was responsible for getting a cancerinducing insecticide into the feed of Mississippi broilers a few weeks ago, contaminating four million of them so badly they had to be destroyed. That determination may never be made. But that hasn't stopped Mississippi's Congressional delegation, headed by Senators Eastland and Stennis, from lobbying close to final passage a bill that would oblige the Federal Government to pay up to $10 million in compensation to the poultry growersthe bulk of it to five large companies.

title: Consumer Official Calls Meeting Exclusory

Knauer on White House stationery, has written to protect the threeday National Conference for State, County and City Consumer Office administrators to be held at the Ramada Inn in Washington, D.C. beginning June 19. Mrs. Knauer is director of the Office of Consumer Affairs, Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Castle First In N.Y.A.C. Sail Event

title: Libraries Hit by Decline in Tax Gifts
description: Libraries and archives throughout the country are becoming increasingly concerned about the sharp decline in donations of scholarly material since 1969, when the Congress effectively barred incometax deductions for such gifts.

title: Judge Cites Safety Factor In Reserve Mining Decision

description: The marriage of Miss Susan Gail Bonner to Michael Alexander Mead took place Saturday night in St. Michael and All Angels Episcopal Church in Dallas.

title: Jail to the Chief?
description: WASHINGTON  Most readers of Washington tea leaves say that the House of Representatives will vote to impeach the President about midJuly, around Bastille Day; the Senate will begin its trial a month later. Toward the end of September; in this scenario, conservative Republicans and Southern Democrats would make up that one third plus one necessary to acquit.

title: Coast Inquiry Is Set Today In Killing of Robert Kennedy
description: LOS ANGELES, May 12 (AP) It is nearly six years since Senator Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated here, but a public inquiry scheduled tomorrow will reopen the lingerifig question of whether the man convicted of the killing acted alone.

title: Soaring Bread Prices Help Thrift Stores Sales
description: Seventyfiveyearold Morris Mandel of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, walked into a bakery thrift store on Ninth Avenue near 42d Street last week to stock up on 64cent bread marked down to 35 cents.

description: WASHINGTON, May 12 There were a number of indications today that President Nixon, whatever he may decide in the future about relinquishing his office, is now acting like a man who has made up his mind: to let the constitutional impeachment process in Congress run its course.

title: RedFooted Boobies Safe
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The Interior Department has declared the tiny Rose Atoll in American Samoa a national wildlife refuge for sea turtles, redfooted boobies, fairy noddy terns and a number of other sea birds. The atoll, one of the world's smallest and unusual because of its square shape, is 900 miles south of the Equator and 2,000 miles south of Hawaii.

title: Psychiatrists Debate Private Rights and Public Safety
description: DETROIT, May 12As her lawyer tells it, she was a 58yearold woman who liked to be by herself in a room in a welfare hotel in Manhattan. But she had a kidney problem, and her neighbors accused her of monopolizing the floor's only bathroom. One thing led to another, and soon a sort of war was under way. The neighbors would pound on her walls and she would turn up her radio.

title: Doberman Awarded Top Prize

title: A Federal Safety Drive Closes Fewer Mines Than Expected
description: WASHINGTON, May 12A Government campaign that was described two months ago as likely to force the closing of 500 small Appalachian coal mines for known violations of Federal safety standards has shut fewer than 100 because Government inspectors were ordered to go easy on us, a spokesman for the mine owners said yesterday.

He walked 27,153 meters in two hours, and then went on to break the 30kilometer record with a time of 2 hours 12 minutes 58 seconds.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Some baseball players perform with flash naturally, as Willie Mays or Mickey Mantle did, Others flow smoothly, as Henry Aaron does and as Al Kaline does. Even in Detroit, where he is the symbol of the Tigers, he creates quiet respect, not noisy adulation. His nicknames are typical of his unobtrusive nature. His teammates call him Line, from his last name, or Six for his uniform number. But slowly he is approaching a moment when fireworks will be appropriate. Now a designated hitter as the Tigers open a twogame series with the Yankees at Shea Stadium tonight, Al Kaline needs only 109 more hits to become the 12th majorleague player with 3,000 hits, an exclusive plateau of excellence. To appreciate Al Kaline, consider that he already has more hits than Babe Ruth, George Sisler, Lou Gehrig, Ted Williams and Mickey Mantle.
