title: Screen: 'Going Places':Blier Directs Tale of Two Errant Youths The Cast
description: "Going Places," the new French film by Bertrand Blier, the 35-year-old son of the actor Bernard Blier, is about two muscular young men on the road, going no place though they never stop moving. Jean-Claude (Gerard Depardieu) is the more aggressive of the two. Pierrot (Patrick Dewaere) seems the more resourceful, though he apparently enjoys being told what to do by his buddy. They share everything  stolen loot, hypochondria, boredom, women and, when there are no women, each other.At the beginning of the film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema 2, Jean-Claude and Pierrot rough up a middle-aged woman of faint heart and large pocketbook. They scare hell out of her but don't get around to rape. They later steal a car and kidnap a dim-witted blonde who doesn't mind being kidnapped at all, though she doesn't like getting shot at and beaten up, which the boys do, not so much out of viciousness as out of impatience.By the end of the film, after some funny, horrendous adventures that take them aimlessly from one end of France to the other, Jean-Claude and Pierrot have clearly become the victims. They are the pursued, doomed like that mythical bird Tennessee Williams sometimes writes about, the one that must spend its entire life flying, since evolution has denied it landing gear."Going Places" is handsome, mock-tough and thoroughly empty-headed, like Jean-Claude and Pierrot. It's a movie whose good performances and technical expertise can never disguise the vacuity of its assumed nihilism, which bears about as much relation to the real thing as fashion photography does to the work of Cartier-Bresson.Mr. Depardieu and Mr. Dewaere have a high old time in characterizations that seem composed less of attitudes taken from life than from old movies, early Belmondo, James Dean and any number of early Godard characters. Miou-Miou is also extremely attractive as the blonde who tags along with them, because there really isn't anything better to do. She later gives the pair her overwhelming gratitude when by chance, they set up the circumstances that result in her achieving her first orgasm. Such is the nature of much of the film's sense of humor.Jeanne Moreau, looking tired, wise and very beautiful, comes on screen in the middle of the movie as a woman who's just completed a 10-year stretch behind bars. She gives it, briefly, the weight and direction the film otherwise lacks, much in the manner that Jack Nicholson's appearance showed up the superficial attitudes of the rest of "Easy Rider." You may want to be forewarned, however, that the sequence concludes with what appears to be a suicide in a manner that more or less sums up the film's feelings about women. The suicide makes no sense on any level I can think of.The French are a funny race. The film's ads quote one Parisian critic who found "Going Places" to be "a hymn to life" of the sort that makes one glad to be alive. I must say that though I thought parts of it funny, and Miss Moreau riveting, the net effect was one of irritation and gloom. It's not very invigorating to see so much talent squandered on such foolish mixed-up romanticism.

title: Barnett for Athlete Urban Role
description: Dick Barnett, the Knicks assistant basketball coach and lesserknown scholar, sat in the Hall of Fame Club at Madison Square Garden yesterday and said: There is an aura of irresponsibility of athletes with no allegiance to any team or city. title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)The Consumer Products Safety Commission said today it would issue subpoenas for National Football League injury data if club owners did not furnish it voluntarily by Friday. The commission, under pressure from the N.F.L. Players Association, has been trying since last January to get the team owners injury figures in an attempt to determine whether synthetic turf is more hazardous than natural grass fields.

title: The Kickback Game
description: It is as old as the pyraidds and the Parthenon. The kickback system, for public buildings has operated since the beginning of recorded time. It is a thoroughly rotten, eternal political verity that has surfaced lately because it tripped up a Vice President of the United States. Spiro T. Agnew added little personal refinement to the hoary game. He kept 50 per cent of the take for himself. But even that wasn't original; Boss Tweed did better.

Patterson Jr. resigns. The march came after four days of racial unrest stemming from a confrontation between a black leader, John McCown and city officials. Mr. McCown was arrested last Wednesday after a group of blacks protested at city hall, over the arrest of a black woman on charges of illegal parking.

title: People in Sports
description: They are maniacs, said Bob Watson, a Houston Astro outfielder, talking about some of the fans at the doubleheader in Cincinnati on Sunday. Watson was irately discussing a situation in which he collapsed, after crashing into the leftfield wall in a vain effort to catch a drive by Mery Rettenmund. Bleeding and nearly unconscious, he was rewarded by some of the fans with a shower of beer. They threw three beer cups on him, said Cesar Cedena, the Astro centerfielder. He was lying there bleeding and could have been blinded from hitting the wall. I wish I could have climbed up there with a ladder, Don Wilson, a Houston pitcher, added, This is the worst display of sportsmanship I've ever seen.

The study, headed by Dr. John Stout, professor of biology, had been emhpasizing the use of decoys to divert the sea gulls from airport runways.

description: BOSTON, May 13 (AP) George Hendrick, a Cleveland outfielder, was named today as the American League's player of the week. In 14 times at bat he had nine hits, one a home run, and was the key player in the Indians three straight victories over the California Angels last week.

description: Mayor Beame, in a change of position, decided yesterday to retain Deputy Correction commissioner Jack Birnbaum. In doing so, he returned to the practice of having two deputies in the department. Luis Cadiz is the other deputy to Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm.

description: BERLIN, May 13  Volkswagen said today it suffered worldwide losses of $34.4million in the first quarter of this year and did not expect to get out of the red before the end of 1974.

title: EAGLES SERVE ROCK WITH COUNTRY FLAIR
description: The sometimes misinterpreted fusion of country music and rock n rollcountry rockis in safe hands with the Eagles, who are appearing Saturday at the Capital Theater in Passaic, N.J. The group's concert here last week, including an acoustic guitar, mandolin and banjo segment, would bring a hoot n holler from all but the fussiest bluegrass purist. And, by and large, the Eagles are dedicated to the West of yesteryearperahps a West influenced as much by Hollywood as by history books.

title: Bond Prices Rise
description: Prices were modestly ahead at the close of quiet trading in the Government, corporate and taxexempt bond markets yesterday but in a number of instances wound up below their highs for the day. Aside from the regular weekly Treasury Department bill auction described as vigorous by several specialistsparticipants in the bond markets had little to turn to in the way of new offerings. This week's calendar opens in earnest today, however, with a Detroit utility's negotiated offering of $100million of bonds. A peak, of sorts, will be reached on Thursday in the corporate sector when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company comes to market with its negotiated offering of $500million of debentures.

description: Edwin R. Werner, president of Blue Cross of Greater New York, declared yesterday that his company's merger with Blue Shield, already approved by both organizations, was contingent upon state approval of an adequate rate increase for Blue Shield.

Ellsberg's former psychiatrist in 1971, highly reliable sources said today.

title: SAYINGS BANKERS SNUB NIXON PLAN Assert Mortgage Subsidies Won't Restrain Inflation
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 13Savings bankers were cool today toward President Nixon's $10.3billion mortgage subsidy program because they said it would not curb the inflation that has driven depositors from their doors.

title: Franklin National Bank Dismisses Its President
description: The directors of the financially pressed Franklin National Bank dismissed its president yesterday and disclosed that an executive vice chairman and director had resigned, in the wake of the discovery of large foreignexchange trading losses.

title: Treasury Bills Off At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Yields on threemonth and sixmonth United States Treasury bills were sharply lower in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Ernie Pyle Hall Remodeling
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 13 (UPI)Two newspaper publishers, Scott Schurz of Bloomington and Nelson F. Poynter of St. Petersburg, Fla., will head drive to raise money to remodel Ernie Pyle Hall at the University of Indiana. The drive will seek to raise $650,000.

title: Solomon Cites Oil Impact on Banking
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A leading authority on international monetary affairs suggested today that conventional wisdom about banking practices may have to be modified in light of the unusual financial problems created by the huge jump in oil prices.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, MAY 14, 1974
description: International A majority of Italians want to retain the country's divorce law, final returns of a twoday referendum indicated. More than 59.1 per cent of the 32 million ballots upheld the law that since 1970 has made divorce possible in Italy. Votes in favor of repealing the law totaled 40.9 per cent. [1:2]

title: CAMPUS CALMER, A SURVEY FINDS
description: Although the mood on college campuses today is calmer than in the turbulent nineteensixties, a Gallup poll has found that many studentsnearly 4 in 10continue to believe that violence is sometimes justified to bring about a change in society.

title: Trenton Firemen Stage a Stoppage
description: TRENTON, May 13 (UPI)Trenton fire fighters, protesting unsafe conditions, refused today to man equipment they said was from 15 to 26 years old, but they were ordered back to work nine hours later by a Superior Court judge.

title: and to the Hungry
description: Senator Humphrey has posed a moral challenge wellfedand frequently overfedAmericans with his recent call for generous United States contributions to broad new world food action program.

title: ISRAELI AIRCRAFT STRIKE IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, May 13Israeli aircraft struck Lebanese territory again today, attacking what an Israeli spokesman said were Palestinian terrorist targets near the juncture of the Israeli, Lebanese and Syrian borders.

title: $24BILLION ASKED FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: $24BILLION ASKED FOR MASS TRANSIT

title: Orient Champion Beaten
description: TOKYO, May 13 (UPI)Eddie Perkins of Chicago, ranked second in the World Boxing Association's welterweight class, won a 10round decision tonight over the Orient Welterweight's champion, Ryu Sorimachi of Japan.

title: Conyers. Calls Nixon Guilty Of 5 Impeachable Offenses
description: DETROIT, May 13 (UP)Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, today said he was convinced that President Nixon was guilty of at least five impeachable offenses.

title: Con Edison's Shaky Future: Questions and Answers
description: Not since the nineteenthirties and the days of the old. Ipublicutility holding companies has the possibility of an electric utility's going bankrupt had lany real effect on the stock market.

title: Goldwater Sees Merit In Fleets of Dirigibles
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPDSenator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, today urged the nation to take a second look at the possible merit of building fleets of dirigibles.

title: MILK EXECUTIVE DENIES MEETING
description: CHICAGO. May 13  The president of the American Milk Producers, Inc., denied today he had told a former AMPI official he had met with Herbert W. Kalmbach and been informed by him that a pending antitrust suit against the milk cooperative would be dropped if $300,000 was contributed to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: WESTERN UNION FILES RATES ON WESTAR
description: Western Union proposed yesterday a $1,000 monthly charge for a transcontinental, twoway, private voice circuit using Westar I, the first United States domestic communications satellite. In filing the proposed rates with the Federal Communications Commission, Western Unlion said similar service now available via terrestrial facilities cost $2,100 monthly.

title: Legislator's Wife Guilty of Forgery In School Election
description: Mrs. Betty Beatty, the wife of State Senatot Vander L. Beatty, Democrat of Brooklyn, was found guilty late last night by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn of charges in connection with a voting fraud in District 17's community school board elections last May.

title: Coraggioso, $34, Wins by Nose in Sprint Before 22,429 at Belmont Opening
description: A race befitting the opulent surroundings of Belmont Park served as the feature of the opening day of that track's spring meeting yesterday. The Vagrancy Handicap, attracted a field of 14 class campaigners and tile classiest for older fillies and mares, of all proved to be Bwamazon Farms Coraggioso.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: FUSION, JAZZ GROUP FROM POLAND, OPENS
description: A Polish jazz group, Fusion, led by Michal Urbaniak, a violinist, has begun its American career at Mak's Kansas City, Park Avenue South, where it will be for the next month. The fivepiece enseinblekeyboard, violin, bass and vocalistis all electrified. And, as used with such groups, it is so overamplified that it redices itself to music for masochists.

title: 2 Planes Down in VietnaM; One Was Air America's
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 14 (Reuters) Two planes, one belonging to Air America and the other to the South Vietnamese Air Force, crashed yesterday while flying close to the Cambodian border northwest of Saigon, government military sources said today.

title: Musk: Monument to Mozart in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Ever since the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened almost three years ago, the idea was that it be something more than a series of halls renting out to local or visiting attractions. And it was soon after the opening that Julius Rude!, its musical director, conceived the idea of a mammoth Mozart festival. The idea would be to present a cross section of Mozart's music, from solo to opera. Planning took about three years, and last week the project got under way.

title: SAUDI BACKING SEEN FOR I.M.F. FACILITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (Reuters)Saudi Arabia has not informed the International Monetary Fund of any intention to withdraw support for the oil facility, a spokesman for the said.

title: Connecticut
description: The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation reported yesterday a firstquarter ncrease of 5.6 per cent in net income to $21.3million, or 78 cents a share, from $20.2 million, or 75 cents a share, in the initial three months last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John F. Thompson's May 7 letter dealing with the Port Authority requires the following comments on behalf of the Port Authority.

title: South Africa's Objectives
description: PRETORIA, South AfricaThe Republic of South Africa is a microcosm of the world's ethnic and political complexities. Since South Africa is an imperfect society and since no policy applied to a complex situation anywhere in the world is perfect, we expect and appreciate wellfounded criticism of the way in which we have set about restructuring our society.

title: Brooklyn Antipoverty Agency Is Under Federal Investigation
description: A Brooklyn antipoverty agency, whose acting executive director was arrested Saturday on a series Of criminal charges, has been under investigation for several months by the office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

title: CUBAN MAGAZINE BOMBED IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, May 13  A plastic bomb, apparently placed by Cuban terrorists, destroyed an office last night in the building of Replica, a Splanishlanguage weekly news magazine published here and in New York.

title: Joint Venture Set by Dart And El Paso Products
description: Dart Industries, Inc., an flounced yesterday that it was expanding jts joint ventureja, with El Paso Products, a subla sidiary of the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX

title: SILVER FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Speculative buying pushed silver futures up the daily limit of 20 cents an ounce in most ontracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. July silver, the most active month, which accounted for more than half the day's trading, closed at $6.02 an ounce, up from $5.82.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS AT CRUCIAL STAGE
description: JERUSALEM, May 13 Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East mediation effort entered an apparently crucial phase today as senior American officials reported that Israeli and Syrian differences over a new demarcation line had been reduced to a few kilometers in the latest discussions.

title: Notes on People
description: Clarence Dexter Wiseman, a 66yearold Canadian, was elected yesterday as head of the Salvation Army. He succeeds Erik Wickberg, who retires on July 5. The generalelect of the Salvation Army, who is from Toronto, was chosen by secret ballot of the 40member council of the group after a nineday conference at SunburyonThames, just west of London.

title: Judge Holds Political Contributors Can't Avoid Gift Tax by Splitting Donations to Same Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A Federal judge ruled today that big political contributors could not escape the gift tax on their contributions by splitting them up among a number of different committees supporting the same candidate.

title: Beauty and Beast, New Opera, Evokes 19thCentury Style
description: The ultraconservative composer seems to be gaining new confidence these days. perhaps because we are beginning to tolerate the musical styles of all eras with fewer prejudices than a decade ago. At any rate, Jeremiah Murray's new opera Beauty and the Beast, given its premiere by the Public Opera Theater last week at the Eighth Avenue Y.W.C.A., is unabashedly and often gloriously entrenched in the 19th century.

title: Accord Raises Hourly Pay Of Longshoremen 15 Cents
description: Hourly wages for 25,000 longshoremen from Boston to Hampton Roads, Va., are to go up 15 cents on June 1 under an agreement announced here yesterday, by the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations and the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: New StudentAid Plan Votedin Albany
description: ALBANY, May 13 Legislature today unanimously approved a bill that set up new program of financial assistance to students attending private and public colleges the state. The maximum award, of $1,500 or tuition, whichever; is less, would be available to; a student whose family's taxable income was less than $2,000 a year.

title: MARIUS JALET DIES FINANCIAL ANALYST
description: Marius S. Jalet, who retired last year as supervising analyst for Walston & Co., stockbrokers, died Sunday at his home, 114 Morningside Drive. He was 64 years old.

title: Peril to 400 Million Is Seen by UNICEF
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13The threat of severe malnutritionor even starvationfaces 400 million to 500 million children in poorer countries, Henry R. Labouisse, the executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, warned today.

title: Books of The Times
description: In a way, it's too bad that Carl Bernstein's and Bob Woodward's All the President's Men had to appear at the same time that President Nixon decided to publish a book of his own (which now available in three paperback editions: Submission of Recorded Presidential Conversations to the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives by President Richard Nixon, United States Government Printing Office, $12.25; The White House Transcripts, with an introduction by R. W. Apple Jr. of The New York Times, Bantam, $2.50; and The Presidential Transcripts, with commentary by the Staff of The Washington Post, Dell, $2.45). It's too bad, because if it had appeared after the Watergate scandal had run its coursea course whose future has only been made more dramatic by the appearance of the Presidential transcriptsMr. Bernstein's and Mr. Woodward's All the President's Men would have been one hell of a book to read.

title: PANEL PLANS VOTE ON NEW SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The House Judiciary Committee will interrupt its impeachment hearings Wednesday to vote on what is likely to be the first in a series of new subpoenas of tape recordings of President Nixon's conversations on Watergate.

title: U.S. Says Sohio Deleberatly Reduced Gasoline Supply Here During Shortage
description: The regional office there of the Federal Energy Administration charged yesterday that the Standard Oil Coniany of Ohio had deliberately cut back gasoline supplies to this region during the depths of the shortage in favor of customers in the Middle West.

title: Lead Poisoning Perils Crew Razing El
description: Standing 20 or 30 feet above the ground burning through steel beams with an acetylene torch is a job with hazards. But the men who are doing this work as part of the demolition of the Third Evenue elevated line in the Bronx have run into a danger they had not anticipated  lead poisoning.

title: LEADING SENATORS REFUSE TO PRESS NIXON ON QUITTING
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Prominent Senate conservatives of both parties said today that they had no intention of pressing either publicly or privately for President Nixon's resignation.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Sunny and seasonable weather is forecast today for much of the Northeast. Showers or thundershowers will be scattered from the western portions of New York and Pennsylvania across the Ohio Valley, upper lake region, and the upper and middle Mississippi Valley to the eastern edges of the Plains States.

title: MAGEE ASKS JUDGE TO WITHDRAW PLEA
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 13 (UPI)  Ruchell Magee, onetime codefendant with Angela Davis, asked a judge today to withdraw his guilty plea in kidnapping case resulting from the shootings at the Marin County Courthouse in 1970.

title: CAIRO PAPER LINKS TAPES TO ZIONISTS
description: CAIRO, May 13  The Cairo newspaper Al Akhbar said editorially today that a dispatch in The New York Times reporting, sources as saying that the deleted portions of the Watergate transcripts contained anti Jewish remarks by President Nixon revealed the extent of Zionist plotting that it said was underway in the United States.

title: Vietcong Say They Are Quitting Paris Talks With Saigon Team
description: PARIS, May 13  The Viettong's Provisional Revolutionary Government announced today that it was suspending its negotiations here with Saigon's delegation.

title: I.B.M. Told to Yield Papers U.S. Seeks
description: WASINGTON, May 13The Supreme. Court refused today to set aside a ruling that the International Business Machines Corporation mnstfgive the Govlernment 700 documents that the Justice Department says it needs lo prosecute antitrust charges against the company.

title: StrifeTorn Morristown High Is Reopened Quietly
description: MORRISTOWN, May 13 Classes at Morristown High School resumed in an atmosphere of relative calm today after a weeklong shutdown because of racial incidents.

title: Laney College Elects
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 13 (AP)Lawrence Arnett Davis, noted black educator, was chosen the new president of Laney College today. He will take the $31,000ayear job on June 15.

title: WESTERN UNION FILES RATES ON WESTAR
description: Western Union proposed yesterday a $1,000 monthly charge for a transcontinental, twoway, private voice circuit using Westar I, the first United States domestic communications satellite. In filing the proposed rates with the Federal Communications Commission, Western Union said similar service now available via terrestrial facilities cost $2,100 monthly. Similar in design to the pair of domestic communications satellites serving Canada, Westar I was launched April 13 and then was placed on its orbital station 22,300 miles above the equator, at 99 degress west longitude

title: WILSON'S RENT BILL REMAINS AT IMPASSE
description: ALBANY, May 13The impasse over rent control appeared no closer to resolution today as pressure grew from the Republicans in the Legislature to delete from Governor Wilson's bill a provision that would allow any community to bring itself under a statewide system of rent regulation.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: TWO SUBWAY CARS TESTED HERE: State of the art train, developed by U.S. Department of Transportation, at 57th Street and Sixth Avenue station.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NO YOU This city is people: secretaries, students, social workers, buyers, jetsetters, Strivers, new arrivers, punks, old ladies with shopping bags, nuts, cooks, dishwashers.

title: Stocks Off 4.85 in Dull Trading
description: The stock market, still under pressure of rising interest rates, declined again yesterday in listless trading.

title: Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, 72, ExDirector of UNESCO, Dies
description: MEXICO CITY, May 13 (AP) Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, the father of modern Mexican education and the director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization from 1948. to 1952, shot and killed himself at his home tonight, the police announced. He was 72 years old. Dr: Torres Bodet was suffering from cancer of the prostate

title: Pierre Robbers Terms Are Thrown Out by Court
description: Two men convicted in the theft of $3million in cash and jewelry from the Pierre Hotel 28 months ago have had their sevenyear prison sentences thrown out on the ground that they had been promised smaller sentences in return for a plea of guilty. Two men convicted in the theft of $3million in cash and jewelry from the Pierre Hotel 28 months ago have had their sevenyear prison sentences thrown out on the ground that they had been promised smaller sentences in return for a plea Df guilty.

description: How the Teams Stand Today

title: Franklin Savings Visited By Confused Customers
description: The Franklin Savings Bank, which has no connection with the financially pressed Franklin National Bank, was receiving visits yesterday from some of its customers who had confused it with Franklin National or felt the two were related.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Belmont Race Charts

title: 8 PANELS SET UP BY STATE SENATE
description: ALBANY, May 13With but a few minutes debate, the Senate tonight voted to spend, nearly $1million on eight special study committees composed mainly of legislators.

title: JOBS DROP IN CITY AFTER AN UPTURN
description: The fouryear old trend of declining employment in New York City resumed in February With 22,000 fewer jobs counted for the month than in February, 1973, it was reported yesterday by Herbert Bienstock had of the Bureau of Labor Statistics here.

title: Yanks Sell Hegan to Brewers
description: The Yankees, who made Mike Hegan unhappy by acquiring Chris Chambliss to play first base, made him happy again yesterday by selling him to the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: SENATE IN JERSEY APPROVES BUDGET
description: TRENTON, May 13  A $2.75billion state budget that does not include any nex taxes nor any major new programs was given initial approval in th Senate by a 37to13 vote this afternoon as the New Jersey Legislature strove to adjourn this week.

title: Valentino Will Repurchase Venture From Kenton Corp.
description: Valentino, the fashion designer, and his business man ager, Giancarlo Giammetti, have agreed to repurchase the Valentino business from the Kenton Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Kenton, now operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, has closed the Valentino Boutique on Madison Avenue.

title: Stakes High in Mrs. Gandhi's Rail Gamble
description: NEW DELHI, May 13Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, facing a severe economic crisis, has made one of the riskiest decisions of her career in dealing firmly, even harshly, with the nation's striking railwaymen. The stakes are extraordinarily high. The 56yearold Prime Minister, whose Government had largely acquiesced to unions in the last five years, has decided to face down the powerful railway workers and crush their strike. News Analysis

title: ALBANY APPROVES BILL TO OVERSEE CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: Speaker Duryea's bill would have set the rich man's limit at $100,000.

title: Defeat for Two Tennis Upstarts and Victory for Sets
description: Two giantkillers were bombed into submission and the New York, Sets got their offensive going in the tennis wars over the weekend.

But the men who are doing this work as part of the demolition of the Third Evenue elevated line in the Bronx have run into a dangers they hadnot anticipated lead poisoning.

title: SILVER FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Speculative buying pushed silver futures up the daily limit of 20 cents an ounce in most ontracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. July silver, the most active month, which accounted for more than half the day's trading, closed at $6.021/2 an ounce, up from $5.82 .

description: BOYCOTT IS HINTED IN DOMINICAN VOTE

title: Peril to 400 Million Is Seen by UNICEF
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13The threat of severe malnutritionor even starvationfaces 400 million to 500 million children in poorer countries, Henry R. Labouisse, the executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, warned today.

title: Indians Topple Red Sox, Thanks to a Busy Trader
description: Gabe Paul, general manager of the Yankees, formerly served the Cleveland Indians, and his influence continues to be felt on that team. It was Paul who engineered the recent trade between the Yanks and Indians that bolstered Cleveland's pitching staff with Fritz Peterson, Steve Kline, Fred Beene and Tom Buskey. And it was Paul, then general manager at Cleveland, who brought John Ellis and Charlie Spikes to the Indians from New York.

title: McCarthy Supports Carey As Nominee for Governor
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy yesterday endorsed Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn for the Democratic nomination for Governor, calling the candidate uniquely quaified to handle and solve the prbblems of unemployment, inflation and taxation in the state.

title: 7 Police Officials Protest Appointment in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 13 (AP)  Seven of Argentina's highestranking federal police officers submitted their resignations today rather than serve under Luis Margaride, a former head of the political police who was appointed deputy chief of the federal police by President Juan Domingo Perini on Friday., Alberto Villar was named to the top pest.

title: LILCO POSTPONES A STOCK OFFERING
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday it would postpone a $45million to $60million common stock offering that had been set for next month. Instead, it will reIsort to debt financing through an offering of $60million in first mortgage bonds.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Phnom Penh Says Rebels Near Capital Repel Drive
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 13 (UPI)  Cambodian Government troops were thrown back today in an assault on entrenched rebel forces nine miles north of Phnom Penh, according to reports from the field.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Mr. Ford's Zigs and Zags
description: Vice President Ford asserted the other day that corruption, malfeasance and wrongdoing in Washington were hammer blows to the confidence the American people have placed in their Government. Later the same day, Mr. Ford tempered his strong language by saying,  the President, 1 hope, will survive, because I think he's innocent.

title: MOVES ON ITS PAPER LISTED BY TALCOTT
description: James C. Slaughter, chairman of the Talcott National Corporation and its subsidiary, James Talcott, Inc., issued a statement yesterday in which he reported that James Talcott during the week of May 6 to May 10 had met commercial paper maturities of $65million by selling $39million, or 60 per cent, of additional paper and had met the balance through drawing $26million of its bank credits.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, May 14 (AP)Applications for a pipeline that would bring new natural gas from the Arctic to 26 Midwest and Northeast states were filed today with the Federal Power Commission.

title: Radio
description: 610 AM, WNCN. Sonata in B flat for Piano,. Violin and Cello, Schubert; Harpsichord Concerto No. 5, Arne; Concerto in F, Fux; Le Rouet d'Omphale, SaintSans; Moses Fantasie, Paganini; Piccolo Concerto in C, Vivaldi;, Suite No. 1 in D, Marella; A Shropshire Lad, Butterworth.

title: BOTTLERS FILE SUIT AGAINST PEPSICO, INC.
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14 (AP) Two independent bottling companies have claimed in Federal court suit that Pepsico, Inc., and a related company, violated antitrust laws in the purchase of three other bottlers in New England.

title: Fun for Children
description: Children who are creative with their hands have a chance to let their imaginations run wild with clay in a bona fide potter's studio. The program for 5 to 12yearolds, at the Fish's Mouth Potters Workshop, combines potterymaking with dramatic improvisation.

title: Rainout Gives Mets Pitchers a Chance to Recover
description: ST. LOUIS, May 14Having treated St. Louis to one of their finer performances of skating on thin ice, the New York Mets got a little extra time from the rain tonight to prepare for an encore against the unamused and slipping Cardinals.

title: SCHOOL REOPENED IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: PLEASANTVILLE, May 14This city's senior high school reopened for classes this morning without incident after a threeday shutdown because of racial disorders.

title: Calley Asks Data for Appeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 14 (AP)Attorneys for William L. Calley Jr. filed motions in Federal District Court here today requesting the Government to produce all testimony heard by Army and Congressional committees that investigated the, My Lai massacre. The former Army lieutenant is seeking to reverse his conviction for the; murder of 22 South Vietnamese civilians at My Lai in 1968.

title: East German Voters Voice Complaints
description: BERLIN, May 14At Rostock on the Baltic, East German voters wanted to know why they could not buy milk and fresh rolls before 7 o'clock in the morning.

title: DOCTORS IN STATE GET PREMIUM RISE
description: New York State doctors whose medical malpractice insurance was canceled last fall have negotiated a contract with a new insurance company at 93.5 per cent increase in premiums.

title: 10Day Ban Intended to Allow Bank to Arrange Affairs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday continued the suspension of trading in the stock of the Franklin New York Corporation 10 more days to give the bankholding company more time to unscramble its affairs.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, May 14Outside Princeton, the Great Road runs directly northwest over several hills and ridges like giant rollercoaster track. On the beginning section, closest to Princeton, a stretch half a mile long, there are no stoplights, no sidewalks, no road shouldersit is a straight downward chute that dips, gathers and shoots up another hill.

title: Major League Baseball and Standings
description: Major League Baseball and Standings

title: Dollar Falls Abroad
description: Uncertainties over the political situation in the United States caused the dollar to weaken sharply on European currency markets, touching lows for the year before recovering in late trading. Details on Page 61.

title: Burns Trails By 3 Shots In L.I. Open
description: WOODMERE, LI., May 14 George Burns wants nothing as much as a berth on the United States Walker Cup team that will meet the British in the biennial golf cornpetition 12 months hence.

title: Vern Knudson, Engineer, Dies; ExChancellor at U.C.L.A., 80
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14 (AP) Dr. Vern O. Knudsen, a prominent acoustical engineer and chancellor emeritus of the University of California at Los Angeles, died last evening of pneumonia. He was 80 years old.

title: Waldrop 3:59 8 Is 9th Under 4:00
description: CHAPEL HILL. N.C., May 14 (AP)  Tony Waldrop ran his ninth consecutive sub4minute mile and Maryland won its 19th consecutive team title in the Atlantic. Coast Conference track meet today.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs Detroit Tigers at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Nleado,.K, Queens, 2 P.M, (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.)Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. Television Channel 9. 8:30 P.M.) (Radio  WEN, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Brandeis Victor in Track
description: Brandeis scored 714 points to win the Manhattan public high school track and field championships yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Washington and Stuyvesant were second and third, respectively.

title: Divorce, Italian Style
description: The surprising 3to2 referendum vote in favor Italy's threeyearold divorce law may alter the country's political future more than the institution of marriage.

title: Law, Order and Justice
description: President Nixon came to office promising law and order and a new Attorney. General who would put to aggressive use the wiretap authority contained in the 1968 Omnibus Crime Control Act. This week the Supreme Court overturned a conviction obtained on the basis of wiretap information which the Government had gathered illegally because of Mr. Mitchell's carelessness with the law. The Court's ruling makes it virtually certain that convictions obtained in at least sixty similar cases, involving over 600 defendants, will also be overturned.

title: Court Backs State In Cutting Rent Aid If 'Lodger Is Found
description: A Federal appellate court decision yesterday supported a regulation that enabled the state to reduce aid to families with dependent children if a lodger liked in the household.

title: Dollar Falls Abroad
description: Uncertainties over the political situation in the United States caused the dollar to weaken sharply on European currency markets, touching lows for the year before recovering in late trading. Details on Page 61.

title: EGAN TRIAL HEARS OF CASHSPLITTING
description: A, former police lieutenant testified yesterday that he had received $10,000 to $12,000 in the men's room of the West 54th Street police station as his share of cash seized in 1970 from three LatinAmerican drug peddlers at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Air General Named to Head Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) President Nixon named Air Force Gen. George S. Brown today, to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest military post

title: Con Edison Wins Support For 17% Rise in Gas Rates
description: ALBANY, May 14The Consolidated Edison Company won preliminary approval of a $27.8million, or 17 per cent, increase in its gas rates today as Governor Wilson summoned the bipartisan legislative leadership to his offices this evening for a final effort at resolving the impasse that continued to block state aid for the financially pressed utility.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Six eastern Pennsylvania governmental units have sued to block the Delaware River Basin Commission from adopting any water charges and rates pending an environmental impact study of Tocks Island and other projects on the Delaware River and its tributaries. The plaintiffs brought the complaint in United States District Court here as a class action on behalf of customers in four states who they said would be affected by charges adopted by the commission.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $100million order from the New England Electric System for two 1.2millionkilowatt nuclear power plant reactor systems, along with the initial fuel load. The plant, whose site has not yet been announced, is expected to begin operation in 1982 and a year later for the second nuclear unit. The total cost of the plant and associated equipment is placed at $1.66billion. In another contract, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's defense and space center aerospace division received a $21.9million Air Force contract for advanced development of the electronically agile radar (EAR), a multipurpose radar for use strategic bombers.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CONSTANT READER Mort Sahl, who will be 47 years old this month, a political satirist with a laserbeam wit, constructs his routines, it is paid, around what he reads in the newspapers. These days, then, he has a lot of material to work with and you can bet he's working hard to improve upon the satire in the headlines.

title: Hatching Dinosaur Eggs
description: PARISThe Portuguese coup and the revolution developing in its wake are bound to have important strategic repercussions throughout Africa as that continent's last colonial empire starts to unravel. For now that Lisbon inferentially acknowledges it can no longer forcibly rule Angola and Mozambique, it is inevitable that they must either break away or dissolve in racial war.

title: Tigers, Houk Top Yanks, 52
description: Little by little last night Ralph Houk became less of an exYankee and more of manager of the Detroit Tigers.

title: Australia, Davis Cup Champion, Upset by India in Zone Final, 32
description: CALCUTTA, India, May 14 (Reuters)India brought off a major Davis Cup triumph today when she eliminated Australia, the cup holder, in the Eastern Zone final, 32.

title: Coal Miners Started the Strike Then Their Women Took Over
description: HARLAN, Ky,Although its name rings of gentility, the Brookside Women's Club is not your usual bridgeplaying, cocktailpartying, gardening variety of women's club, where members get, together and cluck over the shine of each other's china: Instead, at the regular monthly meet

title: Red Smith
description: Once upon a time there was a king who loved parties better than he loved his queen, which was not difficult because she was a troublesome bag who had been foisted on him by the ministers of state. The king and his courtiers used to toss a party on any provocation, and since it was a big court with lots of birthdays, wedding anniversaries and such, there always seemed to be something to celebrate. There came a day, however, when nobody had any cause for rejoicing. Nobody at court had been born on that day, or baptized or married or divorced, the kingdom's ball club hadn't won a pennantthere simply was not, in short, any reason for having a party. Well, then, His Majesty asked, could anybody think of a reason for not having a party? Nobody could, so they opened the wine

title: Relative of Seabury Discovered Errors In Tape Transcript
description: The man who discovered that the edited transcripts of the White House tapes released by President Nixon contained two versions of one part of a conversation is a relative of Samuel Seabury, whose investigative efforts led to the resignation of Mayor. James J. Walker in 1932.

title: Six Freed by Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 14 (AP)Uruguay's most famous living novelist, Juan Carlos Onetti, and directors of the leftist weekly Marcha were freed today after being jailed since February because of publication of a short story considered critical of the police.

title: No SayAStop Dividend
description: SayAStop, Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., based nonfoods wholesaler, said its directors voted yesterday to suspend payment of cash dividends on the common and preferred shares because of disappointing earnings. In the six months ended March 2, net income dropped about 94 per cent to $110,000, compared to earnings from continued operations of $1.8million the year before.

title: EARLY MAY SALES OF CARS OFF 28%
description: DETROIT, May 14Domestic newcar sales were off 28 per cent in the first 10 days of May from the yearearlier level.

title: U.N. Command in Korea Protests Firing by North
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, May 14 The United Nations command lodged a protest today with North Korea over the North Korean firing on two United States Army helicopters near the Korean demilitarized zone last Thursday.

title: Concert
description: Bruce PrinceJoseph, head of the music department at Hunter College and for the last 20 years organist and harpsichordist of the New York Philharmonic, conducted the first performance on Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall of his sixmovement symphonycantata entitled ln Praise of Love. An ambitious work, it utilized a large ensemble drawn from the Philharmonic, a chorus of 40, four pianists, organist and four vocal soloists. Its libretto was drawn from the prose and poetry of a couple of dozen writers, including Saint Augustine, Dante, Allen Ginsberg, Lorca, D. H. Lawrence and Yevtushenko, all of whom have had something to say about love of one sort or another.

title: New Archbishop of Canterbury Is Named
description: LONDON, May 14Dr. Donald Coggan, an energetic evangelist and a critic of permissiveness, was named today to be the next Archbishop of Can terbury, the spiritual leader of the world's Anglican communion of more than 45 million people.

title: AREA LOGS IMPACT OF COURT RULING
description: A fifth of the 60 Federal prosecutions against 626 defendants affected by Monday's wiretap decision by the United States Supreme Court originated in New Jersey, a survey of prosecutors in the metropolitan area disclosed yesterday.

title: Envoy to Sweden Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) After almost two years with no American ambassador to Sweden, the post in Stockholm was officially filled this afternoon when Robert StrauszHupe, the new United States envoy took the oath of office.

title: Tishman Posts $4.2Million Loss
description: The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., a leading builder of office towers, reported yesterday that, for the six months ended March 31, it had a net loss of $4.2million, after a charge of $5.2million pertaining to 1166 Avenue of the Americas here.

title: Clash Seen on Ervin Bid For I.R.S. Data on Militants
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Congress and the Nixon Administration appeared today td be headed for a new confrontation over the right of Congress to examine Governnient documents to determine whether there has been wrongdoing:

title: Oil Payments Danger
description: The recent move by the Italian Government to curb nonessential imports is a warning signal that the world energy crisis is far from over and may be entering a new and more dangerous phase. The payments imbalances set off by last year's fourfold increase in Mideast oil prices are beginning to register.

title: 100 Sailing Ships Due For Bicentennial Fete
description: TRENTON, May 14 (AP)The New Jersey Bicentennial Commission announced today that a worldwide fleet of 100 sailing ships would anchor off Sandy Hook on July 3, 1976, as part of the state's celebration of the nation's 200th anniversary.

title: Ervin Says 90% of Mail Favors the Committee
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that the Senate Watergate committee had received a million letters since its hearings last year and more than 90 per cent of them praised the committee's work.

title: CITY PURCHASE AIDE GUILTY OF PERJURY
description: A former city deputy purchase commissioner, Anthony Rizzo, was found guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on one count of perjury. He faces a possible prison term of seven years.

title: District 1 Has FoulUps, but Voters and Officials Agree Election W as Calmer Than in 1973
description: Public School 4 had no interpreter. P.S. 20 had an interpreter but no registration cards for lot of angry voters. P.S. 63 had an interpreter and registration cards, and the voters in 12 election districts crammed into one room. P.S. 169 had no voting at all, which was a surprise to many people who had voted there in all other elections over the last 20 years.

title: New Clash Seen as Ervin Seeks I.R.S. Data on Militant Groups
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Congress and the Nixon Administration appeared today to be headed for a new confrontation over the right of Congress to examine Government documents to determine whether there has been wrongdoing.

title: CIT Sets Bank Merger
description: The National Bank of North America, a subsidiary of the CIT Financial Corporation, announced yesterday an agreement to merge the Empire National Sank into the National Bank of North America. Details on Page 63.

title: Nets Ticket Refunds
description: All holders of New York Nets tickets for playoff games I and 3 can receive refunds for the unplayed games by returning the tickets to the place of purchase, the Nets organization announced yesterday.

title: 2 DIE AS AUTO IS HIT IN STOLENCAR CHASE
description: Two Long Island men on their way to work were killed in Brooklyn yesterday when their car was struck by a stolen auto in which four teenagers were fleeing the police.

title: Soviet Dissident Sentenced, To 5 Years in Labor Can
description: MOSCOW, May 14 (Reuters) A Soviet court has sentenced Gabriel Superfin, a dissentek who once worked as a research er for Aleksandr I. Solzzheiiitsyn, to five years in a labor camp followed by two years enforced residence in a remote part of the Soviet Union.

title: Flyers Subdue Bruins, 42, Take 31 Lead in Playoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14The Philadelphia Flyers took on a Boston Bruin hockey team that its coach admitted afterward had played their best, but the Flyers still came out on top, 42, tonight and were one victory away from taking the Stanley Cup. The triumph gave them a 31 lead in the fourofsevengame final playoff

title: Zumwalt Urged for V.A. Job
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) Senator Peter H. Dominick, Republican of Colorado, recommended today that President Nixon name Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. as head of the Veterans Administration when Donald E. Johnson leaves. The admiral retires June 30 as Chief of Naval Operations.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery, number yesterday was:

title: I.R.S. Aide Still Has Not Been Queried by Jaworski Office on Error in I.T.T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Although more than two months have elapsed since the Internal Revenue Service admitted legal error and revoked a highly favorable tax ruling given to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1969, the Watergate special prosecutor's office has not yet questioned the official who signed the ruling about possible political influence behind it.

title: Quotes From Transcripts
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Following are excerpts from the White House transcription in which portions of the same conversation between President Nixon and Henry E. Petersen are repeated in different versions.

title: JOHN FITZ RANDOLPH, PARTNER IN DUPONT
description: John A. Fitz Randolph, a retired general partner in the investment firm of Francis 1. duPont Co died yesterday at bis home, 1062 Sunset Road, Stamford, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: RADIOACTIVE MATTER FOUND IN 01110 CANAL
description: MIAMISBURG, Ohio, May 14 (AP)Officials at Mound Laboratory confirmed tonight that a small amount of radioactive plutonium238 had been found in the bottom sediments of the Old Erie Canal adjacent to the facility.

title: Upsala to Share Campus With Bloomfield College
description: EAST ORANGE, May 14 The presidents of Bloomfield and Upsala Colleges announced today that effective with the 197576 academic year, Bloomfield students would begin sharing a significant number of academic and housing facilities on the Upsala campus.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Programs of free movies in the city's parks will be presented for the fourth successive year, starting June 30 in Central Park, by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in association with the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration. The series of short films will be shown at 9 P.M., Sundays through Thursdays, for four weeks in approximately 15 parks in the five boroughs.

title: Denny Shute, Golfer, Dies at 69; Won P.G.A. Title in 36 and 37
description: AKRON, Ohio, Mar 14 (AP) Denny Shute, former P.G.A. and British Open champion, died Yesterday at his home here. He was 99 years old.

title: Auto Racing Enters Era of Peace, Joint Sanctions
description: While controversies rage at Indianapolis, auto racing quietly entered an era of peaceful existence on Sunday. In a Mother's Day decision, the Sports Car Club of America and the United States Auto Club agreed, to work toward a common formula for open  wheel, singleseat cars that by 1976, and maybe even by next year, would mean one series to decide the North American driving championship.

title: SADAT SAID TO ASK SYRIA TO SIGN PACT
description: SADAT SAID TO ASK SYRIA TO SIGN PACT

title: N.H.L. Championship
description: N.H.L. Championship

title: A.B.A. Is Supporting Bill To Restructure Bank Laws
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) The American Bankers Association supported today an Administration bill to restructure laws governing the operation of banks and other financial institutions.

title: Inflation's Tax Trap
description: Economic Analysis

title: G.O.P. Chiefs in the States Unhappy Over Transcripts
description: WASHINGTON, May 14I'm disappointed, said Kent B. McGough, the Ohio Republican chairman, It showed the operations around the White House not to be on the high plane I anticipated. It was very disenchanting.

title: NEW DELHI WIDENS
description: NEW DELHI, May 14 The Indian Government cracked down furthertoday against railway union leaders and ex; pressed confidence that the nationwide strike was ebbing.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Legislature Approves $115Million Supplemental Budget, With Raises for Judges
description: ALBANY, May 14The Legislature late today approved a $115million supplemental budget containing funds for items not anticipated when the main budget was adopted in March. Included was $4.5million in salary increases for judges and $1.6million for trials of inmates involved in the Attica prison rebellion of 1971.

title: Gibson Wins Reelection Over Imperiale in Newark
description: NEWARK, May 14In a virtual rerun of his 1970 election victory, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today won reelection to second term on the strength of black votes cast in the city's South and Central Wards.

title: 14 Are Hurt, 2 Seriously, In Queens Firehouse Blast
description: An explosion, rumbling out of the cellar of a crowded Queens firehouse as the day and night shifts changed, enveloped two firemen in flames yesterday and sent a dozen others reeling and pitching about the renovated 71. yearold building.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: Collins and Primus In Ailey Spotlight
description: We're celebrating black women, said Alvin Ailey, director of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. So, for the company's new season, Mr. Ailey has invited Janet Collins and Pearl Primus, two black women who were pioneers in the dance, to stage their works for his dancers. The Wedding, by Miss Primus, will have its company premiere tonight.

title: International Paper Sets $145Million On Maine Expansion
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had authorized plans for a $140million expansion of its Androscoggin pulp and paper mill in Jay, Me.

title: 2 BALK AT HEARING IN E. SIDE GAS BLAST
description: An executive and a mechanic from the Federal Pump Repair Company of Brooklyn, the concern that installed and renovated the waterpressure tank the Fire Department says triggered the April 22 gas explosion in an office building at 305 East 45th Street, refused to testify yesterday at a hearing convened by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: U.S. AIDE REPORTS ON SINDONA TALKS
description: ?? tional to own stock directly in R national bank, the law did not prohibit such a person from owning stock in the holding company Meanwhile, an official in the Securities and Exchange Com

title: STOCKS DECLINE ONAMEX AND OTC Market Index Drops 0.65Imperialoil Falls
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower for the third consecutive session yesterday despite a brief rise early in the morning. Prices also fell in the overthecounter market.

title: John F. Kennedy Jr., 13, Robbed of Bike in Park
description: John F. Kennedy Jr., the 13yearold son of the late President, was robbed yesterday afternoon in Central Park of his bicycle and tennis racket while on his way to a tennis lesson. He was not injured.

title: ST. CLAIR REBUKED ON LEGAL DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Raoul Berger, the legal scholar, has given James St. Clair, President Nixon's chief defense attorney, an academic scolding for basing his impeachment defense on what Mr. Berger calls instant history, farfetched theories and sheer effrontery.

title: Wiretap Ruling Dismays Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Federal prosecutors throughout the country reacted with dismayand, in some cases, angerto yesterday's Supreme Court decision that could result in the dismissal of hundreds of cases based on illegal wiretaps.

title: Phone Talks Start Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company opens labor contract bargaining tomorrow with the Communications Workers of America and other unions representing 750,000 workers in its Bell System. Bargaining is being held on a national basis for the first time instead of having individual Bell companies bargain separately, as in the past.

title: Dollar Falls to Lows in Europe
description: LONDON, May 14Uncertainties over the American political situation gripped the European foreignexchange markets today and the dollar fell to lows for the year against several European currencies, before recovering in late trading after reported centralbank intervention.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which by law is exempt from real estate taxes, asked the State Supreme Court to declare that since Grand Central Terminal was involved in the M.T.A.'s operation the terminal should also not be taxed, The city is claiming $2,144,369 in back taxes from the terminal for the period between Jan, 1, 1971, and Dec. 31, 1973, with interest penalties at $21,500 a month.

title: Gifts of Jewels to Nixons From Saudis Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The White House acknowledged today that Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and her daughters had received gifts of jewelry, including a $52,400 matched set of emer alds and diamonds, from the Saudi Arabian royal family.

title: 150 Are Injured in Fracas At Jackson Five Concert
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) More than 50 persons were injured yesterday when groups of youths started a bottlethrowing melee outside Robert F. Kennedy Stadium during Jackson Five concert.

title: Notes on People
description: The last political party leader in France to endorse a candidate for the presidency in Sunday's election was JeanJacques ServanSchreiber, who yesterday urged his followers to vote for Valdry Giscard d'Estaing, the conservative Finance Minister, rather than his leftwing rival, Francois Mitterrand, leader of the Socialist party.

title: Bar Is Accused of Thwarting LowCost Service Prograrni
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The American Bar Association was accused today of illegal attempts to keep lawyers from participating in plans to provide broad lowcost legal service to large numbers of people under a system such as hospital or medical insurance.

title: U.S. FINANCIAL FILES CONSOLIDATION PLAN
description: U. S. Financial, Inc., which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since last July 24, filed yesterday a proposed consolidated plan of arrangement, with the United States Court for the Southern District of California.

title: Jury Selection Begins For 4 in Siege of Store
description: Jury selection began in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday in the trial of four young Muslims accused of murder, kidnapping and robbery in a shootout at a Brooklyn sportinggoods store

title: INQUIRY FOCUSES ON NIXON IN DAY, AFTER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The House Judiciary Committee, ir its second closed impeachment hearing, focused today on the period immediately after flu Watergate burglary in an effort to determine whether President Nixon played any role in the genesis of the attempt to covet up the breakin.

title: SELLERS DEPRESS SILVER CONTRACTS
description: A limit advance in silver futures prices at the opening set off a swarm of profit taking yesterday in that market and the resulting selling quickly spread to other commodity exchanges.

title: NoWork Charge Is Denied By ExHudson County Aide
description: JERSEY CITY, May 14 (UPI) A West New York town clerk has denied chailes in court that he did almost no County paychecks as a traffic administrator.

title: 13 Football Stars In Coaches Game
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., May 11(UPI)Joe Barnes and Kenneth Wallace, who helped Texas Tech to an 111 wonlost season and a Gator Bowl victory last year, have signed to play in the 14th annual Coaches AllAmerica game along with Texas allAmerica center, Bill Wyman.

title: MOZAMBIQUE SEEN IN ECONOMIC WOE
description: LISBON, May 14Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes, who will shortly enter a new Portuguese Government as Defense Minister, acknowledged tonight that the Portuguese territory of Mozambique faced a serious economic and financial crisis as well as antagonism between the black majority and the white minority there.

title: Reform, Albany Style
description: The state's lawmakers offered an appalling demonstration of nonreform in the legislative process the other night when they gave nearunanimous instant approval to a campaign reform bill that most of them had not even read.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Exxon Unit in Thai Oil Deal
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 13 UN)  Thailand sold today to the Esso Exploration Company, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, an oil concession in the Andaman Sea for $44million, an Esso official said. The total price includes concession fees plus bonus and other benefits for the Government. The price for the concession is a record for the right to prospect for nil off Thailand, according to Pramnok Boonyaratanavej, a member of the executive committee of Esso, Thailand.

title: Productivity Unit Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) The House voted to extend the National Commission on Productivity today with predictions that it could help the nation produce more during these inflationary times.

title: About the Mets
description: Jon Matlack and Tug McGraw, the two ranking casualties on the Mets pitching staff, were examined by the Cardinals physician, Dr. Stn London, who found no complications. Matlack strained a muscle in the left thigh last Saturday but will be allowed to try throwing again in a few days, McGraw warmed up in the hull pen Monday night and found some improvement in his left shoulder intellectual note: The Cardinals audience for the Mets opening game included 12,503 straightA high school students, Even Yogi Berra was impressed Rusty Staub injured his shoulder in the National League playoff last October and people have been challenging his arm since then. So far, he's thrown out nine base runners in 32 games this season.

title: People and Business Brimmer Resigns Reserve Post
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, the first black member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and one of the highest ranking blacks in the Federal government, resigned yesterday, effective Aug. 31. On the following day, he will join the faculty of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Nixon Is Supported in Poll Distributed by White House
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) A public opinion poll that the White House is distributing around the country indicates that 54.3 per cent of the people surveyed want President Nixon to remain in office, while 35.3 per cent feel he should resign.

title: Mobil Pays One Month's Salary To NonUnion Aides as a Bonus
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has paid a onetime bonus equivalent to one month's salary to its nonunion employes in the United States.

title: Disaster Area in Dakota
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (Reuters)President Nixon has declared North Dakota a major disaster area because heavy rains, melting snow and flooding caused widespread damage to public, private and agricultural property. His action will permit the use of Government funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: JUDGE SUSPENDS NADER MILK SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 A Federal judge, citing a danger of jeopardizing the rights of a defendant, suspended proceedings today in a suit charging improper political motivetions for an increase in milkprice supports that was ordered in. 1971 by President Nixon.

title: College Results
description: College Results

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS SHOW NO PROGRESS
description: JERUSALEM, May 14Secretary of State KisSinger shuttled between Syria and Israel today without making any significant progress toward troop separation agreement between the two countries.

description: Today's Entries at Belmont

title: Beame Seeks Stronger Ethics Board
description: Mayor Beame is planning change that will greatly increase the status and authority of the city's Board of Ethics for the first time since it was formed in 1959 and became the model for some 500 similar Imunicipal and state bodies.

title: TV Weighs Using Nixon Tapes; Profanity May Pose a Problem
description: The possibility that some or the White House tapes may be played at the open sessions of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings raises the uneasy question at the networks of whether they should be broadcast on national television  profanity, ethnic characterizations and all.

title: Libyan Premier Flies to Soviet In Bid to Replace Egypt as Ally
description: MOSCOW, May 14Premier Abdul Salam Jalloud of Libya flew to Moscow today on a mission apparently designed to advance his country as a replacement for Egypt as a conspicuous ally of the Soviet Union in the Middle East.

title: Music: Reveling in Talents of Mozart
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Last night it was the turn of some of the big guns to let loose some salvos in the current Mozart Festival here. Alexander Schneider conducted the small orchestra at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Isaac Stern played a Mozart violin concerto, and then Mr. Stern and Jaime Laredo joined forces in the great Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola. Another little fillip was the Mozart's Symphony No. 1 (K. 16). He composed it when he was 8 years old.

description: NEWARK, May 14In a virblack votes cast in the city's South and Central Wardstual rerun of his 1970 election victory, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson today won reelection to a second term on the strength of

title: The Dance: An Exultant Celebration
description: There was a mood of exultant celebration at the City Center 55 Street Theater last night, where the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater opened its threeweek season.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO SEIZE 100 ARABS AS REDS
description: JERUSALEM, May 14 (Reuters)  Israeli security forces have arrested nearly 100 Arabs in the occupied West Bank area of Jordan on charges of belonging to the Palestinian National Front, a Jordanian Communist organization, Israeli newspapers reported today.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs in the States Unhappy Over Transcripts
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 I'm disappointed, said Kent 11. McGough, the Ohio Republican chairman, It showed the operations around the White House not to be on the high plane I anticipated. It was very disenchanting.

title: 2Year Term for Osteopath
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) Dr. David S. Shaid, an osteopath who pleaded guilty April 15 to eight counts of Medicare fraud, was sentenced today to two years in a Federal prison. He also was fined $10,000 and placed on probation for three years after his release. The fine is in addition to a $75,000 payment he agree to make to avoid a civil suit.

title: NATIONAL AIRPORT POLICE CHIEF OUSTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Federal Aviation Administration has removed the police chief at National Airport and initiated other changes as the result of Congressional criticism.

title: Roncallo Says He Advised Donor to Complain to D.A.
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 14Representative Angelo D. Roncallo testified today that he had told a disgruntled businessman to take his complaints of political coercion to the District Attorney.

title: Memorex Announces Shift
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., May 14 (AP)The Memorex Corporation announced today that it had changed its public accounting firm from Arthur Anderson & Co. to Haskins & Sells. The computerequipment manufacturer said it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission of the change in a letter.

title: Outbursts Anger Judge At Trot Trial
description: One defense lawyer drew his sixth contempt citation and another provoked Judge Orrin G. Judd into a rare loss of temper yesterday during the racefixing trial of harness drivers in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: Indians Clash in South Dakota As Judge Ponders Trial Delay
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 141 A Sioux Falls garage operator) sprayed several American In dians with a fire extinguisher and Indian women threw rocks at state prosecutors here this afternoon while a Federal judge pondered whether to delay or transfer the trial of five indians accused of creating a disturbance in Custer, S.D., in February, 1973.

title: U.S. FINANCIAL FILES CONSOLIDATION PLA
description: U. S. Financial, Inc., whicl has been operating under Chap ter XI of the Federal Bank ruptcy Act since last July 24 filed yesterday a proposed con solidated plan of arrangemen with the United States Cour for the Southern District o California.

title: INTERSTATE STORES FACES TRADING CURB
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it plans to suspend trading before the May 28 opening in the common stock and 4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 1992, of Interstate Stores, Inc. Also slated for suspension are the 4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 1981, under, the company's former name, Interstate Department Stores, Inc.

title: Can Workers to Get Raise
description: PITTSBURGH, May 14 (UPI) About 36,300 members of the United Steelworkers of America employed in the can industry will begin receiving a 15centsanhour costofliving adjustment in pay tomorrow. About 400,000 members employed in the basic steel industry received a similar adjustment May 1.

title: PRICES OF BONDS FINISH DAY MIXED Lackluster Trading Marks Three Major Markets
description: Bond prices turned mixed yesterday in lackluster trading in the corporate, taxexempt and Government markets. The start of this week's round of new offerings in the corporate and taxexempt sectors appeared moderately successful. Participants, with $1.1billion in Federal agency obligations due Thursday as well as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $500million of debentures expected the same day, showed signs of some restraint on the day's new marketings. Markets Credit
