description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Yankee Records
description: Yankee Records

title: Mrs. Chisholm Asserts Blacks Now Resist School Integration
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm told a conference of civil rights leaders here yesterday that some of her black constituents and fellow members of the Black Caucus in Congress were having second thoughts about fighting for school integration.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: People in Sports
description: I feel confident I'll be playing somewhere this fall, says Lance Hentzel, despite the fact that he's not on the Los Angeles Rams roster or in their brochure. Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, suspended the Rams receiver year ago for conduct detrimental to pro football. Rentzel was convicted of marijuana possession while still on N.F.L. probation for pleading guilty to an indecent exposure charge in 1971 while with Dallas.

title: Haig Said to Testify Simon Warned of Hughes Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., reportedly told a closeddoor session of the Senate Watergate committee today that he was warned a year ago by William E. Simon, then Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, that a Federal investigation of a $100,000 political contribution from Howard R, Hughes had reached the point where it could eventually prove an embarrassment to President Nixon.

title: Aeros Triumph Over Cougars, 61
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) Andre Hinse scored twice and the Houston Aeros swamped the Chicago Cougars, 61, tonight to take a 20 lead in their fourofseven game World Hockey Association final.

title: Haig Sauid to Testify Simon Warned of Hughes Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., reportedly told a closeddoor session of the Senate Watergate committee today that he was warned a year ago by William E. Simon, then Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, that a Federal investigation of a $100,000 political contribution from Howard R. Hughes had reached the point where it could eventually prove an embarrassment to President Nixon.

title: Screen: Butchery Binge:Morrissey's 'Warhol's Frankenstein' Opens
description: Nowadays, flashing your hash can be a tribute to the film makerjust as belching was said to compliment the hosts of ancient China. While one suspects that the tales about upchuck at "The Exorcist" were eagerly exaggerated, "Andy Warhol's Frankenstein," written and directed by Paul Morrisey, almost begs the gorge to rise. Hence those with iron guts may rank as Philistines  unable to respond to the call of art. The movie opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and West.A fascistic baron (Udo Kier), who plans to create and control a new master race, assembles beautiful rigid zombies out of freshly killed spare parts. As his hands caress kidneys, spleens and gall bladders, his unfinished creatures appear like mutilated corpses, and disembowelment becomes a substitute for sex. (Some of the innards resemble lobster salad, an evocation that stresses the obvious expense of this production.) Throughout, the accents of the wicked are as thick as minestrone"Let's get rrrid of ziss useless trrrunk"  and the blood splashes as noisily as an open fire hydrant.3-D effects (summoning wistful memories of "House of Wax") are used to project the butchery: Dripping giblets on forceps are thrust into the audience, while the performers  including Joe Dallesandro as a sulky stud and Monique Van Vooren as the baron's huffy wife and sister  practically leap into your lap. Since much of the action is slow, these diversions are welcome, although hanging onto the 3-D glasses can be rough if you're a nearsighted, note-taking smoker.In a muddy way, the movie attempts to instruct us about the universal insensitivity, living-deadness and the inabilty to be turned on by anythng short of the grotesque. However, this "Frankenstein" drags as much as it camps; "despite a few amusing moments, it fails as a spoof, and the result is only a coy binge in degradation.

title: 25 Emmys Awarded To CBSTV Shows In Prime Time Slot
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15 Winners of this year's Emmy awards were announced today, and CBSTV, which led in the rating all year and is dominant in situation comedies, won majority of the awards.

title: Recruiting Goal of Army Is Short Again for Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)The Army once again missed its recruiting goals in April, taking in 90 per cent of is objective of 15,600 men, Army sources said today. But officials were increasingly optimistic that the allvolun teer idea would work.

title: Letters to the. Editor
description: Beholdhow good and how pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity.

title: International Harvester Shows Record Earnings
description: The International Harvester Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fiscal quarter and six months ended April 30, reflecting the strong demand for all major product groups  trucks and agricultural, industrial and construction equipment. The report said that the demand for heavyduty trucks offset domestic declines in lightduty units because of customer concern about the availability of fuel.

title: Threats by Nixon Reported on Tape Heard by Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The tape recording of President Nixon's Sept. 15, 1972, conversation with H. R. Haldeman and John W. Dean, 3d, which was heard today by members of the House Judiciary Committee, contains at least one long passage that does not appear in the edited White House transcript of that tape, according to a committee source.

title: Bahnsen's 2Hitter. Tops Blyleven of Twins, 10
description: Stan Bahnsen, for the second time in successive seasons, flirted with baseball's superlative pitching effort, a nohitter, last night in Chicago's White Sox Stadium, before beating Minnesota, 10.

title: OIL DEPLETION AID 11 FACES HOUSE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Democratic members of the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to force a straight yesorno vote in the House on immediate termination of the 22 per cent depletion allowance for the oil industry.

title: LESLIE B. WILLIAMS, CHEMICAL ENGINEER
description: Col. Leslie B. Williams, executive director since 1968 of the American Society for Engineering Education, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He was 59 years old.

title: WORLD BANK BONDS SET FOR EMIRATES
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (Reutern)  The World Bank announced the signing of anagree ment at par of the bank's bonds in the United Arab Emirates. The aggregate principal amount of the bonds is 300 million dirhams, equivalent to $76million.

title: SCHEEL IS ELECTED PRESIDENT IN BONN
description: BONN, May 15  Walter Scheel was elected to the ceremonial office of the West German presidency today in demonstration of solidarity between the two governing coalition parties, Mr. Scheel's Free Democrats and the Social Democrats.

title: DILORFRO LINKED TO THE RAO CASE Identified as the Judge Wha Allegedly Arranged Bail in a Robbery Case
description: Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo was identified yesterday by informed sources as the judge who allegedly took care of the disposition of robbery case that led to perjury case against another judge.

title: Beame Budget
description: Whatever else New Yorkers may have hoped for when they elected Abraham D. Beanie as Mayor last year, they had every right to expect drastic reforms the annual agony from which a new city expense budget ultimately emerges. Widely respected as a prudent fiscal expert, Mr. Beame could be counted upon, most citizens firmly believed, to put an end to the obfuscation, the manipulation and the reckless resort to borrowing for which the veteran Controller had repeatedly criticized his predecessors.

title: PAUL W. GUYLER, 69, LED TRAVELERS AID
description: Paul W. Guyler, who retired in 1973 as executive director of Travelers AidInternational Social Service of America, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 126 East 24th Street.

title: His Tennis Team Is Not Fond of Okker's Absence
description: UNIONDALE, LI., May 15Tom Okker of the TorontoBuffalo Royals was in Las Vegas. Nikki Pilic of the New York Sets was in a jet somewhere over the Atlantic Ocean. And the fans must have been at home watching television as the shorthanded Royals decisively defeated equally shorthanded Sets, 33.22, tonight in their World Team Tennis contest at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: 3 Suspects in Death 1 Of a Jewelry Clerk Seized After Chase
description: Three suspects in the slaying of a clerk during a jewelry store holdup on the East Side yesterday afteroon were seized by the police with the aid of private security guard who witnessed the holdup and then followed the men through the crowded streets.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two brothers who allegedly attacked three bakery employes in Newark with baseball bats were charged with murder after one of the victims shot and killed another man involved in the alleged attack. The suspects, Gerald Kupchack, 19 years old, and his brother John, 21, both of Newark, were charged with homicide in connection with the death of a third man who allegedly took part in the attack, Joseph D'Onofrio, 21, also of Newark.

title: Beanie Proposes $11.1Billion Budget
description: Mayor Beame formally presented his first operating budget as the city's chief executive yesterday, labeling it an austerity blueprint that call for sepnding $11.1billion to run the municipal government in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: For the fourth consecutive session, prices closed lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as a broad retreat by Canadian petroleum stocks and investor concern over rising interest rates continued to exert pressures on investors. Similar conditions prevailed in overthecounter trading.

title: Shaky Economy Lures Record Number at Columbia to Law and Medicine
description: Richard Briffault was managing editor of the campus newspaper, but he isn't going into journalismhe's going to law school. Larry Dana had no idea what he wanted to do when he took a year off and did menial tasks for an insurance company, but he knows nowhe's going to medical school. Warren Stern has been admitted to the Harvard Law Schoolbut he isn't sure he even would have applied if he hadn't gone to a college where everybody wanted to go to law school.

title: THRIFT UNITS SCORE ADMINISTRATION BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (Reuters)Congress was told today that the Administration's financial reform legisiation, as now written, is a death warrant for the savings and loan business.

title: Busing of Pupils Upheld In a Senate Vote of 4746
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 The Senate in effect upheld today the busing of children to end school segregation by vote of 47 to 46.

title: Dissension Flares Again At the Brooklyn Museum
description: The divisiveness that has tormented the Brooklyn Museum for a year and that seemed to have abated with the resignation last December of its director, Duncan F. Cameron, has surfaced again, complicating the museum's search for a permanent director.

title: U.S. to Appeal in Calley Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Justice Department said today it would appeal a decision that permitted William L. Calley Jr. to be freed from confinement. The department said a notice of appeal was filed yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans. The former Army lieutenant, who was convicted in the slaying of Vietnamese civilians at My Lai, was freed on his own recognizance in February.

title: Havlicek, Erving Not Eager For a Basketball Super Bowl
description: While some of the club owners in the National and American Basketball Associations talk and think merger, John Havlicek and Julius Erving like it the way it is two leagues, two champions and the players salaries skyrocketing.

title: Schick, After Loss, To Omit Dividend On Preferred Stock
description: Schick, Inc., which has not paid cash dividends on its common stock since 1958, is also omitting the June 1 quarterly dividend on the preferred, Edward E. Ettinger, chairman, announced yesterday. More than 90 per cent of the preferred is owned by the Schick Investment Company, an affiliate.

title: JOB COMPENSATION TO GET U.S. STUDY Nixon, Calling for Reform, Asks Report Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) President Nixon contended today that state systems for workers compensation have not kept pace with the times and announced formation of a Federal task force to spur reforms.

title: BudgetMaking Process
description: A process that began last December with a solicitous question about a bear that had a toothache reached its peak yesterday when Mayor Beame made public an $11.1billion budget with which he proposed to operate the government of this city of eight million people in the year starting July 1.

title: Fire in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 15 (AP)Fire destroyed rows of small shops and houses in Bangkok business district today, killing six persons and leaving 100 homeless.

title: Watergate. Case Viewed as Peril To Concept of National Security
description: WASHINGTON, May 15By Invoking national security as an integral part of the Watergate affair, President Nixon has set in motion a series of political, constitutional and legal detotes and maneuvers that may continue long after the immediate issues of Watergate are resolved.

title: On Puffery
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Carmine DeSapio, boss of Tammany Hall a generation ago, abolished the smokefilled room during his tenure as leader because his eyes were sensitive to smoke.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Channel 13 will preempt, of all things, War and Peace tonight to show what may be the final game of the Stanley Cup

title: Crime Against Peace
description: The Palestinian lunatic fringe has committed the most abominable yet of its long series of cowardly, murderous outrages. The purpose of yesterday's attack at Maalot, the holding of scores of schoolchildren as hostages, was as obvious as it was heinous: so to inflame passions and suspicions that the negotiations for disengagement between Israel and Syria would collapse.

title: GAF TO RAISE PRICES ON VINYL ASBESTOS
description: The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that  it would raise prices by a range of 10 per cent to 20 per cent on its entire line of vinyl asbestos floor tile, effective June 1.

title: Cardinals Trounce Mets, 101
description: ST. LOUIS, May 15The St. Louis Cardinals buried the New York Mets, 101, tonight under a barrage of 16 hits that included four home runs and sent Jerry Koosman to his first defeat of the season.

title: Disaster Aid Bill Passed
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The House passed today and sent to the White House compromise legislation making expanded disaster assistance available to victims of  recent tornadoes that devastated portions of the South and the Middle West. President Nixon was expected to sign the bill.

title: Music and Theater Blend in Club Debut By Miss Fitzgerald;
description: Geraldine Ftilzgaald, whose acting careen has taken her from the Gate Theater in Dublin to Broadway, Hollywood, television and, most recently, street theater in New York, is making her nightclub debut this week at Reno Sweeney with what she describes as an evening of street songs.

title: White House Silent on Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The White House, which disclosed some of President Nixon's most sensitive conversations when it released recently the transcript of some Watergate tapes, appeared to be taking an opposite tack this week and seeking to remain silent on the entire impeachment issue.

title: PICKET AT HOSPITAL IS SHOT IN SHOULDER
description: A 24yearold man among group of 20 persons who were picketing outside the Lincoln Hospital was shot in the shoulder and three others were injured in a scuffle yesterday, the police of the Alexander Avenue station reported.

title: Democrats All Smiles for Queens Party Dinner
description: Knives were only for cutting the roast beefand not the throats of fellow Democratsat a rambunctious dinner of the Queens County Democratic organization that ran well into early yesterday morning. The evening included an epidemic of embraces, abbrazzos, backslapping, cheekpinching, crushing handshakes and torrents, of mutual flattery.

title: Bitterness Is Voiced In a Cry of 'Revenge!'
description: TEL AVIV, May 15The people of Israel reacted with deep bitterness today to the killings at Maalot.

title: Professional Nurses Open Strike for Wages in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, May 15 lawaii's first strike by professional nurses sharply curailed operations today at the Kaiser Permanente medical facility in Waikiki and threatened to spread to other hospitals in the city.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on International Trade Law10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BudgetMaking Process
description: A process that began last December with a solicitous question about a bear that had a toothache reached its peak yesterday when Mayor Beame made public an $11.1billion budget with which he proposed to operate the government of this city of eight million people in the year starting July 1.

title: Mrs. Meir Pledges Steps To Protect Israeli People
description: JERUSALEM, May 15Premier Golda Meir promised numbed nation tonight that Israel would do everything possible to protect her people against terrorist attacks.

title: Missile Tests Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, asked the Senate Appropriations Committee today to deny funds for test launching of Minuteman missiles in Montana i'next winter. He contended that tests would be a hazard to lives and property.

title: White House Files Contain Job Data for 3,000
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Some 3,000 toplevel Government employes have been advised that their names and other vital statistics  including ethnic background and political affiliations  are filed in a White House computer.

title: City Market Basket Increased 16.3% inthe Last Year
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went, up 16.3. per cent in the last year, the Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterdayl as it marked the first anniversary of its weekly Market] Basket Survey.

title: Ecology Groups Offer Ratings Of Legislators Vote Records;
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15  A blizzard of charts as big as small tablecloths is signaling the start of environmental activists nationwide efforts to influence 1974 election contests.

title: Dominican Bid Made To Get Opposition To Join in Election
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 15The Government of President Joaquin Balaguer sought through the day today to persuade the country's main opposition group to participate in the election tomorrow.

title: New Environmental chief Will Focus on Land Use
description: TRENTON, May 15 David J. Bardin, the new Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said today that controls over land use in New Jersey would be a major challenge to his office, and he warned that failure to deal with the problem on an urgent basis now would mean a higher price in the future.

title: Notes on People
description: Ian Ball, the former mental patient accused of trying to kidnap Princess Anne and with wounding three persons in the attempt, will go on trial in London's Old Bailey courthouse next Wednesday on six charges of attempted murder and kidnapping. He was ordered held for trial yesterday.

title: ULSTER BADLY HIT BY PROTEST STRIKE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 15 Ulster was badly hit today by a general strike called by militant Protestants against the proposed allIreland council.

title: WILLIAM S. MURPHY
description: William Storey Murphy, a retired foreign exchange broker who had headed his own firm in the financial district for many years, died yesterday at his home, 116 East 83d Street. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW BUS STRIKE NOW THREATENED
description: CLIFTON, May 15Between 18,000 and 20,000 passengers using Clifton Bus Company routes, which primarily serves Morris and Essex Counties, may be forced to find other means of transportation when the contract with the company's 200 drivers expires Friday at midnight.

title: Jumpers to Close Saturday
description: Tom Stoppard's comedy Jumpers will end its run at the Billy Rose Theater on Saturday, after 32 performances. The comedy, starring Brian Bedford and Jill Clayburgh, was directed by Peter Wood. It opened here on April 22 under the sponsorship of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in cooperation with the Billy Rose Foundation.

title: Advertising: Meeting at J.W.T.
description: Those poor folks down in Washington, they can walk or ride all, over the place and hardly ever see an adnone on cabs, none on buses and, since 1902no billboards. Well, coming to their rescue is Environmental Advertising of America, which will be selling poster space on the four sides of 10,000 MediaKiosk Displaysor fancy trash cans.

title: Colonial: TexasStyle Masters Golf
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 15In a state where bigness is a proud trademarkthe DallasFort Worth airport is bigger than Manhattan Island the Colonial Country Club plays a cooperative role. It is a big monster, a fitting venue for the Colonial National Tournament, first of the season's designated tournaments, which begins tomorrow.

title: Southern Pacific's Plans
description: Southern Pacific Company stockholders were told at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday that its capital, improvement expenditures this year would reach $297million, of which $240million will be for the company's railroad subsidiary. The last three years have been the best three years we've ever had, Benjamin F. Biaggini, president, told the meeting and he added, 1974 shapes up as another good year.

title: Bathsheba Tapestries Grace Metropolitan
description: One of the more eccentric of human institutions is the Mode de Cluny. Born of a forced marriage between the finest remaining medieval town house in Paris and a set of majestic but irremediably tumbledown Roman baths, it was opened in 1844. In no time at all it became the repository of a great many very beautiful objects from near and far. Near in this context could mean the Sainte Chapelle, five minutes walk down the hill. Far could mean Basel, Burgos, Florence, Toledo. This was one of the great ages of accumulation; and when a magpie assumes human shape and travels on a French passport there's no limit to what it can get hold of.

title: Argentine Colonel Released
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 15 (AP) An Argentine Army colonel held by leftist guerrillas since last November was freed today, the police said. No other details were available on the release of Col. Florencio Crespo, 49 years old.

title: PRINTERS IN CAPITAL AUTHORIZE A STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Union printers voted by a 3to1 margin today to authorize a strike against The Washington Post and The Washington StarNews, their leaders announced.

title: Personal Finance
description: A taxpayer cannot shield money against seizure by placing it in certain types of trust accounts for children, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Channel 13 will preempt, of all things, War and Peace tonight to show what may be the final game of the Stanley Cup

title: Merrick Passes Budget
description: Residents of Merrick, L. I., yesterday approved a $5,663,507 school budget by a vote of 968 to 357. The new budget reflects an increase of $154,054 over last year's but the tax rate will be 24 cents lower, at $5.82 for each $100 of assessed valuation, because of lower interest payments on outstanding loans.

title: 1,960 Receive Baccalaureates
description: The meaning of Watergate and the nation's reactions to the scandal provided the points of departure for major commencement addresses yesterday at Columbia University and Barnard College.

title: Hope Cooke, Separated From the King of Sikkim, Is Living on the East Side
description: Hope Cooke, the Sarah Lawrence debutante who became the Queen of Sikkim in the Himalayas, has left her husband, the King, and is living almost unnoticed on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Leone Designates May as Festival of the Arts Month in Brooklyn
description: Bright sunshine and warm temperatures brought out many onlookers at the plaza in front of Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday as Borough President Sebastian Leone esiwated May as the borough's Festival of the Arts.

title: Paterson Mayor, Loser by 161, Said to Plan a Recount Demand
description: Mayor Thomas C. Rooney Jr. of Paterson who apparently lost a bid for reelection to Lawrence F. Kramer by 161 votes, was asked to have the voting machines impounded and will almost certainly demand a recount, an aide said yesterday.

title: Rheumatic Fever Test Vaccine Is Reported to Display Promise
description: WASHINGTON, May 15An experimental vaccine sprayed into the nose and mouth shows promise of helping to prevent rheumatic fever and some serious diseases of the kidneys, scientists reported today.

title: SETBACK IS SEEN IN PEACE EFFORTS
description: JERUSALEM, May 15The terrorist attack at Maalot today forced Secretary, of State Kissinger to suspend his Middle East peace efforts for one day.

title: N.H.L. Championship
description: May 7Bost. 3, Phila. 2.

title: EXON BIG WINNER IN NEBRASKA RACE
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 15Gov. J. J. Exon won convincingly in Nebraska's Democratic primary election yesterday, not only auguring a secondterm triumph in November but also putting himself in a solid position for a 1976 run for the United States Senate.

title: Mrs. Graham Given Ovation at Columbia On Honorary LL.D.
description: The longest applause at the Columbia University commencement yesterday greeted the award of an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to Mrs. Katharine Graham, publisher of The Washington Post.

title: CHAPIN SENTENCED TO 1030 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, was sentenced today to a minimum of 10 months in prison for lying to a Watergate grand jury about political sabotage in the 1972 campaign.

title: Senate Votes $150Million For Stricken Lands Relief
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) The Senate passed by voice vote today a $150million aid authorization bill to provide disaster relief to Pakistan, Nicaragua and droughtstricken areas of Africa.

title: Gasoline Output Up Last Week But Off From Level in 73
description: WASHINGTON. May 15 (AP) The American Petroleum Institute reported today that cial tat estimated gasoline production for aviation and motor purposes for the latest week amounted to 6.33 million barrels a day, compared with 6.27 million barrels a day in the previous week and 6.6 million barrels a day a year ago.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Article on Jewels Is for the Birds, Mrs. Nixon Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 15(UPI) Mrs. Richard Nixon, in her first public remarks on a report that she kept gifts of jewelry for nearly two years without advising White House record keepers, said today the article was for the birds.

title: A Mozambique Town Fears More Violence
description: INHAMINGA, Mozambique, May 14  Around this raw, onesaloon railway junction town deep in the bush, at least 221 blacks are reported to have been rounded up and killed by Portuguese forces in the first four months of this year.

title: Horses & Equipment
G.I. Bill Is Broadened
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The House refused today to pass a Senate bill extending Vietnam veterans benefits another two years without also expanding them by an estimated $2billion annually. Instead, the bill was broadened to expand benefits in the manner voted by the House two months ago when it sent the Senate its own veterans benefits bill.

title: Meetings Would Exclude Big Oil Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 The Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the producing states now preferred to negotiate prices with other governments rather than with the internatidnal oil companies.

title: MAYORSURGE CHANGE IN POLICE RESIDENCY
description: TRENTON, May 15 (AP)The mayors of New Jersey's major cities told a legislative committee today that they would like theilr police and firemen to live in town. The mayors of Newark, Jersey City, Trenton and Paterson, or spokesmen for them, told the committee they favor a Senate bill that would give municipalities the option of requiring public safety personnel to live where they worked.

title: JACOB L MORENO, PSYCHIATRIST, 82
description: BEACON, N. Y., May 15 (AP)Dr. Jacob L. Moreno, the psychiatrist who pioneered psychodrama as a method for treating mental illness, died at his home here yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: TV: Author, on Cavett Show, Tells of Sex Change
description: Tonight at 11:30, the sole guest on ABCTV's The Dick Cavett Show is Jan Morris, a woman who, until a transsexual operation two years ago, lived for more than 40 years as a man. James Morris had been a travel writer and journalist, his major stories for The Times of London including an eyewitness account of the Hilary expedition to conquer Mount Everest. He was also married and the father of five children, one of whom died in infancy.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: For the last three years the Stanley Cup champion has won the deciding game on the opponent's home rink. In 1971 the Montreal Canadiens took the title in Chicago, the next year the Boston Bruins triumphed in Madison Square Garden and last year the Canadiens again won in Chicago.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Perhaps the African art inspired him, The faces of small wooden statues and straw masks, primitive artifacts of Zaire on loan from the Tribal Arts Gallery, stared from behind him. Other props included wooden drums, which were superfluous, Muhammad All has never needed drums in order to beat them. In the Rainbow Room yesterday, 65 floors above the sidewalks where he acclaims himself as the people's heavyweight champion, he produced his finest performance as an orator. His style as a speaker always has been part Demosthenes, part Billy Graham, part Edgar Guest and part Flip Wilsonhardly the best of each but surely the loudest of each. And when George Foreman, apparently saving his breath for the chase, didn't appear, Muhammad All was all alone at the microphone. I was just setting down here thinking, he opened, how I fought Ronnie O'Keefe, a little white boy, back in Louisville in my first amateur fight, Won a threeround decision, Got paid $4.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Edison Captures Queens Title Track
description: Edison posted eight victories and scored 173 points yesterday to win the Queens public high schools track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Bryant and Jackson were second and third, respectively.

title: Western Union Asks F.C.C. For Increases on Telegrams
description: Western Union asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to permit price increases of up to 42 per cent or telegrams sent within the continental United States and Canada, The Associated Press reported.

title: Reds in Cambodia Sink Mekong Barge With U.S. Munitions
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 15 (UPI)  Communist gunners sank an ammunition barge today and set afire two other vessels in an attack on a Meking River convoy.

title: Assembly Leadership Kills Bill That Would Assist Con Edison
description: ALBANY, Thursday, May 16 The Assembly leadership or dered Governor Wilson's bill) that would have rescued the financially pressed Consolidated Edison Company killed in the Assembly early today, after it appeared certain that the State Controller would be given carte blanche to conduct a full audit of the affairs of the company.

title: That Soviet Gas
description: President Nixon apparently wants to give his Russian hosts next month a firm commitment in the joint development of Siberian natural gas reserves, without having at the same time to assume specific responsibility for the controversial project before the United States Congress and public.

title: Senate Approves Measure to Curtail the Activities of Lobbyists
description: ALBANY, May 15The Senate voted final approval today of a bill designed to control the activities of lobbyists, as critics of the measure said it would penalize amateur groups and exempt public officials who lobbied heavily for or against legislation.

title: G.A.O. Study Citing Fairness of I. R. S. Called Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Tax Reform Research Group said today that a report by the General Accounting Office on the Internal Revenue service was inadequate and does not contain sufficient evidence to support its conclusion that taxpayers are treated fairly.

title: An Amnesty in Turkey Reduces Life Sentences of 3 Americans
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 15 (UPI)The National Assembly passed a disputed amnesty bill today that reduced the life sentences of three Americans and freed a British teenager. All had been convicted on drug charges.

title: Market Place. Negotiations In Small Trades
description: Since the beginning of April, Big Board member firms have had Securities and Exchange Commission permission to negotiate commission rates on stock transactions involving less than $2,000.

title: Industrial Production. Up 0.4% in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 The fourmonth slide in industrial production came to at least a temporary halt in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Con Ed's Nuclear Plant Shut Down for Repairs
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that a steam safety valve blew Monday night at its main nuclear plant at Indian Point and the plant was shut down.

title: Baraka Party Seen on Wane After Gibson Vote
description: NEWARK, May 15  In the aftermath of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's emphatic reelection as an independent, the Community's Choice designation, under which the Mayor ran successfully for a first term in 1970, app ared today in splinters.

title: Radio
description: 9:0610 AM, WQXR: Piano Personalities. Harold Bauer and Arthur Friedheim. Scherzo No. 3, Polonaise No. 1, Chopin; Hungarian Rhapsody No. 2, Transcendental Etude, Liszt.

title: United Air Lines And American Post Improved Results
description: United Air Lines, the nation's largest domestic air carrier, and American Air Lines, the second largest, reported yesterday sharply improved results for April.

title: People and Business
description: Consumer electronics products will become a $42billion worldwide business in the next decade, an RCA official predicted yesterday.

title: SYRIA PESSIMISTIC ON GOLAN ACCORD
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 15  The Palestinian attack on the Israeli school deepened the pessimism today among Syrian officials involved in negotiations with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Long Branch's Mayor Gains Reelection by 2.1 Margin
description: LONG BRANCH, May 15Mayor Henry R. Cioff won a second term yesterday, defeating three opponents by more than a 21 margin in an election after being cleared of corruption charges just six days before the vote.

title: Beame Asks $11.1Billion For an Austerity Budget
description: Mayor Beame formally presented his first operating budget as the city's chief executive yesterday, labeling it an austerity blueprint that calls for spending $11.1billion to run the municipal government in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: LEGAL
description: To the Debtors, Creditors, Policyholders, Stockholders, Persons having claims against Policyholders, and all Other Persons Interested in the Affairs of PROFESSIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK. NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN: BENJAMIN R. SCHENCK, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York has been directed by an order of the Supreme Court, New York County, made and entered on April 12, 1974, to take possession of the property of PROFESSIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK and to liquidate Its business Pursuant to Article XVI of the Insurance Law of the Slate of New York, The undersigned has, pursuant to said Article, aepointed JAMES W. DOWLING, Special Deputy Superintendent of Insurance and LEONARD H. MINCHES, Assistant Special Deputy Superintendent of Insurance, as his agents, to liquidate the business of said company at the office of said Deputies, 116 John Street, Borough of Manhattan, City and State of New York, 10038. Pursuant to the aforesaid order, the Proceeding for rehabilitation of PROFESSIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK, heretofore commenced, has been terminated, its charter has been forfeited, surrendered, and annulled and the company is dissolved. The rights and liabilities of said company and of all persons under Insurance obligations of the said company, except ball bonds, will cease and are fixed as of July 12, 1974, 12 o'clock midnight, Eastern Daylight Savings Time. To have continuing coverage, all persons whose policies are now In force are required to replace such policies in another company before July 12, 1974The Liquidation Order further provides that the rights and liabilities of said Company and of all persons under BAIL BONDS, issued by the said Company, will cease and are fixed as of October 14, 1974, 12:00 o'clock Midnight, Eastern Daylight Savings Time. To have continuing BAIL BOND coverage, all persons whose BAIL BONDS are now In force, are required to replace such BAIL BONDS in another Company before October 14, 1974, The Liquidation Order further provides that all other subsisting contracts and other obligations of the company terminate, and all other liability thereunder cease and be fixed as of April 12, 1974. All persons Indebted to or having any property of said company In their possession are hereby required forth with to render an account of said indebtednese and to pay the same and deliver such Property to the Liquidator at his office above stated. All creditors of PROFESSIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY OF NEW YORK and all persons having any unsatisfied claims or demands against It or Its policyholders are hereby required to present the same in writing duly subscribed and affirmed by him as true to JAMES W. DOWLING at his office above stated ON OR BEFORE JANUARY 13, 1975, WHICH IS THE LAST DAY SET BY COURT ORDER FOR THE FILING OF CLAIMS IN THE LIQUIDATION PROCEEDING. A form of proof of claim is furnished herewith, ALL POLICYHOLDERS ARE URGED TO FILE A CLAIM FOR THEIR POLICY PROTECTION WHETHER OR NOT A CLAIM HAS BEEN FILED AGAINST H POLICYHOLDER IN THE SAME FORMT ASE SET FORTH IN PARAGRAPH VI. OF THIS NOTICE. The attention of policyholders, who are defendants in actions on account of claims arising out of occurences in connecltion with III the kinds of insurance with lespect to coverage of property or risks located or resident In the State of New York and which come within the provisions of Section ?.34 of the Insurance Law, IS PARTICULARLY DIRECTED TO THE ADDITIONAL ENCLOSED NOTICE AFFECTING SUCH PERSONS. All persons and policyholders against whom actions are now Pending, who do not come within the provisions of Section 334 of the New York Insurance Law, concerning which the company may be liable on its policies or contracts and which have been defended up to the dale of the order of liquidation on their behalf by an attorney employed or retained by the company, are advised that the employment or retention of said attorney has been terminated by the entry of the order of liquidation. EACH SUCH PERSON IS THEREFORE ADVISED TO EITHER RETAIN THE SAID ATTORNEY AS HIS ATTORNEY TO CONTINUE TO REPRESENT HIM IN THE ACTION OR TO SUBSTITUTE AN ATTORNEY OF HIS OWN CHOICE, AT HIS OWN EXPENSE. Reasonable and necessary expenses In relation thereto may lie included and be the part of the subject matter of your claim in the Liquidation Proceeding. Liabilities will be determined as to all claims duly presented and all assets will he distributed In accordance with the Insurance Law of the Stale of New York without further notice to persons faillm, to Present claims within the aforesaid time. All communications and transactions relating to the company and to the liquidation thereof should be addressed to said JAMES W. DOWLING at his office above slated. Dated: New York, N.Y., April IS, 1974. BENJAMIN R, SCHENCK. Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New Ions, as Ileuidator. JAMES W. DOWLING, Special peputy Superintendent of Insurance, LEONARD H. MINCHES, Asst. Special Deputy Superin.

title: Arab Terror: Earlier Acts
description: A list follows of major Arab terrorist activities since Feb. 10, 1970, when an attack on an El Al Israel Airlines plane at Munich killed one passenger and wounded eight. An Egyptian and two Jordanians were arrested but they were later set free.

title: World Team Tennis
description: TORONTOButi ale 33, New York 22. Chicago at Houston. Philadelphia 35, Cleveland 30. Baltimore 31, Detroit 28. Golden Gaters at Minnesota. Florida at Los Angeles. Pittsburgh at Boston. Only matches scheduled.

title: India Is Disrupted by General Strike Supporting Rail Stoppage
description: NEW DELHI, May 15A oneday nationwide general strike, supporting India's picketing railworkers, disrupted major cities in India today but failed to paralyze the nation.

title: Calley Asks Data for Appeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 14 (AP)Attorneys for William L. Calley Jr. filed motions in Federal District Court here today requesting the Government to produce all testimony heard by Army and Congressional committees that investigated the My Lai massacre. The former Army lieutenant is seeking to reverse his conviction for the murder of 22 South Vietnamese civilians at My Lai in 1968.

title: Yankees Lose to Tigers, 65, on.Errors BasesFull Walk
description: There's nothing subtle about the difference between the Yankees old manager and their new one. Ralph Houk and Bill Virdon depicted the difference in full view of everyone at Shea Stadium yesterday as Detroit gained a 65 decision in one of the sloppier games of the season.

title: Expansion Is Set by Jones & Laughlin
description: The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday plans for spending $200million on expansion of steelmaking and finishing facilities at its Aliquippa Works about 15 miles northwest of Pittsburgh on the Ohio River.

title: City Ballet Gets $800,000 From State
description: The crisisbeset New York City Ballet yesterday was promised a oneyear $800,000 grant from the New York State Council on the Arts for the year starting July 1, the largest oneyear grant in the company's history and one of the largest ever given by the state agency.

title: VICTORIOUS GIBSON MARKS 43D YEAR
description: NEWARK, May 15Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson celebrated his 43d birthday today by jogging three miles around the Weequahic Park lake before going to the office to resume normal work schedule after his strong reelection victory yesterday.

title: Goodby, Scarsdale. I Wish You Well
description: Goodby Scarsdale. It was fun while it lasted. You had nothing to do with the breakup of our marriage. But you were the setting. You were what we wanted, what most kids in the Bronx in the nineteenfifties wanted. Family. Upward mobility. Land. Trees. Commuter railroad. Split levels. Colonials. Wall  to  wall carpeting. The American dream. And, you delivered, Scarsdale. You really did. The children had room in which to romp. The schools, which are your major industry, seemed to live up to their reputation. Life was good. Tennis. Paddleball. Swimming pools in the summers. Barbecues. Parties. Martinis. Gin and tonics. Scotch and sodas.

title: Shoppers Shift Buying Habits To Cope With High Food Bills
description: Food prices have gone up so much during the past year that I don't know how people can afford to eat, Martin Hornstein said as he paused from his bookkeeping at the Waldbaum supermarket that he manages in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Beame's budget message.

description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three, numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

description: In the most ambitious effort yet undertaken to apply space technology to weather prediction, a satellite designed to function as a weather bureau in the sky is scheduled to bei launched today from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: Bridge: 13 American Teams Reach Final in Open Pair Tourney
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, May 15The final of the world openpair championship of the World Bridge Federation began here this afternoon, with 13 United States pairs and two Canadian pairs challenging for the title.

title: The Subpoenaed Tapes: An Explanation Of What Evidence They Could Provide
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Theing tapes of 11 of Presidentito Nixon's conversations that subpoenaed today by the Judiciary Committee could provide concrete evidence of President's action on three critical days in the Watergatelpapers case.

title: STOCKS AGAIN DIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market showed no signs of snapping out of its doldrums yesterday as prices finished lower in lethargic trading.

title: Prices Move Narrowly In Quiet Bond Trading
description: Trading was mostly quiet and prices moved narrowly in the bond markets yesterday as participants awaited word late in the afternoon for the indicated terms of today's two large offerings. In the corporate market the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's S500million of debentures, due 2005, are scheduled to be marketed today at an expected price of par with 8.8 per cent coupons, to yield 8.8 per cent. The AAArated obligations are being offered, in a negotiated transaction, by a group of uncerwriters headed by Morgan Stanley.

title: Split Lip Is Deftly Staged
description: Clever staging, zestful playing and some winking music make Split Lip a pleasing entertainment bauble in one of the more intimate auditoriums of Theater In Space, 344 West 36th Street. It plays through Sunday.

description: TRENTON, May 15Governor Byrne will propose a state income tax for New Jersey on Monday as part of a $1billion revenue program that includes a controversial proposal for the state financing of public schools.

title: Stelco Price Rises Defy Canada's Plea for Delay
description: TORONTO, May 15 (UPI) The Steel Company of Canada, Ltd., today increased prices on about one third of its product line, in defiance of Federal Government pleas to delay the rises.

title: Post as Walton's Next Coach Available
description: Jack McCloskey, the Portand coach, resigned yesterDay just as Bill. Walton, the University of California, Los Angeles 6foot11inch center, will be coming on the scene, hopefully to right all of the Trail Blazer wrongs of the last four seasons.

title: TIMES COMPANY BUYS PAPER IN CAROLINA
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had acquired for cash The Hendersonville TimesNews, a 47yearold daily newspaper with circulation of 13,000 that is published in Hendersonville, N. C.

title: Board to Uzone 17 Schools in Move For More Choices
description: A program to allow parents of elementary and junior high school students to send their children to any school within their district, instead of only to the one in their immediate neighborhood, was announced yesterday by Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Says Fund Drive Is Gaining
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP)George Bush, chairman of the Republican National Committee, says that, Watergate notwithstanding, the national committee's fundraising drive is 20 per cent ahead of last year's rate.

title: Pain Voiced by Pope On Italy's Divorce Vote
description: ROME, May 15Pope Paul VI today voiced amazement and pain over the outcome of the referendum Sunday and Monday in which Italians voted, 59.1 per cent to 40.9 per cent, to retain the nation's threeyearold divorce statute.

title: 2 Indians Get Right to Cross Examine
description: ST. PAUL, May 15Federal District Judge Fred J. Nichol agreed today to allow two American Indian militants, Russell C. Means and Dennis J. Banks, to crossexamine witnesses in thdir trial on charges of leading last year's armed, takeover by Indians of Wounded Knee, S. D.

title: New President in Bonn
description: BONN, May 15 Walter Scheel, who was elected to the ceremonial office of the West German presidency today, became something of a celebrity this winter by recording a traditional German folk song, High on the Yellow Wagon, which then became a hi' on Europe's biggest radio stations.

title: Nastase Is Victor; 2 Americans Lose
description: MUNICH, May 15 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania had little trouble beating Attila Korpas of West Germany 62, 75 today in the Bavarian international tennis championship. Two Americans were beaten.

title: Meredith Wood, ExPresident Of BookoftheMonth Club, Dies
description: Meredith Wood, retired president of the BookoftheMonth Club, died Tuesday night in White Plains Hospital after stroke. He was 78 years old and lived on Underhill Road in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Zumwalt Urged for V. A.
description: I WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) President Nixon was urged today to name Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt as head of the Veterans Administration. The recommendation was made by Senator Peter H. Dominick, Republican of Colorado. Admiral Zumwalt; now Chief of Naval Operations, is retiring soon from the Navy.

title: 2 Parties, 800 Guests, 1 Big Night
description: It was one of those Manhattan nights when that tired old phrase, Everybody who is anybody is out tonight, might have been uttered, and probably was.

title: Texts of Memorandums to the House Judiciary Committee by Doar and St. Clair
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Following are the texts of a memorandum submitted to the House Judiciary Committee by John M. Dour, its special counsel, in justification of a subpoena of tape recordings of 11 White House conversations, and of a memorandum presented informally by James D. St. Clair, the President's chief defense attorney, in opposition to subpoena of additional Watergate evidence. The text of a second memorandum by Mr. St. Clair was not immediately available.

title: Bid to Impeach Governor Is Rebuffed in Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 15 (UPI)A special committee of the state House of Representatives said today that it had an inquiry into impeachment of Gov. David Hall.

description: WASHINGTON, May 15The House Judiciary Committee issued today two new subpoenas for White House tape recordings and other documents amid charges by some committee members that significant portions of President Nixon's Watergate conversations had been omitted from edited White House transcripts.

title: Public Service
description: The public library system in Brooklyn is tooling up for a pilot project that will make its 55 neighborhood branches not only dispensers of books but information centers on virtually all the governmental and voluntary services available to individual citizens. Supported by Federal contract with the city, the Citizens Urban Information Centers scheduled to open early next year will be staffed by specially trained personnel recruited from the local community. These paraprofessionals will furnish information ranging from Social Security and other benefits to questions about legal assistance, the availability of educational and recreational programs or special aid for the elderly and disabled. An added gain will be an extension of the hours during which the library branches can be kept open.

title: DEADLINE IS SET IN NEWS DISPUTE
description: The executive council of thel International Typographical Union last night deferred action on a request by Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6, for support of his local in its dispute with The Daily News.

title: Nothing to Hide
description: The President has nothing to hide in this matter. President Nixon, television address, April 29, 1974.The President feels he has given them Lthe committee] everything that he thinks they need. James St. Clair, May 5, 1974 (emphasis added).

title: News Summary and Index
description: Sixteen Israeli highschool students and three Arab guerrillas were slain when Israeli soldiers attacked a schbol in the northern town of Maalot where the terrorists had held about 90 students hostage, demanding the release of 20 terrorists held in Israeli jails. The Israeli attack on the school came shortly before a 6 P.M. deadline set by the guerrillas to blow up the school. [1:8.]

title: Mrs. Wyman Wed To C. L. Resseguier
description: Mrs. Olga Perger Wyman, of New York and Holmes, N. Y., widow of Charles A. Wyman, was married here yesterday to Clemens L. Ressguier, also of New York. The noon ceremony in the Unitarian Church of All Souls was performed by the Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring.

title: Defense and Prosecution Rest In Extortion Trial of Roncallo
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 15The prosecution and the defense in the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo and Frank J. Antetomaso rested today in Federal District Court, and the case will be presented to the jury tomorrow.

title: Wright, With 205, Takes L.I. Open by Six Strokes
description: for his eagle. He also had four birdies, two of them offset by a double bogey on the 11 th.

title: OIL DEPLETION AID FACES HOUSE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Democratic members of the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to force a straight yesorno vote in the House on immediate termination of the 22 per cent depletion allowance for the oil industry.

title: Neighborhoods
description: New York is a city of neighborhoods, each one singularly insular and intensely aware of its own destiny. Change brings localized trauma. When a neighborhood is blitzed with big new apartment houses, for example, it is the local residents who find themselves bereft the essential services that were accommodated modestly in the bulldozed old buildings. Even new residents take notice when it almost becomes necessary to make an appointment to get into the supermarket.

title: Jamaica to Impose Taxes On the Bauxite Industry
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 15, (Meuters) Jamaica tonight decided to impose new taxes: on the totally foreignowned bauxite industry here to help bolster her economy, whichwas hard hit by the international energy crisis.

title: Mrs. Meir Pledges Steps To Protect Israeli People
description: JERUSALEM, May 15Premier Golda Meir promised numbed nation tonight that Israel would do everything possible to protect her people against terrorist attacks.

title: TERROR AT SCHOOL
description: MAALOT, Israel, May 15A day of terror ended in this northern town this evening with a savage, 10minute burst of gunfire and grenade explosions that killed three Arab terrorists and 16 of the highschool students they, were holding hostage.

title: ABRAHAM L. FRIEDMAN
description: Abraham L. Friedman, Newark labor lawyer for 41 years with Rothbard, Harris & Oxfeld, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J., at the age of 62. He lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Expo Raises Estimate
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 15 (UPI)Expo 74's general manager, Peter Spurney, told the fair's board of trustees yesterday that Expo will need an attendance of five million to break even, instead of 4.8 million, as previously estimated. He said the dollar figure was low because officials have estimated half of those attending so far have been season ticketholders.

description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Over a cup of fruit brandy and warm gingerbread, both of his own making, Forrest McMains lamented the loss of the fine old ways of preserving, pickling and marinating meats, fruits and vegetables. Mr. McMains, in his early forties, is a collector of oldfashioned techniques.

description: Gen. Antonio de Spinola took office as President of Portugal and named a leftleaning Government promising democracy, at home and in Portuguese Africa. Details on Page 3.

description: A deluge of grain export orders, the largest in many weeks, hit the big Midwest exchanges late yesterday and turned early weak prices around.

title: Ballet: Safe Swan Lake
description: As its new Swan Queen and for its final Swan Lake of the season, the Royal Ballet presented Deanne Bergsma as OdetteOdile Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: No One. Holds a Monopoly on America
description: You do not have to pay too much attention to the din in the media to gain the impression that all of our American institutions are in jeopardy. If you are tempted to reflect on the fact that America is at peace with its neighbors, and that never in history have more people been employed at higher wages in a free society, a poll can be produced to show you how wrong you are. Arined with multiplechoice questions, pollsters knock on doors to inquire about the timetable to doomsday. According to the pollsters, very little about American life has our approval. Congress, the Presidency, business, the media, universities are all held in low esteem.

title: Auto Industry Backs Clean Air Delay
description: DETROIT, May 15 (UPI)Congress was urged by auto industry executives today to complete action quickly on law that would give them until 1978 to meet the original clean air standards set for 1975model cars.

title: Salant Defends Coverage of Watergate
description: Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News, yesterday defended the policies of his division, the amount of coverage it has given to the Watergate story and the work of Dan Rather, the White House correspondent, to some of the angriest critics of CBS, Newsthe managements of stations affiliated with the CBSTV network.

title: PoliceKilling Mistrial
description: A mistrial was declared here yesterday in the trial of five reputed members of the Black Liberation Army who were charged with murdering two policemen. Page 45.

title: Foreign Investments in U.S. Still High
description: In spite of economic uncertainties, foreign companies are continuing to invest in United States plant facilities at close to the high level reached by such investment in 1973, according to a Conference Board report yesterday.

title: TERROR AT SCHOOL
description: MAALOT, Israel, May 15A day of terror ended in this northern town this evening with a savage, 10minute burst of gunfire and grenade explosions that killed three Arab terrorists and 16 of the highschool students they were holding hostage.

title: Hardcourt Upset Scored by Knittle
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 15 Steve Knittle of Hewlett upset fifthseeded Rey Garrido of Huntington, 4.6, 64, 63, to reach the quarterfinals of the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championships today at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: A Feminist Think Tank Sets Its Sights On Reshaping the American Economy
description: A new think tank, awash with feminists, futurists and other rarefied thinkers, has been formed to ponder women's hidden economic power and possibly reshape the American economy.

title: U.S. Starts B52 Pullout From Big Thailand Base
description: U TAPHAO AIR BASE, Thailand, May 15 (AP) Three B52 bombers left here for the United States today, beginning the first withdrawal of the big planes from Thailand since the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: TYCO LABS BUYS MAKER OF CABLE
description: Tyco Laboratories, Inc., of Waltham, Mass, has purchased the Simplex Wire and Cable Company of Newington, N. H., for $22million, it was announced yesterday. Under terms of the agreement, Simplex will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Tyco, with Simplex shareholders receiving $24.25 for each share of the company's 907,823 shares of stock outstanding.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, May 15The Ford Motor Company today announced it sold 56,462 cars in the May 1 to 10 period, a decline of 20.6 per cent from its sales of 71,150 in the same period a year ago.

title: April Exports Set Record
description: LONDON, May 15The dollar strengthened today against European currencies, apparently in response to reports that major central banks were ready, to enter the market with stabilizing purchases.

title: Sports Today
description: Mats vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. (RadioWHN, 1:30 P.M.)

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ADVENT OF FREDERICK GILES By Josiah Bunting 3d. 246 pages. Little, Brown. $6.95.

title: U.S. Report on Payments
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Two measures of the United States balance of international payments moved in opposite directions in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON. May 15The promotion of a program that is for the good of our youth  the teaching of basketball skills, as well as developing physical fitness and mental improvement  basic ideals of good sportsmanship and fair play.

title: Harriman, 82, Honored by 700 Democrats and BrokenDown Bull Mooser,
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 With the usual ingredients filet mignon and politiciansand some unusual leavening, including a rare political appearance of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, several hundred Democrats gathered here tonight to honor one of their own, W. Averell Harriman, and to raise money to elect more Democrats in November.

title: Administrator Is Named By University Hospital
description: Everett V. Fox, an administrator with the New York University Medical Center since 1965, has been appointed a vice president and administrator of University Hospital.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, MAY 16, 1974
description: Sixteen Israeli highschool students and three Arab guerrillas were slain when Israeli soldiers attacked a school in the northern town of Maalot where the terrorists had held about 90 students hostage, demanding the release of 20 terrorists held in Israeli jails. The Israeli attack on the school came shortly before a 6 P.M, deadline set by the guerrillas to blow up the school. [1:8.]

title: Venezuela Reports Exports
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15 (AP)Venezuela's crudeoil exports to the United States last February totaled 12,859,692 barrels, the Mines and Hydrocarbons Ministry reported today. The ministry said that the total included 3,064,692 barrels of crude shipped to Puerto Rico during the same month.

title: Police Investigate Role of a Helicopter In Suicide Plunge
description: Police Investigate Role of a Helicopter In Suicide Plunge

title: RESERVE IS AIDING IN BANK LIQUIDITY
description: The Federal Reserve, in an apparent effort to assure the money market in the wake of the Franklin National Bank's recently disclosed problems, has been making more money available all week, signaling that there is plenty of money to go around to take care of any hank liquidity problems.

title: World Leaders Condemn Maalot Attack
description: to deflect us from our goal of an enduring peace and a work where neighbors live as corn passionate friends and the in nocent walk unafraid.

title: The Shift on Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The drum roll of appeals for President Nixon's resignation, which built to a crescendo last week, has suddenly subsided. For the time being at least, the White House and most Congressional Republicans and Democrats find themselves in unaccustomed agreement that the proper way to resolve Mr. Nixon's Watergate agony is to allow the constitutional impeachment process to go forward.

title: Deadlocked Jury Brings Mistrial in Police Killings
description: The judge in the trial of five reputed members of the Black Liberation Army accused of murdering two police officers declared a mistrial yesterday after the jury announced it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: JACK MAGIDSON
description: Jack Magidson, distribution and controls manager for the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, died Tuesday. He was 46 years old and lived at 16 Turkey Hill Road South, Westport, Conn.

title: Dance: A Nureyev World Premiere
description: It was an evening of sheer dance power last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Royal Ballet preseated for the first time this season, Frederick Ashton's ta Fine Mal Gardee, and Rudolf Nureyev's staging of petipa's La Bayadere. It also represented two fascipating debuts: Mr. Nureyev dancing in Fine for the first time anywhere, and Anifibny Dowell making his New York debut in La Bayadere.

title: ROBERT GRAHAM, 81, OF UNION CARBIDE
description: Robert N. Graham, a retired officer of two divisions of the Union Carbide Corporation, died Tuesday at the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital, He was 81 years old and lived at 75 Carlton Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Defense Takes Jurors to Movies in TrotFixing Trial
description: The breath of scandal gave way to the pastoral sweetness of newmown hay and fast horses yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court as the defense began its case in the racefixing trial of New York harness drivers. With the lights dimmed, the jury of seven men and five women watched attentively as famous trotters and pacers like Dan Patch, Greyhound, Cardigan Bay and Adios flashed across a movie screen to the accompaniment of guitar and harmonica music.

title: Installation in Lisbon
description: Gen. Antonio de Spinola took office as President of Portugal and named a leftleaning Government promising democracy at home and in Portuguese Africa. Details on Page 3.

title: Consumer Notes Excellent Buys Available in Factory Outlet Stores
description: Bargainseeking consumers have long pursued their fancies in places called factory outlets, and there is no question that these can often be the source of excellent buys. There is even an annual Factory Outlet Shopping Guide, and in these inflationary times the guide is especially useful.

title: Survey on Epilepsy Shows Less. Bias
description: Public attitudes toward epilepsy have undergone profound changes in the last 25 years, atcording to the results of Gallup Poll published yesterday.

title: MUSICAL SLATED FOR CITY'S PARKS
description: Mayor Beame could not be there yesterday morning because of such pressing matters as the city's new budget, but, if he had he would have observed his Commissioner of Cultural Affairs in a handclapping footstomping dance with cast members of Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope.

title: United Air Lines Contract With Machinists Ratified
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., May 15 (AP)The International Association of Machinists ratified today a new contract with United Air Lines.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Blacks in Rhodesia Expected to Weigh Political Settlement
description: LONDON, May 15  Black Rhodesian leaders are to meet next month to consider proposals for a constitutional settlement worked out with the white government led by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, The Times of London reported today in a dispatch from Salisbury, the Rhodesian capital.

title: Contract Awards
description: Pipe Line Technologists, the consulting engineering division of Kaneb Services, Inc., said yesterday it had been chosen to provide engineering services for the Florida Gas Company's new $115million petroleum products pipeline. The new line will run from Baton Rouge, La., to Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: SCHEEL IS ELECTED PRESIDENT IN BONN
description: BONN, May 15  Walter Scheel was elected to the ceremonial office of the West German presidency today in demonstration of solidarity between the two governing coalition, parties, Mr. Scheel's Free DeMocrats and the Social Democrats.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Spinola Installed as President in Lisbon
description: LISBON, May. 15Gen. Antonio de Spfnola became President of Portugal today and named a leftleaning Government dedicated to organizing democracy here and in Portuguese Africa.

title: INQUIRY BLAMES 4 IN E.SIDE GAS BEAST
description: The city's board of inquiry into the April 22 gas explosion at 305 East 45th Street, issuing its report yesterday, cited the building owner, a tenant, plumbing contractor and a pump company for law violations in the installation of a waterpressure system in the basement of the 24story building.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHA'S HAPPENIN Are Puerto Ricans doing the same number here that previous migrant groups did? Is their life style similar to their predecessors  blacks from the South and the West Indies, whites from Eastern and Southern Europe?

title: A. T. & T. Is Authorized To Expand Its Facilities
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its 16 Bell System companies to expand their facilities between various locations and to Canada.

title: MAHEU TESTIFIES ONA HUGHES LOAN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15Robert A. Maheu described today how he had tried unsuccessfully to prevent details of the HughesNixon loan from being publicized before the 1960 Presidential election and said he had rebuffed a suggestion from Howard R. Hughes that some relationship be established between the Hughes Tool Company and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: LAWMAKERS VCIT ABORTION CURBS,
description: ALBANY, May 15A bill that would restrict the state's fouryeatold abortion law received final passage in the Senate this evening after it was revived and approved in the Assembly with what Conservative party officials called the very active help of Governor Wilson. The vote in the Senate was 43 to 13.

title: Sharp Questions Put to DogSh ow People
description: The exhibitor, breeder and judge all face a responsibility in the show world, Mrs. Irene Nail: told the Dog Fanciers Club last week at its final luncheon before the summer hiatus. She could speak with authority, for the Texan had played each of the three roles until she joined the American Kennel Club family as a field representative.

title: FASHION TALK At Anne Klein, Young Designer Is Triumphant
description: You just went out and came back a star, Kay Thompson, the entertainer, told her. Donna Karan, clutching a bunch of white roses and a furry bunny someone had handed her for her infant daughter, wept. She had just proved that the Anne Klein fashion spirit lives.

title: Lane Bryant in New Stores
description: Lane Bryant, Inc., will open its first Smart Size stores today the Bronx and Queens, with these new partially selfservice stores representing the company's third means for selling apparel for the heavy or tall woman. Earlier vehicles for this type of clothes have been the company's fulfservice Lane Bryant stores and its mailorder divisian.

title: Victorious Gibson Marks 43d Birthday
description: NEWARK, May 15Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson celebrated his 43d birthday today by jogging three miles around the Weequahic Park lake before going to the office to resume normal work schedule after his strong reelection victory yesterday.

title: U.S. Govt. and Agency Bonds
description: U.S. Govt. and Agency Bonds

title: Panel Releases LandUse Bill; Floor Fight Expected in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The House Rules Committee reversed itself today and sent to the House floor a landuse planning bill it had bottled upi last February.

title: Chess: A Long View in the Beginning Makes Short Work in the End
description: Why did Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, entertain such a strong preference for the exchange variation Ruy Lopez?

title: HOUSE UNIT ISSUES 2 NEW SUBPOENAS TO NIXON FOR DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The House Judiciary Committee issued today two new subpoenas for White House tape recordings and other documents amid charges by some committee members that significant portions of President Nixon's Watergate conversations had been omitted from edited White House transcripts.

title: CHAPIN SENTENCED TO 1030 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, was sentenced today to a minimum of 10 months in prison for lying to a Watergate grand jury about political sabotage in the 1972 campaign.

title: VENEZUELA WIDENS FOREIGN EXCLUSIONS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15 (Reuters)  The Venezuelar Development Ministry an nounced today new regulation restricting foreign investments.

title: Texans Sign 3 Players
description: HOUSTON, May 15 (UPI) The Houston Texans of the World Football League signed three players today. Art May, a 6foot3inch, 242pound lineman; Virgil Robinson, running back from Grambling, and David Urie, a lineman from Montana, accepted terms.

title: New Rent Bill Modifies Tenants Rights
description: ALBANY, May 15The Republican leadership of the legislature tonight prepared to pass, with virtually no Democratic support, a drastically revised rent bill that removes most of the tenant protections Governor Wilson offered last week.

title: MOSCOW ACCUSES PEKING ON PURGES
description: MOSCOW, May 15The Soviet Union charged today that Peking was purging the ranks of its military and civilan officials out of fear that they might mount organized opposition to the current antiSoviet course taken by the regime of Mao Tsetung.

title: Tartan Colt Triumphs At Belmont
description: Elliott Burch, the trainer of Rokeby's Winds of Thought and many in the sunbaked crowd of 19,625 at Belmont Park yesterday anticipated that the 4yearold son of Hail to At the Reason would triumph in the Race day's $20,000 feaTracks ture. But Winds of Thought, sent to the post as the 85 favorite, failed to live up to expectations despite a display of speed and some patient guidance by his jockey, Ron Turcotte. Instead, the winner of the 1 1/16mile contest was Tartan's Two Harbors, who returned $10.40 for $2.

title: Quiet Day in Newark
description: Tuesday was a relatively quiet day in Newark, topped off by an evening of reasoned and conciliatory statements by the city's two most prominent local politicians. That is unremarkable except for the fact that it was the election day when the city's first black Mayor, Kenneth Gibson, was reelected decisively in a headtohead contest with State Senator Anthony Imperiale, who was, a few years ago, a symbol of militant white resistance to the growing political power of blacks.

title: CARTER SETS ACCORD WITH COLUMBIA COAL
description: The Carter Oil Company al subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that its Monterey Coal Company subsidiary had signed agreements providing for early development of certain lowsulphur coal reserves in West Virginia held by the Columbia Coal Gasification Corporation, a unit of the Columbia Gas System, Inc. The agreements also cover future gasification opportunity for sonic Carter Coal reserves in Illinois.

title: SETBACK IS SEEN IN PEACE EFFORTS
description: JERUSALEM, May 15The terrorist attack at Maalot today forced Secretary of State Kissinger to suspend his Middle East peace efforts for one day.

title: COL. MICHALOWSKI OF N.Y.U. DIES AT 79
description: Roman Michalowski, who lectured on international politics at New York University, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 243 East 71st Street.

title: Study Says Arms Treaty Will Save U.S. $6.5Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  The United States will have saved $6.5billion in military spending by 1988 because of the first treaty with the Soviet Union limiting strategic arms, the Arms Control Agency said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 15 (AP)Australian tennis officials said today they would seek to have the Davis Cup played over a limited period to enable countries field their top teams. The move followed the surprise defeat of Australia's defending cup holders by India the Eastern Zone final in Calcutta yesterday.

title: Threats by Nixon Reported on Tape Heard by Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The tape recording of President Nixon's Sept. 15, 1972, conversation with H. R. Haldeman and John W. Dean 3d, which was heard today by members of the House Judiciary Committee, contains at least one long passage that does not appear in the edited White House trailscript of that tape, according to a committee source.

title: Man, 32, to Sue Over Birth
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (UPI)Ronald E. Chaffin has the go ahead of the Indiana Supreme Court to sue the doctor who brought him into the world 32 years ago. The court ruled yesterday that, despite the statute of limitations, Mr. Chaffin is entitled to sue Dr. John B. Nicosia. Mr. Chaffin has asked $225,000 damages for eye damage he says was caused when the doctor used forceps to deliver him after his mothrt had been in labor 72 hours.

title: GUERRILLA CALLS PEACE BID TARGET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16A Palestinian leader said here today that the attack at Maalot, Israel, that three meMbers of his organization staged yesterday had been aimed against the Middle East peace mission of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Chamber Society Sets 7475 Season
description: New and rare works to be performed next season by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center were announced yesterday by Charles Wadsworth, its artistic director. Also announced were a new set of commissioned works, the addition of a new player and a slight rise in ticket prices.

title: Robbins's Dybbtik Has Its Premiere
description: Jerome Robbins's Dybbuk, with music by Leonard Bernstein, has been long time in its creation, and in the 30 years since the collaborators first discussed the project it has passed through many manifestations.

title: White House Sued on Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) The Congressional Rural Caucus filed suit in Federal District Court today to force the White House to release nearly $4.5billion in impounded funds. The money was appropriated by Congress for nine separate Federal programs, including highway aid, but was frozen by President Nixon's Office of Management and Budget.

title: Danes Strike Over Rise in Sales Tax
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 16 (AP)  Two hundred thousand workers walked off their jobs today to protest sales tax increases pushed through Parliament last night by the minority Liberal party Government of Premier Poul Hartling and a temporary group of parliamentary allies.

title: 31 Are Indicted in Jersey As Members of Theft Ring
description: NEWARK, May 16Federal and Essex County grand juries today indicted 31 persons who they charged were members of a loosely knit crime federation that had allegedly committed more than a score of armed robberies and burglaries in northern New Jersey and in the Scranton, Pa., area since 1969.

title: 20 Years After Historic Rights Decision On Schools, Celebration Is Restrained
description: Their faces first appeared, before the public framed within the 15inch world of American television screens the children moving through cordons of Federal marshals, anxious parents. in obseute Dixie towns, clergyMen preaching change and challenge,, grimfabed lawyers, a United States Attor riey General.

title: SHELLING REPORTED ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
