title: Shootout a Gruesome Drama on Los Angeles TV
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 The gruesome drama of a real police story played openended on live television for nearly two hours here this evening.

title: 23 IN DUBLIN DIE AS BOMBS GO OFF DURING RUSH HOUR
description: DUBLIN, May 17At least 23 people were killed and about 80 were critically injured at the height of Dublin's rush hour tonight by bombs planted in three automobiles.

title: Byrne Upset by Failure To Give Life to Pushers
description: Governor Byrne told representatives of local governments in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut metropolitan area yesterday that he was disturbed by the failure of the New Jersey Legislature to enact a law providing life sentences for major narcotics pushers.

title: CHARGES DROPPED AGAINST GURNEY
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 17 A county jtidge dIsmiSed today a misdemeanor indictment that charged Senator Edward J. Gurney with violating a state election law on campaign contributions.

title: VENEZUELAN PLAN ACCEPTED CALMLY
description: Venezuela's first concrete step toward nationalization of her petroleum industry was greeted yesterday with little surprise and less consternation by the major international oil companies that will he most affected.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Held After Ransom Frees Bank Officer
description: BUFFALO, Minn., May 17 (AP)A suburban Minneapolis man is being held in the Wright County jail here in connection with the abduction of a Waverly, Minn., bank officer.

title: Latin Economic Talks Planned
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 17 Brazil's new president, General Ernesto Geisel will leave the country this month for the first time since his inauguration two months ago to hold economic talks with the leaders of Paraguay and Bolivia.

title: 23 IN DUBLIN DIE AS BOMBS GO OFF DURING RUSH HOUR
description: DUBLIN, May 17At least 23 people were killed and about 80 were critically injured at the height of Dublin's rush hour tonight by bombs planted in three automobiles.

title: Governor Signs Measure To Restore Death Penalty
description: ALBANY, May 17A limited death penalty was restored today by Governor Wilson, who found sufficient benefit to mandate it for the murderers of policemen and prison workers, and in murders committed by lifeterm prisoners.

title: Mollen, Ross Score at Woodbury Net
description: WOODBURY L.I.Harold Mollen of Great Aleck, L.I., and Joel Ross of Westbury, L.I., the second and thirdseeded players, won quarterfinal matches today in the Eastern men's hard court tennis championships at the Woodbury Cpuntry Club.

title: Antiques: The Appeal of Music Boxes
description: In the pretelevision, preradio era, the box around which families gathered to be entertained in homes across the land was, more often than not, a Regina or Symphonion.

title: State's WaterPollutionControl Plan Is Stagnating
description: ALBANY, May 15New York State's program to clean up its rivers and lakes has been set back at least two years because of exces sive bureaucratic regulation from Washington, environmental conservation officials herehave charged.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Legislature Votes Raises for Judges

title: Indian World Park Planned
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 (UPI) A $5million Indian world", cultural and recreational park, will be built in southern California within the next three or four years, Henry Rodriguez, the chairman of an intertribal group of American Indians, announced yesterday.

title: Let the Tourist Beware
description: After every outrage against innocents committed by Arab terrorists anywhere in the world, a dismal and futile pattern has been repeated: governments deplore the crime, Israelagainst whose survival the crime is ultimately directedretaliates and the United Nations then solemnly condemns the retaliation. There were signs last night that the horror of Maalot might finally bring a break in this cynical U.N. charade. But that still will not erase the callousness reflected

title: Consumer Activists Get Backing
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS W. Va., May 17A surprising suggestion that demands by re sponsible consumer activist: should be examined with ar open mind was made here to day by the head of one of the country's largest food compsnies and a major advertiser.

title: 133 Are Hart in Wreck of a Train in Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 17 (AP)One hundred and thirtythree persons were injured when eight cars of the Southern Railway's Crescent passenger train derailed today, the authorities said. One woman suffered a broken neck.

title: Maheu Says Hughes Told Him To Offer a Million to Johnson
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 Robert A. Maheu testified here today that in 1968 Howard R. Hughes assigned him to offer $1million to President Johnson, provided nuclear weapons testing in Nevada was ended.

title: TRANSCRIPT LINKS MITCHELL ACTION II WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The transcript of President Nixon's June 30, 1972, conversation with John N. Mitchell and H. R. Haldeman shows that the three men related Mr. Mitchell's resignation as the President's campaign director to the Watergate burglary.

title: The Choice in France
description: PARIS, May 17Comparing the stands taken by the two candidates in the French presidential election campaign, it appears that it will make little difference to French policy whoever wins on Sunday.

title: Economy's Activity Revised Downward
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The performance of the United States economy was a little worse in the first quarter of this year than had been estimated earlier, with inflation greater and the decline in total output deeper, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A New Group to Preserve Commercial Theater Urged
description: The establishment of an organization to preserve the commercial theater has been recommended in a report by the Theater Industry Committee.

title: Asbury Park Strives for Past Glitter As Its Centennial Opens Tomorrow
description: Centennial bumper stickers and commemorative signs have blossomed all over Asbury Park, once one of New Jersey's more popular seaside resorts,.as it prepares to begin its centennial observance tomorrow.

title: Lisbon and Guinea Rebels Agree to Talks in London
description: LISBON, May 17Portugal and the rebel movement in Portuguese Guinea have agreed to open ceasefire talks in London at the end of next week.

title: Two Identified as Leaders In Hearst Abduction Slain
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17The police stormed a reputed hideout of the terrorist group that kidnapped Patricia Hearst and engaged the occupants in a fierce 60minute gunfight tonight.

title: 5 Statements and 1 Message From Salvador Dail
description: 1. Today the capital of the artistic avantgarde is no longer Paris, but New York.

title: Art: Lawrence Epic ofBlacks
description: Among the American artists who came of age in the nineteenthirties, relatively few have remained loyal to the spirit that informed their early work. This is especially the case with artists who aligned their art with the social concerns that so much dominated the intellectual life of the Depression era. In all too many instances, this attachment to social themes proved to be superficial and easily expendable a sop to the fashionable ideas of the moment rather than the expression of a personal vision.

title: Federal Charge Dropped Against Boyle in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, May 17 (AP)A judge dismissed Federal charges today against W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers. Mr. Boyle was convicted last month on state murder charges in the Yablonski slayings.

title: Sciences Dean Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) Robert A. Alberty, dean of the school of science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been named chairman of the Commission on Human Resources, formed within the National Research Council.

title: COLLEGE FINDS WAY OF RECYCLING COWS
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo. (AP)  Colorado State University has come up with a process to recycle cows.

title: CarBomb Cowardice
description: After Maalot the world needs no reminders of the mad horrors political terrorism can produce. But few atrocities compare to the cowardly practice of planting time bombs in public places for indiscriminate killing innocent passersby.

title: Governor Signs Bill to Restore Limited Death Penalty in State
description: ALBANY, May 17A limited death penalty was restored to day by Governor Wilson,, who found sufficient benefits to mandate it for the murders of policemen and prison workers, and in murders committed by lifeterm prisoners.

title: Officer's Trial in Death of Boy Begins
description: The trial of the first New York City policeman to be charged with murder during the course of his duty began in Queens yesterday. The prosecution charged that the policeman had killed a 10yearold boy without any justification and the defense retorted that the shooting came after the boy had pulled a gun on the policeman.

title: Wilson to Sign, but Asks New Rent Bill
description: ALBANY, May 17Saying repeatedly that it is not the bill I want, Governor Wilson said at a news conference today that he would sign into law the rent measure passed by the Legislature in the closing hours of the main session, and then try to persuade the legislators to modify the bill at the special session that begins here May 29.

title: Red Smith
description: BALTIMORE, May 17In Louisville not far from Churchill Downs is a primary school where the teacher an early grade digs horse racing. Each year as the Kentucky Derby approaches, the kids in her class fashion horses heads from paper, affix them to broomsticks and name them after steeds entered in the Derby. Then, straddling their broomsticks, the kids race around the classroom with Teach serving as starter, placing judge and steward.

title: CHRYSLER PRICES INCREASING AGAIN
description: DETROIT, May 17  The Chrysler Corporation announced; today that it was increasing car and truck prices another $46, or 1 per cent, on the aver age. Some fullsize models, however, will go up as much as $155, where radialply tires are being made standard equipment.

title: Four Black Muslims Convicted in Deaths Of Seven in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  Four Philadelphia Black Muslims were convicted today in the slaying of seven Hanafi Moslems on Jan. 18, 1973, at their northwest Washington headquarters.

title: 3d Official Quits Department
description: The manager of the foreignexchange trading desk of the Franklin National Bank, which has had large losses, has resigned, it was learned yesterday. The departure was the third this week from the inter= national banking department.

title: PRIME BANK RATE RAISED TO 11%
description: The prime lending rate at !leading commercial banks in the United States moved up as had been expected  to 11 per cent yesterday, reflecting continued tightness in shortterm money markets.

title: Sutherland's 3 Hits Lead Tigers Over Indians 43
description: Things are so tight in the American League's Eastern Division standing that the team positions are subject to instant change.

title: South Korean Loan Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The International Monetary Fund today authorized South Korea to borrow up to $24million between now and the end of 1974. The standby loan arrangement may be used to meet South Korea's international payments as it attempts to hold down domestic price increases and deals with problems related to higher import costs, the I.M.F. said. South Korea hasn't any outstanding borrowings from the I.M.F.

title: Firemen Say Uniforms Are Highly Flammable
description: The Fire Department has suspended its sale of new firefighting uniforms for the city's 11,000 firemen amid gathering rankandfile complaints that the newly prescribed clothing is highly flammable.

title: Britain Disapproves BootsFraser Deal
description: LONDON, May 17  The British Government refused permission today for the proposed takeover of the House of Fraser, whose interests include Harrods, the famous London department store, by the Boots Pure Drug Company, Ltd., Britain's largest retail pharmaceutical chain.

title: Books of The Times
description: The andthenIwrote image of the lyricistheartache leading directly to love songwas a sentimentalized portrait. The real lyricist is a nononsense (no nonsense about his craft's being an art form) professional, as exemplified by Howard Dietz, Who once wrote 94 songs in 39 weeks. Facility is not the only key to the lyricist. There is also sheer exuberance. He adores what he is doing and he is bringing happiness to millions (and if only they would let him sing his own songs). Popular songs endure, as Mr. Dietz and his longtime collaborator, Arthur Schwartz, demonstrated with Dancing in the Dark. His songs are usually upbeat, but the man is a practicing realist, and often his own toughest critic. When we wrote Dancing in the Dark,' Mr. Dietz says in his autobiography, suitably entitled after his most famous song, I thought it was a good song but I thought it was dull.... Time and applause have

title: Notes on People
description: In an effort to unseat the powerful Republican who is Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Perry B. Duryea, the Democrats of his home Suffolk County have nominated Mrs. Joyce Burland as their candidate in the 1st Assembly District on Long Island. Although Mrs. Burland is a newcomer to county campaigning, she is no neophyte in politics. She is the daughter of Clark M. Clifford, a power in Democratic party circles for two decades and a former Secretary of Defense, and she has been an active fundraiser in party politics for many years. Honesty and openness in government will be her campaign theme, said Mrs. BurI and.

title: Ins and Outs of Cannes Film. Festival Competition
description: CANNES, France, May 17  Michelangelo Antonioni, angry that the Italian Government didn't defend him when China attacked his television documentary, China, won't allow his new film, The Reporter, to represent Italy at the current Cannes Film Festival.

title: Forego Is Favorite in Carter Handicap at Belmont Park Today
description: Having spent a twomonth vacation away from the rigors of racing, Lazy F. Ranch's highly regarded Forego returns to the wars this afternoon to oppose seven expected rivals in the $50,000added Carter Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: WNEW Officials Defend Secret Service Newsfilm
description: A bizarre bit of newsfilm on WNEW  TV Thursday night, which many viewerS have criticized as tasteless and as the exploitation of an unfortunate person, has been defended by news executiVes of Channel 5 as valid reportage that sheds some light oh the laxity of the Secret Service in looking after the safety of, 13yearold John F. Kennedy Jr., so nof the late President:

title: TRANSCRIPT LINKS MITCHELL ACTION WITH WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The transcript of President Nixon's June 30, 1972, conversation with John N. Mitchell and H. R. Haldeman shows that the three men related Mr. resignation as the President's campaign director to the.Watergate burglary.

title: PAIGE L'HOMMEDIEU, JERSEY CIVIC LEADER
description: Paige D. L'Hommedieu, a retired executive of Johnson & Johnson, surgical goods manu facturer, and a New Jersey civic leader, died yesterday in St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, Houston. He was 69 years old and lived in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: 92 Reading Breaks A 78.Y ear Record, Brings Voltage Cut
description: In an unseasonable burst of summertime weather, the temperature climbed past a 78yearold record of 87 degrees here yesterday and set a new May 17 mark of 92, leading the Consolidated Edison Company to begin its first hotweather voltage re'duction of the year and causing extensive delays on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Las Vegas Oddsmaker Likes Rabe the Great
description: BALTIMORE, May 17Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder put it on the line today, blurting out what others have been too diplomatic to say publically about Cannonade's chances in tomorrow's 99th Preakness.

title: Stennis Unit Slashes Military Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The Senate Armed Services Committee has cut $1.3billion from the Defense Department's weapons and research proarams and voted for a $700 million reduction in the level of military aid to South Viettram.

title: Soviet Union Uranium Deal
description: MOSCOW, May 17 (UPI)The Soviet Union signed a $40million deal today with Spainthe largest ever between the two nationsto furnish enriched uranium for nuclear power plants, Spanish trade sources said. They called the contract, which was signed by the Spanish company Enusa longterm, but did not specify the number of years involved.

title: SchoolTax Hearings Slated
description: TRENTON, May 17 (AP)Three legislative hearings will be held, beginning next week, on seeking tax reform to overhaul the system of financing, local schools: next Thursday! the Bergen County Administrative Building in Hackensack, the following day in the Ocean! County College Fine Arts Thea! ter in Toms River, and on May 28 in Brookdale Community College auditorium in Middletown.

title: Byrne Upset by Failure To Give Lite to Pushers
description: Governor Byrne told representatives of local governments in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut metropolitan area yesterday that he was disturbed by the failure of the New Jersey Legislature to enact a law providing life sentences for major narcotics pushers.

title: Par Defeats Qualifiers at Garden City
Chock Full o'Nuts In Stock Dividend
description: Directors of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation declared a 3 per cent stock dividend Thursday night but decided not In declare a cash dividend.

title: Lieut. Egan Is Found Not Guilty In U.S. DrugConspiracy Case
description: Lieut. John J. Egan, former head of the Police Department's elite special investigations unit, was acquitted yesterday of Federal charges growing out of the alleged theft of $180,000 from several LatinAmerican drug dealers.

title: Paris Suburb Is Upwardly Mobile, but Politically It Mirrors All of France
description: MAUREPAS, France, May 14This is one of those bedroom suburbs of Paris, more like Levittown than Chappaqua, where the houses are going up faster than the people can buy them and where the 7:34 to Montparnasse Station is filled with people reading Le Figaro or Le Nouvel Observateur.

title: CALVIN P. FOULKE
description: Calvin Pardee Foulke, president of the Pardee Company, a realestate holding company of Philadelphia, died of a heart attack Thursday. He was 68 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Lebanon. Protests Israeli Strike to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 17Lebanon protested to the Security Council today. over Israel's air attack on her territory yesterday, calling it murderous and barbaric rampage.

title: Borden to Raise Prices on 2 Chemicals
description: The Borden Chemical division of Borden, Inc., announced yesterday that it would raise its prices for methanol and formaldehyde, two major chemicals that have been in tight supply since last summer. Methanol, which is, derived from natural gas, is the base ,material for formaldehyde and other intermediates. Formaldehyde, also the base for intermediates, finds wide applications in the forest products, foundry, textiles, abrasives and other industrials.

title: American Woman Cleared Of Arms Charges in Britain
description: LONDON, May 17  A jury today cleared a young American woman of conspiring to smuggle arms into Britain to be used in a political kidnapping, but found a Moroccan and a Pakistani guilty.

title: Larson, Giants Center, Quits Football
description: Greg Larson, a courageous competitor who missed only three regularseason games in 13 years as an offensive lineman with the New York Giants, announced his retirement yesterday from professional football.

title: Voting on Oil
description: Democratic members of the House of Representatives have staged a revolt against the ironclad control over tax legislation exercised in the past by the Ways and Means Committee, with the traditional backing of the House Rules Committee,

title: W hitlam's Government Favored To Win Close V ote in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia May 17 The Labor Government of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam is favored to survive tomorrow when. Australians vote in their second national election in 17 months.

title: Yankees Win, 32, End Slide
Communists Push Fighting To 25 Miles From Saigon
description: SAIGON, South.Vietnam, May 17 (AP)Fighting advanced to within 25 miles of Saigon today when North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces took two more Government outpost, military. sources said.

title: Black Windmill Comes to Music Hall
NIXON MAY MOVE ON ETHNIC REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., counsel to the President, said today that the White House was considering action to show that President Nixon made no disparaging remarks about Jews in recorded conversations submitted to the Federal Court in New York in the recent MitchellStans trial.

title: Court to Study Stans Data Sought in Jaworski Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 President Nixon asserted the doctrine of executive privilege again today in an effort to block a Government subpoena for correspondence between himself or his White House aides and Maurice H. Stans, who was his chief fund raiser in the 1972 campaign.

title: FOES OF BAUER CITE BAD BALLOTS
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17  Dominican opposition groups said today that massive abstentions and spoiling of votes in yesterday's general elections were a dramatic sign of the unpopularity of President Joaquin Balaguer's conservative Government.

title: N.J. Football Playoff
description: ROBBINSVILLE, N.J., May 17 (AP)High school football championship playoff games will he held at the conclusion of the 1974 season, the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association announced today. The proposal had been approved last December, but was not final until the N.I.S.I.A.A. Executive Committee approved it.

title: INTEGRATION PLAN HAILED AT SCHOOL
description: Community leaders in the area surrounding Franklin K. Lane High School and officials at the school expressed optimism and pleasure yesterday with an integration order by court that could drastically alter the ethnic makeup of the school, which straddles the BrooklynQueens border.

title: Cannonade 95 Favorite in Richest Preakness
description: BALTIMORE, May 17 Triple talk was the theme today at Pimlico, in anticipation of the 99th running of the Preakness Stakes tomorrow. The presence of John M. Olin's Cannonade in the field of 13 listed to compete in the race that holds the. Middle spot in the Triple Crown for 3yearolds (between the Kentucky Derby and the Belpont Stakes) is the reason.

title: G.O.P. Legislators Appear United in Silence on Nixon
description: TRENTON  Republican legislators in New Jersey seem unanimous in declining to join the chorus of Republicans; throughout the country urging! President Nixon to resign for! the good of the party.

title: U.S. Five Victorious
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 17 (UPI)  The United States basketball team badly beaten Thursday night by the Brazilians, defeated Mexico, 9883, tonight in the third and last round of the Rio de Janeiro international basketball tournament.

title: Maurice Lehmann Dies; Managed the Paris Opera
description: PARIS, May 17Maurice Lehmann, theater directorproducer and former general manager of the Paris Opera, died here today at his home. He was 79 years old.

title: Mrs. Helwig, Who Walked 600 Miles for P.O.W.'s Dies
description: GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., May 17 (AP)  A Gloversville woman who once walked nearly 600 miles to remind Americans that United States soldiers were missing in Vietnam, died Wednesday at the age of 52.

title: 7 Injured in Paris Attack On Lebanese Student Home
description: PARIS, May 17 (Reuters)Seven people were injured, one seriously, when about 50 people attacked a Lebanese student residence here tonight, the police said.

title: Radioactive Leak Found
description: RICHLAND, Wash., May 17 (UPI)Another leak in the underground waste storage tanks at the Hanford Atomic Works has been discovered, and this lone amounted to some 2,000 gallons of radioactive liquid. The officials said yesterday that monitoring equipment had !alerted them that 11,20yearold tank was leaking May 4 but they were unable to confirm It until now.

title: Who's Frightening Whom?
description: PARISCoincidental with recent rumors of Chou Enlai's gradual, decline either in health or in the Chinese power scene are reports that Peking, while in no sense reducing its fears of possible Soviet military intentions, has begun to suggest a different appreciation of Moscow's strategy.

title: Newspaper Talks Again Recess Without a Pact
description: Bargaining talks between the printers and the city's three major daily newspapers recessed at 12:55 A.M. today without a settlement.

title: Bridge: U.S. and British Teams Win IN World Pair Tournament
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, May 17The World Bridge Federation's fourth pair Olympiad ended here in the early hours of this morning, with the main titles going to the United States and Britain.

title: WHEAT DECLINES ON CANADIAN CUT
Nixon to Name Three to F.C.C. And Withdraw One Nomination
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 17President Nixon announced today plans to nominate three members to the Federal Communications Commission. He also said he was withdrawing a previous, controversial nomination to the regulatory agency.

title: Rep. Roncallo Is Acquitted; Asks House Study of Case
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 17Representative Angelo Roncallo was acquitted of all charges of extortion and conspiracy by a Federal jury today and immediately announced

title: Officials of WNEW Defend Its Newsfilm On Secret Service
description: A bizarre bit of newsfilm on WNEW TV Thursday night, which many viewers have criticized as tasteless and as the exploitation of an unfortunate person, has been defended by news executives of Channel 5 as valid reportage that sheds some light on the laxity of the Secrit Service in looking after the safety of 13yearold John F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late President.

title: Soviet Police Stop U.S. Emigre Outside Embassy
description: MOSCOW, May 17 The United States Embassy has formally protested efforts by. Soviet policemen Wednesday to bar an American Communist who settled here 17 years ago from visiting consular officials to reclaim his American citizenship.

title: Senate Panel to Study Early Days of Watergate Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  A possible line of Presidential defense in the Watergate coverup will come under close study next week in hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Albanian Archbishop Dies
description: VIENNA, May 17 (Reuters)The head of the Eastern Orthodox Church in Albania, Archbishop Damian, has died in prison at the age of 80, the Austrian Catholic press service, Kathpress, reported today. The Archbishop, who had been in prison for some six years, died last November, but the news has only just reached Orthodox communities abroad. Albania, which claims to be the world's first atheist state, bans religious activity.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLIFTON, May 17Bob Potts, manager of the Clifton V. T. M. Phillies, defending Metropolitan Baseball League champions, is hoping that he loses his shortstop, Rail Gordon, and his right fielder, Jim Szep, in the next month's major league draft.

title: Ford Asks Everyone to  Cool It In Dispute on White House Data
description: HONOLULU, May 17  Vice President Ford, seeking to head off a possible confrontation over additional White House material sought in the Presidential impeachment inquiry, suggested today that everyone involved ought to cool it for the time being.

title: Talks in Ulster Protestant Strike End in Deadlock
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland May 17  Northern Ireland, faced a disruption of its power supply and essential services after talks to settle a threedayold strike organized by militant Protestants ended in deadlock here tonight.

title: PORTUGUESE STRIKES IDLING THOUSANDS
description: LISBON, May 17 (AP)Wildcat strikes idled thousands of Portuguese workers today as Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos called his new Government to its first working session.

title: Dance: Cool and Couth
description: There is a somewhat parochial tendency in American dance, particularly perhaps American moderndance, to believe that it started on the East Coast and, unlike the wagon trains, never traveled West. Like most prevalent myths this has a strong element of truth to itpermitting it to prevail. But once in a while we encounter something like the Californiabased Bella Lewitzky Dance Company and the myth evaporates.

title: An 827 Session
description: The latest sitting of the State Legislature, which ended in the usual nondeliberative frenzy as dawn broke Thursday, can perhaps best be classified as an 827, though some critics would write it off as an 805.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRESH AIR Into the streets, parks and playgrounds today for homemade food, cooking demonstrations, amusement rides, entertainment and prizes for fun and sometimes a good cause. Admission is always free but bring money to spend.... Carl Schurz Park Spring Fair. Today, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., East End Avenue and 84th Street, Batiking, Tshirts, paintin, animal exhibition, a fire engine for climbing on, fireboat display, roller skating, plus. Rain date: tomorrow. Information: 6281270 or 2493804. Grant's Tomb. Today. 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Music, dancers, drama and a steel hand. A roast suckling pig, spinach pastries and on view the park's mosaic tile benches. Rain date: May 25.. . Grove Street Block Association.. Today, noon to 7 P.M, On Grove between Bleecker and Bedford Streets in this landmark area. Raffles, crafts, refresh ments and the regular block party fare. Rain date: tomorrow. Information: 9891765... Adventure Play ground, in Central Park near West 67th Street. Today noon to 5 P.M., gourmet treats, puppet and magic shows, Chinese cooking, weaving, yoga, games. Rain date: Tomorrow Informa

title: Gibson and Imperiale Talk AndPledge Cooperation
Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Mary Rooney Wed To George A. Hitz
description: Miss Mary Josepha Rooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Rooney of Overbrook Hills, Pa., formerly of Brooklyn, was married yesterday evening to George A. Hitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Hitz of Havertown, Pa.

title: High School Notes Student Wins 5th Time In School Science Fair
description: Barry Hartglass, a 17yearold junior at Yeshiva University High School, was still basking in the praise of teachers and classmates last week for winning the first place prize in the School Science Fair first, his fifth firstplace science fair prize in five years.

title: Rebozo Associate Cites Stans Letter Acknowledging Gift
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 17 (AP)C, G. Rebozo has a letter from Maurice H. Stans, who directed fundraising operations in President Nixon's 1972 campaign, acknowledging a secret contribution given to Mr. Rebozo by the head of the WinnDixie food chain before the campaign, a source said today.

title: DOORWAY SLAYING AFFORDS NO CLUES
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., May 17Borough police officials said today that they had no definite leads in the murder of Mrs. Shirley Kirsch, a 52 yearold jewelrystore owner who was shot down for no apparent reason yesterday __in front oP her home here at 71 Valeptin, Street.

title: Drug Arrests in Naples
description: NAPLES, Italy, May 17 (Reuters)The Naples police, acting on information from the United States Narcotics Bureau, today arrested four Italians in connection with the import of Peruvivn cocaine worth more than $ 15million.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Shots Break Window of Police Car

title: Trainer Sees Choice Taking Triple Crown
The Screen
description: The sometimes simplistic views of emerging African nations are given humanity and meaning through the subdued conflicts between the white and black principals of Two Men of Karamoja, which opened yesterday at the Beekman and Forum Theaters. As a socalled nonfiction feature, this study of the reluctantly retiring, young British chief warden of Uganda's Kidepo Valley National Park and the Ugandan he's instructing as his prospective successor quietly speaks volumes for the involved people and their just. if perhaps losing, causes.

title: Black Eye Promises Much, Gives Little
Brief Chicago Strike Halts Midnight Transit Service
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (UPI)A brief strike halted Chicago's rapid transit trains and buses early today but the city's two million daily riders found service almost back to normal by the morning rush hour.

title: Kissinger's Peace Mission Approaches Decisive Point
ROBERT D. FARREN
description: Robert D. Farren, who retired three years ago as board chairman of the New York Furniture Exhibit Corporation, 453 Park Avenue South, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 33 East End Avenue.

title: Quiniella Bets Spur OTB Handle
Newark Catholic Paper Backs New York's Homosexuality Bill
description: The Advocate, official weekly of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, has come out editorially for the New York City Council bill banning discrimination against homosexuals,

title: ExHead of Milk Coop Is Guilty In Illegal Donation to Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The former president of a small Eastern milk: producers group pleaded guilty today to consenting to an illegal $50,000 contribution to the Finance Committee to ReElect the President.

title: In Lebanon, Just Rubble And Despair
description: NABATIEH, Lebanon, May 17An old woman, her head wrapped in a kerchief, trudged through the rubble of this village, talking to herself.

title: Stocks Off Sharply On Prime Rate Rise
Fatter Food Prices
description: Despite daily reports that the farm prices of meat, wheat and many other basic commodities are heading down sharply from their alltime peaks of a few months ago, it costs the average New York City family $7 today to buy the same amount of food $6 would buy a year ago.

title: WINE TALK Open the Bottle, Air Gets In, and That's Good Or Is It?
description: Letting the wine breathe is one of those stilted phrases that cries out for a George Price cartoon. Of course, wine does not breathe. It oxidizes, and the oxidation can be good for the wine or it can be bad depending on the circumstances.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: N.F.L. Owners Give Injury Data

title: SATELLITE LOFTED IN WEATHER STUDY
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 17 (UPI)A new type of weather satellite was launched today into a lowerthannormal orbit, but space agency officials hoped to save the $23.6million mission with some fancy rocket maneuvering.

title: In Coal Mine No. 29, Two Women Work Alongside the Men
description: JENKINS, Ky.It was 5:30 A.M., and as usual, it was cool, dark and dank inside mine No. 29 near here. All of sudden, the darkness was pierced by the light on the safety helmet of Diana Baldwin, who came tooling out of an opening in the mine shaft on a shuttle car full of coal.

title: A DIOCESE BACKS HOMOSEXUAL BILL
description: The Advocate, official weekly of the Roman Catholic Arch! diocese of Newark, has come out editorially for the New! York City Council bill banning discrimination aganst homo1 sexuals.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The Dynamics Corporation of America, which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Aug. 2, 1972, said yesterday that it had filed a plan for restructuring its, debt with Judge Edward J. Ryan of the United States Court for the Southern District of..New York.

title: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:
RIGHTS DEMANDS GROW IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, May 17  Women end homosexuals have joined the, revolutionary movement that has swept Portugal since a military coup overthrew a half century of dictatorship April 25.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television, programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM BAHAMA STAY
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 18 (AP)President Nixon returned to Key Biscayne from the Bahamas at 6:21 P.M. today, the White House reported.

title: The Baha'is on Long Island Reflect the Changing Image of the Sect Nationally
description: MANHASSETIn the living room of Mrs. David B. Thomas, 103 Andrew Road, Arabic letters in a black picture frame spell out a reference to the founder of her faith with the words: O Thou, the Glory of the Most Glorious.

title: Peter Brown, Lawyer, Weds Mrs. Stoddard
description: Mrs. Alexandra Johns Stoddard, an interior designer with McMillen, Inc., was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Megargee Brown, a partner in the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. The Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. J. Burton Thomas.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  According to the rules of the State Legislature, lobbyists are supposed to stay outside the Senate and Assembly chambers when either house is in session.

title: Marian Sabety Wed in Garden
description: Miss Marian Farideh Sebety, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Moeyed Sabety of Montclair, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael James Dzvonik, son of John Dzvonik of Allen Park, Mich, and.Mrs. Thomas Gerald Clarke of Hixson, Tenn.

title: Kimball Overholt to Marry July 27
description: Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George T. Overholt Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Lee Goodwin of Scarborough, Me.,

title: American Express to Purchase A 40Story Downtown Building
description: The American Express Company, after a century at, Broadway, is planning to buy a nearly vacant threeyearold office building a few blocks away to serve as its new international headquarters.

title: Washington Crews Win 4 of 7 Races
Ends
B'NAI B'RITH TO ADD TO CAPITAL OFFICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 B'nai B'rith, the 500,000member Jewish service organization, will break ground tomorrow for the construction of an 8story wing to its international headquarters here.

title: STEVENS IS URGED FOR APPEALS POST
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan has warned that the effectiveness of the Democratic statewide ticket in this year's election would be impaired if the party rejected Harold A. Stevens, associate judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: Hospital Unit Seats Leader
description: The installation of Morrell Goldberg, executive vice presi dent of the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center as president of the Greater New York Hospital Association was announced yesterday. He succeeds Irvin G. Wilmot, executive vice presiof the New York University Medical Center, whose oneyear term expired.

title: Hofstra Falls To Hopkins In Lacrosse
The Lines Are Drawn
description: President Nixon clings to office by his fingernails. The Watergate scandals have destroyed his capacity for leadership. Neither Congress nor the country would respond with instinctive trust to any initiative from him. Yet he seems determined to hold the husks and symbols of office, though shorn of his moral and political authority. His hope apparently is to tough it out.

title: Top Planner Hints A Zoning Overhaul
description: Thirteen years ago the city adopted a new oning ordinance that took six years to prepare. Its lengthy text and numerous maps supplanted a resolution that had been adopted 45 years earlier and amended more than 2,500 times.

title: Press Official Elected
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., May 18 (AP)Hubert L. Kaltenbach, publisher of The South Bay Daily Breeze at Torrance, was elected vice president of the Copley Press, Inc., this week.

title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Are Confident
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 18While confidence in the nation's leadership is probaby at the lowpoint of the century, a Gallup poll released today  both at the Presidential and Congressional level  finds that almost seven Out of 10 Americans (68 per cent) retain high degree of confidence in the future of this country.

title: Plan for Museum Development At Fraunces Tavern Imperiled
description: The plan to create a downtown museum development around the landmark Fraunces Tavern appeared jeopardized last week as scaffolding was erected for the demolition of two buildings on the squareblock site.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NUMBER of new books have been issued during the past year that should prove of interest to doityourself carpenters and home craftsmen who are looking for fresh ideas, or simply for new ways to improve their working techniques.

title: INQUIRY TO FOCUS ON I.R.S, POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 For the first time in 20 years, the Internal Revenue Service's treatment of taxpayers is to be the subject of a major investigation and review by an independent Federal agency.

title: A quite moving and very traditional celebration of love
description: Though our turbulent era has certainly dismayed and overwhelmed many writers, forcing upon some the role of propagandist or, paradoxically, the role of the indifferent esthete, it is really the best possible time for most writersthe sheer variety of stances, the multiplicity of styles available to the serious writer, is amazing. Those who are bewildered by so many ostensibly warring points of view and who wish, naively, for a single code by which literature can be judged, must be reminded of the fact that whenever any reigning theory of esthetics subdues the others (as in the Augustan period), literature simply becomes less and less interesting to write.

title: The President's Transcripts Touch on Unanswered Questions
description: With the release of the edited White House transcripts, the Ellsberg case has emerged prominently once again. For the President's conversations with his aides raise, like the Ellsberg trial itself, some important and nagging constitutional questions.

title: Point of View
description: As long ago as the late nineteenthirties, any sciencefiction film fan could tell you that the cities of the future would be run on solar energy'We all enjoyed the comfortable knowledge that one day we would live and work in that gleaming white metropolis designed by the M.G.M. special effects department, with its superduper suncatcher rotating blissfully as it brought us all the heat and light we needed.

title: Nixon Ouster Is Fought By GrassRoots Forces
description: WASHINGTON, May 18We want to be heard, a student at Miami University, Ohio, wrote to President Nixon, I am 21 years old, very conservative but very radical. I am supporting you and praying for you.

title: People and Business
description: Magnetic tape recorders have become what millions of people probably consider a recreation orbusiness necessity, but the Lockheed Electronics Company of Plainfield has produced a new unit that only a handful of people will ever get to see or hear.

title: Vice President Says House Would Vote to Reject Impeachment Now
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Vice President Ford says he thinks there is an even chance the House Judiciary Committee will vote to impeach President Nixon. But Mr. Ford says he does not think an impeachment resolution would pass the House.

title: The Theater Is Running Short on Talent
description: OUR theater has become dependent upon the kindness of strangers. Once upon a time it was dependent upon the industry of our writers, men and women who sat themselves down in quiet rooms to wrestle with their creative imaginations until some sort of dramatic shape danced in the air. Then, when the dance was at last reduced to paper, actors and directors and producers came along to snatch up the sheaf and make a show of it. Today Broadway makes its shows out of anything it can borrow, beg, purloin or paste together. The actors do it themselves, the directors and managers make the packages themselves, everyone is engaged in either transportation or manufacturewith nary, nary a writer in sight. Or that's almost the case.

title: SOVIET AIDES SAID. TO GRILL ISRAELIS
description: LONDON, Sunday, May 19 (UPI)The Sunday Times of London reported today that Soviet military interrogators, using medical techniques, had been grilling Israeli prisoners held in Damascus since the October war in the Middle East, gaining an invaluable windfall of information.

title: Retiring AirPollution Chief Urges New Controls
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Controls over the use of automobiles and restrictions on land development are necessary to improve New Jersey's air quality and protect its environment.

title: It's a Long Way From Batman to Larry
description: THE ways of reputations in television are infinite in their variety. When Thomas W. Moore leftor was maneuvered out ofthe presidency of the American Broadcasting Company a few years ago, he was considered most likely to be remembered as the man who brought Batman and The FBI to the masses. That particular distinction was doubtlessly interesting and doubtlessly dubious.

title: The World In Summary
description: Portugal Has Domestic Troubles, Too

title: Shakespeare Fete Offering Courses
description: MADISONCourses in acting, mime and body movement will be offered at Drew University, starting June 24. The courses will be held under the auspices of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival.

title: $4.80 Choice Pace Victor At Yonkers
Ad Man to Marry Rita O'Shaughnessy
description: Mrs. Theodore P. O'Shaughnessy of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rita Anne O'Shaughnessy, to Thomas M. Hamilton of Harrison, N. Y.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: GovernOr Wilson yesterday ordered a special election on June 18 in White Plains to fill Common Council vacan, cies by the resignations of Mayor Carl J. Delfino and Harry H. Gordon. Last week the Westchester city formally asked the Governor to call a special election in an effort to end a state of legislative paralysis there. In addition to the rest ignations, illness and political division had reduced the governing body from six Councilmen to four.

title: Planning Unit Lists Talk By State Aide,
description: PASSAIC  Commissioner Patricia Q. Sheehan of the state's Department of Community Affairs will address the annual conference of the Planning Association of North Jersey on May 28. Mrs. Sheehan will speak on Changing Concepts of Planning and Zoning at the conference's dinner session, which will be held at the Pennington Club.

title: On House Tours,
description: One of the advantages of spring is that is casts a pall of politeness over snooping around other people's houses.

title: Klein Is Expanding Role in State G.O.P
description: HAUPPAUGE  There is general agreement among high; Republican officials that when Suffolk County Exeautive John V. N. Klein sat down with the state Republican Platform Committee last week in. Syracuseand Bingantion, he was starting a new phase of his career in which he will attempt to extend his influence statewide.

title: The Candidate as Governor
description: ALBANYWith the closing of the legislative session, Malcolm Wilson has spent half of the precious campaign contribution left to him last December with Nelson Rockefeller's resignationthe gift of eleven months in which to serve as Governor before facing the voters next November.

title: Huntington Attics Feed Antiques to Museum Shop
description: HUNTINGTON  The attics of homes in this historic town would be an antique dealer's dream  but the Huntington Historical Society got there first. The group recently opened a new antique and handmade gift shop on the grounds of one of the oldest houses in Huntington, the 320yearold Thomas Powell House, run by the society as a museum.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The chairman called to order the meeting of his financial executives and the auditor to analyze the Equity Funding fraud. He expressed the hope that an agreement on procedures at the meeting would lessen the possibilities of repeating that scandal.

title: BruinFlyer 6th Game Today Hinges on Many Ifs
description: If Philadelphia keeps cool and doesn't play nervous hockey... If they can contain Boston for two periods, then Philly might be in business. But if Boston plays its game, and Philadelphia lets them, then Philly is in trouble.

title: OPEN EDUCATION GETS $975,000 AID
description: One of the first major efforts to link some of the country's leading centers of open education is to be undertaken with the aid of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund through grants totaling $975,000.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Smut, Variously Defined, Is Booming Nationwide
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., May 18A look of pained amusement crosses Gordon Wilson's face when he is told about a new trend in America's growing pornographic market, such as the dirty talk sessions in Chicago establishments where, for a price, a woman employe will whisper sexual fantasies in a customer's ear while he views a hardcore sex film.

title: Irreplaceable Resource...
description: By a single vote, the House Rules Committee has decided to abandon its attempt to keep the entire House Representatives from voting on legislation for landuse planning. That is a narrow victory for democratic procedure in Congress; it at least gives hope that a modest advance may yet be made this year toward a sensible and coherent use of the nation's land.

title: Black Woman Doctor Honored
description: A retired schoolteacher's efforts to have his grandmother honored as Brooklyn's first black woman plysician will bear fruit next fall when Sands Junior High School, in the Brooklyn Navy Yard district, will be renamed in honor of Dr. Susan Smith McKinney.

title: Rail Tours of L.I. Sites Scheduled
description: Starting today,. the Long Island Rail Road is once again offering vacationers and sightseers the increasingly popular escorted tours to many of Long Island's cultural, scenic and historic attractions and others in Connecticut.

title: Mrs. Madeleine Davis Married To Robert Miller of Time Inc.
description: Mrs. Madeleine Burns Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robert Burns of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Lyman Miller, son of Paul Albert Miller of Los Angeles and Mrs. Frank L. Mansell of New York and East Hampton, The Rev. Edwin M. Ward, headmaster of the Salisbury (Conn.) School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Burns home.

title: Middlesex to Hold Afternoon in Arts
description: EDISON  The Middlesex County Arts Council and Middlesex County College, in association with the county's Parks and Recreation Department, will sponsor A Sunday Afternoon in the Arts today.

title: Fashion: Designer clothes at proletariat prices
description: In some affluent circles, fashion designers are on a firstname basis with their customers. They may never have met, but a woman who spends a certain amount of money for her clothes feels free to refer to the designer as Bill or Oscar or Geoffrey or Chester*. Her friends know whom she means.

title: Politicians Eye Gibson Victory
description: NEWARK  Kenneth A. Gibson has gained new political stature as a result of his reelection Tuesday to another four years as Mayor of New Jersey's largest city.

title: The Nation
description: Inflation Is Even Worse Than Had Been Expected

title: Should children decide what is best for them?; Public Schools of Choice; By Mario D. Fantini. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $8.95.; Escape From Childhood; The Needs and Rights of Children. By John Holt. 286 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $7.95.; Birthrights; By Richard Farson. 248 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $6.95.
description: The failure of recent radical experiments in education to transform the schools has been a sign for many that we have been too permissive, that we must return to a more authoritarian, more traditionally subjectoriented pedagogy. Diane Ravitch's recent book on the school wars in New York City (The Great School Wam, Basic Books) implies what many of us in education have seen, that genuine pedagogical reform has not been tested seriously despite all its publicity.

title: Maryland Advances In Lacrosse
U.S.POLISH LINKS GROWING FIRMER
description: WASHINGTON, May 18United States relations with Poland have improved considerably in recent months, in large part because of the discovery of a mutual stake in meeting energy shortages, a high State Department official reports.The improvement is marked 1:iy the current visit of Deputy Premier Jan Mitrega, the highestranking Polish official to come to the United States in more than a decade. He is also Minister of Mining and Power, and he and the three other members of his delegation are Spending most of their 11day visit concentrating on energy questions.

title: Dining Out in New jersey
description: ***Steve's Wortendyke Inn, 34 Central Avenue, Midland Park. (201) 4454141. Steve Leanheart's Wortendyke Inn can be a delicious surprise if you are prepared to pay New York,City prices for fine food from an imaginative menu and are not dismayed by the number of people who already consider it a culinary oasis.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: I realize that Lionel Trilling's interesting review of The Freud/Jung Letters (April 21) dealt primarily with the period covering the correspondence between 19061913, but a wrong impression of Freud's ambivalent attitude toward the occult should be corrected'Mr. Trilling states that Freud could not stomach the occult leanings of Jung and Ferenczi, and this is true as far as it goes. But Freud's attitude toward what he called an occult tide of mud that had to be stopped changed considerably immediately following the FreudJung friendly years.

title: Byways of our national character
description: Erik Erikson's new book, an amplified version of his Jefferson Lectures for 1973, is not so much an argument as a series of preparatory hems, transitions, digressions, excurses and recapitulations in search of an argument. Had he found it, were it not always just disappearing around the curve of his psychohistorial and psychoanalytic thought, it might have turned out to be about this onceinhistory chance for selfmade newness that was and is the singular significance of the phenomenon of the United States.

title: Nature Conservancy Gaining Ground
description: SOUTHAMPTON  Peter Salm thinks there Is too damn much asphalt and chrome in the world and not enough greenery.

title: Metroliners Reach 150 M.P.H. in Test Of Modifications
description: TRENTON, May 18  Test runs reached speeds of up to 150 miles an hour today when the Federal Department of Transportation and the General Electric Corporation ran four modified Amtrak Metroliner cars between here and New Brunswick.

title: ELMER C. WALZER OF U.P.I. DIES AT 80
description: CLERMONT, Fla., May 18 (UPI)  Elmer C. Walzer, who retired in 1960 as financial editor of United Press International, died yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: IN. CRITICIZED ON ARMS REPORT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18China and Tanzania have complained about a United Nations report that indicated that Peking has a military base on Tanzanian territory.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: An Exception Gone Awry;Dealing With The Terrorists
description: JERUSALEMThe policy was nothing if not clear: never negotiate, never bargain, never give in. Prior to last Wednes. day, it had been the cardinal rule covering Israel's dealings with Arab terrorists. Examples of its application abound:

title: Booth for Sale at Penn Station
description: Who wants to buy the Long Island Rail Road's glass information booth? No one, as yet. But the people at Smith McCord, the contractors who are building its replacement, are still hoping someone will.

title: Burlington in Favor of an OffCampus Center
description: PEMBERTONIn a recent survey conducted by Burlington County College, 68 per cent of those responding to a questionnaire said they would attend an offcampus college center. The survey, conducted by Dr. G. L. Mears, Director of Institutional Research at the college, was aimed at gathering public opinion toward construction of a proposed offcampus college unit in the areas of Willingboro, Delran and Moorestown.

title: Diane Caravatt, Richard Holden Have Nuptials
description: Miss Diane Caravatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Caravatt of Wilton, Conn., and Ludlow, Vt., was married at noon yesterday to Richard Capel Holden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick C. Holden of Hudson, Ohio.

title: Asbury Park Holds A Centennial Party
description: ASBURY PARK  This city, once a leading summer resort, began its 100th birthday celebration last night by memorializing the past and preparing for the future.

title: Joan Mirovsky Married
description: Miss Joan Anita Mirovsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mirovsky of Hopkins, Minn., was married in Hempstead, L. I., yesterday to Jeffrey Lee Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Cohen of Franklin Square, L. I. Village Justice Lawrence J. Goldstein of the town of Hempstead performed the ceremony.

title: Montclair Handicapped Get Advice From One of Their Own
description: MONTCLAIRWhen Ruth Anderson was asked to join the Montclair Rehabilitation Organization, her first impulse was to say no.

title: 2 Jockeys Hail Their Triumphs
description: BALTIMORE,.May 18In Spanish or English, Little Current's explosive runaway in today's mudsplattered 99th Preakness added up to what could become a Triple Crown for Puerto Rico.

title: An Ecological Bonanza
description: WHY the spectacular growth of the fish population in Westchester and Putnam Counties? Experts offer some remarkable and remarkably illassorted explanations.

title: Why Are They Being So Mean to The Great Gatsby'?
description: VICTIM of its own publicity overkill, The Great Gatsby has become the movie to hate. Slaughtered by the critics, the film is also being insulted in the subways: this movie stinks, and less flattering evaluations, are scribbled on many of the ads. The picture has been dismissed as a desecration of a great American novel; it's been damned as insensitive, numbingly reverential, ludicrously miscast, stultifyingly dull.

title: Read Any Good Movie Books Lately?
description: MOVIE books! They keep multiplying like the rats in Hamelin. They fill up the bookshelves. They're stacked on the floors. The stacks topple over and after a while no one bothers to pick them up.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I believe that. two recent articles demonstrate the tragedy the United States faces with the kind of inflation it has and the lack of expertise or leadership in stopping it (Who's in Charge Now, and Improvising a Price Control Policy, April 21)

title: For Drew, a Changing Mood
description: MADISON  Next Saturday, Drew University, like many of New Jersey's other colleges and universities, will be bidding farewell to the Class of 74300 out of the original 400and in the fall the cycle will begin again.

title: Beame and Goldin Spar Over a$65Million Item
description: A disagreementexpressed in sober budgetary language but actually reflecting a good bit of political shadowboxing has arisen between Mayor Beame and Controller Harrison J. Goldin over an item on the fringes of the Mayor's proposed municipal budget.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Is Boxing Really a Sport?
Women Battle for Funds On College Sports Scene
description: In Fayetteville, Ark., last week, Lon Farrell, administrative assistant to the athletic director, Frank Broyles, was talking on the telephone about the women's athletic program at the University of Arkansas.

title: Henry Goldstein to Wed Miss Ellen Monaghan
description: Miss Ellen Deborah Monaghan, an administrative assistant with Oram Associates, and Henry Goldstein, president of Oram, fundraising and publicrelations consultants, plan to be married June 15 at the Carlyle.

title: Vegetables For a Summer Cottage
Helping Handicapped Into Education's Mainstream
description: separatedfor those so severely handicapped, say, the schizophrenic, that no integration seems feasible to totally integrated.

title: The Three Worlds of City Island, an Exercise in Coexistence
description: AT the head of Long Island Sound, connected to the mainland Bronx by a hyphen of a bridge, lies City Island. From overhead, the tiny narrow strip of land has something of the look of a fish skeletons a single, Spinelike thoroughfare down its length and a score of cross streets that run from water's edge to water's edge. The reality of City Island supports the image it is a boating and fishing community and has been since settlers dropped in to stay two centuries ago.

title: Mixed Baths Survive In Japan, but Barely
description: THE American notion of the public baths of Japan stems from the movies of the fifties: young G.I. meets demure geisha in pool of steamy water; they scarcely have time to say hello before a family joins thema boon for the censors if not for all viewers.

title: Miss Nancy Paull Wed To James S. Rosebush
description: Miss Nancy Dianne Paull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Oliver Paull of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to James Scott Rosebush in the Trinitarian Congregational Church in Concord, Mass. The Rev. Chandler W. Gilbert of Concord performed the ceremony.

title: Abourezk Urges Pay Curb
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, has urged that retirement pay be withheld, from former military personnel holding other Federal jobs. He told the Senate Defense Appropriations subcommittee on Wednesday that there were more than 100,000 double dippers on the Federal payroll drawing a salary as well as military retirement pension.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, MAY 19, 1974
description: NORTH ARLINGTON This squaremile community at the southern tip of Bergen County is wrapped up these days in what is being done to develop municipal facilities, which were allowed to age without much thought to expansion or modernization. But now there is a rush to complete a library, long a tenant of a small store in a residential area, and to revamp Borough Hall by yielding an adjacent park site for the library.

title: The Whole COSMEP Catalog
description: This catalogue, a firsttimeinhistory artifact, indicates that something has changed in American publishing, but something is definitely unchanged in the American spirit of happy, cranky individualism.

title: Man Protesting Abase of a Dog Is Slain Here
description: A 39yearold man wes slashed to death on a midtown street yesterday afternoon when he sought to intervene with a dogwalker whom he observed mistreating the animal, the police reported.

title: Headliners
description: The new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will be General George S. Brown, provided the Senate confirms the appointment. General Brown, currently Air Force Chief of Staff, was chief of air operations in Southeast Asia while secret bombing missions were being carried out in Cambodia in 1969 and 1970. During the hearings on his confirmation as Air Force chief, General Brown conceded that the bombings had been covered up, but explained that reports had been falsified in accord with instructions from higher authority as special security precaution. Despite sonic Senate murmuring over his testimony, that appointment was approved without dissent.

title: Mary Reilly Married To Richard W.Farrell
description: Miss Mary Alice Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Reilly of Schenectady, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard William Farrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Farrell of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Clettis Dallinger performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in tilt chapel of Manhattanville lege.

title: U.S. WILL PULL OUT PLANESON TAIWAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 18American combat aircraft will begin leaving Taiwan this summer or fall in another step designed to improve WashingtonPeking relations and remove the vestiges of the Vietnam war.

title: U.S. MAY CANCEL TRIBAL MINE DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Interior Department was reported today to have decided to cancel leases for stripmining for coal on 260,000 acres ,of the Northern Cheyenne Indians reservation in Montana.

title: Make a Collection of Ferns to Brighten a Shady Nook
description: ONE of nature's first Gardens was a vast planting of many ferns and their allies. This can be imitated in miniature even in the restricted area of a city courtyard or a small plot of a nearby suburban development.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Julius Erving of the Nets, already rated the No. 1 star Of the American Basketball Association, talks about improving his game: The main thing want to do. is maintain my consistency. I don't think I'll ever run any faster, jump any higher or shoot any better. And I don't think my defense needs much improvement.... But it's maintaining consistency, under pressure, that's:aloft important.

title: The Region
description: Albany Approves Election Reform; Will It Work?

title: Miss Thompson Bride Of John Strasenburgh
description: Miss Suzanne Cooper Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Webb Thompson of New Vernon, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to John Griffin Strasenburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Beaver Strasenburgh of Lawrenceville, N. J. The Rev. Philip Cato performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N. J.

title: A Sri Lankan Couple Quietly Gains Political Power
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  A young Government official whispens, Kumar and Sunethrathey are two of the most iinportant people in Colombo. A dissident journalist says, Kumar and Sunethra are the Jack and Jill of politics; they seem to be all over the place.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Subject for a Ph.D. thesis. The Number of Mystery Sto ries Written in California Weighed Against the Output of Other American Population Centers. There was a reason for it in the old days. When Hollywood was in full flower, many of America's slickest writers went there to work and a large number of them remained. Today there is no film industry to speak of. Yet an amazing number of current mystery writers come from California, as witness the current batch.

title: Patricia Fix Is Married
description: The marriage of Miss Patricia Carolyn Fix, daughter of Walter E. Fix of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Ethelyn S. Fix, to Ralph Laurence Peek of Fairport, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Peek of Prattsburg, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles T. Newberry 3d.

title: Princeton: The New Engineer
description: PRINCETON  After several years of dwindling enrollments, the Princeton University School of Engineering and Applied Soience is regaining popularity among applicants to the university. The number of high school seniors applying to the school this year rose by 32 per cent, the second year in a row that there has been an increase.

title: Mary Charlotte Heller Wed To Dean Francis Chatlain Jr.
description: The marriage of Miss Mary Charlotte Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Austin Heller of Hershey, Pa., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., to Dean Francis Chatlain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chatlain of Gahanna, Ohio, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Chairman Elected By Common Cause
description: TRENTON  New Jersey Common Cause, the 14,500member citizens lobby for governmental reform, has elected Richard A. Zimmer of South Orange as its chairman for the coming year. He succeeds James M. Banner Jr. of Princeton, who will be on leave from his position on the Princeton University faculty and will be living in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Arce Hurls NoHitter
description: Tony Arce, a freshman righthander, tossed the first nohitter In the history of Hunter College, as he defeated York. College, 11.0, yesterday.

title: Finding an Equitable Oil Price
description: WASHINGTON  Under the headline Still a Bargain, the Oil and Gas Journal, a usually authoritative weekly, has published a comparison of crude oil prices with prices of other fluids.

title: The World In Summary
description: India, Uninvited, Joins the Nuclear Club

title: Drawbacks Aside, They Like the Pay
description: WASHINGTON  What woman would be interested in treating sewerage as a career? Isn't it dirty,, smelly and lonely, with just gauges and machines to keep you company?

title: Malabar Farm: Louis Bromfield's Paradise Lost.
description: IT was already twilight and the lower Valley was the ice blue color of a shadowed winter landscape at dusk and the black, bare trees on the ridge tops were tinted with the last pink light of the winter sunset. There were already lozenges of light in the windows of the distant house. Like Brigham Young on the sight of the vast valley of Great Salt Lake, thought, This is the place.

title: ChildAid Center Will Honor Berra
description: BLOOMFIELDThe Child Development Center here has announced that its first New Jersey Citizen of the Year award will be given to Lawrence P. (Yogi) Berra, manager of the New York Mets and a resident of Montclair. The center is a nonprofit treatment center for emotionally disturbed children.

title: MAN IN 68 BIAS CASE SLAIN, BROTHER HELD
description: ST. LOUIS, May 48. (UPI)J. D. Jones, 24 years old, was charged with murder in the stabbing death of his brother, Joseph Lee Jones, a principal figure in a landmark Supreme Court decision. outlawing discrimination in housing.

title: Brewers Pin Loss on Stottlemyre
SEYCHELLES CHIEF EXPLAINS POLICY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18James Mancham, the Prime Minister of the Seychelles Islands, gave diplomats here a sample of the candor for which he is known the other day.

title: U.S. Admits RainMaking From 67 to 72 in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Defense Department has acknowledged to Congress that the Air Force and Navy participated in extensive rainmaking operations in Southeast Asia. from 1967 to 1972 in an attempt to slow the movement of North Vietnamese troops and supplies through the Ho Chi Minh Trail network.

title: Doctor Heads Lung Group
description: CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP)Dr. Joseph B. Stocklen of Cleveland, a former tuberculosis patient, is the new president of the American Lung Association. He was installed last night at the association's convention here.

title: Means
VIEWS OF SPORT
description: Motor racing holds a unique place In the world of sport. It is followed by more people than perhaps any other sporting activity. Football may be big in Buffalo, baseball might be the thing in Atlanta, basketball or hockey hold their own in Los Angeles or Toronto, tennis spreads to many places other han Forest Hills or Wimbledon, and golf has already crossed new frontiers, but nothing, not even horse racing, aptures the attention of so many people as does motor sport.

title: Sludge Is Studied As Safe Fertilizer

title: Opened up for living

It looks like the work of a precocious child, but is, in fact, the work of Ivan Chermayeff, a graphic designer, whose signs and symbols are landmarks for New Yorkers. One of his hardto miss signs, is the fat orange on the sidewalk in front of 9 West 57th Street, the slopefronted building designed by Skidmore Owings & Merrill. The number is 10 feet high, 5 feet wide and weighs three tons.

title: Brezhnev
description: Current efforts, both in Washington and in Moscow, towards a new set of relationships between the United States and the Soviet Union, commonly known as dtente, have focused increasing attention on the background, personality and aims of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the man who has committed himself to seeking a relaxation of tension on the Soviet side. The appearance of this first booklength biography of the General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party is particularly timely as President Nixon is preparing to meet again with him in Moscow next month despite the uncertainties of the Watefgate affair.

title: Rome Widens Ban on Cars
description: ROME, May 18 (Reuters)In Its latest move to counter traffic congestion, the City Council of Rome banned private cars today from a fourmile area of fashionable shopping streets in the center of the city. Since the antitraffic campaign began ten months ago, nine miles of the narrow streets, notorious for traffic jams, have been closed.

title: Mollie; MakeBelieve; By Alice Bach. 147 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $4.95. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Mollie MakeBelieve is evocatively named in that, initially, it requires the reader to suspend various strains of disbelief. First of all, don't believe the flap copy. The book is not about the confrontation of the title character with Jaimie, a boy whose life patterns are completely different. Next, don't believe the title. The book is not about escape into unreality, whether psychotic or merely fantastic. No, thank goodness, this is not another sociology unit. Mollie MakeBelieve is much better than that. It is a true novel of character, populated with indisputably human beings rather than wax works, Munchkins, automata and Jungian nightmares.

title: Music: Curious Cantata; Ocean Flight (1929), by Brecht and Weill, Is WellSung by Choral Society
description: The oddity on the New York Choral Society's program Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall was Ocean Flight, an overtly didactic cantata by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill. Composed in 1929, it is devoted to Lindbergh's flight as a symbol of human aspiration. This was billed as a New York premiere, although more accurately it seems to have been the premiere of Brecht's slightly revised version. The cantata was originally called Lindbergh's Flight, but in 1950 Brecht, for obvious political reasons, decided to delete all references to the Lindbergh name and to transform the piece into something more universal.

Indeed, the I.R.S. has not charged fraud. Many people are asking, why not?

title: Designed to resist the human imprint
description: If a visit to an airline terminal (or bus station, zoo, school, prison) makes you feel as if compressed air is being pumped into your cerebruma sort of uptown sigmoidoscopyyou probably are the victim of your architectural environment. This style of construction has been dubbed by, California psychology professor Robert Sommer hard architecture, which he defines as designed to be strong and resistant to human imprint. To the inhabitants it seems impervious, impersonal and inorganic. The primary reasons for hard architecture, Sommer theorizes, are a garrison state mentality on the part of the builders or owners, and their desire to create or maintain facilities the users cannot deface or destroy. Sommer has divided hard architecture into seven major representative groupsmental institutions, prisons, airports, zoos, schools, offices, universities.. In all of them he finds common characteristics: Expensive to construct, alter, or raze. Clear differentiation of status levels.... Passive adjustment and psychological withdrawal are encouraged. Materials and furnishings selected for ease of purchasing and maintenance.

In fact, the troubles began last October, when the full scale of the country's disastrous drought became apparent, followed by indisputable evidence that the old government was too corrupt and inefficient to have at least 100,000 Ethiopians from starving to death.

title: Authority in Bonn

The government he has formed in close negotiations with the Free Democrats augurs well for his prospects. No second step was possible until this essential first move had been made to reshape and preserve the political alliance that provides his Bundestag majority.

Sails made of Kevlar yarn were used by Ted Hood, the noted sailmaker, when he won the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit championship last winter in his One Ton sloop, Robin Too II.

title: The Birth of Nations;By Philip C. Jessup. 361 pp. New York Columbia University Press. $14.95.
description: In this book Philip Jessup has plucked and woven together a few common strands from the period of his rich, varied and distinguished career when he was United States Representa tive and Ambassador at Large to the United Nations. In the early postwar year's Jessup watched the birth of a hand ful of nations and played a significant, and sometimes major role in their tangled of fairs. The Birth of Nations is a difficult book to assign to any standard category. And that, in itself, is perhaps a reason for its freshness and vitality.

title: Psychoanalysis and Feminism
description: Ah, penis envy! Is it on its way to becoming a topic for nostalgia, baking its place in the museum along with chastity belts and corsets? Will it fade away along with Viennese hysteria and Victorian pornography as we become freer to be you and me? Or will it still lurk in the timeless unconscious, too deep to be reached by social reforms and fashionably liberated attitudes? Do girls only become feminine women through an unconscious acceptance of inferiority in early childhood, which leaves them very liable to collude in their own oppression? Papa Freud evidently thought soand so does radical feminist Juliet Mitchell, whose astonishing new book, Psychoanalysis and Feminism, reopens these questions with a militant gravity.

title: HARTFAD COT EXPECTS A PURGE

title: No Energy Crisis for Summer Music
description: THE news about summer music in the United States is that there is no news. Earlier in the year, when the energy crisis had generated the worst fears and gas was strictly rationed, there was much speculation that countryside festivals would suffer because people would have difficulty driving to them. The Boston Symphony management went so far as to set up a system whereby patrons of the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., would have free telephone service telling them where gas was available.

title: Cosmos Low Attendance

Although the New York Cosmos attracted few fans, last weekend's crowds were the largest in the history of the league. Out of the nine games played last weekend, the attendance at five of the games was more than 10,000. Miami had 18,290, San Jose had 15,678, Seattle had 12,132 and the St. Louis game at Busch Stadiom, shown live on home television, attracted 10,382.

Be alert for emergence of gypsy moth.... Use malathion for scale crawlers....
