title: Book. Ends
description: Hard Sell. Everybody knows that publicity sometimes helps sell a book and everybody also knows that it is a bit more difficult to hook up a novelist on the talkshow circuit. So we will call an expert witness to the stand on the subject of publicizing a novel, Sol Stein, the Stein of Stein & Day, publishers (his wife, Patricia, is the Day). He the only publisher, as far as we know, who is also a successful novelist; his last book, The Magician, sold over 500,000 copies in all editions. Since Mr. Stein has a new book out, published by Arbor House (sea page 38) and is reputed to be a man who knows how to push a hook, we were not.surprised to learn that he had just returned from a tour of a dozen or so cities. Another writer we know whose path crossed Mr. Stein's on the circuit noticed with awe his custom of appearing with a 3 by 5 card in hand. Mr. Stein explained that the card contains reminders to himself of things to talk about. The notes, printed in a large typeface known as Orator, Prod Mr. Stein to set the scene of the book, discuss all the characters, rather than just the main one; there are also such cryptic mnemonics as coupling without a contract (to remind Mr. Stein to say that he is no longer in favor of living together with benefit of clergy) and after women's lib what? which brings him around to the theme of his book. As for the importance of publicity, he learned from his last book that sales were highest in (a) the four cities which he had visited personally and (b) the cities in which the David Frost Show on which he had appeared was shown in prime time. His advice to novelists who want to go the talkshow route: Have a nonfiction theme to talk about (his is postwomen's lib so War and Peace is, as Woody Allen said, a book about Russia). Also, being a publisher helps, since there are a lot of wouldbe writers out there who want to know how to write a successful novel, Mr. Stein imparts three rules. What else did he learn? The distribution of books in this country is abysmal. There followed a typical author's story about none of his books being on display when he showed up for a bookstore appearance. Authors, even when they're publishers, are all alike.

title: Israelis Report Golan Fighting But No New Raids in Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, May 18Retaliatory Israeli air strikes in Lebanon appeared to have been halted today, but Israeli and Syrian artillerymen continued to exchange fire in the area of the Golan Heights.

title: Little Current, 131, Rallies to Win $209,000 Preakness by 7 Lengths
description: BALTIMORE, May 18Little Current flashed along on the inside to score a sparkling victory in the 99th running of the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico today. The Kentuckybred colt, owned by John Galbreath's Darby Dan Farm, responded to a brilliant ride by Miguel Rivera to score by seven lengths over the long shot, Neapolitan Way, and the favored Cannonade.

title: Newcombe Is Toppled By Riessen
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. May 18 Marty Riessen ended John Newcombe's string of 1974 tennis triumphs today and advanced to the final of the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament. Rode Laver also reached the final by beating Tom Okker at Caesar's Palace earlier on a gray, windy afternoon.

title: Delivering The Spirit Via the Flesh
description: TANTRISM, the secret cult within Hinduism that developed in India about 14 centuries ago, has a lot going for It in 1974, including sex, violence and demonism. You might add, as well, a touch of women's lib, since Tantrism is commonly summed up as the worship of female energy in conjunction with a passive male deity, to paraphrase an early note in the catalogue of a current exhibition of Tantric art at China House Gallery. It is a tiny exhibition for so large a subject, but has a considerable potential for straightening out a number of confusions.

The three Americans are Katherine Zenz, 28 years old, of Lancaster, Wis., Joann McDaniel, 29, of Salem, Ore., and Robert E. Hubbard, 23, of San Diego.

The fact that a certain woman is a widow may mean, little to someone who does not know her. If it also is known that she has bees left a large income, that she subscribes to numerous romance magazines and occasionally drinks too much, she may quickly become the target of unscrupulous approaches.

title: Photography
description: SAN FRANCISCO UNLESS they are imported Magnum opuses such as the Paul Strand retrospective or French Primitive Photography, Bay Area museum presentations of photography are generally distinguished by their close proximity to the rest rooms. Of all the local museums only the Oakland Museum has a permanent (if modest) installation devoted to creative photography. When it comes to temporary shows, the regional institutions shunt photography off into corridors, hallways and remote cubbyholeswhen they present it at all.

description: No one would mistake 6foot5inch Dick Woodson for Tiny Tim, but Woodson harbors strong suspicions that Calvin Griffith is the reincarnation of Scrooge.

title: How the Philharmonic Survived the Flood
description: THE chances could well be that when in future years the management of the New York Philharmonic talks about the 197374 season, which ends on Saturday, it will be in much the same terms that the natives of Johnstown talk about the Flood. The subscription season started, as scheduled, on Sept. 18, with Pierre Boulez conducting. That was the last bit of sanity for some time. The musicians went on strike, after the first, week of concerts, and remained out until the concert of Dec. 6. All nine weeks of programs had to be scratched; all the soloists were unheard. There must have heen bitter tears; many of them were making their first appearances with the Philharmonic, and a Philharmonic date still carries deal of clout.

title: Red Smith
description: BALTIMORE, May 18Between the seventh and eighth races a female streaker looking slightly undernourished went weaving through the Pimlico infield today pursued by cheering young males. Half an hour later a blazefaced chestnut named Little Current went streaking on an arrowstraight course along the rail while his panting pursuers dropped farther and farther behind. At the finish of the 99th Preakness Stakes, Little Current was out there alone by seven widening lengths and his owner, John Galbreath, had temporary title to the only trophy in the Triple Crown series that he had never won.

title: Fair Day And Another; Step Begun; By Katie Letcher Lyle. 157 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company. $4.95. (Ages 12 and up)
description: Fair Day, and Another Step Begun was inspired by the old English ballad, Childe Waters, and, like the ballad, it seems unduly harsh on Ellen Burd, its heroine. The cruelty of the ballad is thought to be a prime factor in its disappearance from living folk repertoires. Fair Day deals with the pursuit of one John Waters, about 22 years old, by the 16yearold girl he has made pregnant. Ellen, like the irretrievably pathetic masochist of the old ballad, risks everything for the exquisitely diabolical Waters. Somehow her obsession (love?) for John's male beauty sustains her through her tribulations, for it is only at the end, following the birth of their son, that John Waters will acknowledge his relationship to the baby.

title: Hackensack River Wins as a Raft Race Founders
description: TEANECK  A scheduled raft race between Fairleigh Dickinson University and Montclair State College earlier this month was washed out because neither crew could stay afloat before the start. However, there was a winner: The Hackensack River Coordinating Committee.

title: Without U.S. Help, Millions May Suffer or Die
description: WASHINGTONFarmers in the American Southwest last week had already begun the harvest what will almost surely be a record crop of winter wheat by the time the combines finish in North Dakota. In the Midwest, farmers were planting massive acreage of corn and soybeans.

title: Heart disease has its reasons
description: For some of us, the very awareness of the heart's beating is a source of terror as if each thump might be the last. Cardiac neurotics, as they are called, observe the contractions of the heart as one watches the stars on a clear night. There are so many of them and each of them is of such consequence that it seems almost inevitable that one must explode before our eyes and bring an end to our petty consciousness.

title: J.P. Morgan and company
description: Allen Churchill's latest volume of American social historyhis twelfth concerns the great fortune makers of 18501910those men he calls the nefarious breed of robber barons who lusted for lucre and were ardent worshipers at the shrine of the Almighty Dollar. The work tells how they conspicuously consumed their illgotten gains in building mansions in New York and in trying to outshine each other in architecture, furniture, summer palaces, and life styles.

title: Bronx Luncheonette Owner Is Shot to Death by Robber
description: The owner of a Bronx luncheonette that also reportedly was used as a policy gambling drop was shot to death yesterday during a struggle with one of two men apparently attempting to rob him in the store.

description: SOUTHAMPTON  Until last fall, the Rogers Memorial Library here had not been painted in more than 20 years.

title: Architecture
description: THE New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects has mounted an exhibition in its headquarters offices at 20 West 40th Street called Women in Architecture (through June 7th). It is extremely interesting both as architecture and as polemics. The initial (thankful) reaction is that the trap one feared of having to judge architectural design in terms of sex, with appropriate allowances and innuendos, just doesn't exist. The product is blessedly asexual.

title: How to Hit Winning Volley and Enjoy It
description: For the average tennis player, there are few more exhilarating shots in the game than a crisp, artfully placed volley. He's up at the net, an opponent tries to angle the ball by him, but he intercepts it and finishes off the point with a decisive placement that leaves the opponent flatfooted.

title: Artist and Poet Meet, Perfectly
description: LONDON THERE are exhibitions that remind one of a pebble thrown into a pond; the implications extend further than the original cause. This is the case with the neatly conceived Auden/Moore exhibition, a selection of drawings and prints by the English sculptor Henry Moore, now on view at the British Museum, through June 30. The core of the exhibition is a series of lithographs which Moore executed in 1973 as accompaniments or interpretations of a group of poems by the late W. H. Auden. (The Petersburg Press will be publishing the book later this year.)

title: Governor Wilson an Unwitting Enigma

As usual, the heading State of New York, Executive Chamber, Malcolm Wilson, Governor, appeared in the upper left corner. Only in the first sentence was something amiss. Governor Rockefeller, the press began, announced today....

description: Thank heaven for a good proletarian novel for young readers. I've been trying to figure out the best way to tell my grandchildren that there were hard times back in the thirties. Now Edward Fenton has saved me the trouble.

title: Sheehans Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr: and Mrs. Robert W. Sheehan of New York on MaY 6 at the New York LyingIn Hospital. The child, named Thomas Vietor, is a grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander O. Vietor of New Haven, where Mr. Vietor is curator of maps for Yale University, and of Mrs. John T. Heard of New London. description: Miss Barbara Leigh Mortimer, who was graduated Friday fromthe University of Verinobt, plansto be married Sept. 7 to Lawrence Daniel. Stone, who graduated from Vermontlast year.

title: The Uncollected Essays and Reviews of Yvor Winters
description: On the subject of the late critic Yvor Winters there is an easy consensus: he spoke too exactly for himself and therefore, for posterity, not accurately enough. His preference of T. Sturge Moore to Yeats is well known, together with many others like it. Fullscale attacks were launched on him in midcareer by F. 0. Matthiessen, Randall Jarrell and Theodore Spencer, and long ago a popular survey of literary criticism dubbed him a bad critic of some importance. Apparently it is hard not to listen to Winters but no trouble at all to dismiss him. Dramatic justice seems to be at work here: a critic whose own intolerance is so thoroughgoing will not, even among the shades, find the fruits of ordinary human charity.

title: U.S. Sees Adverse Impact
description: WASHINGTON, May 18A spokesman for the Stare Department Said today in reaction to India's explosion of a nuclear device that the United States has always been against nuclear proliferation for the adverse impact it will have on world stability.

title: Big Weekend Planned for DogShow
description: There's a triple for metropolitan fanciers next weekend, and the three shows have drawn a total of 5,280 dogs.

title: Future Social Events
description: Putting It All in Black and WhiteMay 22Wouldn't you like to fare Pakistani, eye some mime and listen to harpsichord musk, in a storied part of the city, within a house without walls? Naturally that means interior walls, and wait  it gets even better. Where more prosyminded persons might have partitioned off rooms, this imaginative owner has used massive black and white sculptures by Louise Nevelson as dividers. Who could afford that? Not to make a mystery of it the housecumstudio is Mrs. Nevelson's and a short. walk from the once no torious Mulberry Bend, now Columbus Park. She has offered it as a setting for a Black and White Event and the doings described above have been arranged to honor Merce Cunningham and benefit the Cunningham Dance Foundation. Everyone is to wear black and white. If inflation has got you, wrap up in newspaInternational ActionMay 22If you want action, then go where it's at. English in Action, a nonprofit organization, provides English conversation practice on a onetoone basis, but the odds will be a little differentand so will the action  at their International Gaming Night in the Gotham Hotel. It will be an un usual casino, with games from the far corners of the earth. Have you tried Australian swy or sieto y medio, a kind of Spanish black jack, or Swiss holtzle? You might like an Italian card game, ziganette, or even that old Chinese torturer, fan tan. Winners numbered stubs will be drawn for some smashing donated prizes. Tickets, $25 a couple, $15 for one, includes hors d'oeuvres for you to bite as you concentrate. Drinks from a cosh bar. Mrs. Kurt Waldheim is honoraryRiveting Good RelationsMay 22The Ralph Bunche Institute on the. United Nations will libld its first award dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. I. W. Abel, president of the Steelworkers of America, will be the honoree. Brian Urquhart, UnderSecretaryGeneral of the United Nations, will be the guest speaker. As this is a sitter, a Meyer Davis orchestra wit play dinner music. Henry Cabot Lodge is chairman, and as for vice chairman, get hold of a Who's Who in America. Tickets, $100, from Frank H. Berend and Associates.Diamond JubileeMay 22  More than 2,000 celebrants will tax (don't mention that word) the capacity of the WaldorfAstoria Grand Ballroom at the annual benefit dinner dance and 75th birthday party of the National Jewish Hospital and Research Center in Denver. Started as a tuberculosis sanitarium, the hospital has become one of the country's largest for treating respiratory. diseases. Thomas M. Macioce, president of the Allied Stores Corporation, will receive the hospital's Diamond Jubilee Award. Stanley H. Kunsberg is chairman. Tickets, $150.Wine and Woman But no SongMay 22Sir Frederick Ashton's La Fille Mal Gardee, based on a work that first saw the footlights at Bordeaux, France, in 1786, and La Bayadere, another aspect of the eternal feminine as delineated in ballet, will be danced by the Royal Ballet in the Metropolitan Opera House as part of the annual spring festival that benefits the scholarship fund of the Hebrew Arts School of Music and Dance. It won't be a late night because the prefatory champagne dinner starts at 5:30 o'clock, just about the time you feel the need to bubble. Tickets, $75. Mrs. Ronnie Shapiro and Mrs. Robert Greer are cochairPlenipotent RidottoMay 23It's good thing the St. RegisSheraton has iniles of red carpet because some of the brightest scarlets will have to be rolled out for The Ambassadors Gala, a dinner dance in The Roof to benefit the Hospitalized Veterans Service, an arm of the Musiclans Emergency Fund. Mrs. Lytle Hull, who has worked 40 years for the organization, will Share the receiving line with former Ambssadors Spruille Braden, Wiley T. Buchanan, Guilford Dudley Jr., Angier Biddle Duke, George J. Feldman, John Davis Lodge, Emil Mosbacher Jr. and John A. Scali, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, along with their wives, and that onetime Ambassador and former Mayor, Robert F. Wagner. The party will honor the Philadelphia committee of the Hospitalized Veterans Service. Mrs. S. Gubelman and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope are cochairmen. The $100 ticket is taxdeductible and will enable you to sip, swallow solids and slip round the dance floor to

title: Johnny Rutherford's Sad Indy 500 Saga of 1974
description: Johnny Rutherford had calmed down. It was the day after he found out, because of a technicality, that he was ineligible to qualify for the pole at Indianapolis, and he was amiably posing for pictures with one of those friends of a friend who are as much a part of Gasoline Alley as the mechanics.

title: Four novels
description: Shirley Harman is brilliant, beautiful, outspoken, a loner. When the book opens she is on her roof, about to commit suicide. At 28 she is a celebrity. Receiving the Mayor's Award for civil achievement in front of TV cameras she proceeds to tell him what's wrong with the city, that a woman should run it. On the Dick Cavett show she gives her ad agency's major competitor a free (and better) idea for their product. At her own agency she singlehandedly saves none other than the Ford account (ask for Shirley's car) and even makes Ford redesign the body.

title: Harold Rabinovitz to Wed Miss Lerner
description: Miss Sharon Holly Lerner, who graduates next month from Vassar College as a member of Phi Beta Kappa, plans to be married in August to Harold Rabinovitz, a cum laude graduate of Princeton University and student at the University of Miami Medical School.

title: 2 REFINERY PLANS ON SOUND IN DOUBT
description: HARTFORD, May 18The State Department of Environ!mental Protection threw a heavy damper this week on two separate plans to build oil refineries on Long Island Sound., One of the refineries, capable I of providing 400,000 barrels a ;day, would be built about a mile from shore.

title: TENOR AND PIANIST GIVE JOINT RECITAL
description: Two performers of qualityJohn Morrison, tenor, and Raymond Jackson, pianistgave a joint recital at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon.

title: Many Women Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Women are running for office in unusually large numbers, a tally by the National Women's Political Caucus shows. With filing deadlines past in 23 states, 823 women have. announced their candidacies for state and Congressional offices the caucus said Wednesday

title: Impeachment Class Planned
description: GAINSVILLE, Fla., May 18 (AP)An impeachment class will be taught at the University. of Florida this summer so students will better understand the House Judiciary committee's inquiry.on President Nixon, a university spokesman said this week.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: A market consisting of 44 million American women who enjoy both working with their hands and the economies of sewing clothes at home can hardly be called a depressed market.

title: Marks Is Retiring As District Director For Immigration
description: After a career of some 40 years in Government service Sol Marks, the district director of the New York district of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, will retire next Friday.

title: The Music Man Teachers Go To
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I.When public school bands, orchestras and choral groups perform on Long Island, there is a good chance that the selections they offer have been influenced by an exmusician who holds no position in any school district.

title: A Company That Prefers to Mind Its Own Business
description: John G. Phillips, the recently elected chairman of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, was in town the other day and he was talking about the great changes that have come over the oil and gas industry at a time of energy shortages.

title: Twins'Thompson'sLack Again Scrapes Bottom
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. May 18 (AP)  The baseball career of Danny Thompson has reached another question mark, and the 27yearold shortstop of the Minnesota Twins could remain on the disabled list indefinitely.

title: Parent and child;You really hit that one, man! said the Little League boy to the Little League girl
description: It was a scene calculated to gladden the heart of a militant feminist and give your average male chauvinist a severe attack of dyspepsia. Girls were playing in Little League baseball! What was worse, the star of the game was a 12yearold named Felicia Lee, tall, rangy and undeniably female.

title: Foyt Keeps No. 1 Spot In Indy 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP)A. J. Foyt, on the hot seat for a week, held on to the pole position today as a field of 33 starters was finally completed for the Indianapolis 500mile race on May 26.

title: Atoms Girls Dominate Track Meet
Mozambique Political Prison Frees 440 More Detainees
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mo zambique, May 18 (Agence FrancePresse) An additional 440 political prisoners were set free from Machava Prison near here today.

title: Hope Forsyth Engaged To Geoffrey Platt Jr.
description: Miss Hope Gifford Forsyth, who is on the staff of the Mill Iron Lazy W. Ranch in Carbondale, Colo., and Geoffrey Platt Jr., director of program development for the Colorado State Council on the Arts and Humanities, Denver, plan to be married in September.

title: Marjorie Harrison Plans Bridal
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I, May 18  Mr. and Mrs. David Alexander Harrison 3d, of this community have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Anderson Harrison, to Vincent Cosmas Webb Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Webb of Glen Cove. An early summer wedding is planned,

title: Woman Has Best of 2 Worlds
description: Every weekday morning, Mrs. Ann Berk of Plandome, LI., wakes up at 7 o'clock, dresses with her 5yearold daughter, reads her a story if there's time, makes breakfast and heads, often with her husband's dirty shirts in her attache case, for the 8:39 train to Manhattan and ,her job as advertisingpromotion manager for WNBCTV.

title: U.F.T SLATE WINS IN DISTRICT 1 VOTE
description: The United Federation of Teachers slate won a 54 majority on the new District 1 School Board yesterday when counting in the complex election was completed

title: Frogs They Would ASwimming Go
description: NEW HAVEN ONE morning last January, while Larry Blyden was packing for vacation in the Orient, he received an unexpected phone call. We're doing Aristophanes The Frogs at the Yale Repertory Theater, sounded a ritzy, foghornish voice. How'd you like to play Dionysos?

title: ROCKEFELLER PICKS CHOICES PANELISTS
The Education of Henry Adams
Pulitzer People Are No Prize
description: So this year, once again, there was no Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Such negligence would not ordinarily move mnany people to climb into their motorized golf carts and run down a Girl Scout in frustration. This is because, for most people, a Pulitzer Prize in fiction doesn't mean much and never has, having been bestowed with dreary regularity on the lame, the halt, the blind and the folksy. It's almost as though the trustees of Columbia University and their advisory panel conspired at ignoring everything that's vital in American literature, which is one way of holding the confusions of the 20th century at bay.

title: Braves Sideline Gentry
description: ATLANTA, May 18 (UP1)The Atlanta Braves put Gary Gentry, a pitcher, on the disabled list yesterday and purchased Max Leon from their Richmond Farm club to replace Gentry. Gentry, out with ,a right elbow injury, missed half the 1973 season and most of this year.

title: U.S.C. Edges U.C.L.A. In Coast Conference Meet
Inquiry Asked on Appointee To Chairmanship of P.S.C.
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, said last night that his office had been asked to rule on the eligibility of Dr. Alfred E. Kahn as the new chairman of the State Public Service Commission, because Dr. Kahn had been paid consultant to A.T.&T.

title: COL. GRAFTON KENNEDY
description: Col. Grafton Sherwood Kennedy, a retired Army ordnance officer, died yesterday in Baltimore. He was 80 years old and lived in Havre de Grasse, Md.

title: Parsippany Salutes Munich Dead Today
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., May 18 A special ceremony to commemorate the 11 Israeli athletes and coaches who died in the 1972 Munich Olympic terrorism, will. be held at noon tomorrow at the second Morris County Maccabiah Games at Parsippany Hills High School.

title: Mint Shows Its Three New Stars
description: IN the year 2076, when this country is celebrating its 300th anniversary, collectors will treasure the coins issued to celebrate the nation's 200th anniversarycoins with special reverse designs bearing the letters D.R.W., S.G.H. and J.L.A., the initials of the three Bicentennial coin designers shown above, The names of these artistsDennis R. Williams, Seth G. Huntington and Jack L. Ahrwill soon be found in all the numismatic reference books, alongside such past greats of the coinengraving art as Victor D. Brenner, Christian Gobrecht, Adolph.A. Weinman and

title: Byrne Proclaims World Trade Day
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne has formally declared next Thursday as World Trade Day in New Jersey.

title: Miss Whiting Wed To Eddy F. Laird
description: In All Angels Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Wendy Margaret Whiting and Eddy Finley Eaird, members of the class of 75 at Gallaudet College, Were married by the Rev. Eric J. Whiting, rector of the church and father of the bride. The service, at which the Rev. Ray Anderson of St. Paul's Mission for the Deaf in West Hartford, Conn., assisted, was interpreted in the language of signs.

title: State Acts To Prevent Crimes In Resorts
description: TRENTONThe State Law Enforcement Agency is plan ming additional programs to help prevent crime in seashore communities, historical parks that will be used during the bicentennial celebration in 1976 and the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Japan Voices Protest
description: TOKYO, May 18 (AP)Japan today protested the Indian nuclear test. The Government can only express, regret because we have been and are still against any nuclear test by any nation for any reason, a Cabinet spokesman said.

title: Two first novels
description: In order to respond fully to this savage comedy, I think you have to be keyed in"that is, pushed to the brink of hysteria by all the trait, the pervasive anonymous threat of violence in the thick poisonous air, the enormous punishment for no crime except (according to Beckett) the stupid mistake of being born. If, like Harvey Grosbeck, you can't empty your insides of the worm of fear, which keeps growing fatter and longer; if you agree that the ultimate act of bravery is taking a walk after 11 at night; if you recognize that the metaphors and systems by which you used to live are rotted at the edges or rusted into holes in the middle, then you're indeed keyed in and ripe for this vision of Hell on plastic roller skates. My trembling guess would be that I've just described nearly all of us.

title: Experts Urge I.L.O. to Spur A Fairer Deal for Women
description: GENEVA, May 18  Strong measures are still needed to insure a fair deal for the working woman, according to expetits brought together by the International Labor Organization.

title: Pop
description: HONESTY in music is hard to find these days. With so much emphasis on albums that truly reflect the heart of their makers often get shunted off into special categories which never reach the large audiences they deserve. Classified as contemporary country musicians, Willie Nelson and Waylon Jennings both Texans and veterans of the country music scenehave only recently begun to cross over the country line to attract followings at urban rock/folk showcases like Max's Kansas City here in New York or Los Angeles Troubador. Yet Nelson's Phases and Stages (Atlantic SD 7291) and Jennings's This Time (RCA APL 10539) demonstrate that they are men who know the value of simple truths simply stated.

title: Christine Thurber Wed. to T. J. Ervin
description: Miss Christine L. Thurber, who graduated last week from the University of Rochester School of Nursing, where she received a bachelor's degree magna cum laude, was married yesterday afternoon in Rochester to Thomas J. Ervin, who will graduate next week with a medical degree from the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry.

title: TOTAL OF DEPORTEES EXPECTED TO GROW
description: MIAMI, May 18The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service expects to increase by almost 50 per cent the number of apprehensions and deportations of illegal aliens in the coming year.

title: New Enoval
description: This little stunner of a novel seriously questions Tolstoy',s aphorism: All happy families resemble one another; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own fashion. The family of Will Turnbolt, a Texas cotton farmer, is happy in a unique style. Turnbolt is choleric, moody and vicious. He is capable of beating his dog, his children or his motherinlaw. He is impulsively mean. And yet, his family is unexplicably happy, living in a curious balance between terror and joy.

title: Mrs. Huxtable Is Honored As Woman of Achievement
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, a member of the editorial board of The New ,York Times, yesterday received the 1974 Woman of Achievement award from the New York City branch of the American Association of I University Women at the branch's.headquarters, 111 East 37th Street.

title: WHITE HOUSE SILENT ON WIRET AP ACCOUNT
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 18 (UPI)The White House declined comment today on what appears to be a conflict between President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger over who ordered telephone taps on Government officials suspected of leaking secret information to newsmen.

title: If Impeachment Comes Should TV Be There?
description: ON TUESDAY, barring any more bombshells, the networks will start televising the House Judiciary Committee's inquiry into the matter of the impeachment of the President. ABC, NBC and CBS will rotate their coverage, as they did during the latter stages of the Ervin hearings, thus protecting the right of the American public to remain ignorant if it chooses.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: College seniors who majored in engineering and accounting are on many a company's most wanted list this spring as the job market for seniors is up, though only slightly, for the first time in four years.Engineers of all kindschemical, mechanical, electrical, metallurgical and computerare in shortest supChemical engineers top the list of starting salaries for this year's graduates at $12,360 a year, according a. Michigan State University recruiting survey.

title: Christine Lintz Wed to Kevin McShane
description: Miss Christine Ann Lintz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Worth B. Lintz of Bronxville, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Kevin P. McShane, son of Thomas P. McShane of Nalcrest, Fla., and the late Mrs. McShane, the former Miss Mary Ryan.

title: Vasiliadis Resigns Bergen Culture Job
description: HACKENSACK Constantine G. Vasiliadis, executive director of the North Jersey Cultural Council, has announced his resignation in a letter to Lee Bronster, president of the council's Board of Trustees. The council serves 70 arts groups in Bergen County.

title: Cynthia Coote Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Coote of Westbury, LI., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Jan Coote, to James Breckenridge Blackburn 3d, He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Blackburn Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: Police Offer Antiburglar Hints
description: DOVER TOWNSHIPThe Police Department in this Ocean County community has embarked upon program designed to prevent house burglaries.

title: Westchester Teems With Fish
description: A FEW weeks ago at the Kensico Reservoir I watched a fishsurvey crew from the New York State

title: After Me, the Deluge
description: WASHINGTON, May 18In his selfrevealing interview with James J. Kilpatrick of The WaShington StarNews, President Nixon gave three main reasons against his resignation or impeachment: first, it would be wrong. For, he added, I am not, guilty of any offense under the Constitution that is called an impeachable offense.

title: Storm Halts Women's Golf
description: PROSPECT, Ky., May 18 (AP)The second round of the Bluegrass invitation golf tournament was delayed 50 minutes because of a thunderstorm today, then postponed until tomorrow morning, when another severe thunderstorm swept over the. Hunting Creek Country Club course. The leader through 31 holes, was Mrs, JoAnne Carner, five under par.

title: Campaign Office Bombed
description: LOS ANGELES, May 18 (AP) A small bomb today blew out the front windows of a campaign office for San Francisco's Mayor, Joseph L. Alioto, who is running for Governor.

title: Blood Sport
description: The problem is to keep things in perspective, to offer objections to Robert F. Jones's first novel, Blood Sport, without denying the author's considerable talent and accomplishment. Sentence by sentence, the book often displays a resourceful style and palpable dramatic  as well as thematic  possibilities. But as the chapters pile up, some of the potential remains unrealized while Jones indulges himself in aimless digressions, indigestible brews of fact and fantasy, and incessant puns and word plays.

title: Dale Woods Is Fiancee Of W. S. Dingledine Jr.
description: Miss Dale Collins Woods, a fashion assistant at Bride's magazine, plans to be married to William Stribling Dingledine Jr., who teaches biology at the Boy's Latin School in Baltimore. The ceremony will take place June 29 at St. James Episcopal Church here.

title: Essential Exodus
description: Can we really eat these carrots that came out of the dirt? asked a city child who had never seen vegetables grow or cows being milked. The youngster was one almost 20,000 who last year were given a chance to leave the hot and crowded urban canyons to spend a rural vacation in one of the seven camps operated by the Fresh Air Fund,

title: Hard Scrabble
description: In 1960, when John Graves's first book, Goodbye to a River, came out, reviewers ought to have had climbed their bell towers like Quasimodo and kicked and pummeled the big bells in celebration. There are a handful of other writers, in fact, who might have written as beautifully about a canoe trip on a twist of river that was about to be damned, though not about Graves's own Brazos. But his achievement was unique because, unlike the others, Graves kept his head and wasn't scathing. He remembered that part. of a naturalist's responsibility is to feel a due humility in the face of the futdre as well as simply in the face of nature as we happen to know her, since we don't know what is to come.

title: Drug Clinic Proposal Is Fought In Jamaica
description: Plans for a methadone treatment center in Jamaica were angrily opposed Wednesday night at a combined meeting of Community Boards 8 and 12.

title: How much corn is in the can?; The American; Food Scandal; Why You Can't Eat Well on What You Earn. By William Robbins. 254 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $6.95.
description: Food prices soared 25 per cent in some American cities in 1973, and consumers face more bad news in 1974. The industry and Government try to explain these price gyrations in terms of the supply and demand equation, but with Congress arguing such issues as the Russian wheat deal, skepticism spreads. The public puzzles over the disappearance of its bountiful food supply and wonders what goes on in the supermarket.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS AN ACCORD IS NEAR IN MIDEAST TALKS
description: TEL AVIV, May 18  Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Israel tonight from Damascus after achieving an apparent breakthrough in his efforts to bring about a troopseparation agreement between Syria and Israel on the Golan Heights.

title: Movie Mailbag Burning Up About Blazing Saddles'
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: GROUP DEDICATES WILDLIFE REFUGE
description: WANAQUE, May 19A72acre expanse of unspoiled wood land was dedicated here today as a nature and wildlife sanctu. ary, to be preserved in perpetuity with a $250,000 endowment donated by Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Weis of New York City.

title: DOROTHY COMPTON, FOUNDATIONTRUSTEE
description: Mrs. Dorothy Danforth Compton, a trustee of the Danforth Foundation and of College Careers of Westchester, Inc., died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Opera: Moliere Adapted
description: Since short comic operas that sparkle and amuse do not turn up every day of the week, Saturday was special in bringing us Walter Kaufmann's Sganarelle in its first United States performance. The gift came by way of the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music, and the theater group knew about it from George Schick, the Manhattan School president, who conducted the premiere of the work in Vancouver about a decade ago.

title: HOPE KRIEGER GIVES A RECITAL OF SONGS
description: HOPE KRIEGER GIVES A RECITAL OF SONGS

title: Going Out Guide
description: TICK Lord Thomson of Fleet, Canadian press baron; late First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt, Irish playwright Dylan Thomas, Gauguin, the painter, Muslim leader Malcolm X, photographer Imogen Cunningham, Supreme Court Justice William.0. Douglas, disenchanted Federal Bureau of Investigation agent Robert Wall and others. What made them tick?

title: 100 NewCar Dealerships Forced Out of Business
description: DETROIT, May 19 (UPI)More than 100 newcar dealerships have. been forced out of business this year by slumping sales, and up to 1,000 may fold by the end of, the year, an official of. the National.Automobile Dealers Association said today.

title: Judicial TwoStep
description: Another roundelay for seats on the New York State Court of Appeals, with judges dancing for party and popular favor, is in prospect for the third year in a row. Having merely gone through the motions and failing create a prescreened appointive system for the judiciary, the State Legislature has put the burden back on the ballot. That is where the politicos, who control the nominations that usually determine the outcome, want it.

title: 34 Sing Sing Inmates Come to City Daily For Bilingual Studies at Hostos College
description: For fourteen hours a lay, five days a week, Gilberto and J. R. live like free men, almost. From, early morning, when they leave the place they call. Sing Sing, until night, when they return for the big shakedown, both are students at Hostos Community College in the Bronx.

title: A Peaceful Town in Ireland Tastes Terror
description: MONAGHAN, Ireland, May 19Today the people of this village attended a funeral, went to church, sat in the sunshine on the benches of the main square and strolled solemnly past the devastation in front of Greacen's pub.

title: Whitlam Foe Gains Prestige in Defeat
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 19 Although Gough Whitlam, the Labor party leader, is expected to remain Prime Minister of Australia after the apparent narrow victory of his party in yesterday's national election, the chief victor seems likely to be Bill Snedden of the Liberal party, who heads the Opposition.

title: Body of Missing Boy, 7, Found in Harlem River
description: The body of a 7yearold boy whO disappeared 11 days ago was found yesterday afternoon in the Harlem River off the north Up of Manhattan, the police reported.

title: He Shall Take Care...
description: BOSTON, May 19An, essential task that will face the House Judiciary Committee in due course is to take the massive charges against. President:, Nixon and reduce them to a relatively few counts in a bill of impeachment. For in this process, as in criminal justice, focusing on a few manageable issues is likely to be more effective.One count could'charge specific attempts to obstruct justice in the Win; ter of 1973. In the opinion of many lawyers experienced in the criminal law, the edited White House transcripts provide evidence, ample by indictment standards, that Mr. Nixon approved the payment of hush money and suborned perjury to keep the cap on the bottle of Watergate.A second count could well allege a larger design to impede the Watergate investigation. It would cite many overt acts by which, over a period of months, Mr. Nixon sought to frustrate the regular process of law.1. Thepublished transcripts show Mr. Nixon persistently working to suppress as much information for. as long a time al; possible. He and bit aides schemed to stonewall, to make empty claims of national security and executive privilege, to:threaten the Speaker of the House, to maneuver prosecutorsall in order to keep the facts from. coming out in either a Congressional or a judicial forum. 2. At least as of Parch 13, and even More explicitly on March 21, 1973, the President knew that various present and former members of his staff had committed crimes. He did not inform any. of the Justice Department or F.B.I. officials in charge of the Watergate investigation:

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, MAY 20, 1974
description: International

title: Teaching Theory of Evolution Discussed Again in Tennessee
description: DAYTON, Tenn., May 19More than 600 people from the east Tennessee hill country gathered for a symposium yesterday afternoon in the old brick courthouie where the famous Monkey Trial was fought, in a circus like setting almost 50 years agoand the question of evolution bobbed up. again.

title: An Auto Owned by Sovit Is Set Ablaze in Queens
description: An automobile registered to the Soviet Misaion to the United Nations was set afire and heavily damaged early yesterday in Queens, the police said.

title: HARLEQUIN DANCED BY JOHN CLIFFORD
description: George Balanchine's delectable Harlequinade, to the Drigo score, bubbled to the surface for the first time this season Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It is one of the happiest ballets in the New York City Ballet repertory.

title: Playoff Is Won By Mrs. Carner
Controversy Threatens Indy 500
CHARLES BRASWELL
description: Charles Braswell, a featured stage and screen actor, died of cancer Friday in the Albert Ein, stein Hospital, the Bronx. He. was 49 years old and lived at 344 West 72d Street.

title: Faubus Gaining in Race for Arkansas Governor
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  The people who scoffed when Orval E. Faubus announced that he was running again, for the eighth time in 20 years, are now grimly conceding that he has an outside chance of becoming the Governor of Arkansas once more.

title: ExConvict Holds His Family Hostage
description: CARLSTADT, May 19A 45yearold mechanic with a record of two prison terms for assault held his wife, two children and a stepdaughter at gunpoint for 12 hours in their house here today before a judge, a police detective and a priest persuaded him to release everyone unharmed and then surrender.

title: Woman Is Killed on Thruway
description: WEST NYACK, N.Y., May 19  Mrs. Elaine Patrone, a 39yearold housewife of 422 Cedar Avenue, Upper Nyack, was killed here today on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway when she was hit by a car while walking across the roadway after stopping her car. The accident delayed the heavy traffic for two hours. No charges were made against the driver of the second car, John Di Benedetto, 49, of 1479 Arno Avenue, the Bronx.

title: A Flower of Many Uses
description: To the gardener, dandelions are anything but splendor in the grass.

title: Study Shows Christian Backing Of Israel's View in 73 War
description: The American Jewish Committee reported yesterday that Roman Catholic and Protestant church groups throughout the country had voiced support for Israel during and after last year's Yom Kippur war.

title: SADAT SAYS SOVIET SENT FRIENDLY NOTE
description: CAIRO, May 19 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat said tonight that he had received a friendly message from the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, that would usher in a new stage in relations between the two countries.

title: Lisbon Coup Creates Political PartiesMostly White in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 19Soldiers ride through the streets of this bustling African city, where skyscrapers and highrise apartment buildings adjoin extensive areas of slum shacks.

title: M'Anally Hurls 4Hit Shutout
description: Don't talk to the Mets about what is supposed to be a baseball player's dream of paradise: a doubleheader at home. The Mets played their fifth twin bill of the National League season yesterday and the result was depressingly familiar. They lost a pair to the Montreal Expos, 74 and 50, because of continued offensive and defensive failures.

title: Dan Topping Dead at 61; Yankee Owner 22 Years
description: Dan Topping, an owner of the New York Yankees in their glory years after World War II, died of complications of emphysema Saturday night at the Miami Heart Institute. He was, 61 years old.

title: Father Zicarelli: Controversial as
description: POUGHKEEPSIEE N. Y.A few years ago a little girl from a distant neighborhood mistakenly thought she had lost NI', mother on a busy street in the heavity Italian Belmont section of. the Bronx and wandered into a pasta shop, crying.

title: Advertising: Ogilvy's Farewell
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 18The legendary David Ogilvy, who attended his first American Association of Advertising Agencies meeting in 1938 and last spoke at one 15 years ago, delivered a sentimental thank you to Madison Avenue today as the association ended its 57th annual meeting.

title: Miss Hearst Called Dangerous Fugitive F.B.1 F.B.I. Charges Due in MachineGunning

title: Screen:Liv Ullmann, Hackman in 'Zandy's Bride'
description: What promises to be an engrossing character study of a lovely, lonely mail-order wife and her adaptation to a crude, pioneer huband tapers off episodically and disappointingly in "Zandy's Bride."It does so despite an intelligent performance by Liv Ullmann, whose luminous eyes light up the screen every minute, and the steady, watchful direction of Jan Troell, who has impressively rooted his first California film in a wild sweep of the Big Sur area. But for simple, sustained impact and depth, the new picture can't touch Mr. Troell's two superb pioneer dramas, "The Emigrants" and "The New Land," filmed in his and Miss Ullmann's native Scandinavia.The Warner Bros. release that opened yesterday at the Sutton has two snags in character and drama. The first is the rolenot the performanceof Gene Hackman, that of a selfish, thick-skulled hero, who savagely assaults his new bride and actually expects her to accept and love him. And indeed she does, though our acceptance is something else. An actress less skillful than Miss Ullmann might have run him through, for his persistent brutality, with a pitchfork, script or no script.Furthermore, the emotional tug-of-war is scuttled toward the end of the picture by isolating Mr. Hackman with some cattle thieves and then scooting him farther away to San Francisco for some brief soul-searching. This is the fault of Marc Norman's screenplay, adapted from Lillian Bos Ross's novel, "The Stranger." By shedding the wife's viewpoint, it breaks the real narrative. The story-line and Mr. Hackman have nothing to do but ramble back home, where, of course, the mountain grass is greener.Of the supporting cast, Eileen Heckart wisely underplays a burdened pioneer mother. Maria Cordova is especially good as a warmhearted but wanton woman. Eventually, though, the restless viewer begins peering more and more beyond the people to the awesome reality of Big Sur, where at least Miss Ullmann, her director and his photographer, Jordan Cronenweth, find and hold firm footing.
