description: BASEBALL

title: Tropical Winds Boil Up
description: MIAMI, May 21 (AP)The year's first tropical depression has boiled up in the Gulf of Mexico about 600 miles southsoutheast of New Orleans, the National Hurricane Center said today. Forecasters said the weak depression had winds of 30 miles an hour but was not expected to grow.

title: School Pact Reached
description: BRISTOL TOWNSHIP, Pa., May 21 (AP)Negotiators for teachers and the Bristol Township School District concluded 18 months of bargaining early today when they agreed on tentative contract for 700 teachers. James McNichol, president of the Bristol Township Education Association, said no details of the contract could be released until the membership voted.

title: Krumpe to Head Jersey Sports Complex
description: The former president of the New York Racing Association charged the state yesterday with frustrating bureaucracy in running thoroughbred racing and said Albany had no longterm solution to racing's problems.

title: Flyer Fans Get Reward: 5 Days to Love the Cup
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP)  Philadelphia Flyers fans will have a fiveday opportunity to see the object of their affection  the 84yearold Stanley Cup.

title: British Foreign Secretary Calls For Strong TransAtlantic Ties
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Foreign Secretary James Callaghan of Britain said today that there was an urgent need for a transAtlantic partnership in which the United States and ,Europe consulted, coordinated and cooperated with each other in meeting at least seven problem areas.

title: ISRAELSYRIA PACT IS BROUGHT CLOSER
description: TEL AVIV, May 21Secretary of State Kissinger flew between Israel and Syria again today, virtually wrapping up the details for the ceasefire line that will separate Israeli and Syrian troops and making progress in other areas of the proposed accord on disengagement on the Golan Heights.

title: PANEL HINTS NIXON KNEW OF COVERUP BEFORE DAY CITED
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 The House Judiciary Committee raised tonight the possibility that President Nixon may have known of White House involvement in the alleged Watergate coverup before March 21 of last Year.

title: INTERSTATE PLAN ON CHAPTER XI SET
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., a retail chain that lost more than $60million in the last year, disclosed yesterday that its directors had authorized the company to file a bankruptcy petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Foreign Policy Association Designates New Chairman
description: Carter L. Burgess, chairman of Flagship International Inc., has been designated chairman of the board of directors of the Foreign Policy Association.

title: SEAMAN IN SOVIET MAY SEEK U.S. TIES
description: MOSCOW, May 21A Lithuanian seaman imprisoned in the Soviet Union since his unsuccessful defection to a United States Coast Guard cutter in November, 1970, cOuld become eligible for American citizenship following Washington's acknowledgment: Friday that his mother was an American citizen.

title: 2 Former U.S. Aides Ask Total Nuclear Test Ban
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Two former Government officials today criticized diplomatic efforts to reach a threshold nuclear test ban treaty rather than a comprehensive prohibition on nuclear tests.

title: Andrew Johnson on Impeachment
description: Gentlemen of the Cabinet: You no doubt are aware that certain evildisposed persons have formed a conspiracy to depose the President of the United States, and to supply his place by an individual of their own selection. Their plan of operations seems to contemplate certain accusations against the President, which are to. take the form of Articles of Impeachment, and that hereupon, before hearing or trial, he is, under color of law, to be placed under arrest, and suspended or removed from office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 4Nation Truce Unit Is Strained by Halt of SaigonVietcong Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21  With political talks between the Saigon Government and the Vietcong halted, the fournation International commission of Control and Supervision is beginning to show signs of severe strain.

title: Daily $10,000 Lottery Begins Sales Today
description: TRENTON, May 21 (AP) The state lottery office announced today that ticket sales for the new $10,000 topprize daily lottery would begin tomorrow. The daily lottery prize structure has been revised to provide new $100,000 grand drawing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor C. Guggenheimer urged the New York City Taxi Commission to exercise the greatest possible caution in acting on a request by taxi fleet owners for a 20 per cent increase in fares. We're deeply concerned that an additional fare increase may compound an already very difficult situation facing the riding public, Mrs. Guggenheimer said at a public hearing on the fareincrease application held by the commission at the Commodore Hotel. The Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, representing the owners of 5,725 cabsseveneighths of the fleet total in the cityhas asked that meters be reset to charge 70 cents for the first onesixth of a mile, 10 cents for each additional onesixth and cents for every Minute of waiting time. The fare is now 60 cents for the first onefifth mile, 10 cents for each additional onefifth and 10 cents for each I minute 12 seconds of waiting time.

title: Y at Sheepshead Bay Is Paid for Before Start
description: The new $2.25 million Y.M.Y.W.H.A. in the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn, construction of which is scheduled to start later this year, is almost fully paid for, it was announced last night.

title: URBAN ACADEMY PLANNED BY CITY
description: An Urban Academysaid to be the first municipally sponsored training institution in the country for city employes and executiveswill be established jointly by the city and The City University, Mayor Beanie announced yesterday.

title: Miss Goolagong Challenging French Tourney Ban
description: PARIS, May 21 (AP)A OIspute broke out today over ft bid by Evonne Goolagong enter the French open tennis championships.

title: The Jaworski Letter
description: Like the Bourbons of old, President Nixon seems have learned nothing and to have forgotten nothing. When he broke his word to the Senate and fired Archibald Cox as special prosecutor last October, he evoked such a firestorm of adverse public reaction that his own impeachment for the first time became a live possibility.

title: Notes on People Maharaj ji Weds His Secretary
description: The Maharaj Ji, the young Indian guru, has married his secretary. The plumpish itual leader of a reputed total of six million people associated with his Divine Light Mission, who says he is 16 years old, was married Monday night in his $80,000 Denver home.

title: LIFE OF ERVIN PANEL EXTENDED A MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Overcoming vigorous objections by conservative Republicans, the Senate ektended today the life of its Watergate committee for another month.

title: Search for 2 Boatmen Ends
description: OCEAN CITY, May 21 (UPI) The Coast Guard today called off a search without finding a trace of two men presumed drowned in a boating accident.1 Robert Beisswenger, 57 years old, and F. Stanley Blakley, 83, both of Ocean City, disappeared soon after their 28foot boat sank yesterday in high wind and waves off Longport. A companion, Robert Moninghan, 53, survived six hours in the chilly waters.

title: BONDS ARE MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
Red Smith
description: The world Dan Topping lived in for almost 62 years wasn't exactly the same as the one where Yogi Berra grew up. Material things came more easily to Dan than to Jock Sutherland or Casey Stengel or many others who worked for him. In baseball he was a contemporary of Birdie Tebbetts, but there was a difference. Faced with a major expenditure, Birdie would remind himself: This is money I saved sliding into second base. Dan never had to. Grandson of a tinplate king on one side of the family and a steel tycoon on the other, he always knew where his next yacht or private plane was coming from.

title: Ford Isn't Running for Office but He's Running Fast
description: WASHINGTON, May 21For seven months now, Gerald Ford has been the Marco Polo of troubled Republican party, an airborne circuit rider who has traveled more than 75,000 miles, visited 28 states and made 350 public appearances.

title: Alan Dunn, Cartoonist, Is Dead at 73
description: Alan Dunn, who filled the pages of The New Yorker magazine with wit In nearly 2,000 cartoons published over a span of nearly 40 years, died Monday at his home. He was 73 years old and lived at 12 East 88th Street.

title: MOSCOW PLEDGES PALESTINIAN HELP
description: MOSCOW, May 21  The Soviet Union and Libya today pledged to render every assistance to the Palestinian guerrilla movement.

title: Two Deans in Paddling Case Removed
description: Two junior high school deans who have been accused of using a thick wooden paddle, leather belts( and..their fists to beat students who misbehaved were removed from their posts yesterday by the district superintendent.

title: President's Wife Read All of the Transcripts
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that she had read all of the 1,300 pages of Watergate transcripts and chided a reporter who confessed to reading only 300 pages. She said that she had read the transcripts over a period of nine to 12 hours.

title: Pro PuntRule OpentoSubter fuge
description: Three prominent head coaches in the National Football League indicated here yesterday that they were already at work undermining the spirit if not the essence of one of the new rules changes instituted by the team owners for pro football this season.

title: President Reported at Peace With His Decision Not to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 President Nixon returned last night from a long weekend at his Florida retreat reportedly at peace with himself and With his decision to reject all pressures for his resignation.

title: LANDLORD IS HELD IN THREE SLAYINGS
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 21 Town police officials and the Essex County Prosecutor's office today charged Sidney Selip, the owner of the house in which a mother and two daughters were found dead after an explosion on May 8, with three counts of murder in connection with the case.

title: BrightandSlow Classes Resulting in Segregation
HOUSE BUILDERS CALL FOR ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The nation's largest organization of home builders bitterly denounced today the state of the economy and urged President Nixon to take steps immediately to curb inflation and aid the housing market.

title: Grand Union Reports Loss in Quarter
New Jersey Briefs
description: Women May Join State Troopers

title: JUNE RISE BARRED FOR SALES TAXES
description: An attempt by the Beame administration to wangle an extra week or two of receipts from the 1cent increase in the sales tax was rejected as technically impossible yesterday by Albany.

title: SENATE VOTES RISES IN SCHOOL LUNCH AID
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Senate voted significant increases today in Fed. eral contributions to the food stamp and school lunch programs. The estimated cost ,of the increases is $331million in the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: TV: Monkey, Monkey Plumbs Lives of 5 Women
description: Public television's Theater in America series tonight concludes its first run with a new play discovered at Cincinnati's Playhouse in the Park. The drama is called Monkey, Monkey, Bottle of Beer, How Many Monkeys Have We Here? The title is taken from a nurseryrhyme in which a mother balances a child on her feet. The child reaches out for support, jumps off or falls.

title: Pushouts Inquiry
Hunt Is Continued for Two After Rikers Island Escape
description: The police and Department of Correction officers continued to look for the last two of nine inmates who escaped May 6 from the Rikers Island prison complex after a body found in the East River was identified yesterday as one of the fugitives.

title: A.B.A. Sets June Meeting
description: The American Basketball Association said yesterday its annual trustees meeting would be held June 20 and 21 at Louisville, Ky. A league spokesman said the chief items on the agenda would be discussion of three franchise situationsthe possible sale of the Memphis Tams and Virginia Squires and the announcement by die Carolina Cougars that they would no longer operate in North Carolina. No new location has been disclosed.

title: The Rod and the Law
description: Charges that staff members of Jordan L. Mott Junior High School have routinely resorted to corporal punishment as a means of disciplining students would, proven true, constitute a serious violation of law and sound pedagogy. The suspicion of official wrongdoing was compounded by the initial refusal of Community School District 9 to let representatives of the Board Education investigate the accusations made by teachers and students. Under pressure from school Chancellor Anker, however, the district superintendent has now removed two staff members accused of administering the illegal discipline.

title: AirConditioning Units to Face 6% Higher Costs Beginning June 1
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices by 5 per cent to 6 per cent on major appliances in both its G.E. and Hotpoint product lines, begin4 fling June 1. Also on the same date, the company will raise prices by 6 per cent on room airconditioners and central airconditioning products.

title: Boston Medical Educator Appointed Dean at Einstein
description: Dr. Ephraim Friedman, an ophthalmologist who is dean of the Boston University School of Medicine, has been appointed dean of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and vice president of medical affairs at Yeshiva University.

title: Crime Rate in Coast City Is Linked to Marine Base
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., May 18  This resort city of 52,000 at the entrance to the Marine Corps sprawling Camp Pendleton is seeking Government help in combating an epidemic of murders and a soaring crime nate that it attributes largely to the lawlessness of a new breed of young leathernecks.

title: MacMillan Upholds Role as Director
description: A talk with Kenneth MacMillan, director of Britain's visiting Royal Ballet, turns out to be marked by that legendary English reserve. Yet if the replies are succinct, they are devoid of false modesty and are replete with firm opinions. There is no doubt that this softspoken, 44yearold choreographer is the same Kenneth MacMillan who has been a controversial figure on both sides of the Atlantic since he succeeded Sir Frederick Ashton in September, 1970.

title: New Museum for Photography To Be Headed by Cornell Capa
description: A new museum devoted exclusively to photography will open in October, with the photojournalist Cornell Capa as its executive director. The museum, to be called the International Center of Photography, has acquired Audubon House, a landmark building at Fifth Avenue and 94th Street, as its headquarters.

title: Radical Mayor of Madison. Wis.. Stirs Wide Criticism, but Is Unfazed After Year on Job
description: MADISON, Wis.  It has been a year since Paul R. Soglin, a 29yearold alderman and University of Wisconsin radical, shook the people of Madison by becoming their Mayor.

title: About New York The Way Things Work Out
description: A man who prefers not to be identified woke up early the other morning with severe stomach pains. Vainly, he tried medication, and finally he decided to go to New York Hospital. He went downstairs, hailed a cab, and was taken there, but when he tried to pay the fare he found that he had only $20 bills. Moreover, the driver had no change.

title: Two Deans in Paddling Case Removed
House Unit Backs A Stiffer Tax Rule On Medical Costs
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)The House Ways and Means Committee has tentatively agreed to increase the amount of medical expenses a taxpayer must have before medical deductions can be claimed.

title: An Explanation: How Tape Could Supply Answers to Questions on Hush Money
description: WASHINGTON, May 21If President Nixon authorized payments or a lighter sentence for a convicted criminal in return for the criminal's silence about the facts of his crime, then the President participated in an obstruction of justice. Few Congressmen doubt that that would be an impeachable offense.

title: LTV CORP. ADJOURNS MEETING TO JUNE 17
description: The annual meeting of the LTV Corporation was adjourned after three hours yesterday until June 17 after management learned that a required twothirds of the 500,000 shares of the company's Class A peeferred stock had not been voted for a recapitalization plan. The plan calls for issuing common stock in exchange for the Class A shares and also for Class AA special stock.

title: Baroque String Ensemble Starts an Unusual Series
Patricia Hearst Is Facing New Charges in California
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21The office of District Attorney Joseph Busch of Los Angeles County said today that new charges of kidnapping, armed robbery and assault with a deadly weapon would be filed against Patricia Hearst, herself a kidnap victim of the terrorist group that apparently claimed her heart and mind in captivity.LOS ANGELES, May 21The office of District Attorney Joseph Busch of Los Angeles County said today that new charges of kidnapping, armed robbery and assault with a deadly weapon would be filed against Patricia Hearst, herself a kidnap victim of the terrorist group that apparently claimed her heart and mind in captivity.

title: MAGRUDER GIVEN A10MONTH TERM
BRITAIN HOPEFUL ON OIL OUTLOOK
description: LONDON, May 21.The accelerating pace of North Sea oil discoveries in the last year indicates that Britain will be selfsufficient in oil by 1980 and perhaps sooner, the Government said today.

title: Pershing Missiles Fired
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 21 (AP)Troops from the Seventh Army in West Germany successfully fired three out of four Pershing missiles into a target area 400 miles into the Atlantic today, Kennedy Space Center officials said. The fourth rocket went off course and had to be destroyed.

title: ExAide Charged In GolfBall Theft
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. May 21 (UPI)A former security guard employed at the Uniroyal plant has been charged in connection with the theft on Feb. 18 of 144,888 golf balls from the plant.

title: Survey Finds Young U.S.Workers In Dissatisfiedand Frustrated
description: Workingclass young people in the United States are taking on many of the attitudes on sex, politics, patriotism, religion, the family, morals and lifestyle that marked college student thinking of five years ago. The result, according to an attitudinal research study, is that workers are becoming increasingly dissatisfied and frustrated at a sense of unfulfillment.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, May 21 (UPI)The Japanese Government announced today a substantial step toward removing restrictive measures imposed on business activities in the wake of the oil crisis.

title: 2 Ideals at Issue
description: A tradition in the city's public schools of having separate classes for bright students and for slow students is resulting in repeated situations in which pupils walk through the doors of schools that are outwardly desegregated only to find themselves in racially, imbalanced elassrooms.

title: Crime Strike Force Gets New Chief
description: Gerard T. McGuire, head of the Newark Joint Organized Crime Strike Force since November, 1971, was shifted yesterday to become chief of the Organized Crime Strike Force in the Eastern District of New York. He replaces Denis E. Dillon, who resigned last week to seek the Democratic nomination for Nassau County District Attorney.

title: Rally by Flaherty Gains Slim Lead In Pennsylvania
The Homosexual as a Teacher. Parents Express Their Views
Screen: Stoolie Arrives
Energy BID Rejected
description: The House rejected yesterday a bill designed to cut fuel prices and to give the President standby authority to impose gasoline rationing. Details on Page 8.

title: In Philadelphia News Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP)Claude Lewis, a columnist for The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, has been named associate editor of the newspaper, it was announced today. He worked for Newsweek magazine and The New York Herald Tribune before joining The Bulletin five years ago.

title: Drop in Food Costs Slows Rise in Consumer Prices
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  A rare decline in the cost of food slowed the overall rise in consumer prices last month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: $2MILLION AWARD IS VOTED BY JURY
description: In one of the largest malpractice judgments ever recorded, a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn awarded more than $2million yesterday to a 12yearold girl who suffered brain damage shortly after birth as result of negligence by Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Jesuit Superior to Summon Nixon Aide
description: BOSTON, May 22The religious superior of the Rev. John J. McLaughlin, who is an adviser to President Nixon, has summoned the Jesuit priest to return to Boston from the White House for prayer and reflection.

title: NIXON REJECTS SUBPOENAS, TELLS RODINO HE WILL GET NO MORE WATERGATE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 22President Nixon informed the House Judiciary Committee today that he would refuse to comply with two subpoenas for additional Watergate tapes and documents and would do the same on future demands.

title: I.B.M. Withdraws Its Plan For Center in Ridgefield
description: International Business Mn. chines yesterday withdrew its plans to build a management training center on 50 acres of residential land in Ridgefield, Conn. A proposal to change the zoning on the companyowned land had met fierce op;position at a recent hearing because of a proposed heliport ;on the property.

title: Notes on People
description: An indefinite commitment to a mental hospital was ordered for 26yearold Peter Sydney Ball, alias Ian Ball, after he entered a plea of guilty in London's Old Bailey to the attempted kidnapping of Princess Anne and related charges. The plea was entered after the court heard a bizarre tale involving a $7.2million ransom note to Queen Eizabeth II a demand for amnesty and plans to flee to Zurich.

title: Wilson Signs a Bill Making City Liable For Acts by Police
description: ALBANY, May 22A bill that makes the City of New York liable for all negligent acts or torts committed by a policeman during the performance of his duties, whether the acts were done while on duty or not, has been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office reported today.

title: Two Teams at 147 In Women's Golf
Great Lakes Pollution Fight Is Gaining
For Child Abuser: Parents Anonymous
description: EAST ORANGE, May 22Increasing numbers of phone calls from New Jersey parents and teenagers concerned about their relationships are coming into the New York chapter of Parents Anonymous because of a lack of similar groups in New Jersey, Gertrude M. Bacon, former Family Court judge, said today,

title: Howe and Son Slated to Add Last Chapter to Aeros Success
description: One of the strangest sports stories of the year will draw to a close in a few days with a Texassized ending.

title: U.S.SOVIET UNIT ASKS AN ECONOMIC ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The joint United StatesSoviet Union commercial commission decided today to recommend to the two Governments a 10year formal agreement. to facilitate economic, industrial and technical cooperation.

title: PHONES TO SPEED EMERGENCY CARE
description: A telephone system to summon emergency care for people who are injured in accidents, suffer heart attacks, swallow poisons or are subject to other lifethreatening conditions will be set up in 32 states and Puerto Rico under a privately financed program announced yesterday.

title: Wine Tasting and Auction A Mostly Serious Affair
description: CHICAGO, May 22  A savvy toper could, and perhaps a few did, have a marvelous bash here yesterday.

title: Frances's Pregnancy Troubled by Toxemia
description: New York's bestpublicized ladyinwaiting, Frances, the pregnant whale, has become ill in her tank at the Aquarium at Coney Island.

title: Read All About It!
description: There's a different kind of streaker a species that predates the recent nudity buff, He or she specializes in a different kind of disclosure. Remember when people had love affairs and kept quiet about it? No more. In bed tonight and in print tomorrow.

title: Waksman Institute Marks Two Decades of Research
description: PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, May 22  A group of scientists who hope to help solve some of the world's biggest problems through control of its smallest living organisms celebrated the 20th anniversary of their combined effort this week.

title: Slippery Water
description: Mayor Beame is reported planning to phase out the city's business with the Rand Institute, offshoot of California think tank that former Mayor Lindsay commissioned to analyze a broad range of urban problems and help streamline the city's bureaucratic structure. Gleeful Beame aides, long hostile to Mr. Lindsay's penchant for hiring outside consultants, have made light recently of slippery water, an innovation introduced by a Rand expert to improve firefighting efficiency.

title: Panel Backing Immunity To Jacobsen in Milk Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Senate Watergate committe seeking testimony about alleged campaign payments by milk cooperatives to John B. Connally, voted today, to obtain immunity from prosecution for Jake Jacobsen, a Texas lawyer and longtime friend of the former Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Atoms Hand Cosmos 4th Loss in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22The Cosmos, who played three soccer games at home and had lost all three, came to Philadelphia to play the Atoms tonight, and played well. The problem was the Atoms played better and defeated the New Yorkers, 10, before 10,117 fans.

title: CEASEFIRES SEER TOPIC IN LISBON
description: LISBON, May 22President Antonio de Spinala today presided over a meeting of the military junta in which the new Government's efforts to end fighting in Africa were reported reviewed.

title: Cairo Is Shuffling Top Editors In Bid to Promote Its Policies
description: CAIRO May 22President Anwar elSadat has ordered new shakeup among the editors of the nationalized Egyptian press.

title: Italians Insist Connors Is Barred From Tourney
description: ROME, May 21 (AP)Jimmy Connors will not be allowed to play in the $100,000 Italian open tennis championships because of his involvement with the new World Team Tennis league, the Italian Tennis Federation asserted today. The tournament starts Monday.

title: Protesters at White House Burn Their Utility Bills
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Utility bills were burned in front of the White House yesterday by demonstrators protesting high power bills.

title: Case Rested By Defense At Trot Trial
description: Apparently following a quit  while  you're  ahead strategy, defense attorneys rested their case yesterday in the racefixing trial of New York harness drivers.

title: PROSECUTOR TELLS OF FEAR ON AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, May 22 (UN)According to the chief prosecutor in the Spiro T. Agnew case, one reason the former Vice President was allowed to plead no contest to reduced charges was fear that he might become President.

title: GOING OUT Guide
Credit Cards Are In, Paper Money Out, For Cornell Dining
description: Just as Marco Polo told incredulous Europeans that paper was being used as money in Cathay, so now travelers from Ithaca report that paper money will no longer buy sustenance at the academic caravanserai there.

title: Roosevelt Entries
PRICES DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
DISASTER AID BILL IS SIGNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)President Nixon signed legislation today expanding Federal aid to victims of natural disasters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Nixon's Gallup Rating 25% in Latest Survey
description: The Gallup Poll has found that President Nixon's latest popularity rating, taken May 10 to 13, was 25 per cent and matched his low point to date, recorded in a survey taken in early April.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Daniel International Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $17million contract to build an addition to the manufacturing facilities of the Sugar Growers Cooperative of Florida at Belle Grade, Fla.

title: Rustle of Spring Stirs Bustle of Ideas by Block Groups
description: From the edge of the Bronx down to Coney Island, block associationsthose little cities within a cityhave blossomed forth once again with the brightening light of spring.only way the city will be saved, says Wallace Andrews, deputy director of the United Block Association, a cityfunded federation comprising 107 block associations throughout the five boroughs. The city is just too large to care about the single block. It is the people themselves who hold the key to their own survival.To many, the associations symbolize people power in its most pure and effective form, a way for the individual to overcome a feeling of powerlessness in the face of a mechanized bureaucracy and seize control of his own life Some of the older associations are minigovernments in themselves, complete with sanitation committees, youth patrols and recreation and beautification boards.

title: MRS. GEORGE C. MILES
description: Mrs. Lucy Eleanor Briggs Miles, wife of George C. Miles, retired executive.director and chief curator of the American Numismatic Association, died of cancer Tuesday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 70 years old and lived on East Hudson Road in IrvingtononHudson, N.Y.

title: PAULKAUPER DIES; LEGAL EXPERT, 66
description: Prof. Paul G. Kauper, an. authority on constitutional law who taught at the University of Michigan Law School, died yesterday at Ann Arbor at the age of 66. He was the father of Assistant Attorney General Thomas E. Kauper, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: Rustle of Spring Stirs Bustle of Ideas by Block Groups
description: From the edge of the Bronx down to Coney Island, block associationsthose little cities within a cityhave blossomed forth once again with the brightening light of spring.

title: BHASKAR APPEALING IN DANCES OF INDIA
description: The Indian dancer Bhaskar described the piece that opened his program at the Cubiculo on Tuesday as being an invocation to the gods, the audience and, he added with a sly smile, to any critics who might happen to be in the house. Thus invoked, one must admit that while ethnicdance enthusiasts might be put off by the overriding theatrical element in his work, Bhaskar is a very appealing performer, with his rich speaking voice and lithe, compact body. He has a winning exuberance and draws in an audience with direct appeal to it.

title: Cordero Up On 32 Victor At Belmont
description: Garland of Roses, leading all the way, scored an easy victory yesterday in the $15,000 feature on the grass at Belmont Park.

title: Plumbers Trial May End If the U.S. Withholds Data
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Federal judge in the White House plumbers trial raised the possibility today that he would be forced to dismiss the case if the Government refused to turn over national security evidence that was. helpful to the defendants.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS BUSING IN ALABAMA
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 22 (AP)A Federal judge rejected today crosscity busing as a solution for desegregating some predominantly black schools in Montgomery County and ordered a new integration plan.

title: Anker to Issue a Directive Restating Ban on Beating
description: Anker said yesterday that he would issue a new directive within days to all 950 city schools enforcing the school system's ban on corporal punishment. School Chancellor Irving

title: Of Human Prospects
description: WASHINGTONIs there hope for man?

title: O.E.C.D. PAYMENTS EXPECTED TO LAG
description: PARIS, May 22The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development expects that balance of payments deficits of the industrialized nonCommunist countries will amount to $40billion this year and will be concentrated mainly in a few countries such as Italy, Japan, Britain and France.

title: Maheu Says Benefits Kept Him in Hughes Job,
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22Robert A. Maheu said today that in the spring of 1970 he wanted to leave Howard R. Hughes's employment, but did not because he liked the perquisites of his job.

title: Mrs. Meyner Is Charged With Conflict
description: TRENTON, May 22The race for the Democratic nomination in the 13th Congressional District was intensified today by conflict of interest charges made against favored candidate, Helen Stevenson Meyner.

title: A.E.C. Stations to Monitor Krypton Dispersion in Air
description: Thirteen weather stations lownwind from the atomic rector development center in outhern Idaho are monitoring adioactive krypton from that ite in a fourmonth study of lispersal processes in the at. mosphere, the Department of Commerce announced yesterclay,

title: Bridge:; ?? ?? Recapture Some Cround in Team Play
description: VENICE, Italy, May 22North America regained some lost ground in the world team championship here tonight by taking maximum points against New Zealand. Italy moved to the head of the standings by defeating Indonesia, 17 to 3, while Brazil had a hard match against France, losing 4 to 16.

title: Chess
description: The good old days of the gambits are gone. While Bobby Fischer or Boris Spassky may occasionally surprise an opponent with a king's gambit, that hoary, and somewhat rusty, weapon is not to be found in the regular repertoire of any of the leading players.

title: London Banks Cut Rate
description: LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) Barclays Bank and the National Westminster Bank said today they would reduce their base lending rate to 12 per cent from 12 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Next to high prices, one of the most vexing problems in the supermarket for many peopleelderly, single, on fixed incomes like Social Security, widowed, illis the popular package of packing foods in packages with relatively large amounts, such as half a dozen apples or lemons, and so on.

title: Jordan Returns Guerrillas Arrested in War to Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 22  Sixtytwo Palestinian guerrillas who were arrested in Jordan while trying to enter Israeli territory during the October war arrived here today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (Reuters)The Federal Energy Authority promised today that by the end of May or early June it would have a complete audit of the 30 largest refineries in the United States and could then decide if the companies had increased prices more than allowed.

title: Energy Choice
description: How can the Federal Government best spend $10billion for research and development to cope with the nation's energy shortage?

title: Books of The Times
description: When Charles Baudelaire said, I cultivate my hysteria with joy and terror, he was posing just a bit, playing the dandybut for Philip Roth, in My Life as a Man, the statement is disturbingly true. In fact, it is even something of an understatement, for there is far more terror than joy in his book, and cultivate may be too detached a word for what he does with his hysteria. I would say, rathar, that he exacerbates it. The title of his novel not very different from Baudelaire's My Heart Laid Bare, but Mr. Roth is even less able to locate his heart. He very nearly disembowels himself in grappling for it.

FASHION TALK
description: For many women, fashion change doesn't happen over night. After they see some radically new styles in the stores for a while, or on their friends, they begin to consider wearing them themselves. Or at least trying them on.These are the women who were reluctant to accept pants, until recently, and who are certainly not going to accept calf length skirts next fall. But they are open to suggestions in such areas as color and texture, they will accept some loosening up in the fit of clothes and they are ready for more casual styles.Kimberly, which has long been a security blanket for these women, touches all three bases. It offers plum tones and mauvepink in the color category. It deepens some armholes and blouses some tops. And best of all, it puts everything together so a women doesn't have to shop around for a shirt after she finds a suit.The pants suit, which Kimberly has turned into a way of life for many fans, now comes equipped with sleeveless sweaters and shirts. Patterns such as wallpaper designs, geometric shapes or bold stripes liven things up. At night, there are glitterknit sweaters with black pants with tunic tops.Everything's knitted and the price range is $75 to $240.Take a fake leather jacket, tweed pants and a print blouse. Or a flareback jacket in melton cloth over a pleatedfront dress. Sportswear? No. Casual clothes by Shannon Rodgers for Jerry Silverman. This is only part of the story at this traditional dress house. It offers flowered velvet pants and jackets tor lounging around the house, plenty of chiffon and sequins for going out at night and little suits to wear to dinner.Mr. Silverman is particularly enthusiast:lc about a casual dress with a fly front closing that has sold spectacularly well in cotton for spring and is being done in gabardine for fall. He's calling it his million dollar dress because stores have ordered 10,000 styles to sell at $110.The other prices are mostly in the $25 to $200 range.Now, nobody wants to be sensible all of the time. Fernando Sanchez figures that even conservative types will let themselves go in the privacy of their own home. So he's invented some seductive little styles to wear lounging, sleeping or even under clothes for those women who still fancy underwear.Some are rather versatile, such as the lacetopped camisole that can be teamed with boxer shorts under dresses or with long pants at dinner.

title: Invasion by Bats in 'Chosen Survivors'
description: Movie science-fiction, which has threatened mankind with all kinds of berserk fauna from ants to dinosaurs, now is transmitting future shock with bats in "Chosen Survivors," which landed at Loews State and other theaters yesterday. If the chills are intermittent, the combination of the voracious vampires and fumbling scientists as unwitting partners in disaster gives some novelty and a sardonic twist to this latest manufactured view of a possible doomsday.The 11 survivors here have been selected by computer to live in a seemingly safe, luxurious, gadget-filled environment miles below the earth's surface, presumably to save mankind after a wholly destructive thermonuclear war.Naturally, this American lite includes young, handsome male and female scientists, a tycoon, a writer, a Congresswoman and a black Olympic gold medal winner, who cautiously accept their fate until those screeching bats invade their haven. And the behaviorial expert among them soon drives them up the stainless steel walls by confessing that there is no nuclear holocaust and that they're actually guinea pigs in a controlled experiment.Who survives is not important here. Sutton Roley, a television director, maintains a fair level of suspense aided largely by scientific gimmickry, technical effects and action sequences that accentuate the inmates' terror. The script by H. B. Cross and Joe Reb Moffly, newcomers to this observer, offers them some dialogue that realistically reflects on man's inhumanity to man.Properly taut, if not memorable, performances are contributed by the principals, among them Jackie Cooper as the self-centered tycoon; Lincoln Kilpatrick as the proud Olympian; Barbara Babcock as the pretty and proficient doctor; Bradford Dillman as the behavorial observer hoist by his own experiment, and Richard Jaeckel as the beleaguered electronics overseer.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: Edited

title: Dave Anderson
description: In what he calls his private Thought Book, the 1972 Olympic 400meter champion once wrote, I'll die before I can really live.. But even the obituary of Vincent Matthews will be a reminder not so much that he won the gold medal but that he slouched on the victory stand. In the hours and days that followed, his explanations were minimal. He even told his mother that he just didn't feel like standing at attention. Now, almost two years later, with the publication of his compelling autobiography, MyRace Be Won (Charterhouse, $10), his explanation spills out in a torrent, Vincent Matthews is black and that influenced him. But beyond that, he is an individual, and all track and field athletes are by the nature of their individual role in their individual events, He is an individual who is complex, sensitive, brooding and concerned with living with what he demands of himself rather than what others demand of him. Perhaps more important to the world, he has emerged as a sYmbo! of what the Olympics have become, a farce of politics among nations, instead of what the Olympics are supposed to be, the flame of competition among athletes.

title: HOUSE BARS CUT OF 100,000 TROOPS STATIONED ABROAD

title: Prof. lrmgard FluggeLotz Dies; Taught Engineering at Stanford
description: Prof. Irmgard FluggeLotz, the first woman to hold a full professorship in engineering at Stanford University, died yesterday in Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 70 years old.

title: Canoeists Make Portage to City Hall to Carry Plea for More Space
description: Members of the Sebago Canoe Club of Brooklyn tray eled overland yesterday to City Hall to carry out their plea for more waterfront space.

title: Italians Insist Connors Is Barred From Tourney
CHARLES MANTIA
description: Charles Mantia, who retired in 1961 as bonding secretary of the Actors Equity Association after having served on the staff of the actors union since 1928, died Friday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: SCHOOL VOTE HELD IN WESTCHESTER
Keeshond Outwalks His Master
description: Somebody took a 32mile walk to Cruf L's in London last February, and it wasn't because of the energy crisis. It was a charity hike by Dr. Michael Stockman, chairman of the Keeshond Club, and his 7yearold dog, Valmiik of Vorden. For every mile we walked, a donation was made to the humane society, said the British veterinarian. As a matter of fact, we ran the last quarter of a mile to get to the ring on time. I was in much worse shape than my keeshond.

title: Buses for Handicapped Students Are Vandalized in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 22 A Westchester bus company specializing in the transportation of handicapped children was the target last night of vandals who slashed tires and broke windows on most of its 75 vehicles.

title: Biblical Garden Has No Apples
description: It's not exactly a Garden of Eden, but it is as charming an assortment of plants mentioned in the Bible that you will find the length Amsterdam Avenue or maybe anywhere in the city.

title: Screen: Daisy Miller
Atoms Hand Cosmos 4th Loss in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22The Cosmos, who played three soccer games at home and had lost all three, came to Philadelphia to play the Atoms tonight, and played well. The problem was the Atoms played better and defeated the New Yorkers, 10, before 10,117 fans.

title: URUGUAY'S ARMY FORCING CHANGES
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 22President Juan M. Bordaberry, who has jointly ruled Uruguay with the military over the last year, is again under pressure from army leaders frustrated by the country's deepening economic crisis.

title: Two Memorial Days Stir Illinois Confusion
description: CHICAGO, May 22 (UPI)There will be two Memorial Days in Illinois this year.

title: Newsmen's Privacy Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)  Representative Edward I. Koch, Manhattan Democrat, has proposed a newsman'srighttoprivacy act designed to guarantee additional protection for the confidentiality of the telephone records of reporters. Under the proposal, court order would be needed before telephone or telegraph information could be released by the companies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA SUSPENDS ATOM AID TO INDIA
description: OTTAWA, May 22In protest against India's explosion of a nuclear device last Saturday, the Canadian Government today suspended its aid to the Indian atomic energy program.

title: Kathleen Cannel, 82, Dies; Covered Fashion for Times
description: Kathleen Eaton Cannell, who covered European fashions from Paris for The New York Times from 1931 to 1941 and in recent years had contributed balScience reviews to The Christian Science Monitor, died Sunday in Boston. She was 82 years old.

title: INDIAN RULES OUT ATOMIC WEAPONS
description: NEW DELHI, May 22India's Defense Minister today ruled out the use of nuclear weapons and said that her new technology would be developed solely for peaceful purposes.

title: What Price Arrogance?
description: The White House decision to defy the House Judiciary Committee's subpoenas for additional evidence concerning the Watergate coverup, as well as its request for evidence dealing with the I.T.T. and milk price cases, is a calculated aci of arrogance.

title: U.S. Envoy to Sweden Takes Up Post After Rift
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 22 (Reuters) A new United States Ambassador, 71yearold Robert StrauszHupe, arrived here today, restoring diplomatic relations to normal after a rift that began in December 1972 with a Swedish denuniciation of American bombing of North Vietnam,

title: HOUSE BARS CUT OF 100,000 TROOPS STATIONED ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 The House rejected today 100,000man reduction in American forces abroad, but approved a $474million cutback in military aid to South Vietnam and then went on to pass a $22.6billion arms budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: ATTEMPT PLANNED TO SHIFT SATELLITE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 22 (UPI)Space scientists will try early next month to correct the faulty orbit of a weather satellite, the project manager said yesterday, adding, We expect to be right on the money.

title: Convicted in Bank Robbery
Gambling Museum Burns
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 22 (UPI)Fire destroyed a museum casino operation on the Las Vegas Strip last night, but firefighters managed to scrape of the currency that had been used to wallpaper the inside of the resort. The blaze broke out shortly before 8 P.M. at Bob Stupak's World Famous Million Dollar Historic Gambling Museum and Casino.

title: Wallace Leading Own Poll Over Nixon and McGovern
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 22 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace has been running far ahead of President Nixon and Senator George McGovern in a Presidential preference poll conducted by Mr. Wallace's campaign coordinators, his staff said yesterday.

title: Miss Gerulaitis Wins
description: WOODBURY, L. LRuta Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, defeated firstseeded Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N.J., 61, 62, to reach the final of the Eastern women's hardcourt tennis championship today at the Woodbury Country Club. Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, won the other semifinal, beating Debbie Campbell of Greenwich, Comm., 36, 60, 62.

title: Vietcong Decide to Set Up Permanent Paris Mission
description: PARIS, May 22 (AP)The Vietcong said today that they were setting up a permanent mission in Paris and expected it to lead to full  diplomatic recognition by France:

title: Jail Guards Held Hostage
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 22 (UN)  Three guards were overpowered and held hostage for two hours last night by rebellious prisoners in the Jackson County Jail. The guards were released unharmed when County Executive George Lehr accepted the prisoners demand for a news conference.

title: People and Business
description: The United States probably will adopt some form of economic controls again in the next few years, according to C. Jackson Grayson, a former head of the old Price Commission.

title: New jersey Sports
description: SUMMIT, May 22On Sunday evening, at the home of Bill Persichetty here, two school teachers, a, business exeCutive, an orthopedic surgeon and a retired track, coach will gather for a quiet celebration of a race held 20 years ago in Los Angelea.

title: CONSENT ACCORD SET BY BLOCK PRODUCERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment yesterday in which 11 concrete block producers in the Chicago area would be prohibited from conspiring to fix prices or allocate customers.

title: F.T.C. INVESTIGATING ADS ON HEARING AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was investigating the possibility that hearing aid manufacturers and marketers have used unfair selling practices or false advertising.

title: Chabrol's Memorable Wedding in Blood
Two Issues Said to Delay TroopSeparation Accord
description: TEL AVIV, May 22  Amencan officials said tonight that two major issues  the size of the United Nations buffer force and the limits to be placed on Israeli and Syrian troops were holding up the completion of a troopseparation agreement far the Golan Heights.

title: The Painful Road to Brandt's Resignation
description: BONN, May 22It was 11 A.M. Monday, May 6, a gray, windy, rawcold morning. Willy Brandt had just finished telling those of his staff who did not already know it that this would be his last day as Chancellor of West Germany.

title: F.C.C PETITIONED ON POST CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The Federal Communications Commission has been asked to determine what, if any, basis. The Washington Post's publisher, Mrs. Katharine Graham, had for saying that an effort to take away The Post's Miami TV station was politically motivated.

title: Corporal Punishment
description: A Federalcourt decision week in Richmond upholding the ConstitutiOnal right of thirdgrader to due process before being paddled by a principal may pose a serious newchallenge to corporal punishment in schools. The decision, by Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr., that a child isentitled to a hearing before being punished, is likely to buoy the hopes of critics of corporal punishment that somehow the schools can be compelled to end the practice.

title: Sweden Reports Submarine Has Fled Bay in the Baltic
description: STOCKHOLM. May 22 (AP)  An unidentified submarine that was reported trapped by a small task force of the Swedish Navy in a Baltic bay left Swedish waters after the task force was withdrawn, the defense headquarters reported.

title: Rights Amendment Fails
description: SPRINGFIELD, HI., May 22 (UPI)  The Illinois Legislature has again rejected the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution. State Senator Esther Saperstein, a Chicago Democrat withdrew her ratification resolution yesterday when it appeared that support. for it would fall four votes short. The Senate president, William C. Harris, a Republican from Pontiac, had determined that ratification would require a threefifths vote in hoth houses of the Legislature. Mrs. Saperstein said she would wail NI. a ruling on a suit filed in Wederal Court challenging his in cling he fore trying again for ratification.

title: Flaherty to Face Schweiker for Senate
description: PHILADELPHIA. May 22 Peter Francis Flaherty, the boyishfaced Mayor of Pittsburgh, won Pennsylvania's Democratic nomination to the United States Senate yesterday with a narrow plurality victory over Herbert S. Denenberg, the former State Insurance Commissioner.

title: Use of U.S. Funds For UNICEF Help In Hanoi Is Barred
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22  The United Slates insisted today that its money should not be used for aid that the United Nations Children's Fund provides for North Vietnam and for Communistcontrolled areas in the South.

title: Liddy Wins Revision Of Judge's Sentence
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)G. Gordon Liddy, serving heavy prison terms for the Watergate breakin, succeeded today in persuading a judge to lift a portion of sentence that Mr. Liddy considered illegal and felt he could not fulfill.

title: OMEGAALPHA, INC., SUES ACCOUNTANTS
description: OmegaAlpha, Inc, of Dallas, has filed suit in ihe United States Southern District Court of New York asking $115million from the accounting firms of Touche Ross & Co. and Hertz Herson & Co.

title: From Italy's Piedmont Region, a Group of Savory Dishes
Christian Buchheit Dead at 89; ,Honored by Art Students League
description: Christian Buchheit, the only nonartist who was made an honorary member of the Art Students League, which he served as building superintendent from 1905 to his retirement in 1971, died Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital, Denville, N. J. He was 89 years old and lived at 6925 Manse Street, I Forest Hills, Queens.

title: MRS. JOSEPH A. RIELLY
description: Marie E. Rielly, who retired last year as president of the Rielly Company, sportswear manufacturers of 960 Avenue of the Americas, died yesterday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N. Y. Her age was 81 and she lived in Kinderhook, N. Y. Her husband, Joseph A. Reilly, was president when he died in 1960. Their son, Gerard Rielly of Scarsdale, N. Y., now president.

title: 4 Americans Are Killed In a Collision at Montreal
description: MONTREAL, May 22 (UPI)Four persons from New York and Connecticut died this morning when their car collided with another near Monteal.

title: Personal Finance
description: Stock is commonly given as a gift. Parents bestow it on children when they are born, when they graduate from college, get married, move into a new home or on dozens of other occasions.

title: Merola Drops Inquiry of a Teacher Showing Students Sex Film, Saying Law Was Not Violated
description: Complaining that you can legally show in a school pictures that you can be locked up for showing to youths in a public theater, District Attorney Mario Merola yesterday dropped the investigation of a Bronx highschool teacher who showed his classes a filmstrip depicting intercourse and oral sex.

title: Los Angeles Will Pay for Damage in Its Raid on S.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22Re. sentment over the way the Los Angeles Police Department han died last Friday's attack on hideout of the terrorist Sym. bionese Liberation Army sub. sided somewhat today as Mayor Tom Bradley said the city would compensate the homeowners whose property was damaged in the raid.

title: Senators Bid Saxbe Aid Jaworski's Independence
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Senate Judiciary Committee told Attorney General William B. Saxbe today that he should use all reasonable and appropriate means to guarantee the independence of Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: ASHBY BLADEN DEAD. PROTESTANT LAYMAN
description: Ashby E. Bladen, a retired insurance executive, former presiI dent of the New York Board of Trade and a prominent layman in what is now the United Church of Christ, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived at 379 Ridgewood Avenue in Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: Senator Buckley Joins Eskimos on Hunt for Whales:
description: POINT HOPE, Alaska, May 22Senator James L. Buckley of New York arrived here yesterday to join this Eskimo village in its annual hunt for bowhead whales.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Shot Kearny Teacher Sues Again

title: McCord Thinks Nixon Authorized Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)A convicted Watergate conspirator, James W. McCord Jr., says in a book released today that he believes President Nixon set in motion both the Watergate breakin and the subsequent coverup.

title: Poor Bet
description: Revenue estimates in a new budget are always something of a gamble, but Mayor Beame is taking a long shot with the offtrack betting surcharge foisted off on him by Governor Wilson in place of the stock transfer tax originally requested by the city.

title: Indians Say Halt in Canada Aid Will Not Affect Atomic Projects
description: NEW DELHI, May 23Indian officials are said to feel that Canada's decision to suspend her nuclear aid to India will not affect New Delhi's Inuclear energy program.

title: Notes on People
description: On a sentimental journey back to the scenes of some of his more notable diplomatic achievements, W. Aver ell.Harriman is enjoying a 10day visit to the Soviet Union. Mr. Harriman was United States Ambassador to Moscow during World War 11, when he dealt with Stalin and Molotov, and in the years following the war he was often a negotiator for American Presidents, In 1963, he represented President Kennedy in negotiations that led to the partial nuclear test ban treaty. With the former New York Governor in Moscow are his wife, Pamela; his daughter, Mrs. Kathleen Mortimer, and Winston S. Churchill, Mrs. Harriman's son by the late Randolph Churchill and grandson of he late Sir Winston.

title: Miss Hearst Faces Terrorist Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP) A rapid series of auto thefts and threats on people's lives is alleged against Patricia Hearst and two comrades in an official report detailing levents of the last week.

title: A Satellite Will Bring Patients to Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, May 23A complex satellite that can bring doctors and patients face to face by television across hundreds of miles of mountains is to be launched from Cape Kennedy next Thursday.

title: Corporate and TaxFree Bonds Rise in Price in Quiet Trading
description: Prices moved up in the Government bond market yesterday in continued quiet trading. Elsewhere participants reported that a somewhat better tone prevailed in the corporate and taxexempt markets, where the trading pace was also slow. In the Government market, gains of as much as 12/32ds to onehalf point were registered in the intermediatecoupon issues. The upturn also showed up in the Treasury bill market, which will be engaged today in the regular weekly auction the Treasury Department normally holds every Monday. Because of the Memorial Day holiday on Monday, the auction is being held today.

title: For Israelis, War. Makes Inflation Doubly Punishing
description: JERUSALEM, May 23 For Yehiel and Sarah Gadassi, who immigrated here from Yemen 25 years ago, inflation has meant a drastic cutback in everything. They have slashed their food budget, postponed improvements in their modest apartment and, most important, lost the feeling they had before the October war that  for the first time in their lives they were finally getting ahead financially.

title: Red Smith From Here to the Coosaw River
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 23  Between a vacant storefront and a car wash across Broad Street from the North Philadelphia railroad station stands the Manor House of fistlight gyms, perhaps the only bloodpit in America with walltowall carpeting, recessed lighting and music coining out of the wall  if you accept the blastfurnace sounds of rock as music. This is the Cloverlay Gym, one of the properties of Cloverlay, Inc., the benevolent agglomerate preachers and politician  and schoolmarms and stenographers who moonlight as fight managers owning pieces of Joe Frazier. At last count these managers numbered about 800, including some named St, Joseph's College, the Pennsylvania Ballet, Drexel Institute and Temple and Villanova Universities, and they shared 37,486 pieces of the former heavyweight champion of the world.

title: Contradiction by Rebozo Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The testimony of Charles G. Rebozo in a civil deposition taken last December apparently contradicts his sworn assertion before the Senate Watergate committee that he received a $50,000 Republican campaign contribution in early April, 1972.

title: Retailers Mixed in Results for Quarter,
description: Four of the country's largest retailers  Federated Department Stores, Inc., R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., the W. T. Grant Company and the Allied Stores Corporation  reported fiscal quarter results yesterday that indicated a mixed pattern of consumer buying and pressure on earnings.

title: Kidder to Absorb Clark, Dodge
description: Kidder, Peabody & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it would acquire Clark, Dodge & Co., Inc., a well regarded, oldline brokerage house that in recent months had fallen into the vise of inflation and sagging trading volume that has been crippling many Wall Street firms.

title: Memorial Day
description: Monday is Memorial Day,4.4 Following is a list of services that are affected:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Contract Awards
description: The Town of Hempstead, L. I., awarded a $44.6million contract yesterday to the Hempstead Resource Recovery Corporation, a subsidiary of Parsons & Whittemore, Inc., to build and operate a fully integrated garbage resource recovery plant to generate steam for electrical power.

title: Newark Boys, 9 and 12, Seized For Throwing Child, 2,Off Roof
description: NEWARK, May 23  Two boys who allegedly told the police that they like to beat up kids have been arrested on charges of kidnapping a 2yearold boy from his crib, beating him and throwing him off the roof of an abandoned threestory building.

title: OLIN TO SPIN OFF OLINKRAFT UNIT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 23 Shareholders of the Olin Corporation voted overwhelmingly today to spin off Olinkraft, Inc., a forest products subsidiary, as an independent company.

title: Brazil to Release French Missionary Jailed Last Year
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23A French priest who was sentenced last year to 10 years in prison on charges of having incited Brazilian peasants to violence is expected to be freed shortly, authoritative sources reported today.,

title: Market Place: New Fee Plan Has Problems
description: Under the arrangement, firms could set rates at any level they saw fit for trades involving less than $2,000. Since that date, a number of different plans have evolved, including a novel arrangement by an outofstate firm that agreed to let new customers make their initial trade without commissions if the transaction involved less than $2,000.

title: U.S. TO RENOUNCE MIN ATOM ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The United States gave assurances today that it would not develop a new generation of miniaturized nuclear weapons that could be used interchangeably with conventional weapons on a battlefield.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ORADELL, N. J., May 23  After grabbing a handful of dirt arid a couple of hearty practice swings, Jack Lazorko, rated as one of the best high school baseball players in Bergen County, is ready for the confrontation. When I'm at the plate it's me against the pitcher and I've got to prove I'm better, said Lazorko, an 18yearold senior at River Dell High.

title: ERA. ASKS ACTION ON XRAY LEAKAGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had ordered repairs on 68 airport baggage Xray machines that were leaking up to 300 per cent more radiation than the Government permits.

title: David Coe on Way To Strong Career Asa Song Stylist
description: David Allan Coe, who made what amounted to a New York debut Wednesday night at Max's Kansas City, is a coun tryflavored singer and song writer of impressive stature. Now 34 years old, he has spent nearly 20 years of his life in reformatories and prisons, including a stretch on death row at the Ohio State Penitentiary.

title: EDWARD T. REILLY
description: Edward T. Reilly, executive secrete, of the Particular Council of the New York Society of St Vincent de Paul, a division of Catholic Charities, and director of the society's camp for underprivileged children at Glen Wild, N. Y., died Wednesday at his home, 1483 East 18th Street in Brooklyn. His age was 62.

title: Lisbon Shifts 2 Held Since Coup From Madeira to the Mainland
description: LISBON, May 23The armed forces today transferred two ministers of the administration overthrown last month from the island of Madeira to the Portuguese mainland.

title: Performers at Space Get Notice to Quit
description: Eight performing art groups have received notices to vacate the Space for Innovative Development, an arts center for experimental groups, on June 30 because of operational losses.

title: Pope, Proclaiming 1975 a Holy Year, Calls for Amnesty
description: ROME, May 23 (AP)Pope Paul VI appealed to world governments today to consider granting amnesty to prisoners, especially those held for political crimes.

title: YUEN SU WONG DIES; AIDED SUN YATSEN
description: Yuen Su Wong, editor and Chinese Ambassador to Mexico from 1932 to 1937, died Monday at Mercy Hospital in Sacramento, Calif. His age was 86, and he lived in Sacramento.

title: Medical School Cutback
description: Federal aid to medical education has been earmarked for drastic cuts, spelled out in a recent report by Henry E. Simmons, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Health. The new policy rests on the Administration's forecast of surplus of physicians, combined with the theory that medical students should pay more of the cost of their training because they can expect to become members of a highly remunerative profession.

title: Virdon, Seeking Way to End Slide, May Yank Some Yanks From. LineUp
description: Despite their inept play the past two weeks, the Yankees aren't ready to push the panic button. For one thing, they haven't played at Shea Stadium long enough to know where the button is; for another, what would it be like if they pushedit and nothing happened?...

title: Thomson and Branca Team Up for Lawsuit
description: Bobby Thomson and Ralph Branca Learned up yesterday and launched a $1.85million lawsuit against three companies for violating their civil rights in showing a film clip of The Shot Heard Round the World. It has been on New York television often in the last few months. The shot was Thomson's home run against Branca that lift ed the New York Giants to the National League title against their hated rivals, the Brooklyn Dodgers, in the 1951 playoffs.

title: Paris Blast Damages Sacre Coeur Basilica
description: PARIS, May 23 (AP)  An explosion early today heavily damaged a dome of the Sacre Coeur basilica, a Parisian landmark.

title: Ziegler Charges Distortion in Leak Of a Nixon Quote
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) Ronald L. Ziegler, President Nixon's press secretary, criticized today news leaks that he said distorted the President's characterization t of the events of March 21, 1973.

title: RAW MATERIALS SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Prices of most basic raw Materials closed slightly higher yesterday on the leading commodity. exchanges after earlier lower quotations attracted buying late in the day.

title: Ford Calls on Nixon to Release Relevant Data to House Inquiry
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 Vice President Ford urged the White House last night to release all relevant evidence to the House Judiciary Committee the quicker the better.

title: COUNCIL DEFEATS HOMOSEXUAL BILL BY 224019 VOTE
description: The homosexual rights bill was defeated by the City Council yesterday, 22 to 19, while supporters in the balcony shouted bigot and shook their fists at the Councilmen below.

title: House Panel's Call For Nixon Tax Data Rejected by I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service has declined to supply the House Judiciary Committee with information on President Nixon's tax returns for its impeachment inquiry, an I.R.S. spokesman said tonight.

title: Bache &
description: Bache & Co., Inc., reported yesterday a thirdquarter loss,& for the period ending April 30 of $1.4million on revenues of $41.7million. This compared with a loss for the same period last year of $496,040 on revenues of $38.9million.

title: Soviet Ship Starting Cruises to Nowhere
description: Luxury cruising a la Russe from the Port of New York becomes a reality tonight.

title: Divided We Stand
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.This is not just the end of another school year. On campus, and in the nation at large, it is the end of an era.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officials of Cazenovia College reached agreement yesterday, with the state on a plan they hope will save the twoyear upstate women's school. The agreement with the State Dormitory Authority is to be presented to the college's board of trustees for approval.

title: City Unemployment Is Put at 7 Per Cent
description: New York City's unemployment rate hit 7 per cent In April, the State Labor Department reported yesterday, making the city immediately eligible for at least $11.7million in Federal publicemployment program funds.

title: Bowery. Savings Bank to Offer A PaymentAccount Service
description: The Bowery Savings Bank, the nation's largest mutual savings bank, will today begin offering customers a payment account that in most respects resembles a commercial bank's checking account. Two days ago, the much smaller Erie County Savings Bank in Buffalo announced a similar service.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Less than a year old, a little out of the way, it's one of the finest small parks in the city. It's Harlem River State Parkthe only state park in New York Cityon the eastin bank of the Harlem River, at West Tremont and Cedar Avenues in the Bronx, west a the Major Deegan Express

title: Brockington Signs Packers Contract
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., May,23 (UPI)  John Brockington, the Green Bay Packers running back, signed a multiyear contract today with the National Football League club, ending speculation he would jump to the new World Football League.

title: ExHead of Miami Hospital Faces Forgery Charge
description: MIAMI, May 23Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of a Miami hospital that once drew praise from President Nixon, has been charged with 64 criminal counts in connection with the alleged forging of checks totaling $525,000.

title: Jesuit on Nixon's Staff Ponders Superior's Request for Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Rev. John J. McLaughlin, the priest on the White House staff whose strong defense of President Nixon has embroiled him in a dispute with his superior in the Jesuit order, said today that he had not yet decided whether to heed a call to return to Boston for prayer and reflection.

title: You Wouldn't Believe Some of the Stuff People Toss Out
description: Greta Garbo waves to them, Senator Jacob Javits says good morning, and Debbie Reynolds always smiles. They're on nodding ,terms with Walt Frazier, Bess Meyerson and other wellknown tenants who live in the elegant town houses and luxury apartment buildings on the Upper East Side.

title: RISE IN VETERANS AID AWAITS NIXON ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)The House passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill providing a $566.9million increase in benefits for veteran disabled in service and their dependents.

title: FRENCH LEGISLATOR RECEIVED BY CHOU
description: PEKING, May 23 (Agence FrancePresse)Premier Chou Enlai today met Pierre Sul. dreau, a French member of Parliament, at a time when the Premier has considerably reduced his activities because of fatigue.

title: COUNCIL DEFEATS HOMOSEXUAL BILL BY 22TO19 VOTE
PRESS ISSUE HALTS INQUIRY BY A JURY
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 The Virginia Supreme Court, the state's highest, ordered today a recess in the proceedings of a special grand jury until freedomofthepress issue involving the jury could be decided by the courts.

title: KISSINGER NOTES MORE PROGRESS
description: TEL AVIV, Friday, May 24Secretary of State Kissinger, after another day of negotiations in Syria and Israel, said early this morning that he had made good progress toward removing a principal obstacle to the conclusion of a SyrianIsraeli troop  disengagement agreement.

title: On Those CarRental Deals: Slow Down, Curves Ahead
description: While gasoline supplies may or may not be a problem for vacationing motorists this spring and summer, trying to figure the cost of renting a car definitely is, what with a maze of packages, deals, specials and freemileage offers.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 4.2 From WeekAgo Level
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Needham Is Reelected
description: James J. Needham was unanimously reelected yesterday to a third oneyear term as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. The exchange also named Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Co., to a third oneyear term as vice chairman.

title: Music: Promenade Time
description: Spring and the New York philharmonic's Promenades have become inseparable phenomena in New York, and on Wednesday night the 12th season, of the informal concerts led by Andre Kostelanetz got under way at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Whitney Board Elects
description: Howard W. Lipman has been elected president of the board of trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art, succeeding David M. Solinger, who has been named chairman of the board. Mr. Lipman is a partner in the investment firm of Neuberger & Berman. Mrs. Flora Whitney Miller, daughter of the museum's founder, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, and formerly chairman of the board, becomes honorary chairman.

title: $2.5Million for Tocks Darn
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The House Public Works Appropriations subcommittee has approved $2.5million to begin construction of the Tocks Island Dam on the Delaware River in Pennsylvania, sources close to the committee reported today. The subcommittee re., fused to make public its actions until a final vote was taken by the full committee.

title: 2 PaddlingCase Deans Back at School
description: Two Bronx juniorhighschool deans who have been accused of beating students with a thick wooden paddle, leather belts and their fists to punish their for misbehaving, have been re. stored, without explanation, tc their posts at the school by the Idistrict superintendent.

description: FICTION
