description: WASHINGTON, May 24 President Nixon will name Kenneth Rush, the Deputy Secretary of State, as his chief economic coordinator tomorrow in an effort to deal with deepening inflation problems and squabbling between other economic aides, high Administration officials said today.

title: Oregon Papers to Gannett
description: ROCHESTER, May 24 (UPI) GannettNewspaper, Inc. has purchased The StatesmanJournal Company of Salem, Ore., which publishes the city's afternoon, morning and Sunday newspapers. With the acquisition, which cost about $15.3million, Gannett now owns 54 lnewspapers.

title: Sadat Pushes Plans to Transform Egypt
description: CAIRO, May 24 Although he': has been hampered by the delay in achieving a separation, of.. Israeli and Syrian troops, President Anwar elSadat is pushing ahead with his program for the political and economic transformation of Egypt.

title: Equal Prostitution Guilt
description: BATON ROUGE, May 24 (AP)  The Louisiana Senate has decided that a man is just as guilty as a woman if he pays for her sexual favors. By a 325 vote, the Senate approved a bill to make the state prostitution law apply to both the buyer and the seller. The measure how goes to the House for action.

title: Pittsburgh Southpaw Yields Only Hahn Homer
SOVIET REPORTED RESUMING SUPPLY OF ARMS TO EGYPT
description: CAIRO, May 24The Soviet Union has resumed limited shipments of arms and spare parts to Egypt as part of an effort by both countries to improve their recently strained relations, informed foreign diplomats sakl today. The shipments are understood to be the first in about six.months.

title: Belmont Race Charts
Lisbon Pledges to Respect African SelfDetermination
description: LISBON, May 24, Foreign Minister Mario Soares, leaving for London to start ceasefire talks tomorrow, with the rebel movement of Portuguese Guinea, told the nation today that Portugal will respect selfdetermination With all its consequences in its African possessions.

title: CYPRIOTES TO RENEW NEGOTIATIONS JUNE 4
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24  The Greek and Turkish communities on Cyprus are scheduled to resume talks on June 4 to negotiate their longstanding differences, Secretary General Waldheim reported today.

title: The Trauma of Watergate Cited by Ford
description: LANSING, Mich., May 24Vice President Ford said today that the nation is going through some very, traumatic experiences, citing Watergate and economic problems in particular.

title: A New Middle East
description: Measured against the scarred history of nearly three decades, or even against the ossified situation of just one year ago, the achievements and the attitudes Israel and neighboring Arab governments in these recent days are close to the miraculous.

title: Rodino Said to Ask Release Of Evidence on Watergate
Police Tell Shea Trial of Futile Gun Hunt
description: An array of police officers narrated yesterday how they had walked elbow to elbow with rakes and shovels sifting Queens lots, in a futile search for a gun alleged to have been aimed by a 10yearold boy at a police officer before the offi cer killed him.

title: HIGH COURT GETS JAWORSKI APPEAL ON NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, appealed to the United States Supreme Court today for access to 64 recorded White House conversations.

title: Strike Injures Indian Economy
description: NEW DELHI, May 22The twoweek old railroad strike ha caused considerable damage to the Indian economy, although it has failed to halt freight and passenger traffic.

title: Device Spurs Computer to Do Several Jobs at Once
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The International Business Machines Corporation patented this week an invention that is historic in the industrya method of getting an electronic cornputer to do several jobs at once. Three staff members at company's development laboratory in Poughkeepsie were granted Patent 3,812,475 for what is called a date synchronizer. The inventors are Carl L. Christiansen, Lawrence E. Kanter and George R. Monroe.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, May 24Gov. Brendan Byrne broke a national precedent when he named Thomas J. Swales Jr. of Edison to the State Racing Commission, succeeding the late chairman, Hugh Mehorter.

title: SOVIET DRILLING LARGE GAS WELL
description: Working under the Arctic conditions of a snowswept Siberian tundra, Soviet crews have begun drilling the first producing well in a large natural gas field that has been suggested as a potential source of fuel for the eastern United States.

title: Opera: Static Idomeneo
PRICES OF GRAINS SHOW ADVANCES
description: A Grain and soybean futures prices moved higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but silver, silver coins and platinum futures were down as traders prepared to observe the long holiday weekend.

title: Sanya Returns as Premier of Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 24 Premier Sanya Dharmasakti, who resigned with his Cabinet three days ago, today accepted a parliamentary appeal to return to office, thus ending the first major leadership crisis of Thailand's young civilian order.

title: House Panel Reports U.S. Spent 5.9Million on Johnson in Texas
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The House Government Operations committee said yesterday that Federal expenditures on former President Lyndon B. Johnson's property had totaled $5.9million.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
29 States Pledge Aid to U.S. in Oil Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 24In an unusual show of stateFederal cooperation, 29 states pledged support to the Federal Trade Commission today in its antitrust case against the eight largest oil companies.

title: Text of Jaworski Appeal on Watergate Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Following is the text of the appeal by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, to the Supreme Court asking for access to 64 tape recorded White House conversations:

title: RCA UNIT WILL RAISE SOME PRICES BY 5%
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that its RCA Electronic Components division would raise prices by an average of 5 per cent on the industrial tubes and products it sells to originalequipment makers in the industrial, comunications, aerospace and military markets.

title: Colleagues and Admirers Pay Tribute
description: The following are some of the tributes to Duke Ellington expressed yesterday:

title: Assemblyman Berle Drops Race for District Attorney
description: Assemblyman Peter A. A. Berle, DemocratLiberal of Manhattan, yesterday announced that he would not pursue further his quest for the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of Manhattan, following the endorsement by the New Democratic Coalition of Robert M. Morgenthau, former United States attorney.

title: The Dance: Sanasardo's Platform
description: The Paul Sanasardo Dance Company opened the second of its twoday engagements at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night with a good house and several distinguished dance figures in attendance.

title: U.S. Scholars and Artists Are Flourishing in Rome
Antiques: Russian Art
description: The six sales of Russian art that began in Diisseldorf, West Germany, in midApril and ended here at Sotheby Parke Bernet last Saturday, replenished this esoteric market with a bonanza of icons, enamel work, niello wares, porcelains, sterling silver, glass and some Carl Faberge prizes.

title: Kheel Gives Details On Innovative Pact Of Papers and Union
description: The newspaperindustry contract agreement reached Thursday will give the publishers of The New York Times and The Daily News the unrestricted right to use automated processes in exchange for lifetime guarantees of employment to regular and substitute printers and sixmonth paid sabbaticals as incentives to retirement.

title: Art: WaterColor Mastery
description: That some of the most IIlustrious of American painters have produced some of their most distinctive work in the watercolor medium is not exactly a secret, yet it is still rare to encounter a major exhibition devoted to such work. Watercolor is somehow regarded as a minor art. Custom thus decrees that it be consigned to supplement or emhellish displays of oil painting, which is held to be of major importance. Never mind that the visual evidence often contradicts this facile hierarchy.

title: Women in Highway Patrol
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 24 (UPI)The California Highway Patrol began taking applications today from women, the first step in breaking its 45year history of maleonly traffic officers. Forty women cadets will begin training next September at the patrol academy here.

title: MARY C. YEOMANS
description: Mary C. Yeomans, a former elementary school teacher here, died Thursday in a Long Island nursing home at the age of 98. She lived in Greenvale, L.I.

title: Mexican: Border Watched in Hearst Hunt
description: SAN DIEGO, May 24Tight surveillance is being maintained along both sides of the Mexican border against the possibility that Patricia Hearst and two fugitive companions of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army may try* to reach a hideout in the mountains of Baja California.

title: JESUIT CALLS RIFT A FAMILY DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 The Rev. John J. McLaughlin, the Jesuit whose role as 4,White House aide and defender of President Nixon aroused critical comment from his superior in the order, said today that the dispute ought to be handled within the privacy of the Jesuit family like any other family dispute.

title: HIGH COURT GETS JAWORSKI APPEAL ON NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, appealed to the United States Supreme Court today for access to 64 recorded White House conver, sations.

title: Slain Undercover Aide Mourned
description: The faceless onesthe men and women of the police forces who have gone underground to fight organized crime from the insidesurfaced yesterday to join thousands of their comrades in uniform and in civilian clothes in a tribute to State Trooper Leslie Grosso.

title: A Memo to Congress on Democratic Procedures
description: Congress while asserting its impeachment power must also guarantee to the citizenry a functioning Government within the framework of a constitutional democracy. What follows, in an open memorandum to Congress, is a series of steps designed to achieve this end.

title: CHILE IS RETURNING 21 SEIZED CONCERNS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 24 (AP)  Chile's military Government announced today that 21 metal factories seized by the former Allende Administration had been returned to their previous owners.

title: Bronx Project Is Lifting Face of River's Banks
description: An alien growth is poking out of the banks of the Bronx River near West Farms Square. It is grass.

title: North America Takes Lead Bnuge: In World Team Tournament
Liddy Sentenced Again Alter 2 False Starts,.
description: WASHINGTON, May (AP)G. Gordon Liddy was sentenced today for a third, time for refusing to testify or be sworn before a House sub committee. The reason was that the judge had been wrong the first time and wrong again the second

title: UNICEF Says Food Crisis Faces Young in Poor Lands
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23The 30member board of the United Nations Children's Fund declared today that a state of emergency existed for children living in the poor countries that faced an increasing threat of malnutrition and even famine.

title: MARKET RALLIES; DOW CLIMBS 11.42
Garr's 2 Homers, Capra's Pitching Win for Braves
description: Mention of Grambling College in Louisiana brings an immediate thought of the National Football League because of the number of the school's graduates who perform on the league's fields.

title: Politics Before Children
description: Citing Washington's deep disappointment in the olleged failure of Vietnamese Communists to show genuine commitment to peace, the United States Government has insisted that the United Nations Children's Fund not use American money to help finance new programs for child aid in North Vietnam and Communistheld areas Of the South. It is the American people who should be disappointed that their Government could stoop to put politics ahead of the welfare of children anywhere.

title: Added Franklin Loss
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, said in an interview yesterday that the Franklin National Bank had lost $5million in securities transactions above and beyond the foreignexchange losses previously disclosed. Details on Page 41.

title: A Man's Life
description: On a sunny afternoon on West 32d Street, a man pulled harshly at a dog on a leash and another man observed, audibly that that was no way to treat an animal. The man with the dog also had a temper and a razor. There Were two quick slashes and.the man with the razor and the dog quickly disappeared. The observer fell to the sidewalk mortally wounded. By speedy police action, his alleged assailant has since been arrested.

title: Wade Plays Heldman in Net Final
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 24 (UPI)Virginia Wade of England moved into the final of the British hardcourt tennis championships today with a 62, 26, 62 victory over Jackie Fayter. She will play Julie Heldman of Houston in the final.

title: Shore Looks for a Big Holiday Weekend
description: WILDWOOD, May 24With bookings indicating a banner Memorial Day weekend for Jersey shore resorts, spokesmen for the multimilliondollar New Jersey resort industry call this a harbinger, barring spate of bad weather, of a big summer season.

title: The Show Is in Olde Mistick, but the Quilts Aren't Olde at All
description: MYSTIC, Conn.It wasn't a quilting bee, but a bee about quilting, that sparked the convivial gathering this week in the shade of Sharon McKain's pillared porch outside The Great Noank Factory, just southwest of here.

title: ExTimes Aide Gets Post
description: ALBANY, May 24 (UFOAndrew Fisher, a management consultant and former executive vice president of The New York Times, has been elected president of Albany Medical College, it was announced today. The college is part of Union University.

title: State Is Planning to heal Overturning of 2 Sentences
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday that it would appeal a recent ruling by a ,State Supreme Court justice that set aside the sevenyear prison terms of two men convicted in the theft of $3million in cash and jewelry from the Pierre Hotel 28 months ago.

title: City Hall in Newark Visited by a Streaker
description: NEWARK, May 24, (UPI) Mrs. Esther Estrella was fined $50 yesterday for streaking through Newark City Hall. Authorities told the court that Mrs. Estrella, 41 years old, of Newark, works in a burlesque house and began her nude romp outside of her apartment house last May I. She streaked up busy Broad Street, they said, stopping automobiles on her jaunt toward City Hall.

title: Rea Wins 4th Year In Jump
Holiday Closings
description: Securities and commodity exchanges, banks and United States Government offices will be closed Monday, May 27, for the Memorial Day holiday.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the three decades before the Civil War, the United States experienced prodigious growth at a breakneck.speed. Its territory doubled; its population more than doubled; industrial end agricultural production soared;. science and technology, responding to a need, blossomed, and evidences of a rising standard of living were everywhere abundant among the dominant whites. This eruption ofthe nation's productive forces profoundly shaped its culture and society, giving them an expressly American identity.

title: G.O.P. in State Urged, to Stress AccountabilitY
description: State Senator John 12, Dunne urged the paltform committee of the Republican State Cornmittee yesterday to develop a theme of openness and accountability in the party platform this year.

title: An 80Seat Restaurant Is Just a Front In the Kitchen, Mon Dieu!
description: Would you care to order a small party for 25,000 guests and serve dishes in aspic and truff led pts? Can la grande cuisine be mass produced?

title: TRANSIT OFFICIAL QUITS COAST POST
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 24B. R. Stokes resigned today as general manager of the troubled Bay Area Rapid Transit system and accepted an apptjintment as executive head of the new American Public Tcansit Association, both effective June 30.

title: VANCOUVER GETS CHINESE MONEY
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaChinese capitalists in Hong Kong and Southeast Asia, looking beyond the uncertain political and economic climate of their surroundings, are investing heavily in this growing Canadian West Coast city.

title: Condemnation Price on Part Of Green Acres Plan Upheld
description: TRENTON, May 24 (UPI) The Appelate Division of the Superior Court, the secondhighest court, upheld today the condemnation price of $508,500 for 339 acres of land in Upper Freehold Township to be used as fishing lake as part of the Green Acres project.

title: Sadat Says Qadaffi Virtually Sabotaged Egypt's War Effort
description: CAIRO, May 24  The controyersy between Egypt and Libya took anew turn today with publication here this marning of a hitherto secret letter in which President Anwar alSadat charged that Col. Muammar elQaddafi's attitude during the October war amounted almost to sabotage.

title: Byrne Seeks Constitutional Limit on Local Taxes
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 24Governor Byrne said today he would sponsor a constitutional amendment to limit the amount of new local taxes that could be imposed if his proposal for a state income tax and other tax reforms was approved.

title: Notes on People
description: Valery Panov, the former star of the Kirov ballet whose emigration from the Soviet Union to Israel has been blocked by the refusal of Soviet authorities to grant an exit visa to his wife Galina, was formally notified yesterday that he had been stripped of his title as an honored artist of the Soviet Union. Although the move does not alter Mr. Panov's situation, it was regarded as another form of harassment of the ostracized dancer. In a telephone call from Leningrad to Moscow, Mr. Panov said that his ballerina wife, who is expected to deliver their first child in a few months, has no strength left: she keeps telling me I ought to go to Israel alone, but I cannot leave her, least of all now. .. Meanwhile, in Moscow, Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist, said he would leave the Soviet Union tomorrow for a twoyear stay in London. Long under cultural quarantine for his support of dissidents, he has been granted permission to1ive and work abroad.

title: OFFICIALS ACCUSED IN NEGLIGENCE SUIT
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) A class action suit was filed in Federal court here on behalf of an estimated 1,000 stockholders of the now defunct United States National Bank who said they suffered damages of $100million'because of Government officials.

title: Indy Scene Is Genuine American
description: The sign outside the door of the Speedway Cafeteria, which clings like some kind or outmoded garage to the business end of Gasoline Alley, the day before the big race reads DRIVERS AND CREW ONLY, which is about as exciting as a sign can get, especially to a nondriver or noncrew member.

title: WILSON SIGNS BILL TO TAX OTB POOL
description: ALBANY, May 24A measure calling for the imposition of a 5 per cent surcharge on the winners pool at all offtrack betting parlors in the state has been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office announced today.

title: Bombings Under Inquiry
description: YUA CITY, Calif.; May 24 (UPI)Four bombing attacks here against public agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were under investigation today. The other targets include the police station, the Department of Motor Vehicles and a county sheriff's car.

title: Ohio State Instructor Named To Federal Aviation Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  Federal Aviation Administrator Alexander P. Butterfield confirmed today that he had asked a teacher at Ohio State, lUniversity to become the new assistant administrator for general aviation for the F.A.A.

title: WINE TALK
description: If French wine names are confusing, Italian wine names are doubly so. For one thing, people tend to make an effort to learn the Fench titles. After all, it is entirely possible to know a great deal about wine and absolutely nothing about Italian wine, but it is impossible to avoid the French.

title: Bearne Offers Legislature New Plan for Rent Control
description: Mayor Beame proposed last night that the special session of the Legislature next week replace the current rentcontrol system here with a rent guidelines formula that is said provide benefits for landlords and fewer and smaller rent rises than tenants must pay now in rentcontrolled apartments.

title: State Awards $46.3Million In Housing Loans to 6 Cities
description: TRENTON, May 24 (AP)The State Community Affairs Department announced today the award of $46.3milliort in loans to finance multifamily housing in six cities.

title: CostofLiving Rises Urged On Supplemental Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  The Nixon Administration asked Congress today to provide automatic costofliving increases for the 3.3 million aged, blind and disabled persons receiving Federal Supplemental Security Income benefits.

title: Volcker Asserts I.M.F. Should Be Strengthened
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 24 1Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs since the Nixon Administration took office five and a half years ago, said in his validictory address heard at Pepperdine University today that the International Monetary Fund, severely shaken when the Administration suspended the convertibility of the dollar in 11971 should be significantly strengthened.

title: Giscard's Presidency Proclaimed by Council
description: PARIS, May 24 (AP)Valery Giscard d'Estaing was formally proclaimed President of France today by France's Constitutional Councir.

title: Big Oil's EnergyCrisis Blitz
description: WASHINGTONThe oil industry is spending millions of dollars trying to convince the American public that is the Caesar's wife of the energy crisis. The culprits, they would have everyone believe, are Government, environmentalists and the people themselves.

title: KENNETH RUSH SET FOR ECONOMIC JOB
description: WASHINGTON, May 24President Nixon will name Kenneth Rush the Secretary Of State, chief economic coordinator tomorrow in an effort to deal with deepening inflation problems and squabblingbetween other economic aides high Administration officials said today.

title: Battle for CNA Financial Develops in Loews Suit
description: A battle for control of the $4.6billion CNA Financial Corpdeveloped decisively yesterday with the disclosure that the Loews Corporation had filed a $120million damage suit against two CNA officers an charges :.. that they were attempting to defeat a tender offer that Loews planning to make for 20 million CNA shares.

title: Al Predicts a Sales Upturn in 1974
description: DETROIT, May 24The General Motors Corporation, whose profits fell 85 per cent in the first quarter, told stockholders at the annual meeting today tlgt sales were turning up and tat the company's five car divisions would, bring out new span cars by next fall.

title: Voldwater Calls Defense Of Nixon a Hard Task
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 24 (AP)Senator Barry Goldwater said today that it was becoming increasingly difficult to defend President NixIn in the Watergate scandal. But the Arizona Republiran said at a news conference at his home that he ould see no circumstances now under which he would no to the President and ask tor his resignation.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System announced yesterday at Richland, Wash., that its directors had authorized the purchase for $129.million of three turbinegenerators from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Delivery was requested for 1977. The generators, each with about 1.3millionkilowatts of capacity, will be used at each of three nuclear power plants the power system plans to have operating between 1980 and 1983.

title: ALVIN D. STONE JR.
description: Alvin D. Stone Jr., cable editor in the New York bureau of Stars and Stripes, died yesterday of cancer. He was 62 years old.

title: Decathlon Margin 3 Points
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark., May 24 (AP)  Runes Herron of Cameron (Okla) State College collected 6,039 points to capture the decathlon today at the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics track and field meet. Herron edged Steve Alexander of Southern California College, who had 6,936 points.

title: Eban Turns Down Role In New Cabinet in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, May 24Abba Eban, who has been Foreign Minister of Israel for nine years, announced today that he would not take a post in the forthcoming Government of Premierdesignate Yitzhak Rabin,

title: Screen: A Vapid Huckleberry Finn
Backers of Homosexual Rights Plan to Resubmit Defeated Bill
description: The homosexualrights bill de feated in the City Council on Thursday by 22 to 19, will be resubmitted next week, but its cosponsors will not press for action until after the November election.

title: Algeria Said to Favor End Of Oil Ban on Two Nations
description: ALGIERS May 24 (AP) Foreign Minister Abdel Aziz Bouteflika has declared that Algeria is in favor of lifting the eightmonthold oil embargo against the Netherlands and Denmark.

title: F.B.I.,Before Raid ,Gave Police Plan of Chicago Panther's Flat
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation gave a detailed floor plan of Fred Hampton's apartment, marked to indicate where he slept, to the Cook County State's Attorney's office shortly before the police carried out the predawn raid in which the Chicago Black Panther leader was slain.

title: India's Nuclear Threat.
description: The nations which have supplied India with the nuclear reactors, fissionable material and technology that have enabled New Delhi to explode an atomic device have an obligation before mankind now to act together to contain this new threat of nuclear proliferation. It is essential not to be diverted by political diplomatic considerations, nor by protettations from India that its explosions are intended for peaceful uses and are not in violation of the 1970 nonproliferation treaty, which New Delhi has never signed.

title: 8 Psychiatrists Are Seeking New Vote on Homosexuality as Mental Illness
description: Eight psychiatrists are calling for a new referendum by the American Psychiatric Association on homosexuality to invalidate an earlier vote they Icontend was improperly influenced by a letter signed by top association leaders but conceived and paid for by the National Task Force.

title: Francesca Quintano Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Quintano of New York and Sterling Forest, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francesca Alice Quintano, to Ronald Mattson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Mattson of Rocky Point, L. I.

title: Seattle Fans Welcome Sounders in a Big Way
Kathleen Worobec to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Russell N. Worobec of Williamsport, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Ann Worobec, to Stephen Francis Story, son of Mrs. George W. Cross of Covington, La., and the late Dr, Stacy Hammond Story Jr. of Valdosta, Ga. The wedding is planned for Aug. 17.

title: The defending of the President
Deciding On Utilities: Public or Private?;
description: On May 16 the New York State Legislature voted, with unusual haste, to buy two partially completed power plants from the Consolidated Edison Company for $500million. The move rescued the utility the largest privately held firm in the nation's biggest industryfrom its immediate financial troubles. But Charles F. Luce, Con Edison's board chairman, hinted that his firm may yet have to sell its entire system to New York State. This prospect may soon confront other private electric systems, also squeezed by escalating fuel and capital costs. Which raises again the issue of the centurylong ElectricWar: the competing merits of the two dominant forms of electric power, investorowned utilities and publicly controlled utilities.

title: Puente Cycling Victor
description: CARPEGNA, Italy, May 25 (AP)Jose Manuel Fuente of Spain won the ninth leg of the Tour of Italy bicycle race today. He finished more than a minute ahead of Eddy Merckx of Belgium.

title: Daughter to the Gabays
description: A daughter was born May 11 to Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Gabay of New York and Cheshire, Mass., at Mount Sinai Hospital here. The child has been named Sari Vivienne. Mrs. Gabay is the former Miss Vicky Geula. The child's father, a lawyer and insurance broker, is chairman of the Council of Insurance Brokers of New York, Inc.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: **Sancho Panza 52 Garden Street, Passaic. (201) 4739654.

title: More Minority.Candidates Pass Test for Police Here
description: The proportion of black and Hispanic candidates who passed the recent Civil Service examination for police officer appointment increased substantially over previous tests, the City Personnel Director, Harry I. Bronstein, said yesterday.

title: Some Items Were Exquisite, Some Weren't
description: Claire Hall gave an openhouse the other day. Oh, nothing fancy  no invitations, no food, no drinks. But about 20 people showed upmost of them strangers carrying bags and boxes filled with feather boas, silver cigarette cases, handpainted straw hats and sequinstudded Tshirts.

title: Editors Choice
description: General

title: Pioneer Mental Program Is Given a Reprieve
description: PRINCETON  Thanks to the efforts of a local state legislator and hundreds of letters to Governor Byrne and other New Jersey officials, an unusual program aimed at helping former drug addicts, alcoholics and mental patients adjust to everyday life will not be phased out on June 30, as previously planned.

title: Chess: You Can't Put That There. That Move's Not in the Book!
Duke Ellington's Friends, Great And Small, Pay Their Respects
description: Oh, yes, said Alfred (Slick) Chester, saying a last goodby yesterday to Duke Ellington, yesterday is going to miss him.

title: CIVIC UNIT SCORES BEANIE ON BUDGET
description: Mayor Beame, who on Wednesday will be presented with the Citizens Budget Commission's Gold Medal for High Civic Service, has been roundly criticized by the nonpartisan civic group for the extensive borrowing and oneshot gimmicks be used to balance his $11.1billion operating budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: L.I.R.R. Adds Trains to East End Run
description: The Long Island Rail Road has added two evening trains to carry weekend passengers to the East End of the Island through the summer.

title: Sally Symmes Swanson Bride Of. John J. Carter in Noroton
description: Miss Sally Symmes Swanson and John Jeffery Carter were married yesterday afternoon in the Noroton (Conn.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Lawrence MacColl Horton.

title: New Hearing Is Set On Douglaston
description: The city's Board of Standards and Appeals will hold a third hearing Thursday on the proposed Douglaston shopping mall. The hearing is set for 10 A.M. at the board's offices, 80 Lafayette Street in Manhattan.

title: Red Smith
description: If anyone should ask, three men who played baseball with the New York Giants and football with the New York Giants were Jim Thorpe of the Carlisle Indians, Steve Filipowicz of Fordham and Red Smith of Notre Dame, also known as The Imposter. The best pitcher who ever lived, when his performance is compared with that of his team, was Grover Cleveland AlexSports ander. Joe Grim had of more than 300 fights a and was knocked out The Times only three times, but Theagenes of Thaos, the Olympic champion of 450 B.C., fought 1,406 bouts with the cestus (a leather doughnut loaded with iron) instead of gloves. Most of his opponents killed.

title: The Divided Leaders of Palestinian Resistance
description: BEIRUTThe Palestinian resistance, an unstable collection of large and small guerrilla organizations, is trying to form a united liberation front to lay claim to control of any independent Palestinian state formed as part of a Middle East peace settlement.

description: PEKING, May 25 (Reuters) Edward Heath, leader of Britain's Conservative party, met with Mao Tsetung today for nearly 90 minutes.

title: Stamps U.S. Marks Settling of Kentucky
description: THE westward movement of Americans came to its first halt at,the barrier of the Appalachian Mountains. Finally the barrier was pierced, and settlers moved into a land of plenty, with its back to the great Appalachian wall and its face to the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers. This was Kentucky, the first state to be organized west of the Appalachians.

title: U.S., Having Paid 32 Years Back Rent to Japan, Starts Work on Building a New Embassy in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, May 25The United States GoVernment, which had been 32 years behind in rent for the embassy here, paid up in full this monthshortly before a demolition crew started knocking the place down.

description: American Place Changing Policy

description: HOBOKEN Track gangs, working at night in the cramped darkness of a castiron tunnel deep under the Hudson River, are renewing the roadbed of a vital transit line that carries 130,000 passengers daily.

description: DETROIT, May 25Henry Ford 2d, characterizing the Watergate affair and its aftermath as awful and terrible, has urged President Nixon to turn over to the House Judiciary Committee all tapes and other evidence that it asks for in its impeachment inquiry.

title: SHOP TALK Rugs, Prints, Frames, Etc.
description: PLAINVIELDSwain's Art Store is venerable and imposing enough not to be overlooked. It is possibly the oldest (nee 1868) and the biggest (five floors of galleries and workrooms) establishment of its kind in New Jersey.

description: A son was born April 28 to Rabbi and Mrs. Ivan George Marcus of New Rochelle, N.Y., at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital in the Bronx.

description: These first few years of the decade of the 1970's point to vast changes in the complexion and outlook of an entire generation of young people....

title: TRASHPLAN SEW FOR WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 25Westchester officials completed plans this week to promote new and unusual garbagedisposal plan to the county's municipal leaders rather than try to sell it to the public.

description: Last March 16, the National Football League Players Association submitted to the N.F.L, Management Council, the bargaining agent of the 26 clubs, 57 written contract demands, and last week the union submitted 33 more. That is a total of 90 separate demands for alterations in the N.F.L.'s operation.

title: Valdez Knocks Out Briscoe, Wins Title
description: MONACO, May 25 Rodrigo Valdez, who used to fish the Caribbean with dynamite, landed one version of the world middleweight championship tonight with a left hook.

description: LOS ANGELESThis is the time of year when a 20yearold college girl is taking final exams and making plans fill the days ahead with sunshine, some travel and perhaps dash of adventure.

description: The Eastern sprints are over and the Western sprints are over, and the crews that have Made the biggest collegiate splash this season are now well established.

title: Food Prices Spur Gardening in Nassau and Suffolk
description: Spiraling food prices and a yen to return to the land are nurturing a bumper crop of vegetable gardeners across Long Island.

title: Retriever Is Best at Monmouth
The gentle giant in the garage
description: When Tom Gatch went down with his balloon last February, trying to be the first balloonist across the Atlantic, my wife had , no comment. But knew she was thinking about that balloon I have in the garage, and wondering whether I would be next.

title: GUNFIGHT SURVIVOR SEIZED IN SHOOTING
description: A 29year old Queens painting contractor, wounded last year by gunmen who killed both his parents, was arrested yesterday after a gun battle in front of his home during which he himself was shot.

title: Steelworkers to Get Raises
description: PITTSBURGH, May 25 (UPI) The United Steelworkers of America has announced that 30,000 workers employed by three major aluminum companies will receive pay increases of 13 cents an hour effective June I under the cost of living clause in their wage contracts. The concerns are the Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

title: State's Air Force Keeps Eye on Roads
description: WEST TRENTON  New Jersey's Air Force, officially known as the State Police Helicopter Patrol Unit, will be in the skies today, just as it is throughout the year.

title: Brewers Beat Red Sox, 92, Regain Lead
description: BOSTON, May 25 (AP)Johnny Briggs drove in four runs today with his 10th and 11th homers of the season and the Milwaukee Brewers defeated Boston, 92, snapping the Red Sox sixgame winning streak and regaining fir.st place in the American League's East Division.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayAssociation of Abedcan Motorcycle Road Racers races at Bridgehampton (LL) Race Circuit, 1 P.M.

title: $50,870 Trifecta At Delaware Park
description: STANTON, Del., May 25The winning trifecta combination in Delaware Park's seventh race paid $50,870.70 to an unidentified bettor today.

title: Freedoms Beat Sets To Win 11th
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UIP)  The unbeaten Philadelphia Freedoms won every set tonight and defeated the New York Sets, 3016, to record their 11th victory in World Team Tennis.

title: Suffolk Gets Grant For Ambulance Plan
description: HAUPPAUGE  Suffolk County received a $346,711 grant last week for a program to insure speedy ambulance service in medical emergencies.

title: Fresh and candid, unlike an emperor
description: The worst thing about translations . from the Chinese, I used to think, is the language into which they are translated: something dreadful seems to happen to foreign scholars when they set to work turning Chinese into English. Because they can't possibly write so badly all the time, I figured, it must be something about Chinese literature that awes them and casts a shadow over the result. Look at this line, fOr instance, perpetrated by an eminent English mis sionary when translating a wellknown classic poem:

description: To the Editor:

title: Waldrop Finishes 4th in 3:57.7 Mile
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 25 (AP)  Paul Cummings of Brigham Young University upset previously unbeaten Tony Waldrop of North Carolina in the featured mile and Ivory Crockett successfully defended his title as world's fastest human tonight in the 33d California Relays.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A price of $32million has been paid for the white elephant near the Battery that has remained virtually tacant since its completion almost three years ago.

description: WAYNE  A number of junior high school jazz bands will perform in a fivehour program to be held at SchuylerColfax Junior High School Friday.

title: Something sensitive, something camp
description: Some of the photographs here may be just what squeamish readers have been secretly waiting to be ambushed by. But what does it all mean, this book with a title from Job and a pop painting of a crocodile nipping cyclop breast? Those who buy Eyelids of Morning" or find it on coffee tableare likely to read Alistair Graham's account of The Mingled Destinies of Crocodiles and Men because of Peter Beard's pictures. But the photographer needs the biologist, maybe more than either of them knows.

title: Pop Music
description: Two members of the folksinging Taylor family are playing in New York this Memorial Day weekend. James, the most famous of the family, appears at Carnegie Hall tonight and tomorrow night. And Friday through tonight, his younger brother, Livingston, has been at the Bottom Line.

title: Hold It! Where's That Great Scene With...
By RONALD SULLIVAN Special to The New York Times
description: TRENTONDemocratic leaders have begun testing support in the Legislature for Governor Byrne's taxreform program, and they are coming up short.

title: VOTE IS SET TODAY FOR LUXEMBOURG
description: LUXEMBOURG, May 25 The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, a small island of stability in Western Europe, has ended an election campaign in which the voters have paid more attention to the changes in neighboring France and West Germany than to local issues.

title: Judge Was Born Into Show Business
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FRANKLIN NATIONAL BANK deposits fell $325million, or 11 per cent, to 52.67billion in the two weeks since the bank announced large losses in foreignexchange trading. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated had lent more than 51billion to Franklin to bolster its financial position. And the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in shares of the Franklin New York Corporation, the bank's parent company, for more days.

title: N.F.L. Kept in Quandary Over Next Move of Finks
description: James Edward Finks announced he had resigned as general manager of the Minnesota Vikings last Sunday night, played golf on Monday and stopped answering his telephone. It was coming off the wall all week hecause his resignation had piqued the pro football establishment which wants to know the next move of the Man regarded by many as the most talented executive in the National Football League.

title: Out of the Old World, into the New;
description: Aside from planting a foot next to Neil Armstrong's on the moon, I'd like most to have knelt beside Howard Carter that day in November, 1922, as the English archeologist peered into Tutankhamen's tomb in Egypt's Valley of the Kings. Can you see anything? asked Carter's benefactor, Lord Carnarvon. Yes, gasped Carter. Wonderful things.

title: No, To Everyone
description: President Nixon, who prides himself on being a fighter, took on almost everyone last weekCongress, the courts and the special prosecutor. In the process of defending the secrecy of White House tapes that have been subpoenaed for the impeachment proceeding and court trials, Mr. Nixon precipitated some of the most bitter and potentially damaging opposition he has encountered in the long controversy over his conduct in office. There were these developments:

title: A Nixon Visit to Mideast Likely Before the Planned Soviet Trip
description: MIAMI, May 25  White House officials said today that President Nixon was likely to visit the Middle East soon, possibly on his way to Moscow next month for a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: In Philadelphia, Sisterly Love
description: PHILADELPHIA P HILLY, the city that W.C. Fields loved to hate (thus proving it can't be all bad), is doing its bit for women artists. Thanks to an effort called Focus, celebrating the achievements of women in the visual arts, the city's major art institutions and schools, galleries, universities and cultural centers are mounting, from April through June, no less than 150. exhibitions, panels, lectures, films, workshops and demonstrations devoted to women's art. We're redubbing Philadelphia The City ofSisterly Love, proclaimed one euphoric exhibitor.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday called upon Governor Wilson to sign a bill that would repeal the covenants that restrict the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from giving financial aid mass transit facilities.

description: The smoothness of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater is something to behold. Yesterday afternoon at the City Center 55th Street Theater it gave the first performance this season of Joyce Trisler's Dance for Six and a partly new cast in John Butler's Carmina Burana.

title: Technically, Many Nations Have the Capabilities
description: All it takes to make a recognizable nuclear weapon, the American soldierscientist said, is about $30million, probably more in these inflationary times, a fairly advanced industrial base, a moderately high technological level and tight security.

description: LONDON, May 25Peter Sydney Ball, alias Ian Ball, the man who tried to kidnap Princess Anne, thought he was. mentally ill. He first sought psychiatric treatment at a hospital in 1967 and again in 1969; although he missed appointments and appeared irregularly for consultations.

title: Music: Promenade Mix
description: The New York Philharmonic's A Night for Dancing Promenade seems to have had more than its share of misfortunes. John Clifford of the New York City Ballet was engaged to choreograph and perform with Gelsey Kirkland a dance work to go with a medley of Richard Rodgers songs. Mr. Clifford did the choreography, then injured his back and could not dance.

description: Miss Mary Louise Moore, daughter. of Dr. and Mrs. William Moore of Titusville, N. title: Silence of the Leaders: The Other Cover Up

They are obviously not without opinions on the moral squalor of the Nixon Administration, for they state them eloquently and even vehemently in private, but most of them say nothing in public.

title: Regrouping Urged In Taped Message To S.L.A. Fugitives
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 25 (AP)A taperecorded message by a man and a woman who identified themselves as affiliates of the terrorist group that calls itself the Symbionese Liberation Army said today that Patricia Hearst and two other fugitives should regroup.

title: Raspy statesmanship against earnest politics
Compassion Takes Part In L.I. Sports Car Rally
description: For its next rally, on June 9, the Long Island Sports Car Association will add a fourth element, that of compassion, to the usual time, speed and distance event. The proceeds will go to the Nassau County Cerebral Palsy Center for Living. This will be the 22d year that LISCA has devoted its energies toward the charity, operating under the slogan of Drive so that others may walk. The rallies, which in recent years have been under the guidance of Mrs. Gerry Munroe of Jackson Heights, Queens, have averaged about 70 cars a year with. returns of about $400 from each going to the cerebral palsy organization.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrIdgehamptonCollages by Alvin Loving, sculpture by Phyllis Mark and Alex MacFarlane, artifacts from Thailand, and paintings from Korea, noon to 6 P.M., daily except Wednesdays, Benson Gallery, Montauk Highway.

title: Camera World News: A Contest, More Summer Programs and Courses
description: PHOTOGRAPHERS who love animals and enjoy photographing them are invited to enter the ninth annual photography contest sponsored by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Each entry should demonstrate the theme of the contest, A Lifetime Commitment Between Man and Animals, and showing the special bond between man and animals. There will be separate categories of prizes awarded for amateurs and professionals$100 for first prize, $75 for second, $50 for third, and several $10 awards for runners upwith all photographs to be judged by a panel of experts who will make their decisions based on quality, composition and clarity of theme. Entries must be submitted by Sept. 15, and the address to write for complete rules and entry form is: ASPCA Photo Contest,. 441 East 92d Street, New York, N. Y. 10028. Brochures in quantity are available to photo clubs on request.

title: R. R. Schalk to Marry Mrs. Amend on June 23
description: Mrs. Lois Scarpino Amend, director of community relations at the College of New Rochelle, and Richard Riordan Schalk, public relations manager here for the Aluminum Company of America, plan to be married June 23 in the college chapel.

title: Love comes to Moe Gross
description: To that crowded roster of voluble Jewish characters that occupies so large a place in recent American fiction, providing it with some of its most hilarious and poignant moments, may now be added the unlikely figure of Moe Gross, the 57yearold housepainter from the Bronx who is the hero and narrator of Eliot Wagner's Better Occasions.

title: Movies He Ran All the Way To ParisAnd Came Back Again
Dave Anderson
description: In his orange sweatsuit, John Newcombe stepped forward as he was introduced Friday night at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: What's New at the Movies?

description: Miss Dorothy Ellen Daly was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald Wayne Mull, Msgr. James F. Nelan performed the ceremony in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: A Critical Week
description: There have been several critical turnings in Richard Nixon's long passage from Watergate to impeachment. But the President took what may in retrospect be seen as a decisive turn this past week when he wrote Representative Peter Rodino, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, that he would ignore subpoenas and furnish the committee with no further evidence.

title: AROUND THE
description: GYPSY MOTH

title: Duke
description: In the works of Edward Kennedy Ellington, the art form of American musicjazzreached full flower.

title: Sailing May Be Losing Its RichPeopleOnly Label
description: At one time, the only way to learn how to sail was at the helm of daddy's yacht. Sons and daughters of the average money. earner had to settle for motorboating classes run by the local power squadron. But suddenly the traditional yacht club oriented sport of sailing is branching out. First came the expensive schools that offer basic sailing courses for between $150 and $200. And now, here and there, free basic sailing courses are popping up to meet a steadily growing demand.

title: Tomb of First Antipope Believed Found in Italy
description: ROME, May 25 (UPI) Archeologists have found what may be the tomb of St. Hippolytus, first antipope of the Roman Catholic church, under an altar in the presbytry of a basilica named after the saint on the Isola Sacra near Fiumicino, the University of Rome said this week.

title: Hopatcong: The Rush Is On
description: HOPATCONG  Borough officials and business leaders predicted last week that at least 10,000 vacationists would be flocking to this southern Sussex County resort area this summer, beginning with the holiday influx this weekend. I can't see any fewer showing up, despite the gas problem and the high cost of things, one merchant said. I think the big thingthe thing that will make it all possibleis the fact that Route 80 is open all the way. That means people from New York can get here in less than an hour, and they'll come. The Talk of Hopatcong

title: Settlement Ends Strike by Guild at Reuters Agency
description: A tentative settlement in the strike by the Newspaper Guild of New York against the Reuters News Service was announced by a guild spokesman last night. The strike began May 16.

title: Constance McCarrens to Be Wed
description: Mr., and Mrs. Arthur Dennis McCarrens of Delray Beach, Fla., and South Dartmonth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance McCarrens, to Joseph Douglas Schwerin, a vice president of the Bradford Trust Company in New York. He is the son of Mrs. McCurry Schwerin of Ridgewood, N.J., and Joseph Schwerin of Forest, Va. The ceremony will take place in South Dartmouth June 15.

title: What makes him write?;
description: A Writer's Capital is a partial autobiography, an account of Louis Auchincloss's early career, including his education through law school, wartime experiences in the Navy, a first job in a law office and then, with publication of a pseudonymous novel, a fling at the literary life before returning to fulltime Taw practice. It would not be remarkable except that it is the background of a social satirist and one of the most productive novelists of our day. Nearly a score of his books about the behavior of the American elite are on my shelves.

title: L. L, HangGliders Are Succeeding Where Icarus Failed
Headliner
description: He always wrote music, everywriere he went. Everywhere was little auditoriums in obscure towns in the Deep South, college dances in the Midwest, nightclubs, churches, convention and concert hallsand, in 1969, the White House. At age 75, Duke Ellington was still writing music. He was in the middle of an opera when he entered a hospital last month with what was described as a respiratory ailment. But on Friday he died, a victim of pneumonia, resulting from complications of treatment for lung cancer.

title: PRISONER ESCAPES FROM QUEENS JAIL
description: A 35yearold burglary suspect sawed his way out of a window of the Long Island City House of Detention lowered himself to the courtyard 40 feet below, climbed a 20foot prison wall and disappeared into a Long Island Rail Road yard outside, prison authorities reported last night.

title: MENTAL FACILITY HALTED BY DISPUTE
description: A dispute between city and state mental health agencies over the number of psychiatric beds to be put in the new Bellevue Hospital is blocking the start of work on the psychi. atric center.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Bill Stone of Roslyn Heights, LI., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Arlyn Stone, to Kenneth R. Felden, son of Mrs. Al Felden New York and the late Mr. Felden.

title: Updated Data on the Adventure of Being Human
description: IN the late 1960's a confusing ideological battle was joined in the precincts of aventgarde art. One of its key issues was the object and whether an obPictbased art could, at that historical juncture, be considered valid any. longer. Proponents of what became known as'Conceptual art said no; they proposed analytidal ideas and systems of information as the new materials of the modern artist.

title: Preservation Is Pushed
description: The Friends of Cast Iron Architecture, a fouryearold group devoted to the preservation of cast iron buildings, has received a $3,500 grant from the New York State Council on the arts for a survey of castiron buildings in the state.

description: GENEVASomething seems to have gone wrong with the 35nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. This has been meeting intermittently for eighteen months with the idea of more or less formalizing dtente between Communist and nonCommunist blocs facing eath other on the Continent.

title: Miss Wade Wins Final In 3 Sets
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England. May 25 (UPDVirgina Wade beat Julie Heldman, 61, 36, 61, in a match that took nearly two hours to win the women's final of the $72,000 British. claycourt tennis championships today,

title: Notes: Bed, Board and Free Movie
description: A NEW YORKER on a business trip called the Host Airport Hotel in Houston about a room reservation the other day and asked, What movie are you showing? 'pat City with Stacy Keach, the reservations clerk told him. O.K., the businessman said, I'll take the room."'TIV. free uninterrupted movie available at the turn of a switch on Channel ,.1,0,,,a TV channel not normally used in Hous; ton, in each of the hotel's 350 c000tt held more charm for the businessman than the hotel's revolving rooftop restaurant or the quality of its pool. And he is not alone. More and more travelers are beginning to regard free inIrdn'f motion pictures as standard rdom, service.

title: Book Ends
description: June. The month of June will erupt with final burst of publishing energy before the summer doldrums set in. A clutch of potential best sellers are slated, as well as numerous biographies and a spattering of political books, related by varying degrees of consanguinity to the President's Watergate troubles. Alexander Solzhenitsyn's muchpreviewed The Gulag Archipelago (you may have heard of it) will at last make its debut. John Le Clare goes back out into the cold with anotber spy novel, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy, and the word is he hasn't lost his touch. Philip Roth returns to a realistic vein, after such ventures as The Breast and The Great American Novel, with My Life as a Man. Already a best seller in some areas a month before publication date is the Watergate uncoverup, All the President's Men, by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, a surprisingly suspenseful tale of hubris in high places (eat your heart out, Allen Drury, Fletcher Knebel, et al).... In a related development. as the newscasters say, Gerald Ford is the hem, on the whole, of a rush biography by Bud Vestal and a team of Michigan newsmen. Peter Schrag studies Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers case of a hundred or so years ago in 4'Test of Loyalty. Thomas Eagleton and George McGovern are chummily paired, as they were not in life, with books in the same month, while Mary McCarthy's coverage of the Ervin Committee hearings is collected in The Mask of State. The Ripon Society anatomizes gameplan mentality in the 1972 election in Jaws of Victory. Jeb Stuart Magruder confesses in An American Life. And on power itself there is Kenneth B. Clark's The Pathos of Power. . One paragraph of Watergateiana is enough, so let us turn to biography and note that we have heard good things about Margaret Drabble's Arnold Bennett. Yukio Mishima's prolonged post mortem continues with a biography, The Life and Death of Yukio Mishima, by Henry ScottStokes. Other biographical subjects Include Dwight Eisenhower, Mick Jagger, P. G. Wodehouse, Frank Costello, Blaze Starr, Marlon Brando, V. Sackville West, Marie Curie, Miles Davis, Yogi Berra, Lenny Bruce, George Raft, Joey Gallo, Babe Ruth and Giacomo Puccini... Piri Thomas (Down These Mean Streets) tells of prison life from the inside in Seven Long Times"; Nikita Khrushchev (Khrushchev Remembers) remembers some more; and Kate Millett (Sexual Politics) lives with her newfound fame in Flying.... The Greek, by Pierre Rey is one of those big commercial novels about thinlydisguised famous people. John Knowles (A Separate Peace) is back with Spreading Fires.... Finally, there Is another Harry Golden, Our Southern Landsman.

title: Directions THOMPSON HOUSE
description: Take Smithtown Bypass east on Route 347, then go left on Nichols Road to Route 25A. Go right 1,?? feet to North Country Road and thee left to Thompson House. Preview and bricabrac sales Friday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Auction, Saturday, 10 A.M. For additional information call (516) 9419444.

title: Impeachment on TV: In the Public Interest
description: WASHINGTONA question that beginning to confront members of the Senate is whether or not an impeachment proceeding, if it comes to pass, should be televised. The House Judiciary Committee has decided that its hearings, after closed sessions, will be aired in the public interest.

title: How to Set Up Is Golf Key
description: Johnny Miller, the golferoftheyear to date with five tour victories and defending United States open champion, has a quietly reflective way of making the game sound as easy as he makes it look. His primary objective is a good setup position, and his theory can help the weekend player.

title: 5Year Fight on Alaska Pipeline Made It Better and More Costly
description: On June 6, 1969, three companies submitted to the Anchorage Land Office a general route map, 12 soilsample sheets and a $10 check to support their application for a rightofway permit to pipe oil from Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's Arctic coast to the Valdez fjord about 800 miles to the south.

title: The Maalot Killings: Mystery Deepens as Versions Clash
description: Early on the morning May 15, a young woman name Narkis Mordechai emerge from the guerrillaheld schoo house in Maalot, where 16 teenage Israeli hostages wer to die in a hail of bullets be tore nightfall.

title: Slow Songs
description: Kathleen Fiore, a soprano who made her New York debut last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, let a curious miscalculation mar the pleasure that was otherwise obtained at her recital. Her selection of songs and arias was almost unvaryingly, slow and lugubrious. In proportion, that kind of music would have been fine. But after a while, as Donald Boks, her accomplished accompanist, broke into yet another bit of soulfulness, one began to long for something lively.

title: The Natipon In Summary
description: The use of busing to achieve desegregation in the public schools is undergoing a new test made explicit In widely divergent approaches to the subject in the House and Senate versions of an aidtoeducation bill.

description: TRENTON  This summer should be a healthier and safer one for the thousands of New Jersey youngsters who attend camps throughout the state.

title: 3 DRUSES ARE KILLED BY GOLAN SHELLING
description: TEL AVIV; May 25(Reuters) Three Druse residents were killed and seven Israeli soldiers wounded by Syrian shelling in the Golan Heights, a military spokesman said here.

title: Three New Definitives Issued by U. N.
description: THE United Nations is putting out on June 10 three new definitive stamps, two to replace issues that have been in use for some 10 years and one to meet revised postage rates. The replacements are 2cent and 10cent values. The third new stamp is an 18.cent denomination.

title: 72 Accipiter Triumphs In Withers

Accipiter had plenty of speed left at the close to beat the Bwamazon Farm's Best of It by 1 lengths.

description: Francis, the only pregnant white whale in captivity, died last night of internal poisoning in her tank at the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

title: A. J. Foyt Is Driver to Beat In 58th Indy 500 Today
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 25The Indianapolis 500, which cannot seem to function without a hassle, has staggered throfigh three controversies in two weeks and now appears ready for its 58th running tomorrow. The race will begin at 11 AM. Eastern standard time, the time zone this city prefers (Noon, New York time), and will run a little over three hours.

title: Emigration of Soviet Jews Declines, but Reasons Are Dispqted
description: MOSCOW, May 25A marked drop in the number of emigrating Soviet Jews has prompted a controversy over the reasons for the decline and has highlighted some new problems that potential emigrants face.

description: MORRISTOWN  The Morris County Public Library will receive a $135,000 state grant next spring in order to establish a film distribution center for six North Jersey counties with a total popu.. lation of 1,368,421.

title: Cannes You Believe What's at Cannes?
description: CANNES. FILM festivals are probably the worst places in the world for assessing individual films. They come at one in such number, in such a short space of time, that one is apt to lose one's bearings. The professional critic finds himself feeling little like the wine taster who gets suddenly drunk. It's not fatal. It's not always incapacitating, but it tends to blunt judgment.

description: Gene McCarthy, All Hallows senior, rebounding from an unexpected defeat in Hartford last week, posted the fastest individual mile run clocking yesterday, in the metropolitan area this season. McCarthy's time was 4 minutes 13.1 seconds.

title: Drama Mailbag Should We Mourn Ulysses?
description: ON May 11, two short months after its opening, one of the most ambitious theatrical productions in Broadway history came to a disastrous end. Every seat in the house was filled. The applause at the final curtain was enthusiastic, but as soon as the house lights went up the applause ended and Ulysses in Nighttown was presumably to be forgotten.

title: Migdal Displays Talent at Piano
description: Marian Migdal, a Polishborn pianist who is now a Swedish citizen, studied for a time at the Juilliard School and in 1971 was a winner in the International Piano Competition at Munich. His New York debut recital at Town Hall on Tuesday night left no doubt of his innate talent or his ability to pour out torrents of notes at great speed. Mr. Migdal played two Galuppi sonatas with appropriate glitter, in the style associated with Scarlatti. He took on the massive Brahms Sonata in F sharp minor and succeeded in making it sound amazingly like Liszt, reminding one that Brahms was an extraordinarily accomplished pianist as well as a composer.

description: This is how I drive one lap of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, 2 miles in less than 50 seconds at speeds exceeding 200 miles an hour.

He goes to God and asks what the matter can be. After a pause, God looks up. I'm so tired, he says.

Seven others in the boat were treated at a hospital for exposure. Troopers said Mr. !Brown was in his early 20's.

(It seems quite in the order of things that the jacket bears a blurb from Auberon Waugh hailing Amis fils as a new novelist of intelligence, wit and an apparently reckless honesty... a formidable and

title: Miss Gerstley Wed to James Dubin
description: The marriage of Miss Virginia May Gerstley to James Michael Dubin took place in Rydal, Pa., last night at the home of Mr. and lkifrs, William Gerstley 2d parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Dubin of Hamden Conn. Rabbi David Wice performed the ceremony.

title: Food
description: Eggplant used to be called mala insane, mad apple, and it was thought to cause insanity. But that was a long time ago. We happen to be crazy about the vegetable ourselves, because it is earthy, yet elegant; meaty (think. of eggplant parmigiana), but all vegetable; versatile and, yes, delectable. There is little more to be saidexcept, possibly, that the object in the picture at right is not a real eggplant, but a soft sculpture by Sydnie Shuman.

title: For Linnaeus
description: It used to be the custom for botanists and other wildflower people to go for a day in the country about now, to look for plants they had read about but seldom seen growing. The trip was an informal tribute to Linnaeus, the father of modern botany, whose birthday was May 23. Linnaeus was one of the first to go into the field, talk to the peasants about plants and study those plants where they grew. Eventually he created the system naming plants in simple Latin terms, organizing botany by species and genus, and lifting it out of the dust and superstition of the Middle Ages.

title: WILSON CONDEMNS HUGS IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 25Prime Minister Wilson tonight denounced striking Protestant extremists as thugs and bullies but stopped short of disclosing any steps to break their strangehold on Northern Ireland.

description: NAMPULA, Mozambique, May 19  In a decade of war between the Portuguese Army and the Mozambique Liberation Front some 25,000 people have been killed, several times that number wounded and nearly a million displaced.

title: No Middle Ground
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland is a dark and tragic place, bombpocked, firescarred and bloodsoaked; victim of ancient hatreds and passions running deep into the bogs of antiquity, religion and nationality. But Ulster, as it is usually cared here, has its men and women of moderation and generosity, struggling to survive amid the savageries of civil war, the uncertainties of violence and disorder.

title: Mrs. Wiggs Was Great, But Who Was She?
description: THE other Saturday night, suffering from an incipient cold, I took medication, went to bed early and drifted into what I hoped was a sound sleep. In some corner of my stuffed and stubborn head I was nagged by the knowledge that Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch was going to be on television early in the morning. When I finally realized that I was not going to sleep at all and turned on the light, it was 1:15. I decided I might as well drag myself to the set and see if the presence of W. C. Fields, like that of Oral could cure cold symptoms.

title: Alaska Whale Killed As Buckley Watches
description: POINT HOPE, Alaska, May 24  After more than 14 hours of silent waiting on an icy promontory, Seymour Tuzroyluk spotted a bowhead whale gliding 150 yards offshore yesterday.

description: A fund has been set up to aid the family of Jim Brolley, the football coach at Erasmus Hall High School, who was killed in a fire in his home on May 17. Brolley left wife and two sons1 and years old.

Last week two boatloads of town officials and ornithologistsprofessional and amateurset out to survey the total bird population, the number of different types, and how they were faring in the wetlands cared for by the town.

title: Air Crash Probe The Grim Task of Learning From Past Mistakes
description: ON March 3, 1974, a DC10 wide bodied jet owned by Turkish Air lines took off from Orly Airpor outside Paris bound for London :Heathrow Airport, only 60 minute ,,way. Eleven minutes later it crashes in a game refuge, killing at least 344 including 22 Americans. It was thi deadliest air catastrophe in history. t Within two hours Edward (Doug Dreifus, a crash expert attached to thi United States National Transportatior Safety Board, and two other N.T.S.B investigators were at Dulles Internation al Airport outside Washington getting ready to take off for Paris. The international agreement in such matters gave France jurisdiction. But because the DC10 had been built in Long Beach, Calif., by McDonnellDouglas Aircraft Corpora;don, the international agreement also gave the United States the right to send

title: Agnew Signs a Lease For Suite of Offices
description: CROFTON, Md., May 25 (AP) Spiro T. Agnew has signed a threeyear lease for a suite of offices at a professional center here, according to a spokesman for the center.

title: Beyond Ammon sense The Lives Of a Cell Notes of a Biology Watcher. By Lewis Thomas. 153 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $6.95.
description: For the past several years a series of remarkableessays has been appearing in the New England Journal of Medicine, that enthralling and somewhat forbidding publicationDr. Lewis Thomas's Notes of Biology Watcher. Readers who have been photostating these essays and teachers who (like me) have been passing them out in classes will be delighted to see them finally collected in one small volume. The rest of the readers, to whom the Notes are new, may have an extraordinarily pleasant surprise in store.

title: State Parkway Police Are Demanding Pay Equal to County Police
description: BABYLON  Carrying large placards stating Parkway Cops Bleed Too, Equal Pay For Equal Work and State Discriminates Against Parkway Cops, Long Island State Parkway Police picketed all last week in efforts to resolve a longstanding dispute.

description: Kid, there ain't no second place in this race. You either win or you ain't nowhere.

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.It was only a few years ago, people here sometimes have to remind themselves, that Nicholas Panuzio was picking up extra money taking tickets at University of Bridgeport basketball games and talking about the city's need to awaken from its legendary torpor and despair.

Howard Marshall Lowell.

title: The World/Continued
description: Expanding on the retaliation raids for the May 15 terrorist attack on Maalot, Israeli forces blasted Palestinian camps in Lebanon. The first bomb and rocket attacks on May 16 left 50 people dead and 200 wounded in reprisal for the massacre of 20 teenagers and 8 others at Maalot.

title: Art Chronicles of Black History
description: HE painter who nowadays attempts to align his work with historical Or narrative materials essential to its under,standing finds himself in an odd situation. The history of art abounds in superlative examples of painting based on the representation of literary, historical and mythological ,potifs, yet our experience of modern art predisposes us to regard the contemporary use lrf Such texts with deep suspicion. Painting is no longer expected to traffic in narrative themes. It shuns a story like the proverbial plague, and the only history ,pf compelling artistic inter2est to most contemporary Painters is the recent history of their own medium.

title: Special Forecasts Prepared For Farmer
description: NEW BRUNSWICK There is not much that anyone can do about the weather. But in New Jersey, it least, farmers can now get forecasts directly oriented to their needs.

title: MEYER WEISGAL WILL BE HONORED
description: At 79 years of age, Meyer Wolf Weisgal, a man of accomplishment in Jewish life, has endless pride in his heritage and in the certainty of the future of thern Jewish peoI pie.

title: Children Take a Walk Into the Past
description: EAST HAMPTON  More than 1,000 schoolchildren from Southi Fork communities went Up and Down, Main Street last Thursday. And while most of them regularly stroll through the village, this time things were different.

title: Nostalgia Rocks On With Murray the K And His Sock Hop
description: Murray Kaufman, better known as the disk jockey Murray the K, took a stab at the nostalgia market Friday at the Felt Forum. He attempted to turn the place into your basic high school gymnasium for Sock Hop, that beloved rite of puberty for America's teenagers of the nineteenfiftiesor, as Mr. Kaufman put it, a blastfromthepast sock hop.

title: INVESTING POINT OP VIEW
description: Here we go again. The securities industry, from its expensive resort surroundings in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., is lamenting its current economic plight. Again and again they repeat the litany: We need the public investor. Negotiated commissions will seriously damage the greatest marketplace in the world. Overthecounter trading of listed securities  the third market should not be allowed to compete on an equal basis with the exchanges.

title: LowRise Shops Go Up on Block On 3d Ave. Zoned For Skyscraper
description: The slack demand for office space is leading some developers to look for other sources of income than the traditional parking lot to help defray the cost of holding land that was assembled for new construction.

title: Cosmopolitan Ends Its Jubilee Season
description: The Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra ended its 10th anniversary season Tuesday night with a concert at Avery Fisher Hall under the direction of Stephen Simon.

title: New &
description: In this unusual love story, love means having to say you are plenty sorry. Merrick Blaine, a young professor of English with great expectations, develops an acute infatuation for Evie Holman, a student so beautiful she resembles A Canova.Venue But Evie's beauty is flawed by a curiously, destructive intensity. And Merrick's ambition screens an arrested state of emotional development. Individually, these two might have muddled along very well; together they are a time bomb. Evie's pregnancy assures their union and a sequence of spontaneous combustions that leave both parties maimed.

title: Buyers Hurt as Builder in Rockland County Falters
description: POMONA, N. Y.Little by little, the spring rains and the vandals are carrying off the dreams of Anthony and Judith Johnson.

Schrier, president of the Copy Shoppe, a New York advertising and copywriting company, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's sister and brotherinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kabbash in Wayne, N. J. Judge Thomas J. Rumana performed the ceremony.

title: Nixon Signs Enlistment Bill
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fld., May 25 (Reuters)  President Nixon signed a bill at his Florida vacation home today that allows women to join the armed forces at the age of 17. Until now, men could join the armed forces at 17, but women had to be 18 to enlist.

title: Linda Warch Married at Yale To Peter. L. Fenton, Librarian
description: Miss Linda Warch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Warch of HoHoKus, N. J., was married at noon yesterday to Peter Low Fenton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Fenton of Brunswick, Me. The ceremony was performed in the Courtyard of the Yale Divinity School in NeW Haven by the bride's brother, Dr. Richard Warch, who is an ordained Presbyterian minister and an associate professor at Yale University.

title: A Napoleonic vision of Iran as a new Japan
description: TEHERAN. Every year on the morning of the spring equinox, His Imperial Majesty, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, King Of Kings, Light of the Aryans, holds court amid the glittering splendor of Teheran's Gulistan Palace to receive the homage of Iran and the world. It is the first day of Nowroze, the Iranian New Year, and as the limousines of the privileged roll into the palace gardens it a ceremony of power. Cabinet ministers, provincial governors, and senior civil servants alight in full court dress, goldfrogged and braided from head toe. Phalanxes of militarygentlemen flash their medals in a continual exchange of salutes and courtesy kisses. Ambassadors in their diplomatic uniforms mingle with academics in robes of black, Islamic mullahs in turbans of whitest white and clutch of Christian bishops in the assorted headgear of their several sects.

title: U.S. to Shift Fighter Squadron From Thailand to South Korea, Air Chief Says
description: TOKYO, May 24The Secretary of the Air Force, John L. McLucas, indicated this week that the United States would soon shift a squadron of F4 Phantom jet fighters from Thailand to South Korea.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Youth, Genetics
description: Three of the world's deepestdiving vessels will penetrate the volcanic rift valley beneath the midAtlantic to study the results of eruptions that shift the sea floor, and, it is now believed, are dragging apart the seabed of the eastern and western halves of the Atlantic.

title: Calley Enjoys Freedom as Lawyers Keep Busy
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.Although he is still military prisoner dishonorably discharged from the Army, former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. appears to be living well while he awaits civilian court action in which some authorities, including the judge in the case, say there is a good chance his conviction mass murder of Vietnamese civilians at My Lai will be reversed.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Lenny Bruce!
description: In the absence of an index, which is about Lb most serious fault I find with this biography biopsy of Lenny Bruce, I'm unable to compile any thing like a complete list of those most likely be aggravated and outraged by Albert Goldmar. That such a list would include Bosley Crowthe and Reinhold Niebuhr, that Dorothy Kilgallen possibly treated more kindly than Lionel Trilling that both Playboy and The New York Review Books are backhanded, testifies to his awesom audacity.

title: Politician Freed in Greece Denounces Prison Terror
description: ATHENS, May 25  George Mavros relaxed in a deep, comfortable armchair, surrounded by the polished wood and leatherbound volumes that mark the office of a successful lawyer. A week ago, he was prisoner on the barren island of Yaros, where an iron bedstead was his only furniture and rusty nail for his clothes was a luxury.
