Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Issues Pesticide Safety Rules
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued new regulations to protect the nation's farmworkers from the adverse effects of pesticides.

title: Woman Fatally Shot Says She Killed Her Assailant
description: A woman who had been fatally shot told Queens police officers just before she died last night that she had shot and killed the man who had wounded her, following an argument in the man's apartment at 150.29 122d Avenue, Jamaica.

title: CANADA WILL BUY AIRCRAFT PLANTS
description: OTTAWA, May 27In a move toward longrange restructuring of the Canadian aircraft manufacturing industry, the Government will purchase the Toronto plant of a major British plane maker, and plans a similar takeover of an Americanowned company in Montreal.

title: Miss Donna Dean Carter Is Bride
description: Miss Donna Dean Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Carter of Sudbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Gagarin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Gagarin of Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Carl R. Scovel performed the Unitarian ceremony in the First Parish Church in Sudbury.

title: How the Teams Stand Today
Gags Galore Going On All Around the Town
description: Personal appearances are not the only ways in which a comic can make himself a dollar in the New York Metropolitan area.

title: Hush Money Tape Held Possibly Harmful to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Three Republican members of the House Judfciary Committee say that President Nixon's hush money conversation of March 21, 1973, is the only evidence they have heard that could tend to implicate the President in the Watergate coverup.

title: JERSEY MAY DROP TRANSIT BOND PLAN
description: Highly placed state officials disclosed yesterday that the Byrne administration was seriously considering abandoning plans for a major transportation bond issue in New Jersey this November.

title: WILLCOX & GIBBS owns Los Angeles Sample Co. (WGAMEX)Advt.
Curiosity Spurs Soviet Sales of PepsiCola Despite High Price
description: MOSCOW, May 24Soviet vacationers on the Black Sea have begun sampling the sweet joys of the Pepsi generation, although they are finding that such tastes can be expensive.

Books of The Times
description: THE DENIAL OF DEATH. By Ernest Becker. 314 pages. Free Press. $7.95.

title: Nixon Makes Memorial Day Plea for a Strong Military
description: MIAMI,, May 27President Nixon, in a Memorial Day address to the nation, coupled an appeal for a strong military with praise for two Southern Democrats in Congress.

title: Problem for Court in Taking Up Tapes Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The Supreme Court, and particularly its Chief Justice, face difficult and politically explosive decisions in the request by the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, that the Court take imme diate jurisdiction of the dispute over President Nixon's refusal to surrender 64 White House tapes. The Court must rule on the question, both procedural and substantive, whether the imperative public importance of bringing the Watergate conspirators to trial this year justifies bypassing an intermediate hearingfor the President in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Brett Loses Bid for Perfect Game in 9th
description: Despite registering a 60 victory over San Diego, the short and otherwise happy day of Ken Brett, a Pirates lefthanded pitcher, was irreparably spoiled by Fred Kendall of the Padres in the first game of a Memorial Day doubleheader yesterday before a crowd of 16,000 at the Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh.

title: On Quackupuncture
description: In 1971, four Americanphysicians, myself included, first visited Mainland China as guests of the Chinese Medical Asso'dation. On returning after the brief visit, the doctors reported on various aspects of Chinese medicine, both modern and traditional, including the use of acupuncture.

title: Giscard Is Inaugurated; Departs From Tradition
description: PARIS, May 27Valry Giscard D'Estaing was inaugurated today at the Elysee Palace as the third popularly elected president of France, the 20th in her history and the youngest in this century.

title: ROONEY IMPERILED BY DISTRICT PLAN
description: The Brooklyn districts of Representative John J. Rooney, dean of the New York Congressional delegation, and of State Senator Carol Bellamy, one of the three women in the State Senate, would be dismembered in a special reap scheduled for approval at a special session of the Legislature tomorrow.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (UPI)The Indianapolis Motor Speedway tonight distributed a record purse of $1,015,686 to the competitors of yesterday's Indianapolis 500mile auto race. Johnny Rutherford, the winner from Fort Worth, Tex., split $245,031 with his crew from Team McLaren of England.

title: Events Todat
WITHDRAWALS UP AT SAVINGS MID
description: The Federal Home Lou, Bank Board reported yesterday that savers withdrew money from savings and loan associations last month at a faster rate than in any April since 1969.

title: 54 Indicted in Seoul As Members of Plot To Oust the Regime
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 27 The army today indicted 52 South Koreans and two Jananese e for trial by courtmartial tmrcharges of Involvement in a Coilimunistinspired student movement said to have been aimed at overthrowing the South Korean Government.

title: 6 OIL GIANTS PAY LOW INCOME TAX
description: The nation's six major multinational oil companies, which had total net profits of $6.7billion in 1973, have reported that they paid worldwide taxes of $25.4billion on their operationsbut they paid only $642million in domestic Federal income taxes. The companies gross revenues totaled nearly $50billion for the year.

title: Police Walk the Halls At Pleasantville High
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. J.For the first time since the columned, threestory brick Pleasantville High School was erected 40 years ago, policemen with guns and tear gas are patrolling its corridors.

title: Caulfield Testified That He Ordered Audit of Newsman
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)  A former White House aide, John J. Caulfield, has testified secretly that he instigated a tax audit of a newspaper reporter, Robert W. Greene of Newsday, who wrote articles about the financial dealings of President Nixon's friend, Charles B. Rebozo.

title: For These Lifeguards, The Experience Pays
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 What makes lifeguards return year after year to the beach patrol here?

title: MRS. RUTH SEDGWICK
description: Mrs. Ruth Woodbury Sedgwick, who edited Stage magazine in the nineteenthirties, died yesterday in a nursing home in Norwalk, Conn. She was 82 years old.

title: Belfast: Survival Test
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27 "If the Executive can survive this, a wellplaced civil servant said of the Protestant strike that has been crippling Northern Ireland, the Executive can survive anything. Maybe, and then again maybe not.

title: The Holiday in Chicago : If Was, and It Wasn't
description: CHICAGO, May 27 (UPI) Depending on whom you listen tothe Federal Government or the state governmentit either was or wasn't Memorial Day here today.

title: The Student Aid Hoax
description: The inflationary rise in college tuition is a direct threat to higher education for students from poor as well as middleincome homes. In the public and the private sector, costs to the student are mounting astronomically. Yet the Federal Government seems determined to accelerate the inflationary trend.

description: International

Chinese Reject Proposal By Moscow on Waterways
description: PEKING, May 27 (Reuters) Official Chinese sources today dismissed as sheer blackmail a recent Soviet proposal about Chinese ships using waterways along the common border.

description: AT MANHASSET BAY Y.C.

title: More News Of Sports On Pages 48, 49
Fellow Musicians Among 12,500 at Services for Duke Ellington
description: The city whose hectic rhythms and melancholy sophistication he caught in scores of compositions said farewell to Duke Ellington yesterday,

title: A Day in U.S. Circuit Court: From Trademarks to. Prisoner Rights to Sex Bias
description: Hear ye, hear ye, here ye all persons having business before this... United States Court of Appeals for the Second Judicial Circuit draw near, give your attention and ye shall be heard.

title: Sealyham Named Best At Queensboro Show
description: The combination of a Welsh handler and a Sealyham from Wales proved an unbeatable one yesterday. The handler was Peter Green, one of the leading terrier men in the United States. The Sealy was Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, owned by the Pool Forge Kennel of Mrs. Dorothy Wymer of Churchtown, Pa.

title: ExCahill Aide Faces Trial With FundRaisers Today
description: Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane is scheduled to go trial in Trenton today on state charges that he misused his office to enrich his brother's career as a stockbroker.

title: Cape Cod Bomb Scare Snarls Holiday Traffic
description: BOSTON, May 27 (AP)A bomb scare on the two bridges over the Cape Cod Canal caused traffic tieups of homewardbound motorists of up to 12 miles today, according to the state and local police.

title: Experts Feel Miss Hearst May Have Undergone Brainwashing
description: LOS ANGELES, May 27The second most important question now in the Patricia Hearst case after the mystery of her whereaboutsis how the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army was apparently able to convert her from a pleasant, nonpolitical young woman to Tania, the machine gunwielding revolutionary on a doomed mission.

title: British Soldiers in Ulster Occupy Key Fuel Facilities
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27British soldiers armed with carbines and machine guns occupied gasoline stations and oil storage depots at strategic points in Northern Ireland today as the general strike threatened to bring a complete stoppage of food supplies, medical services and electric power.

title: Limits of Power...
description: A Federal judge has scuttled the Nixon Administration's claim that the powers of the Presidency are virtually unliMited. In ruling on preliminary matters in the trial of those accused of violating the civil rights of Dr. Lewis Fielding, Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, Judge Gerhard A. Gesell has rejected the claim that a burglary committed by the White House plumbers was consonant with the Constitution under a vague delegation of national security powers by the President.

title: Judger Is Fifth at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J. May 27 Thoroughbred racing's version of the lottery provided another surprise today when Better Arbitor's number came Up in the $160,000 Jersey Derby.

title: Soviet Seeks $500Million Of New Deals With U.S.
description: MOSCOW, May 27 Leonid A. Kostandor, Soviet, minister of the ohemics1 industry, disclosed today that his ministry was talking with American companies, about more than $500million in brandnew industrial projects.

title: TRANSIT WORKERS STRIKE IN LISBON
description: LISBON, May 27A sudden strike today by Lisbon's streetcar and bus workers embarrassed labor leaders, the Communist party and the provisional government.

title: GILLIGAN IS VICTOR IN LABOR BATTLE
description: CLEVELAND, May 27Gov. John J. Gilligan emerged as a significant winner here last week as the huge Ohio A.F.L.C.I.O ousted Frank W. king, one of the Governor's severest critics, from the office of president that he had filled for 10 years.

title: Despite Gains Here, It's Tough to Earn a Living
description: Funny thing about the standup comic in New York: what looked like his last stand here only a few years ago may be turning into a new lease on life, although making a living'out of his art is no laughing matter.

title: Angola Bans Street Gatherings After Blacks Roam in Luanda
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 27An afternoon of racial unrest yesterday led today to a ban on all street demonstrations in Angola. This is the first time since the military coup in Lisbon last month that such a restriction has been placed on political activity in Portugal or her overseas territoies.

title: James Taylor Proves Best in Solos
description: James Taylor, who appeared Sunday night and last night at Carnegie Hall, has always been a folkpop singer of a rather special style. His determinedly soft rock (with or without electric instruments) and his comfortably confidential way of singing made him one of the biggest new superstars of the early nineteenseventies. It also struck his critics as limited, mannered and antithetical to the inherent vitality of contemporary popular music.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said that although he had furthen narrowed the differences between Syria and Israel in toundtheclock talks in Damascus, he had decided to return home tomorrow even without a troopseparation agreement. He insisted, while speaking to reporters who had accornpanied him from Damascus to Tel Aviv, that it was premature to say that his mediation efforts had failed. We will not know until tomorrow what the final outcome will be, he said last night. The Israeli. Cabinet will meet this morning to discuss possible new steps. The Secretary will hold discussions with Israeli leaders after the meeting. [1:8.]

title: SECURITY AT JAILS IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: Correction Department security programs were reported under investigation yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office and the special state prosecutor's grand jury in Brooklyn. Three of 15 city prisoners who have escaped this year remain at large.

title: Roger H. Corbetta, Builder, Dies; Worked on Major Area Bridges
description: Roger H, Corbetta, chairman of the Corbetta Construction Company, and a leader in the industry, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, where he was to attend a luncheon of the PreStressed Concrete Institute in his honor. He was 77 years old and lived at Attebroc Farm in Millbrook, N. Y.

title: Rep. Rooney Is Seen Imperiled By U.S.Ordered Redistricting
description: The districts of Representative John J. Rooney, dean of the New York congressional delegation, and State Senator Carol Bellamy, one of only three women in the State Senate, would be dismembered in a special reapportionment scheduled for approval at a special session of the Legislature tomorow.

title: The Chelsea: Success Story in Brooklyn, of All Places
description: In terms of critical acclaim and artistic achievement, they are for the moment without peer, having won the 1974 Drama Critics Award for the best musical"Candide"and the best play of the season"The Contractor.

title: Housing Construction Continues To Decline in City and State
description: Housing construction, which dropped sharply last year in the city and state, continued to plummet during the first three months of the year, and housing officials have expressed fear that residential building activity would be even more depressed in the state in 1974 than it was last year.

title: Marilyn Home's Mother Dies
description: Mrs. Bernice Home, the mother of Marilyn Home, the opera star, died Sunday of can cer in Long Beach, Calif. She was 60 years old. In addition to Miss Home, she leaves two sons, Richard and Jay, and a daughter, Mrs. Gloria Palacios.

title: Thin Turnouts Salute War Dead
description: Where thousands of proud veterans had once marched triumphantly to the rousing beat of band music and to the cheers of hundred of thousands of flagwaving spectators, a modest parade filed up Riverside Drive yesterday morning before a sparse crowd of onlookers for the city's traditional Memorial Day tribute to its war dead.

title: CHINATOWN TO GET 27STORY TOWERS
description: Two identical 27story condominium towers are planned for. construction on a largely undeveloped square block on the northwest corner of Chinatown near the complex of city, state and Federal office buildings and courthouses.

title: Edward J. Peguillan, 46, Of Chemical Bank, Dead
description: Edward J. Peguillan, a vice president and marketing director of the Chemical Bank, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived at 12 the Knolls, Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Yanks Beaten, 53
description: The Yankees reverted to their more normal style of play yesterday, dropping a 53 decision to Chicago that was routine except for the defensive play of Lou Piniella in left field, who threw out two White Sox runners at home plate on consecutive hits.

description: L.I. CHAMPIONSHIP

title: U.S. and Soviet Hope to Set New Curb on Atom Tests Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Washington and Moscow are pushing hard toward a new limitation on nuclear tests, hoping to have it ready for signing at the summit meeting scheduled for Moscow next month. But Administration officials concede that the agreement is designed more to show that EastWest accommodation is still working than to have any teal impact on arms control.

title: INDIA'S RAIL STRIKE ENDS IN COLLAPSE
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, May 28  India's 20dayold rail strike ended today. The collapse of the walkout was a major triumph for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: India Seeks to Calm Canada Alter Nuclear Blast
description: NEW DELHI, May 27India, which has maintained a warm friendship with Canada, is seeking to calm the anger of Ottawa over the nuclear test here.

title: Anne Kelly Married To Richard Skolnik
description: In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, 371 Avenue of the Americas, yesterday afternoon, Miss Anne Elizabeth Kelly and Richard S. Skolnik, who are with the actuarial department of the RoyalGlobe Insurance Companies here, were married by the Revs Robert V. Lott.

title: Thieu Is Reported to Dismiss A Powerful Inner Circle Aide
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27Authoritative Government sources reported today that President Nguyen Van Thieu had dismissed one of the most powerful men in his inner circle of advisersNguyen Van Ngan, the organizer of the Thieu party and the man who steered to passage a constitutional amendment permitting Mr. Thieu a third term.

title: Invetors Find They're Paying More As Brokers End Some Free Services
description: Dozens of the nation's stockbrokerage firms have started assessing customers for services that they previously provided without charge, and it is apparent that in a month or two, hundreds more will be doing so.

title: SEARCH FOR BOY, 13, IS POSTPONED A DAY
description: KINNELON, May 27  The borough police department has discontinued the search for 13yearold Edward Diggles until Wednesday morning. The decision was made following a meeting tonight with the boy's father, William, and several police officials.

title: GISCARD APPOINTS CHIRAC, GAULLIST, FRANCE'S PREMIER
description: PARIS, May 27  Jacques Chirac, the 41yearold Minister of the Interior, was named Premier of France today.

title: KISSINGER MISSION ENDS TOMORROW; PACT STILL SOUGHT
description: TEL AVIV, May 27  Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight that although he had further narrowed the differences between Syria and Israel in roundtheclock talks in Damascus, he had now decided to return home Wednesday even without a troopseparation agreement.

title: MAN, 31, IS LOST AS BOAT CAPSIZES
description: One man was believed drowned and two were rescued when their 14foot rowboat capsized in rough water about 300 yards west of Execution Rock Lighthouse in Long Island Sound.

title: Getty Museum Is a Hit With Visitors
description: MALIBU, Calif.  Among certain culture devotees in the Los Angeles area, it's the height of chic to knock the opulent new J. Paul Getty Museum without having seen it. I hear it's gussied up like a gl Air dining room, said a painter from the rundown artists colony in nearby Venice, who cheerfully admits he hasn't visited the museum because I don't connect with it.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
BOTH SIDES CONTINUE SHELLINGS ON GOLAN,
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 27 (Reuters)Artilery fighting between Syrian and Israeli forces continued on the Golan front today, a military spokesman said.

title: Levitt Accuses H.R.A. Of Claim Irregularities
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the New York City Human Resources Administration had filed $3,547,330 in duplicate claims for state and Federal welfare reimbursement out of $110,331,490 claimed in a single month  July, 1971. At other times, he said, the city failed to file enough claims.

title: Bruce Biossat of N.E.A., 64; Chief Capital Correspondent
description: Bruce Biossat, chief Washing. ton correspondent for the Newspaper Enterprise Association, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Washing. ton. He was 64 years old.

title: Governors to Visit Expo 74
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 27 (UPI)  At least 17 governors, including Alabama's Gov. George C. Wallace, will visit Expo 74 while in Washington for the National Governors conference the first week of June, Gov. Din Evans's office reported today.

title: Sports Nekvs Briefs
description: FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., May 27Leigh Buck of Baltimore scored six goals as the United States First Team defeated the United States Reserves, 13.7, as the threeday women's national lacrosse tournament ended today Germantown Academy.

title: Purchase Players Offer Rousing Kammermusik
description: The Purchase Chamber Players, a group composed of some of the most, accomplished newmusic performers in this area, dug back into the relatively dim past for the major part of an excellent concert on Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The ensemble, now in its second season, is largely drawn from the music faculty of the State University of New York at Purchase, but virtually all its members appear regularly with other leading contemporary music organizations.

title: Arctic Gas Pipeline Route The New Issue in Alaska
description: Another long, complex and controversial chapter has started to unfold in the continuing saga of the Prudhoe Bay oilandgas field and the means of funneling its Arctic bonanza to market.

title: WHITE HOUSE CALLED MORE RESPONSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton says that the White House seems to be better organized and more responsive since the Watergate affair forced the resignations of H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman.

title: NEWS INDEX
Clean Air, Limited
description: The bill to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970, recently passed by the Senate, is at best an environmentalist rearguard action. In Its original form, as an Administration package designed to meet the oil shortage, the proposed changes were wholly indefensible. They would have all but wiped out effective clean air standards until such time as the United States became, in fact, independent of foreign oil.

title: Sculling Record Broken by Dietz
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 27Jim Dietz, the national sculling champion, lowered the 2,000meter record for the Orchard Beach Lagoon by 15.7 secends today as he defeated Dr. Larry Klecatsky by 2 lengths in 3 minutes 20 seconds. Bill Belden of the Undine Barge Club of Philadelphia was third.

title: Their Place in the Sun Is a Terrace or Yard Carved Out of the City
description: Their friends envy themthey have the sun in the morning and the moon at night, reasonably fresh air and spectacular views of the city. They also have soot, galeforce winds and neighbors who may dump debris on their petunias.

description: WASHINGTON, May 27We went to Dick's house for poker.

title: Quack Wins $115,900 Californian in Stretch Run
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 27 (AP)Bwamazon Farm's Quack repeated his victory of a year ago, without winning in the interim, with a stretch drive to, capture the $115,900 Californian Stakes before 42,930 at Hollywood Park today.

title: Blast by India Prompts HighLevel U.S. Review of Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 India's explosion of a plutonium device has rekindled fears about the spread of nuclear weapons and has prompted a highlevel interagency review of United States aid to India.

title: MRS. GANDHI TERMS INDIA WHIPPING BOY
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared in her first interview since Indian, atomic blast that we are not a nuclearweapons country and complained that India was a favorite and convenient whipping boy.

description: The Knicks need a center for insurance against Willis Reed's recovery, a rebounding forward to replace the retired Dave DeBusschere and a backcourt man who will do the things Dean Meminger did before he was sent off to Atlanta in the expansion draft.

title: Moe Levine, 68, a Leader In Trial Lawiers Group
description: Moe Levine, a partner in the law firm of Shayne, Dachs & Moe Levine, of Mineola, L. I., died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 68 years old and had homes there and at 100 Clinton Avenue, Mineola.

title: Smith Ousts Kuki, Gains At Rome Net
description: ROME, May 27 (AP)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., held off a strong challenge from an unheralded player, Jun Kuki of Japan, to move into the second round of the $134,000 Italian open tennis championships today. Smith, the tournament's No. 4seeded player, downed Kuki, 75, 75.

description: John Vanneck, financier, Industrialist and sportsman, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Parsonage Point, Rye, N. Y. He was 68 years old.

description: The St. George Hotel, once among Brooklyn's grandest Monuments, sits cracked, peeling, and halfempty on Clark Street, a decaying relic amid he affluence of Brooklyn Heights.

He was 85 years old and lived at 700 Park Avenue.gineering and on the university graduate council.

description: The city whose hectic rhythms and melancholy sophistication he caught in scores of compositions said farewell to. Duke Ellington yesterday.

Rochford named three lawyers today to head a new office of professional standards designed to polish the tarnished image of Chicagq's police. The office is to investigate charges of brutality, corruption and other wrongdoings. by the city's 13,000 police officers.

description: LISBON, May 28More Portuguese workers went on strike today undeterred by warnings from military and civilian political leaders.

description: The superintendent of Comnun ity School District 9 in the Bronx refused yesterday to allow a Board of Education representative to observe the] district's factfinding inquiry into corporal punishment at the Jordan L. Mott Junior High (School 22.

description: The Dalkon Shield, a widely preScribed type of intrauterine) contraceptive device (IUD), has been implicated by its manufacturer in the deaths of four woriien who became pregnant while wearing the device and suffered septic spontaneous abortions in the second threemonth period of pregnancy. Thirtytwo other women suffered similar septic abortions, but did not die.

description: ALBANY, May 28Governor Wilson announced today that he had signed a bill that provides $8.2million in state aid to nonpublic schools to reimburse them for the costs of providing services mandated by the state.

description: In a farreaching decision, State Supreme Court Justice Bdton B. Roberts yesterday found that the Uniformed Firer fighters Association, and by ex: tension the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, could be prosecuted under the *state's criminal statutes for any strike that placed the city's residents in imminent peril.

title: State Parole Of Enters a Guilty Plea On Bribery Charge
description: Gene Squitieri, described the Bronx District Attorney's office as the huh of an leged paroleforsale scheme, pleaded guilty yesterday State Supreme Court, Bronx, to bribereceiving, felony.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27 (AP)Sanya Dharmasakti was named to succeed himself as Premier today in a royal decree, ending seven days of political crisis.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 28Dr. L. S. Wolfe, the father of William L. Wolfe, one of six members of the Symbionese Liberation Army who died in shootut and fire in South Los Angeles two weeks ago, arrived here today and said he would insist thatthe Los Angeles coroner conduct a public inquest into his son's death.

description: The collapse of Northern Ireland's fivemonthold moderate provisional government is a triumph for the Protestant extremistsand for their temporarily quiescent Catholic counterpartsthat spells almost certain tragedy for Ulster.

title: LOBBYIST GUILTY IN CAMPAIGN GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The former Washington representative of a small milk producers cooperative pleaded guilty today to charges of aiding and abetting the cooperative's former president in making an illegal $50,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Nixon Asks Health Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May28 (UPI)  President Nixon asked Congress today to vote an addition$10million for the Health; Education and Welfare Depark meat budget this year for spending on social and rehalbilitation services, The budget !director, Roy L, Ash, making the request for Mr. Nixon, said the increase would raise H,E,W, spending in this area to $680million, the maximum authorized under previous legislation..

title: Mrs. Sage Posts 77 To Lead by Stroke
U.S.Soviet Nuclear Arms Race
description: The defense establishment and the scientific community are increasingly involved in a sharp debate over whether the Soviet Union is about to surpass the United States in some areas of strategic nuclear weaponry. The central issue is whether the Russians, since the conclusion in 1972 of thit, bilateral agreement on limitation of strategic armaments, have increased the throw weight of their intercontinental ballistic missiles, or ICBM's, to 10 million to 12 million pounds compared with two million pounds for those of the United States.

title: 3 Lebanese. Hurt in Blast At U.S. Center in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28An explosion in the reading room of the John F. Kennedy American Center here injured three Lebanese today.

title: Phillips Will End 2 Joint Ventures With Japanese
description: Because of a divergence objectives, the Phillips Petro leum Company announced plan: yesterday to sell its share it two joint ventures with Shows Denko KK, a Japanese com pany, and thus withdraw from petrochemical manufacturing in Japan. Phillips said that a Phillips sub. sidiary would continue as export sales agent for the twc Japanese ventures until at least 1977.

title: Congress on Its Own
description: President Nixon is making a persistent, determined effort to delay the House impeachment inquiry and the sppcial prosecutor's multiple investigations. Rightly wrongly, he believes that time is on his side. He has boldly asserted that he will provide no further evidence to the House Judiciary Committee, no matter how many subpoenas it may issue. With regard to Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski, he has adopted the more subtle strategy of insisting that Mr. Jaworski has no legal standing to subpoena evidence in the President's possession.

title: Marcor Dividend Increase
description: The directors of Marcor, Inc., announced yesterday that its dividend would be increased to 25 cents per common share from 22 cents.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For a Safe City: Insure Prompt Justice

title: Diverse Groups Join Here To Promote Construction's
description: Stating that the construction industry in New York City is depressed to the point of crisis, architects, builders, bankers and representatives of the building trades unions have joined together to seek city help in stimulating increased building activity.

title: Sutton Urges Creation of Office To Handle Waterfront Planning
description: The creation of a city of waterfront planning and velopment to integrate and tie together all the competing needs for waterfront space was recommended yesterday by Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan.

title: CHICAGO FACES TRIAL IN BIAS.SUIT BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The Justice Department said today that It had filed suit against the city of Chicago, accusing it of violating civil rights laws in the use of Federal revenuesharing funds.

title: Portuguese Blame Whites in Angola For Racial Unrest
description: LUANDA. Angola, May 28The military command for Angola is deeply concerned over growing racial tension in Luanda, the capital, and believes white agitators to be mainly responsible,

title: NEW RAIL PROPOSAL IS OPPOSED BY BANKS
description: The company scheduled to take over the operation of several bankrupt Northeast railroads probably would run out of money shortly after it began operations, the First National City Bank has charged in court papers filed recently.

title: Music: Happy Marriage
description: The Metropolitan Opera led with one of its trump cards in beginning its June Festival Monday night with Les Contes d'Hoffmann. Few productions of recent seasons have worked so well on so many levels as this rethinking of the Offenbach score by Richard Bonynge, the night's conductor. Hoffmann was never produced in the composer's lifetime and exists in no definitive version, so the opera has traditionally been fair game for every sort of editor, both musical and theatrical.

title: Kissinger, Shifting Plans, Visits Syria Once More
FRANK W. HYMAN
description: Frank W. Hyman, president of Avery Macey International Corporation and a pioneer in the rotogravure printing process in this country, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 25 East 77th Street.

title: Paris: Dangers of Museum Bigness
description: PARISOne of the ultimate acts of the Messmer Government was to give Georges Pompidou's name to the huge cultural agglomeration, known as the Beaubourg Center, which the late President of the French Republic intended to stand as the monument to his term in office.

title: Transcripts Vex Graham, But He Stands by Nixon,
description: The Rev. Billy Graham has called his reading of the transcripts of PreSident Nixon's Watergate conversations a profoundly disturbing and disappointing experience but added that, as Mr. Nixon's friend, he had no intention of forsaking him now.

title: Kissinger, Shifting Plans, Visits Syria Once More
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, May 29Secretary of State Kissin, ger unexpectedly flew to Damascus last night in an attempt to resolve the very, very few problems holding up a troopseparation agreement on the Golan Heights.

title: An Italian Vice Consulate Is Established in Newark
description: NEWARK, May 28The Consul General of Italy in New York established a vice consulate here today to serve 345,000 Italian citizens and ItalianAmericans living in eight northern New Jersey counties.

title: Merger Proxy Material Set
description: The Pacific and Southern Broadcasting Co., Inc., and the Combined Communications Corporation announced yesterday that they had filed preliminary proxy material with the Securities & Exchange Commission. The material relates to second meetings of stockholders of the two companies to consider the merger agreement signed in April, 1973, between the two companies.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company said yesterday it had won a $60million contract to supply 1.26millionkilowatt nuclear steam system and its fuel for the Portland General Electric Company. This would be a duplicate of one the utility bought in 1973. Both units will be located at a site near Arlington, Ore.

title: House Unit Drafting Letter Warning Nixon on Stance
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee are drafting letter warning President Nixon that his refusal to honor impeachment inquiry subpoenas risks the eventual conclusion that the President is withholding incriminating evidence.

title: JUSTICES WILL GET WHITE HOUSE VIEW ON BID FOR TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The Supreme Court announced today that President Nixon's lawyer had agreed to respond within the next two days to the request by the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, for an immediate ruling by the high court on his right to obtain more White House tape recordings.

title: Japan Indicts Oilmen
description: The Petroleum Association of Japan, 12 oil companies and 17 senior oil executives have been indicted in Tokyo on charges of conspiracy to fix prices and to control refinery production during 1973. Details on Page 55.

title: Archie Cox In Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 28When President Nixon dismissed Archibald Cox as his special prosecutor in the Watergate case, he not only misjudged the public outcry that followed but liberated Mr. Cox to speak out on the rules of law and impeachment. This may very well prove to be one of Mr, Nixon's fatal mistakes.

title: 300Foot Banana Split
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 28(UPDSeveral hundred youngsters here have consumed a 300 foot long banana split, served up in a plasticcovered rain gutter. Members of the Spokane Baptist Temple prepared the super split over the weekend with 60 gallons of vanilla, strawberry and chocolate ice cream, 80 pounds of bananas, four large cans of chocolate syrup and 24 cans of whipped cream.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The body of Edward Diggles of 24 Derry Gaily Circle, who disappeared last Friday as he was finishing his newspaperdelivery route here, was found yesterday in Rickabear Lake, about two miles south of Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Scientist Denies Cancer Research Fraud
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 28Dr. William T. Summerlin, the physicianscientist at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center who was found last week by an inhouse review committee to have falsified and misrepresented research findings, said today that, although he had darkened the skin of mice with a pen, he had not faked any results or consciously reported untrue findings.

title: Met Would Discuss Return.of Hoard
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has offered to discuss restitution of a collection of early Greek gold and silver objects that a Turkish official charges were smuggled out of his country, if it can be shown within a reasonable doubt that the objects indeed were illegally removed.

title: Sports News. Briefs Gordie Howe Voted Top W.H.A. Player
description: TORONTO, May 28 (AP) Gordie Howe, 46 years old, was voted the World Hockey Association's most valuable player for the 1973.74 season, the league president, Dennis Murphy. announced tonight. Howe, who finished third in regularseason scoring with 31 goals and 69 assists, drew 135 points in the voting, 49 more than Mike Walton of the Minnesota Fighting Saints, who won the scoring title.

title: ExLegislator Indicted With 5 as Auto Thief
description: Former Assemblyman Joseph A. Fusco, a Bronx Republican, was charged with five other men in a Federal indictment yesterday with stealing Cadillacs and delivering them to customers in Florida and Pennsylvania.

title: KIICHIRO SATOH DIES; MITSUI EXECUTIVE, 80

description: Charles H. Smith, former general manager of the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation and owner of the Central Cadillac automobile agency in Newark died Saturday in Good Samaritan Hospital, Palm Beach, Fla. He was 64 years old.

description: TOKYO, May 28The Petroleum Association of Japan, 12 oil companies and 17 senior oil executives were indicted here today on charges of conspiracy to fix prices and to control refinery production during 1973.

title: RECEIVERSHIP BID IS MADE FOR CHAIN

description: TRENTON, May 28 (UPI)Jury selection began today in the briberyconspiracy trial of Joseph M. McCrane Jr., the former New Jersey State Treasurer accused of using $6million in treasury funds to influence a bank.

description: Manager Bill Virdon made the move last night, moving only Bobby Murcer and Elliott Maddox seemed to care. Virdon, however, made another move in the 10th inning and it instantly became more controversial.

title: Westchester Man Is Accused in Killing
description: A Westchester man who was portrayed as depressed and unable to accept the fact of his yeprold divorce was accused yesterday of murdering his Wife's friend, a 30yearold Woman, in his former Chappatqua, N. Y., home.

title: Redrawing the Lines..
description: The State Legislature meets in special session today to fulfill a Federal mandate to redraw Congressional district lines in Brooklyn and Manhattan amid the usual charges of favoritism and bias and of collusion among political leaders of both major parties. In seeking to satisfy Justice Department demands, to provide fairer opportunities for grossly underrepresented minority groups, it is alleged that regislative mapmakers have deliberately gerrymandered at the expense of lawmakers who happen to be out of favor with local leaders of the Democratic party.

title: Bridge World Team Championship Won Again by Italian Team
description: VENICE, Italy, May 28The great Italian team won the world team championship here this afternoon, its 15th victory since 1957, but only after the American Aces gave them a considerable fright,

description: NEW DELHI, May 28The head of the All India Railwaymen's Federation was released from prison today as rail services around the nation slowly returhed to normal.

title: WILLIAM RICHARDSON JR.
description: William McLemore Richardson Jr., executive vice president of Young & Rubicam, Inc., advertising agency, at his retirement in 1971, died yesterday, apparenty of a heart attack, at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 60 years old.

description: Eugene T. Gunn, president of Gene T. Gunn Company, an insurance and realestate brokerage concern here, died of a heart attack yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital, He was 71 years old and lived at 25 Interlaken Drive, Eastchester, N.Y.

description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) The Senate voted today to provide its special Watergate committee an additional $200,000, bringing the total funds alloted Ithe panel so far to $2million.

title: RENTBILL TALKS STALL IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 28  Delicate negotiations intended to revive the New York City rentcontrol issue for the special legislative session, recessed inconclusively this evening with some participants saying success was likely but others terming a chance of success only fiftyfifty.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: W.H.A. Crusaders Name Hanna Coach
description: CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) John Hanna, 39 years old, was named coach of the Cleveland Crusaders of the World Hockey Association today. Last season he piloted Jacksonville of the American League, the Crusaders farm team.

title: HIGH COURT CURBS SUITS ON BEHALF OF LARGE GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 The Supreme Court ruled today that a class action on behalf of a large group of people must be thrown out of court unless all those people who can be identified receive notice, of the lawsuit and the person who brings it pays for that notice.

title: Nigerian Chief Leaves Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 28 (UPI)Gen, Yalcubu Gowan, the Nigerian chief of state, left. for homel today after an official visit toi the Soviet Union, the press agency Tess reported. General, Gowon left from Thilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia.

title: GOLD PRICE SLUMPS TO A 3MONTH LOW
description: BRUSSELS, May 28 (UPI)The price of gold dropped today to a threemonth low while the dollar moved erratically on European money markets but generally held its own.

title: Jane Pittman Wins Emmy for the Best Program
description: The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman, the twohour drama of a woman born in slavery who survives to see the unfurling of the modren civil rights movement, won the televisibn Emmy award last night as the best special program of theyear.

title: High Court Will Review Policy On Broadcast of Lottery Data
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The Supreme Court today agreed to review a court decision allowing radio and television stations to broadcast the winning numbers in the New Jersey state lottery.

title: France's New Spokesman Abroad
Merger of Hayden Stone And Shearson Discussed
description: Hayden Stone, Inc., and Shearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., two of Wall Street's bigger investment banking and brokerage houses, confirmed persistent rumors yesterday that they were talking merger. The combined firm, the parties estimated, would be the fifth largest in the industry.

title: Braves Defeat Phils, 21, On Aaron's Clout in 10th
description: Henry Aaron of Atlanta, the career homerun leader, smacked his 722d regular season homer in the 10th inning last night to give the Braves a 21 victory over the visiting Philadelphia Phillies and now needs only one more to pass Babe Ruth.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: ARMED SERVICES Affirmed a decision that members of the armed forces reserves qualify for readjustment pay after five years of active duty, not four and a half (No. 73604, Cass v. United States). Dissenting: Douglas.

title: Boyd Named No. 3 By U.S. Attorney; Korman to Be No. 2
description: Edward J. Boyd 5th, who had actively sought appointment as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, will become the No. 3 man in that office, it was announced yesterday.

title: Computer Helps Chimpannzees Learn To Read, Write and Talk  to Humans
description: Timothy Gill peered into a Plexiglas room where a chimpanzee named Lana lives with a computer console. Lana pushed a series of symbolcoded buttons on the console and, outside her room, the computer typed out a translation of the symbols. Please Tim move into room.

title: Reds Defeat Mets by 72 For Kirby
Field of 12 Expected in The Belmont
Advertising: News Magazines
description: One of the moves U. S. News & World Report is making in hopes of getting onethird of all ad pages being placed in newsmagazine (to which it feels entitled) is to restructure the sales department. From now on sales personnel will be assigned accounts by product category so that they can build up expertise in a certain area.

title: Pentagon Seeks Pups But Bars Gas Tests
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)The Pentagon wants 450 more beagle pups but says they will not be used to test nerve gas.

title: Feuding of Radicals Shocks the Japanese
description: TOKYO, May 28  Before dawn one recent morning, a dozen young Japanese radicals burst into a suburban rooming house where two leaders from a rival extremist faction were sleeping and beat them say, agely with axes and metal pipes.

title: Books of The Times
description: Three years ago, in Beyond Freedom and Dignity, the noted behavioral psychologist B. F. Skinner attempted nothing less than to deprive theoretical man of the freedom of his will and the dignity of his autonomy. Now, for all those readers who were enraged by this exercise (and in the din that greeted Beyond Freedom and Dignay you coma hear more cries of rage than songs of praise) Dr. Skinner has tried to provide an antidote. In his compact and modestly titled new book, About Behaviorism, he has begun by listing the 20 most salient objections to behaviorism or the science of behavior, and he has gone on to answer them both implicitly and explicitly. The result sets off few fireworks this time. Dr. Skinner has gone on the defensive, it seems. He has answers and explanations for everyone.

title: Production of Steel Fell By 1.1% During the Week
The Chinese Firmament
description: PARISThe old Byzantine game in which observers measure the relative importance of Soviet leaders by respective positions of their photographs on public display or their listing in official state communiqus is kindergarten stuff when compared with analysis of similar formal hints in China.

title: Rebozo Reportedly Paid. $12,000 on Nixon House
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)Jack Anderson, the columnist, reported today that Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, paid for nearly $12 000 in improvements at the President's house in Key Biscayne, Fla., in 1969.

title: Uniroyal Unit Expanding
description: The Uniroyal Chemical division of Uniroyal, Inc., said yesterday that it would build a new, fine organic chemicals plant at Naugatuck, Conn., at an overall cost of approximately $5million.

title: Parley Spurs New Plan On Justice for Juveniles
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 28 Many of the state's leading juvenile authorities met at Rutgers University here today to discuss ways of developing increased cooperation in the administration of the state's new system of juvenile justice.

title: In Defense of Silbert: A Look at the Record
description: WASHINGTONNormally, the nomination of Earl J. Silbert to be United States Attorney for the District of Columbia would be a matter of only local interest. But inasmuch as Mr. Silbert was head of the original Watergate prosecution team before the appointment of Archibald Cox as special prosecutor, his nomination has been caught up in the intense controversy surrounding every aspect of the Watergate affair.

title: CANADA IS PRESSING FOR NUCLEAR CURBS
description: OTTAWA, May 28Canada is pressing very actively for interoational action to prevent any further spread of the capability to manufacture nuclear weapons, a spokesman for ,the Ministry of External Affairs said today.

title: Oil Depletion Test Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) The House Rules Committee has postponed for a week a showdown over allowing a vote on the floor on A proposal to abolish the oil depletion allowance. Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committtee, asked to the delay, The Rules Committee decides which bills reach the House floor and if they may be amended.

title: Nastase, Borg Gain At Rome Net
description: ROME, May 28 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated Martin Mulligan of Italy, 64, 57, 62, today and Bjorn Borg of Sweden beat France's Patrice Dominguez, 62, 75, in firstround play at the 31st Italian open tennis tournament.

title: Sutton and Wright Say Districting Plan Is Possibly Harmful
description: ALBANY, MAY 28Two of the leading black elected officials of New York City today called on the Justice Department to reject the proposed new Congressional and legislative district lines on the ground that although they favor minorities on paper, they are likely to hindernot enhance  minority representation.

title: Watergate Stirs New Look At Lawyers SelfPolicing
Monetary Strong Man
description: With the imminent departure of Paul A. Volcker from his post as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, the Nixon Administration loses the last of its economic strong mennot counting Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who (though a Nixon appointee) cherishes the Fed's vaunted independence. Economic Analysis

title: INFLATION REPORTED HIGHEST IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) In an unexpected shift of traditional patterns, Southerners felt inflation more than Americans in any other region of the country last year, according to a study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Sets Lose for 9th Time As Women Falter Again
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 28The New York Sets got into woman trouble again last night, and it cost them a World Team Tennis match with the Los Angeles Strings, the Pacific Division leaders.

title: Prices of Stocks Weaken In Much Slower Trading
Antibody Grown by Scientists in Lab
description: WASHINGTON, May 28For more than a year, scientists have been producing an infectionfighting antibody in a factory of living cells growing in a laboratory.

title: ASTER COALITION RESIGNS AS STRIKE CHOKES ECONOMY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 28The coalition government of Northern Ireland collapsed today, setting off victory celebrations by extremist Protestant groups whose general strike has crippled the economy and interrupted power supplies throughout the province.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS FREIGHTCAR FEE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP] The Supreme Court uphel an Interstate Commerce Corr mission requirement today tha railroads pay additional pe diem charges for freight car belonging to other lines.

title: BRAZIL'S CENSORS SHOW NEW VIGOR
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28 Government censors have moved against the independent Brazilian press with renewed vigor after a brief relaxation of controls.

title: PARTNER OF SHEA RECALLS GUNFIRE
description: The partner of Thomas Shea, the police officer who is accused of murder in the fatal shooting of a 10yearold black boy in a lot in Jamaica, Queens, in April, 1973, testified in Queens Criminal Court yesterday that the boy's stepfather, Add Armstead, had fired at him with a gun Mr. Armstead had taken from the totally wounded boy.

title: Going Out Guide;
description: FREE AND EASY Ordinarily, you would have to sit in a small chair at small table in a smokefilled Greenwich Village night spot, nursing a little alcohol and pay to hear the Thad JonesMel Lewis Orchestra and singer Dee Dee Bridgewater. Tonight, it's going to be free and much more comfortable it can't help but behearing them at the Henry Street Playhouse.

title: ARMIN ST. GEORGE
description: Armin Richard St. George, a lawyer with offices at 773 Park Avenue, died last Thursday while on a business trip in Zurich, Switzerland. He was 45 years old and lived at 40 East 78th St.

title: JOSEPH P. CONWAY OF CONSULTING FIRM
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 28 Joseph P. Conway, president of Joseph P. Conway Associates, a publicrelations consulting concern in Garden City, died last night at his home. He was in his mid50's and lived on Chapel Gate Lane.

title: Red Smith
description: After 12 years in the major leagues I do not feel that I am a piece of property to be bought and sold respective of my wishes. I believe that any system that produces that result violates my basic rights as a citizen and is inconsistent with the laws of the United States and of the several states,

title: Lisbon Speculates About Who Holds Power,
description: LISBON, May 28Many Portuguese, and just about every foreign diplomat in Lisbon, spend a good deal of time these days wondering who holds the actual power in this country.

title: Top Black Businessmen Look at Their Problems and Future
description: The top 100 black businesses were announced yesterday by Black Enterprise magazine and some of their officials came to lunch to talk about their problems and thir promise,

title: 7% RISE IN VOLUME SEEN FOR BIG STORES
description: Ralph Lazarus, chairman of Federated Departments Stores, Inc., the country's largest department store chain, said at the annual meeting in Cincinnati yesterday that the department store industry should achieve a 7 per cent growth in dollar volume this year.

title: Trot Lawyer Cites Tape In Assailing U.S. Charges
IRVING WILCOVE
description: ROCHESTER, May 28 (AP) Irving Wilcove, city editor of The Rochester TimesUnion, died, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 48.

title: Israeli Cabinet Is Named; Dayan and Eban Are Out By TERENCE SMITH
description: JERUSALEM, May 28  Premierdesignate Yitzhak Rabin tonight announced the formation of a new Israeli Cabinet that is expected to be more flexible than the outgoing Government of Premier Golda Meir on reaching an accommodation with Arab countries.

title: 23 Drown in California As Heat Spurs Swimming
description: JOHNSONDALE, Calif., May 28 (UPI)At least 23 persons drowned in California during the long Memorial day weekend, nine of them in a 25mile stretch of the treacherous Kern River near Johnsondale.

title: Smith Aims At Garden Sky Tonight
300 Students Given U.F.T. Scholarships Worth $4,000 Eacl
description: Three hundred college schol arships worth $4,000 each were presented last night by the United Federation of Teachers to graduating seniors represent. ing every one of the city's 99 public high schools.

title: Nixon on Inflation: No Panacea
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The message between the lines of President Nixon's interim economic report to Congress today was that the Government has no quick or painless cure for inflation and that the public had better brace itself for a rough period of persistent inflation and a determined squeeze on nondefense spending. News Analysis

title: Morse Wins 4Way Democratic Primary for Oregon Senate Nomination
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 28 (AP)Former United States Senator Wayne Morse won a fourway primary race for the Democratic senatorial nomination today.

title: WNET Is Cutting 51st State To One Hour a Week Next Fall
description: By LES BROWN

title: Kitty Gordon, Star of 1911 Enchantress, Is Dead
description: Kitty Gordon, the Edwardian beauty for whom Victor Herbert composed The Enchantress, in which she starred here in 1911, died Sunday in the Ross Nursing Home in Brentwood,

title: FIRE UNION CHIEFS MUST STAND TRIAL
description: In a farreaching decision, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday found that the Uniformed Firefighters Association, and by extension the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association; could be prosecuted under the state's criminal statutes for any strike that placed the city's residents) in imminent peril.

title: Atlantic Sheriff Backs Casinos Despite Fears of Rising Crime
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 28The Atlantic County Sheriff said today he believed that casino gambling in this faded resort city would increase the pressure on his already crowded jail.

title: Rhodesia's Prime Minister Off for Talks in South Africa
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 28 (Agence FrancPresse)Prime Minister Ian D, Smith of Rhodesia flew to Pretoria today for urgent talks with the South African Prime Minister, John Vorster, reportedly on the new situation in southern Africa since the military coup in Portugal.

title: Dirtying the Soil
description: When, some 200 years ago, that slightly smelly real estate speculator Daniel Boone slashed his way to the top of Cumberland Gap, he saw, blanketed before him what was probably the largest territorial commons in the history of North America. He stood dumb, it is said, silently dipping into the future far enough to envision those grasslands filled with commerce. The land was called Kentucky.

title: ... More Featherbeds?
description: In a city that has recently come under critical Federal election law scrutiny because of the abominable voting record of three of its five boroughs, it would be folly to ignore the plea of New York's Elections Board officials that they must have more money and more help to perform their job.

title: Insurgent Candidates Lose Challenge to Election Law
description: TRENTON, May 28 (AP)A state appeals court today upheld a law that permits local election officials to place the names of candidates in primaiy elections on separate lines on the ballot.

title: SCENIC RIVER VOTE PERILS POWER DAM
description: WASHINGTON, May 28By a vote of 49 to 19, the Senate approved today a bill to include a stretch of the New River on the North CarolinaViiginia border among the rivers to be studied by the Department of Interior for inclusion in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: For Brandt, It's Back To Hustings
description: HANOVER, West Germany, May 28  Willy Brandt, who resigned as Chancellor of West Germany after an espionage scandal three weeks ago, returned to pitch in for his party in a crucial state election campaign here this week, and the crowd loved it.

title: CON EDISON TO PAY ON ITS PREFERRED
description: The trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company laid to rest yesterday, at least temporarily, fears that the giant utility might have to omit its preferred dividends as it had its common stock payment on April 23.

title: Captain, 33, Dealt for Beverley, 27 a Defenseman
description: Vic Hadfield, the RangerS captain and once Coach Emile Francis's pet player,. was traded before yesterday's midnight deadline for Nick Beverley, a joUrneyman defenseman on the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: SADAT SAYS SOVIET IS PEACE MAINSTAY
description: CAIRO, May 28President Anwar elSadat, in a brief but warm message to Leonid I. Brezhnev, declared today that Egypt continued to regard the friendship of the Soviet Union as a mainstay for peaceloving people.

title: Transcripts Vex Graham, But He Stands by Nixon
description: The Rev. Billy Graham has called his reading of the transcripts of President Nixon's Watergate conversations a profoundly disturbing and disappointing experience but added that, as Mr. Nixon's friend, he had no intention of forsaking him now.

title: More for Recycled Cans
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 28 (AP) The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced today It would raise the price it pays for used aluminum cans for recycling from 10 to 15 cents per pound on June 1,

title: It's Still Called The ColonyBut You Wouldn't Call It Elegant
description: Like the old gray mare, Con Edison and the New York Mets, The Colony restaurant has undergone some radical changes. Frankly, it ain't what it used to be.

title: UrbanLoan Head Named
description: TRENTON, May 28 (AP)George G. Woody Jr., a funeral director from Roselle, was named today to head the'State Urban Loan Authority, which awards grants to minority businessmen, Mr, Woody was Roselle Councilman in 1958 to 1963 and is a member of the advisory board of the Community State Bank and Trust Company of Roselle.

title: SAMUELS PROPOSES CONSUMER OFFICE
description: Howard J. Samuels proposed yesterday the establishment of an office of special state consumer affairs prosecutor with broad powers to initiate civil and criminal actions on behalf of consumers.

title: Rev. Herbert Musurillo Is Dead; Classicist at Fordham Was 56
description: The Rev. Herbert Musurillo, an authority on the writings of early Roman Catholic Church fathers and professor of clas sics at Forclham University since 1963, died Monday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y., of injuries suffered in onecar accident last Wednesday on the Bronx River Park way. He was 56 years old.

title: Notes on People Gov. Sargent. Seeks Reelection
description: Announcing his candidacy for reelection yesterday, Francis W. Sargent, the Republican Governor of Massachusetts, said he would be quite happy to have Vice President Ford campaign for him, but as for President Nixon, I prefer that he didn't.

title: Ballard's Horse Wins In Jumpoff
TieUp on New Haven
description: Commuter service on the Penn Central's New Haven line, was disrupted last evening when a train, broke down near Mount Vernon, causing a shutdown. Page 45.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: A record $200,000 has been paid for a single coin sold at auction here, Benjamin Stack, an auctioneer, said yesterday. The coin was a 1907 ultrahigh relief United States double eagle, a $20 gold. piece of which only 13 or 16 specimens were made, It is about the size of a silver dollar.

title: 500 Attend the Funeral Of a Montclair Official
description: Five hundred town and county officials and friends attended a funeral service in Montclair yesterday for Ambrose R. Durning, treasurer of Montclair, who was shot to death Friday night in an apparent robbery.

title: Chicago Gets Extra FirstRound Pick as Draft Is Held
A FLOW OF RHYTHM AT DONEGAN PIANO
description: Dorothy Donegan, who used to roll out the boogiewoogie at the Embers 10 and 15 years ago, is back in town after long absence, this time at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street. There is still a touch of boogie in her piano playing, but that Is just one element in the wide variety of material with which she fills her fastmoving, hourlong sets.

title: Phone Pact Rejected
description: HONOLULU, May 28  Hawaiian Telephone Company employes, who have been on strike since May 7, rejected proposed 3year contract today and resumed picketing throughout. the state. II was the second time the telephone company workers had rejected ?? part.

title: Striking Musicians In Tentative Accord With 3 Networks
description: The Federation of Musicians said yesterday it had reached a tentative contract agreement with the three major net works, temporarily ending the union's 3week strike.

title: Mr. Passman's Expletives
description: A recent edition of this newspaper carried a threequarterpage advertisement billed as a Nonpartisan Letter to the American People from Otto E. Passman, a veteran Congressman from Louisiana. Essentially, Mr. Passman's message was that Richard Nixon has been great President and that he is being attacked unfairly for precisely that reason. Mr. Passman not only failed to make his case convincingly, but he illserved the entire nation by characterizing Mr. Nixon's opponents as the radical elements in the media, lunatics, liberals, bloodthirsty haters and Communists, who still harbor grudges because of the Hiss case.

title: REA EXPRESS ASKING 10% RATE INCREASE
description: REA Express announced yesterday that it was filing for 10 per cent rate increase on all air express rates, effective June 21. The company provides air freight service to about 22,000 communities in the United States and Canada.

title: About New York The Case of the Missing Dachshund
description: Kenneth Patton, who was the city's Economic Developbent Administrator, bought a dachshund puppy not long ago, and one day last week his son took the dog for a Valk in Prospect Park. When he did, he took the leash off the puppy, whose name was Charlie, and allowed him to run with some other dogs.

title: State Liquor Body Investigates Charge By Jiminy's Patron
description: The State Liquor Authority is looking into charges by Nassau County man that he was; held by two bouncers at Jimmy's restaurant here and puncird by Sid Davidoff, one of the owners and a former adniinittrative assistant to Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: Francis Farrell, 69, Owner Of the Brotherhood Winery
description: Francis Farrell, owner of the Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, N. Y., which was founded in 1839 and claims to be the oldest in the United States, died Monday at his home in Washingtonville. He was 69 years old.

title: F.C.C. LOTTERY RULE FACES COURT REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  The Supreme Court today agreed to review a court decision allowing radio and television stations to broadcast the winning numbers in the New Jersey state lottery.

title: A Researcher, 23, Is Slain In Her East 74th St. Flat
description: A 23yearold library researcher for the Dell Publishing Company was found apparently strangled yesterday in her secondfloor rear apartment 488East 74th Street.

title: Jaworski Seeks Tape Believed to Deal. With I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, asked Federal District Judge John J. Sirica today to turn over portions of key Watergate tape that the judge has withheld from him. Mr. Jaworski argued that these portions might be tied to alleged attempts to abuse and politicize the Internal Revenue Service.

title: People in Sports
description: Bep Guidolin, who resigned as coach of the Boston Bruins Monday, said yesterday he believed Phil Esposito's mind was not on winning during the National Hockey League playoffs.

Junior College; Roy Ehron, forward presently playing for Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association; Greg JackSon, guard, Guilford (N, C.); Terry Mikan, guard, St. Thomas (Minn.); Bill Smith, forward, Mercer (Ga.): Dennis McDermott, forward, St. Francis; Earl Brown, center, Lafayette; John O'Donnell, forward, North Carolina.

title: A Consent Decree With Chicago Board Set on Trust Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent decree today to terminate a civil antitrust suit against the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest commodity exchange.

description: WASHINGTON, May 28The Supreme Court ruled today that a class action on behalf of a large group of people must be thrown out of court unless all those people who can be identified receive notice of the lawsuit and the person who brings it pays for that notice.

title: TWO AT THE PLAZA TIED AND ROBBED
description: Early yesterday morning, a man accompanied a California architect to his room at the Plaza Hotel, then  waving a doubleedge razor bladestole $2,000 and some jewelry from the architect and a second mans who was also staying in they room, tied up the two men and escaned, dressed in the architect's $450 butterscotchcolored suit.

title: Boy Missing Since Friday Drowned in Kinnelon Lake
description: KINNELON, May 28  The body of Edward Diggles of 24 Derry Gaily Circle, who disappeared early last Friday evening as he was finishing his newspaperdelivery route here, was found floating this afternoqn in Rickabear Lake, about two miles south of this borough.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ROCKAWAY, May 28Bobby Fernandez was giving his all last September for Morris Hills High School as defensive back on the football team when tragedy struck. Now, Morris Hills has done something to give it all back to Bobby.

title: Consulate in Newark
description: The Italian Government established a vice consulate in Newark to serve the large number of Italian residents in northern New Jersey. Page 45.

title: Sports New's Briefs
description: TORONTO, May 28 (AP)  Gordie Howe, 46 years old, was voted the World Hockey Association's most valuable player for the 197374 season, the league president, Dennis Murphy, announced tonight. Howe, who finished third regularseason scoring with 31 goals and 69 assists, drew 135 points in the voting, 49 more than Mike Walton of the Minnesota Fighting Saints, who won the scoring title.

title: Murder Evidence Sought in Death of Jersey Bride
description: Conflicting portraits of a fortrier New Jersey woman have emerged from an investigation into her death on Jan. 16 by hitandrun driver in New Orleans, The police suspect that she was murdered.

description: UNITED NATIONS, May 28 (UPI)  The Security Council today approved 140 an agreement between Iran and Iraq to end their border dispute and negotiate a comprehensive peace settlement.

title: Weison's Corp. Files Cliapter XI Petition
description: The Wetson's Corporation of Valley Stream, LI., operator or franchiser of 60 fast food restaurants in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, filed here yesterday under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

description: Kurt Wiese, illustrator and writer of children's books, died Monday at his home in Idell, Kingwood Township near Flemington, N. J. His age was 87.

description: PORTLAND, Me., May 28 (AP)Howard Burdwood Jr., president of the New England Homing Pigeon Combine, says those scarlet birds dropping out of southern Maine skies may have simply run out of gas.

description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 28 Gov. Dale Bumpers defeated Senator W. Fulbright in his bid for nomination to a sixth term in today's Democratic primary.

description: Some school administrators reacted tepidly to the controversial test results released yesterday by the New Jersey State Education Department, with many of them maintaining that the reading and mathematics examinations given to fourthand 12thgraders two years ago have only limited utility.

description: In 1966 Tennessee Williams's Slapstick Tragedy  two odd oneact plays The Mutilated and The Gnadiges Fraulein  survived only one week on Broadway. The second half of that double bill has now been resurrected under the title The Latter Days of a Celebrated Soubrette. This revised and somewhat expanded version (two acts and a little more than one hour of playing time), directed by Luis Lopez Cepero and starring Anne Meacham, is now running at the Central Arts Theater.

description: NEWARK, May 28 (AP)The tobacco heiress Doris Duke, who two months ago evicted an animalresearch project from her Somerset County farm estate, said in court papers today that the team lowed her $2.7million for unpaid loans, supplies, damages, rent and the daily upkeep of 43 cows they left behind.

title: Stewart Alsop
description: The death of Stewart Alsop is a marked loss for the profession of journalism. For nearly thirty years, he covered politics and foreign affairs with acumen, grace and amiable authority founded upon intensive and con. scientious reporting. He may be best known to future readers, however, for his book, Stay of Execution, the extraordinary memoir in which he tells of his encounter with the rare disease to which he finally succumbed. is a classic account of the human spirit under stress, book worthy of the brave and sensitive man who wrote

title: COALITION'S FALL DISMAYS DUBLIN
description: DUBLIN, May 28  Political leadrs in the Republic of Ireland expressed dismay and regret today over the collapse of the powersharing Northern Ireland Executive.

title: MRS. JAMES OCSBURY
description: Mrs. Lucile Becker Ogsbury, a prominent New York and Vermont golfer and the wife  of James B. Ogsbury, a retired radio and television station owner and executive, died of a stroke Monday in a hospital in (Waynesboro. Va. the wes 58 years old and lived in Waynesboro.

title: Nixon Aides Predict Inflation Drop to 7%
description: WASHINGTON May 28 President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers predicted today that the nation's inflation rate, now 12 per cent as measured by the Consumer Price Index, would drop to the neighborhood of 7 per cent by the final quarter of this year.

title: DROP IN GOLD HITS PRICE OF METALS
Tomato Bonanza on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. (UPI)  California tomatogrowers produced 4.8 million tons of canning tomatoes in 1973. This is 80 per cent of the nation's supply and had a value of $199million.

title: 25,000 Stranded After Breakdown on the New Haven
description: Massive disruption of evening commuter service overwhelmed the Penn Central's New Haven line and an estimated total of 25,000 riders last evening when equipment snapped off one of the railroad's newest trains just south of Mount Vernon.

title: JAWORSKI AIDE QUITS IN KLEINDEINST CASE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The lawyer who headed the prosecution of Richard G Kleindienst, the former Afton ney General, has resigned from the staff of Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, because Mr. Kleindienst was allowed to plead guilty to misdemeanor charge.

title: Lloyd to Take the Stand In Hearing on Rothko Art

City Council Election Seen in Jeopardy
description: The chances of Holding year's City Council election have been put in jeopardy by a delay in supplying Washingport ton with racial statistics on the districts, a lawyer for the NAACPLegal Defense and Educational Fund said yeaterday.

title: TIME BOMB KILLS 6 AT RALLY IN ITALY
description: BRESCIA, Italy, May 28A highexplosive time bomb hidden in a plastic garbage bag exploded today, killing six persons and injuring 94 at an antiFascist rally in this industrial town in northern Italy.

title: Rules on NOW Accounts Issued By State Banking Department
description: The New York State Banking Department announced yes. terday the issuance of regulations governing noninterestbearing, nopassbook negotiaable order of wtihdrawal accounts offered recently by several local savings banks.

title: A.E.C. Official Calls Energy Reorganization Only Half the Job'
description: Moves by the Nixon Administration to set up new energy agencies are only half the job of providing the United States with a longterm energy policy, William 0. Doub, a member, of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here yesterday.

title: RAPE IS INDICATED IN A STRANGLING
description: After an autopsy on Anne Berizoheimer, the 23yearold librarian found strangled in her apartment at 488 East 74th Street, Dr. Michael M. Baden, city deputy chief medical examiner, said yesterday, the circumstances speak very strongly of rape.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Democratic Committee is seeking to pay off $300,000 in campaign debts incurred by Governor Byrne and by former Gov. Robert B. Meyner. State Senator James P. Dugan, Democrat of Hudson County and the Democratic state chairman, said the party intended to raise the money through a $110aplate dinner June. 27 in Sea Girt, with Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, as the principal speaker. Governor Byrne has a $126,000 debt from last year's general election. The committee will pay that off, but not an $18,500 debt left over from Mr, Byrne's primary campaign. The state will also pay $175,000 still owed for Mr. Meyner's unsuccessful 1969 campaign against William T. Cahill.

title: ProAm Golf Teams State And Church
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 29When the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham addressed his ball on the first tee today, he brought a new dimension to golf: A gallery marshal called out, Kneel, please!

title: A Sheriff Sees Plot To Kill Him
description: COLUMBIANA, Ala., May 29 Sheriff C. P. Walker of Shelby County arrested seven persons last nighttwo reporters for The Birmingham News, the county probate judge, the county coroner, who is the sheriff's opponent in a runoff election next Tuesday, and three of his campaign workersand charged them with conspiracy to murder or maim him.

title: Possible Accelerator Peril Cited in 441,000 G.M. Cars
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)  Government safety investigators said today that a possible defect in about 441,000 Buick and Cadillac cars could cause the accelerator to jam, creating an unreasonable risk of an accident.

title: Disputing Mr. St. Clair on the Jurisdictional Issue

title: Williams Performs Songs Stunningly In Ailey Program
description: Songs Is a display vehicle that Alvih Ailey unabashedly designed for, the considerable talents of Dudley. Williams. Mr, Williams dances it as if it is the most important piece that he is to do, and it is a measure of his artistry that he almost convinces us that it is. It was stunningly presented for the first time this season at the City Center on Tuesday evening.

title: Intrepid Going East
