title: Fulbrzght Loss May Shift Two Major Senate Posts
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Senator J. W. Fulbright's defeat yesterday in the Arkansas Democratic primary could shuffle next year the leadership of two of the Senate's most important committees  Foreign Relations and Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs.

title: Triumph of Diplomacy...
description: These past 32 days have changed the face of the Middle East. In a mood swinging repeatedly from enthusiasm to neardespair, Secretary of State Kissinger has completed a mission of peace and mediation without parallel in the long history of the ArabIsraeli dispute. When the details of this complex negotiation can be made known, it will doubtless rank as a classic example of diplomatic technique.

title: EXCHANGE BACKS FIXED FLOOR FEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The chairman and three directors of the New York Stock Exchange told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that elimination of fixed rates for floor brokerage would jeopardize the operation of an auction market for equity securities and the availability of capital for industry.

title: Nixon Appoints Scientist
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)  President Nixon has announced the appointment of Dr. Ivar Giaever, a physicist with the General Electric Company in Schnectady, N. Y., to the Committee on the National Medal of Science, which recommends individuals for the award. Dr. Giaever was the 1973 cowinner of the Nobel Prize in Physics.

title: Witness Tells Shea Trial of Shooting Outside Lot
description: A woman who lives near the Queens lot where a 10yearold boy was fatally shot by Police Officer Thomas J. Shea 13 months ago appeared to contradict Officer Shea's account of the incident at his murder trial yesterday.

title: H. S. Keller, Lawyer, Violist In Westchester Symphony

title: Market Place: Stock Outlook For Winnebago
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's peace mission in the Middle East lends new substance to the Federal Energy Office's assurances that there will be enough gasoline this summer for vacationers, even for drivers of motor homes. That, apparently, figured in the announcement by the General Motors Corporation yesterday that the company would resume production of motor homes in July, a month earlier than planned and five months after production halted.

title: Malaysia's New Pekin Ties: Neighbors Expected to Follow Suit Gradually

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29Political prisoners continue to disappear in Brazil despite assurances by the new Government headed by Gen. Ernesto Geisel that it will end abuses by the police.

title: Good Conduct Code Is Set by O.E.C.D.
description: PARIS, May 29The major nonCommunist industrial nations, faced with the huge task of financing sharply higher oil payments, are near final agreement on a code to arrest a dangerous slide toward establishment of trade barriers. They are expected to pledge themselves for a period of one year, according to a draft agreement worked out at a ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, to avoid having recourse to unilateral measures... to restrict imports.

description: Capital appropriations of the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers dipped 0.6 per cent in the year's first quarter, the first decline in 11 quarters, the Conference Board reported yesterday in releasing the results of a survey.

title: ...And of a Diplomat
description: Last October this newspaper raised one of many voices critical of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Henry A. Kissinger for his part in the Vietnam negotiations. The dubious effectiveness, of that peace accord, and the cynical bargaining and bombing tactics that led up to did not seem at the time to justify his inclusion in the ranks of such men of peace as Dag Hammarskjold, Ralph Bunche or Albert Schweitzer.

title: GAINESVILLE 8 SUE U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) A $1.2million suit has been filed by seven antiwar veterans and a supporter against Government prosecutors who tried unsuccessfully to convict them of conspiracy to riot at the 1972 Republican National Convention.

title: Australian Voters Backed His Policy, Whitlam Declares
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 29 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said tonight that voters in the midterm election 11 days ago had strongly reaffirmed the program of his Labor party and he declared that the Government would push through controversial legislation blocked by the old Senate.

description: FIRE!!! System for turning in fire alarms  all of this plus scores of famous photographs of New York firefighting action are on view, in the Kodak Photo Gallery.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)  The Government reported today that its indicators of future trends in the economy declined in April, primarily because people are putting in shorter work weeks. The Commerce Department said its composite index of leading business indicators showed a drop of seventenths of 1 per cent from March. It was the first drop since December and the third drop in a year.

description: Nordiska on Fifth Avenue is the kind of place that tempts you to throw out all your old kitchen stuff and start over from scratch.

title: E.P.A. TO CHANCE AUTO FUEL DATA
description: DETROIT, May 29The En. vironmental Protection Agency plans a major revision in the way it reports fuel economy on 1975 cars in the hopes that will, give clearer and more per. tinent information to the average car buyer than in the 1974 model year.

title: New Broom in France
description: President Valry Giscard d'Estaing is setting out by iecessity as well as conviction to move the halfpresilential, halfparliamentary Government of France's Fifth lepublic toward an Americanstyle presidential system. France's new chief of state won office with 50.8 per cent of the popular vote; but in the National Assembly elected last year, his party holds only 11 per cent he seats and his centrist allies another 7 per cent. As result, he has appointed a Cabinet made up primarily of technicians responsive to him rather than a coalition of political leaders responsible to a majority in the Asembly. His strategy is to win parliamentary support by other means.

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 29 (Reuters)Rioting broke out at a South African gold mine and two miners were killed and five injured, the mine's owner said today.

This traffic, says Martin Carr, the producerdirectorwriter; is supported by some of our leading collectors and art dealers and museums.

Sufe,rn's time was 10:14.2, the fastest in New York State this season.

description: BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP)The The Internal Revenue. Service quietly assessed President Nixon a 5 per cent negligence! penalty on his more than $400,000 in back taxes, The Baltimore Sun reports in its Thursday editions.

title: Philip Morris Lifts Payout
description: The board of directors of Philip Morris, Inc., declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on its common stock, which was split 2for1 on April 25 and will be distributed tomorrow. The new dividend rate, equivalent to 40 cents a share before the split, represents an increase from 35 cents. It is payable July 12 to stockholders of record June 17.

title: Turtle Migration Is Linked to Geophysics
description: The remarkable endurance and navigational ability of a particular population of green sea turtle, which migrates annually from grazing waters along the coast of Brazil to its nesting ground on tiny, Ascension Island, 1,200 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean, has long fascinated and puzzled scientists.

title: Soviet Operating Its First MillionKilowatt Reactor
description: The Soviet Union has announced the startup of its first onemillionkilowatt nuclear reactor in a rapidly expanding atomic energy program.

title: House Votes to End Antipoverty Agency
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 The House of Representatives voted today to let the Office of Economic Opportunity die June 30 and to transfer most of its few remaining programs to a new Community Action Admin. istration.

title: Buckley Bids Farewell to Eskimos
description: POINT HOPE, Alaska, May 27With warm affection, Senator James L. Buckley bade farewell today to the Eskimo whaling crew with whom he had spent a week living on the ice of the Chukchi Sea above the Arctic Circle.

title: Nurse Seized in Ethiopia Draws Praise
description: If there is one thing that everybody who knows Deborah Dortzbach is agreed on, it's that the Ethiopian guerrillas picked the right woman when they ab. ducted the 24yearold pregnant New Jersey nurse from a missionary hospital and flew her off in a helicopter to render medical assistance to them.

title: Stock Prices Slump
description: A selloff in the stock market yesterday pushed the DowJones industrial average down 18.93 points, its biggest daily decline, in more than five months. Page 51.

title: Superfecta Case Goes to Jury Today
description: Summations in the conspiracy trial of New York harness drivers drew close to a finish yesterday with the prosecution urging jurors to recognize what is called a mosaic of corruption.

title: 2 Red Cross Planes Ready for Exchange of Prisoners
description: TEL AVIV, May 29 (AP)s The International Red Cross said today that two aircraft were standing by to exchange prisoners taken in the October war between Syria and Israel.

title: Stage: Winning Wildes
description: What do two Off OffBroadway versions of The Importance of Being Ernest and Salome share besides Oscar Wilde? Skill and impact.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Three Lila Acheson Wallace Chairs for distinguished leachers have been established at the Juilliard School. The chairs, the first in Juilliard's history, will be endowed from a special fund that also provides for visiting trusts through the school's Institute of Special Studies.

title: 4 Muslims and Jury Visit Site of 73 Brooklyn Siege
description: Samuel Rosenblum tapped his fingers nervously yesterday as he stood behind the counter at John & Al Sports and looked across at the four black men in Muslim outfits.

title: Impeachment Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, May 29With every passing day, the impeachment proceedings against President Nixon become more intertwined with politicsand as spring passes into summer and summer into fall, the linkage will endure. One of the principal reasons is the timetable. Ever since the House Judiciary Committee began its inquiry, deadlines have been slipping. Originally, the committee hoped to finish its work by April 30; then it began aiming for June 30. Now, although its chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, speaks hopefully about voting by midJuly, other members expect to vote in late July or possibly August.

title: Four Banks Foreclose On a New Office Tower
description: The black 48story skyscraper opened two and a half years ago between 50th and 51st Street on Broadway as one of the initial projects in a revitalization of the Times Square area was acquired yesterday in a foreclosure proceeding by four banks.

title: Morgan Estate's Objets dArt Auctioned
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., May 29A rainy day failed to diminish the ardor of 500 dealers and collectors who bid briskly to day for the contents of Salutation, the stone mansion of Louise C. Morgan, the granddaughterinlaw of J. P. Morgan, the financier.

title: Pirates Feast on Padre Hurling
Butkus Sues Bears for $1.6 Million ,.Charging Breach of Contract
description: Dick Butkus, an allpro linebacker for the Chicago Bears, yesterday sued the National Football League club, for $1.6million, charging breach of contract.

title: A Freedom of Information Bill Signed Into Law by Governor
description: ALBANY, May 29Governor Wilson signed into law today a freedomofinformation bill, which he called a major step forward, not only in this state but also in the nation. The measure requires for the first time that virtually all state and local government records be open to scrutiny by the public and the news media.

title: I.R.S. Held Generally Lax With Presidene's Enemies
description: WASHINGTON, May 29An investigation by the Internal Revenue Service of how it had initially treated persons on the White House enemies list showed more cases where the lax agency had been too lax than the reverse, according to a top official of the agency.

title: 5 G.I.'s Hurt in Racial Clash At Fort Davis in Canal Zone
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 The Department of Defense disclosed today there had been a clash of black and white army enlisted men at Fort Davis in the Panama Canal Zone on May 12 that left five injured.

title: StamfordProducer's New White Way
description: After 40 years in the theater, 26 of them as a producer, Charles Bowden is disillusioned with Broadway. If the ship is foundering, he said, it's wise to say, `Where will the new ship be?'",His answer: Fortyfive minutes from Broadway"in Stamford, Conn.

title: MITCHELL IS CITED IN HOFFA RELEASE
description: MIAMI, May 29John W. Dean 3d has testified that mer Attorney General John MitChell gave him a go to impose a condition on R. Hoffa that would prevent him from seeking the sters union presidency for 10 years in return for release from Federal prison.

title: Pro Fives Slow Gold Flow for Rookies
Rush Sworn as Counselor To President on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Kenneth Rush was sworn in today as the Nixon Administration's chief economic coordinator. Mr. Rush, 64 years old, became a counselor to the President specializing in economic matters.

title: Colt Tickets Go Public
description: BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP)  The public sale of Baltimore Colts seasontickets, something not done since the team's formative years, will begin at 9 A.M. Monday, club officials said today. Only about 36,000 seasontickets for 1974 have been sold by the National Football League, club, as compared with 48,000 last year.

title: Medical Services at Atlantic County Jail Criticized
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 29I A physician who is an elected official and several inmates at the Atlantic County jail today called medical service at the institution inadequate and told of heavy use of tranquilizers to treat inmates.

title: Egyptians Gratified Over the New Pact And Hail Kissinger
description: CAIRO, May 29Egyptian officials expressed gratification today over the conclusion of a disengagement agreement between Israel and Syria and paid tribute to the tenacity, and diplomatic.skills of.. Secretary. of State Kissinger.

title: U.M.W. CITES VOWS TO SHUN DUKE POWER
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)The United Mine Workers union said today it had received pledges from 52 national labor unions and four Major church denominations not to buy Duke Power Company stock to support the union's attempt to unionize a Duk&owned coal mine in eastern Kentucky.

title: Official Comment Withheld
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 29Syrians talked today about military disengagement on the Golan Heights as a development that could lead to real peace for their country, which has lived at war with Israel for 26 years.

title: Court Enjoins the Border Patrol On Use of Highway Checkpoints
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP) A Federal appeals court ruled, yesterday that the Border Patrol's practice of routinely stopping cars at fixed highway checkpoints was unconstitutional.

title: Piers L. S. Diacre, Art Agent, Marries Miss Cynthia Walker
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday afternoon, Miss Cynthia Tilghman Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York, East Hampton, L. I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married to Piers Louis Sunderland Diacre of London, son of Kenneth Diacre de Liancourt of Tryall, Jamaica, W. I., and. Mrs. C. Richard HindsHowell of London.

title: The Meaning of Torture
description: BOSTON, May 29The use of torture as a political instrument is an evil beyond justification or compromise, a practice officially condemned by every civilized society. Yet it goes on, in many places around the world, and arousing people's interest in the subject is singularly difficult. Perhaps we find the reality so unbearable that we turn away rather than contemplate it.

title: Advertising:ExCulverAgencies
description: Just a year ago two brand new agencies joined the mainstream of Madison Avenue with assignments from AlbertoCulver, one of the most volatile of clients.

title: Bridge: Aces Fine Play Frightens Italians Heading to Victory
description: VENICE, Italy, May 29American hopes of defeating the great Italian Blue Team and capturing the world team title were disappointed once again yesterday, but not before the Aces gave their great rivals a considerable fright.

title: Books of The Times
description: Frank Costello and Joey Gallo were both members of the Mafia, the ItalianAmerican syndicate that has dominated organized crime in this country for several decades. There the similarity ends. Costello, a longtime boss of bosses among the crime families of the cartel and an intimate of New York City's highest political leaders, died of natural causes last year at the age of 82. Gallo, a soldier in the Joseph Profaci Brooklyn family, moved up to nearpower after shootouts with the troops of the family's elder statesmen but died in 1972 the way he ascendedfrom an assassin's bullet in an afterhours bistro after nine years in prison at the age of 43.

title: TURKS SEND SHIP TO DISPUTED AREA
description: ATHENS, May 29Greece's armed forces were reportedly placed on alert tonight after Turkey announced that she had sent a research vessel to a disputed area of the Aegean Sea.

title: Son Leads Orchestra Of Ellington
description: Mercer Ellington, the 55yearold son of Duke Ellington, has taken over the leadership of his late father's 17piece band.

title: Mr. Fulbright Loses
description: There has never been a snug fit between J. William Fulbright and the voters of Arkansas whom he has represented in the Senate for thirty yearsand who finally turned away from him in this week's primary.

title: MRS. JAMES CRUMLISH
description: Mrs. Ruth Hardy Crumlish, widow of Judge James C. Crumlish Sr. of the Philadelphia Common Pleas Court, died in Lenox Hill Hospital on Tuesday while visiting a son. She was 84 years old and lived on Schoolhouse Lane in Germantown, Philadelphia.

title: CINCINNATI SUIT ASKS SCHOOL INTEGRATION
description: CINCINNATI, May 29The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the United States District Court here to order the Cincinnati Board of Education to integrate the city's 108 public schools by Sept.

title: Opera: Grand Turande'
description: The Metropolitan Opera performances now in progress are given the heading June Festival, and since most of them are indistinguishable from what we have seen during the regular season, it was good to have Puccini's Turandot turn up Tuesday night. The Metropolitan's production of it is so grand with Cecil Beaton's extravagant designs, that one gets a lift, and festive feeling from looking at it.

title: COURT ORDERS TRIAL OF SUIT ON PRIMARY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)A special Federal court today was ordered convened to decide a suit challenging the California law that gives the winner of a Presidential primary all his party's votes at the national convention.

title: Estimate Board Votes Rezoning, To Preserve Yorkville's Flavor
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday approved a special limited commercial district on 86th Street between Park and First Avenues to encourage and preserve the distinctive character of the Yorkville neighborhood.

title: DEPOSITION USED AGAINST MAHEU
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29Attorneys for Howard Hughes submitted a 1962 deposition today in an effort to cast doubt on the veracity of Robert A. Maheu in his $17.3million defamation suit against the billionaire industrialist.

title: Toasts in Meir Office
House Votes to End Antipoverty Agency
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 The House of Representatives voted today to let the Office of Economic Opportunity die June 30 and to transfer most of its few remaining programs to a new Community Action Admin. istration.

title: WARNINGS PROPOSED ON MICROWAVE OVEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminiistration proposed today permanent warning labels on all microwave ovens but rejected a Consumers Union petition calling for more comprehensive warnings and safety testing.

title: Waldheirn,Welcoming Accord, Says U.N. Is Set to Enforce Its
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29  Secretary General Waldheim, welcoming the new SyrianIsraeli disengagement agreement, said today that he already had begun preparing for the United Nations new role in regard to it.

title: Ervin Criticizes Nixon For Watergate Inaction
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that the bugging scandal would have been over in 10 minutes if President Nixon had quickly questioned his campaign managers after the 1972 breakin at the Democratic offices here.

title: McCrane Offered Bribes, Bank President Testifies
description: TRENTON, May 29A Trenton bank president testified today that he had been offered $6million in state deposits if his bank would invest a like amount in securities with a New York City brokerage concern.

title: A FASTFOOD BAN URGED AT HEARING
description: The growing controversy over fastfood takeout shops in the city was brought out before the Planning Commission yesterday when a score of neighborhood leaders and their elected officials urged tight curbs to keep such establishments out of local shopping areas.

title: CITY WILL RETOP WEST SIDE ROUTE
description: Drivers who have been dodging from pillar to post on the alternative route underneath the elevated West Side Highway since the latter was closed for inspection and repair may have a new twist coming this summer: The city's Transportation Administration plans to resurface the rough roadway under the dilapidated elevated structure from the Battery to about 59th Street.

title: Test Helps Prevent Anesthesia Peril
Jipcho Runs a 3:56.6 Mile, Fastest in Garden History
Muslim Indicted in 1972 Slaying of Police Officer
description: Lewis 17X Dupree, dean of boys at Muhammad's Mosque No. 7 school in Harlem, was indicted yesterday on a charge of murdering Police Officer Philip W. Cardillo during melee and shootout in the temple 25 months ago.

title: Abraham Harmatz of Ratner's Is Dead
description: Abraham Harmatz, owner of Ratner's Dairy Restaurant at 111 Second Avenue, died yesterday, the day after his famous landmark permanently closed its doors.

title: Auto Output Expected To Drop 23.6% in June
description: DETROIT, May 29American auto plants are scheduled to build 705,000 cars in June, down 23.6 per cent from 922,424 in the same month last year and comparing with 726,000 being built this month.

title: Graffiti Bill Cleared
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 29 (UPI)A bill making parents financially responsible up to $2,000 for the graffiti their children scrawl on buildings, restrooms and the like has won final legislative approval and gone to Gov. Ronald Reagan. If signed, the law would also allow judges to require youthful offenders to clean up and repair any damage to property caused by graffiti.

title: Arkansas Giant Killer Dale Leon Bumpers
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 29  Ancestrally, Southerners tend to divide into two types, highlanders and lowlanders. The first are descended from the yeomen farmers who settled the hills and mountains from the southern Appalachians to the Ozarks. The latter sprang from the masters and slaves who tended the plantations of the flatlands and the deltas.

title: A BRIGHT PIANO TONE FROM MISS MEISTER
description: Barbara Meister's piano re cital on Tuesday night at Carnegia Recital Hall went off with remarkable smoothness, but with a lamentable lack of incident. A teacher in Scarsdale, N. Y., and Riverdale, the Bronx, she plays the instrument cleanly and tidily, with a bright tone and light, harpsichordy touch that suited a Haydn Sonata in B minor and Bach's English Suite No. 2 in A minor rather better than it did Berg's Sonata and four Chopin pieces.

title: Hudson Will Serve As an Ecology Lab
description: A project in which the 25,000squaremile Hudson River Basin will serve as an environrmental laboratory to help determine the future quality of life for 20 million people was announced here yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: Morse and Packwood Face Rerun of 68
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 29Oregon Democrats set up yesterday a rerun of the 1968 Senate race when former Senator Wayne Morse was chosen to run in November against Senator Robert W. Packwood, the Republican who ousted him from the Senate in 1968.

title: Wheat Soars on Report of Sales to India
description: Word that India has con. tracted for 3 million tons of American wheatroughly two thirds of this nation's projected carryoversent prices of that grain soaring on Middle Western commodity markets yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS NEW PEACE MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, May 29President Nixon declared today that the SyrianIsraeli troopseparation pact would be followed by further American diplomatic initiatives with all Governments in the area aiming at permanent peace in the Middle East. One of those initiatives will be his. own swing through the region, expected to begin in the second week of June.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MAMARONECK, N, Y., May 29Sadists usually work with whips and chains. But for the sadists in the blue blazers of the United States Golf Association, grass and sand are enough. In two weeks, the United States Open championship will return here to the West course of the Winged Foot Golf Club where Bobby Jones won in 1929, three months before Arnold Palmer was born and where Billy Casper won in 1959, three years before Jack Nicklaus turned pro. Because of the history, lore at Winged Foot is as important as fore. By itself, the West course is among golf's outdoor museums. But with the Open approaching, the U.S.G.A. has turned it into a torture chamber of grass and sand. Grass so high and hostile that it has flogged several wanderers. Sand vast that a camel is as necessary as a wedge.

title: Nurse Held in Ethiopia Called Ideal of Compassion
description: If there is one thing that everybody who knows Deborah Dortzbach is agreed on, it's that the Ethiopian guerrillas picked the right woman when they abducted the 24yearold pregnant New Jersey nurse from a missionary hospital and flew her off in a helicopter to render medical assistance to them.

title: Bearne Accepts Award From Watchdog Group, but Not Criticism
description: A civic group that complains annually that the. city budget is permeated with waste and fiscal gimmickry was sharply scolded yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: Gill's Horse Captures Open Jump
SmallBasiness Loans Set at 800BD% by Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it was raising its smallbusiness, lending rate to 81/2 per cent from 8 per cent in response to market conditions.

title: BIRTHCURB GROUT ACTS ON IUD RISI
description: Planned Parenthood's natior al medical committee directe its 700 affiliated clinics terday to call in all patient using a Dalkon shield intra uterine device, warn them a pdtential risk to their health if they become pregnant an often ,them a substitute contra ceptive.

title: Gulf Western Net Up
DOLLAR SHOWS GAIN IN MOST OF EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS, May 39 (UPI)The dollar gained today on most European money markets. Gold prices on London bullion exchanges stayed above yesterday's threemonth low of $156 an ounce.

title: Realty Trusts in a Profit Bind
description: Last week Justice Mortgage Investors of Dallas, a real estate investment trust, announced that it had placed a total of 11 loans worth $7.9million in its nonearning assets category.

title: Roberts Scott, San Diego Firm, Plans to Close All lts 21 Offices
description: SAN DIEGO, May 29Roberts Scott & Co., Inc., the only San Diegobased member of the New York and American stock exchanges, announced today that it was going out of business and would close all its 21 brokerage offices in California and Arizona because of the uncertainty of the general economy and the continuing decline in the securities market.

title: Friend Now Calls Miss Hearst Loyal To S.L.A. Captors
description: Steven A. Weed, who was engaged to marry Patricia Hearst before her abduction in February, said last night that he was now convinced of Miss Hearst's loyalty to her captors and that she had probably not been coerced into joining their cause.

title: IMPACT OF RULING BY COURT STUDIED
Police Joggers Set Record
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29 (UPI) A 13 man team of Los Angeles policemen jogged into Carson City, Nev., yesterday and claimed a new crosscountry running record. A police spokesman said the team had reached Carson City 18 days after leaving Washington, D. C., a distance of nearly 3,400 miles.

title: Belsen Inmate Wants Ordeal Kept Vivid
description: There was once in Israel survivor of a Nazi concentration camp who was filled with selfpity. One day, friend who wanted to help him, took him to a newspaper vender in Tel Aviv.

title: PRISONER ACCUSED OF KILLING WOMAN
description: CAMDEN, May 29 (AP)A prisoner in Camden County Jail was charged today with the murder of a court clerk, the mother of nine, who was shot to death through a window of her home last Jan. 31.

title: 4 in Governor Race Score Mental Health Program
description: The four Democratic candidates for Governor assailed the state's mental health program yesterday, using such words as fraud, and disgrace as they blamed both Governor Wilson and former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: RONCALLO TO ENTER RACE FOR A 2D TERM
description: MINEOLA, L,L, May 29Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, who was acquitted two weeks ago of Federal charges of conspiracy and extortion, plans to announce next Monday that he will seek a second term in the Third Congressional DiStrict.

title: Levine, Producer, Quits as President Of Avco Embassy
description: Joseph E. Levine, the movie producerdistributor, yesterday announced his resignation as president of Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation, effective June 30, and said he would become an independent producer. He will be succeeded by William E. Chaikin, Avco Embassy's vice president and director of West Coast operations.

title: City Enters the SchoolPaddling Inquiry
description: The city's Department of Investigation disclosed yesterday that it was looking into the situation at the Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22 in the Bronx where teachers and students have charged that youngsters were punished with beatings.

title: On Essays
description: WASHINGTONNothing much is going to happen in June.

title: JAPANESE ANALYST SEES OIL PRICE RISING
description: TOKYO, May 29.A Japanese Government oil specialist predicted today that, contrary to some views in the United States and Western Europe, the price of oil would continue to rise in the near future.

title: ZOLTAN KOMOCSIN HUNGARIAN AIDE
description: BUDAPEST, May 29 (Reuters) Zoltan Komocsin, a leader in the Hungarian Communist party, died yesterday at the age of 51, the official press agency, M.T.I., reported.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PROVO, Utah, May 29 (UPI)Coach John Wooden the University of California, Los Angeles, flew here today for the third time this year, and signed Provo High's 6foot11inch center, Brett Vroman, one of the outstanding schoolboy players in the nation. This is the first time I've ever made three trips just to sign one player to a letter intent, Wooden said. It usually only takes one visit.

title: Amendments to Rent Bill Are Submitted by Wilson
description: ALBANY, Thursday, May 30 With some legislators already heading for home in the belief that the session was over, Governor Wilson early this morning suddenly submitted to the Legislature amendments to the recently passed rent control bill that provide some limited new protections for tenants but give landlords new powers as well.

title: R. M. FEATHERSTONE; PHARMACOLOGIST, 59
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2C. (AP)  Dr. Robert M. Feather stone, chairman of the depart ment of pharmacology at the University of California's San Francisco Medical Center for 16 years, died in Geneva, the university said yesterday. He was 59 years old.

title: Bridge Funds Sought
description: The trustees of the Pent Central Railroad reported mas sive deficits yesterday for till month of April and the firs four months this year. At the same time, they applied to the Federal Railroad Administra tion for a $1.755million ad. vance to help defray the cost of repairing, improving and maintaining the old New Haven Railroad bridge across the Hudson River at Poughkeepsie,

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: F.Y.I. Three restaurants the Brasserie, 100 East 53d Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues; Mama Leone's, 2.39 West 48th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, and the Promenade Cafe, in Rockefeller Plaza, between 49th and 50th Streets offer a 10 per cent discount to patrons on Sunday . if you present for inspection a Metropolitan Transit Authority halffare ticket. The tickets, which allow riders two subway or bus rides for the price of one, are issued only on Sundays and holidays.

title: U.S. Mediators Enter Clothing Union Talks
description: Federal mediators stepped into the sluggish negotiations between clothing workers and manufacturers yesterday in an effort to avert a nationwide strike of 110,000 clothing workers set for midnight tonight.

title: Civic Safeguard
description: A powerful new instrument of community protection against lifeendangering strikes in essential public services will be established if the higher courts sustain ruling by State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts.

title: Cox Warns of PoliticalAcademic Ties
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 30 Archibald Cox, the Harvard law professor and former special Watergate prosecutor, told 7,000 Rutgers University graduates, faculty members and friends today that allconsuming ties between government and universities posed the chief threat to the pursuit of academic truth.

title: U.S. Educational Satellite in Orbital Station
description: The United States launched its $111million Applications Technology Satellite yesterday, and successfully placed the most complex and powerful communications satellite yet built onto an orbital station 22,300 miles above the equatorial Galapagos Islands in the Eastern Pacific.

title: INTERSTATE STORES RESISTS S.E.C. PLAN
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., is resisting efforts by the Securities and Exchange Commission and by some large creditors of the bankrupt retail chain to switch if from Chapter XI to Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Court Bars Church From Posting Bail For Murder Suspect
description: The effort of a Harlem church to guarantee $100,000 bail for a murdercase defendant was rejected yesterday in State Supreme Court after an unusual challenge by the Bronx District Attorney.

title: 2 Tennis Players Sue French Group
description: PARIS, May 30 (UPI) Lawyers for Evonne Goolagong and Jimmy Connors have brought a civil action against the French Tennis Federation demanding that the two players be allowed to participate in the French open championships that start Monday, court officials said today.

title: School in Soviet Union Making Waves in World of Swimming
description: FRUNZE, U.S.S.R.In a decade or so, the world champion swimmers from America and Australia may wake up one day to find their supremacy unexpectedly challenged by some unknowns from the Frunze agricultural machinery plant out here in Soviet Central Asia.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters)Americancontrolled multinational corporations won a reprieve today from a House Ways and Means Committee staff proposal to require them to return 50 per cent of their foreign earnings to the United States annually for tax purposes. le committee's chairman, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, told newsmen that the proposal posed so many technical drafting problems that the committee would be unable to include it in its taxreform package this year.

title: 2 SINGERS PRESENT A BAROQUE EVENING
description: Concerts of Baroque music for solo voices are all too infrequent, considering the wealth of material. from this era. Mary Beth Armes,,soprano, and John Williams, countertenor, assembled a splendid representative prpgram in Carnegie Recital pall on Wednesday night, a tell ing reminder that the human voice was regarded as the supreme instrument by 17thcentury composers.

title: About New York What Makes Manes Run?
description: At first, the question was, is he serious? This was because the borough presidency of Queens is not usually considered a place from which Governors spring and because no one had seem to think of him as a Governor before. Then, Donald R. Manes, the Borough President, became annoyed, and finally even angry. He said he was absolutely serious about running for Governor and he said he could win, too.

title: SESSION ADJOURNS AS WILSON LOSES RENTIAW BATTLE
description: ALBANY, May 30The Republicancontrolled State Assembly today refused an urgent request from Governor Wilson to amend the new rentcontrol law as its leaders adjourned a twoday special session without allowing the Governor's amendments to come to a vote.

title: The Losing Gamble
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandA contradiction was built into the very idea of a powersharing government by a coalition of Northern Ireland's Protestant and Catholic political forces. Any such groups willing to form a powersharing coalition probably could never command enough popular support to govern; while groups with broadbased political appeal are too nearly at opposite extremes to join in a coalition.

title: A.T.&T. Ends Pay Inequity For Managerial Employes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to give back pay and future pay adjustments totaling $30million to 25,000 of its managerial employes who have suffered discrimination in pay.

title: Books of The Times
description: LADIES AND GENTLEMENLENNY BRUCE!! By Albert Goldman From The Journalism of Lawrence Schiller. 565 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $10.

title: Starving Children and the Catholic Church
description: WASHINGTONSome ten million children throughout the world are starving. And 400 million to 500 million are suffering from severe malnutrition in Bangladesh, India, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Chad, Upper Volta, Ethiopia, Senegal and Bolivia, according to the United Nations Children's Fund. Henry R. Labouisse, the Fund's executive director, is agonizing over the impending need to declare a world emergency.

title: Massena Votes Bond ISS?? To Purchase Power System
description: MASSENA, N. Y., May 30The Town of Massena today approved by almost 2 to 1 a bond issue of $4.5million to buy and operate a municipal electricpower system.

title: Study of Ozone Challenges U.S. AirPollution Theory
description: NEWARK, May 30The Federal Government's theory of reducing air pollution primarily by cutting automotive traffic was challenged here today in an areawide study that found levels of ozoneone of the chief components of smoghigher when fewer cars were on the road.

title: ...and on Rents
description: The image of Malcolm Wilson as an unflappable Governor wellversed in dealing with the Legislature has been badly dented by the mess he has made of rent control in both the regular and the special session.

title: Israel Counts on U.S. To Bar U.N. Sanctions
description: JERUSALEM, May 30Premier Golda Meir said today that the United States had privately assured Israel that it would condone and politically support antiguerrilla actions taken by Israel in selfdefense.

title: President Asks High Court To Delay Action on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Nixon's lawyers urged the Supreme Court today not to rush to judgment by agreeing to review on an accelerated basis a ruling that the White House must sur render 64 more tape recordings to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: Advertising: The Tale of Rodney
description: He is the star of a television commercial, a frequent guest on talk shows, has been on the cover of a national magazine and in a movie, mentioned in news magazines, cut a record, presented an Emmy, signed up for a TV series and in July will be 6 years old.

title: Abe Cohen, 76, Managed Shubert Shows on ,Tour
description: Abe Cohen, long an executive of the Shubert theaters organization and a company manager for the Shuberts and independent producers on national tours died Wednesday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 24 West 55th Street.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Sirica Bars Committee Plea for Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Federal District Judge John J. Sirica turned down today a request by the House Judiciary Committee for Watergate recordings, saying that his court would not be dragged into a contest between impeachment investigators and the White House.

title: Cox Says President Could Be Convicted For Refusing Data
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. May 30Archibald Cox, the former special Watergate prosecutor, said today that President Nixon's continued refusal to give the House Judiciary Committee all the material it deemed necessary for its impeachment inquiry would he ground enough for his impeachment by the House and conviction by the Senate.

title: President Asks High Court To Delay Action on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Nixon's lawyers urged the Supreme Court today not to rush to judgment by agreeing to review on an accelerated basis a ruling that the White House must sur render 64 more tape record ings to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor

title: OBSKI OBTAINS TAPE OF KEY TALK
description: The special watergate prosecutor has obtained a tape recording of an April 1973, White The special Watergate prosHouse meeting that investigators say represents a key link! in the coverup in the Watergate bugging cause.

title: Nixon And Fulbright
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The irony of William Fulbright's defeat as Senator from Arkansas is that it happened precisely when he had finally established a close and effective working relationship between the Foreign Relations Committee and the Department of State.

title: Patricia Coffin, Society Writer, Painter and Look Editor, Dies
description: Mrs. Patricia Coffin Lindsay, who as Patricia Coffin was wellknown society and magazine writer in this city, died, apparently of a stroke, in YaleNew Haven Hospital yesterday. She lived in this city and Branford, Conn.

title: Hunter Title Is Taken by CastASpell
Sports News Briefs
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 30 (UPI)The United Statcs national basketball team ended its 23day tour of the Soviet Union and Finland today by soundly defeating the Finns, 11076.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL AS VOLUME DROP
Bank Cool to Plans To Turn Its Interior Into City Landmark
description: Acting under broader jurisdiction powers for the first time, the New York City Landmark Preservation Commission held a public hearing yesterday on its proposal to grant landmark status to the interior as well as the exterior of a notable West Side bank building.

title: Hispanic Queens Political Club Opens
description: A storefront in the Corona section of Queens has become the birthplace of a Democratic club of 300 members who plan to make it the major political voice for some 200,000 Hispanic people in the borough.

title: Kuwait Offering Crude Oil for Direct Foreign Sale
description: BEIRUT, May 30The Government of Kuwait, after nationalizing 60 per cent of the foreignowned Kuwait Oil Company, has come on the market with 1.25 million barrels a day of crude oil for direct sale to foreign customers.

title: Miss Hearst's Presence Felt at Grandfather's Castle
description: SAN SIMEON, Calif., May 30  The tour guide pauses at the foot of a marble stairway leading to the Hearst Cagle and gathers sightseers around her like a mother superior ready to usher a hushed class of novitiates into St. Peter's in Rome. You've heard a lot about the Hearst family in recent days, she says in a confidential tone that assumes her audience knows exactly what she's talking about.

title: A $28,863 Trifecta
description: BUFFALO, May 30  An Unidentified bettor won $28,863 in the 10th race trifecta tonight at Buffalo Raceway when a trio of long shots finiished first, second and third. The 7.28 combination resulted in the largest payoff in history of western New York racing. The winner was Gay Myer, second was Mar Con Kammy and the third horse Was John's Princess.

title: Three Are Appointed To New School Board
description: Mayor Beame yesterday named Dr. Amelia H. Ashe, a school guidance and counseling authority, and Joseph Monserrat as his two atlarge appointees to the new sevenmember Board of Education that will take over on July 1.

title: The Pop Life
description: In those deardead days a few decades back, English and American composers of classical music used to worry about their undue subservience to Continental European composers: Our symphonies sounded German for a while, and later on they sounded French.

title: Stage: Pungent Parable in Storey's In Celebration
A MISTRIAL RULED IN M  CRANE CASE
description: TRENTON, May 30  The bribery and conspiracy trial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. and two other prominent New Jersey Republicans ended in a mistrial today, a day after it started.

title: MUSLIM INDICTMENT ASSAILED AS A PLOT
description: Minister Louis Farrakhan of Muhammad's Mosque No. 7 in Harlem charged yesterday that the indictment of a mosque member on murder charges Wednesday was part of a conspiracy to attack the Muslim movement.

title: Nixon Reportedly Says He Would Quit if Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 UPI)  President Nixon reportedly told a group of conservative Congressmen last night that if I was guilty, I'd get the hell out fast, but I'm not guilty.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS May 30, 1974
PAN AM RANSOMED PILFERED TICKETS
description: Pan American World Airways secretly paid thousands of dollars to an organizedcrime ring to buy hack blank flight tickets stolen from the airline.

title: Mrs. Sage Victor In Long Island Golf
Valiant Bret At 8 to 1 in Realization
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 Bettors with short memories may look over the field for tomorrow's $96,562.50 Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, see an 8.1 morning line on Valiant Bret, and yawn. For among the eight 4yearolds in the race is the imposing Armbro Nesbit, who this year set the track rceord of 1:56 4.5 at Yonkers, and has captured 8 of 11 starts in 1974, including 6 under 2 minutes.

title: Shambles on Districting
description: The controversy surrounding the new Congressional and legislative district lines for Manhattan and Brooklyn that have just been adopted by the special session of the Legislature points up pitfalls in the racial criteria laid down by the Justice Department in ordering reapportionment.

title: GreekTurkish Fight Over Oil Exploring is Termed Unlikely
description: ATHENS, May 30  Diplomats here today minimized the possibility of a confrontation between Greece and Turkey over their rights to explore for oil in the Aegean Sea.

title: Congressional Democrats Policy Vacuum
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans are sounding alarms about a vetoproof Congress, and the Democrats may indeed win the twotoone House margin they are hoping for in November things keep up the way they are. But whether they would know what to do with it is something else. If present performance is any indication, there is no reason to think that policymaking will shift from the White House to Capitol Hill.

title: New Thai Cabinet Reported Set; Less Emphasis Puton Military
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 30  Premier. Sanya Dharmasakti reportedly completed the selection of a new caretaker Cabinet tonight, with a slight emphasis on youthfulness and a deemphasis on military men.

title: Market Basket Cost Up 0.4%, to $59.26
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose fourtenths of 1 per cent last week as the prices for sugar, bananas and other fresh fruits and vegetables began to rise, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: U.S. SAID TO AGREE TO MONITOR ROLE
description: CAIRO, May 30The United States has agreed to conduct reconnaissance flights over the SyrianIsraeli disengagement area in the Golan Heights to monitor the carrying out of the terms of the agreement, a senior American official said today.

title: School Board to Question Employes About Leases
description: The city's Board of Education has prepared a questionnaire to be sent to all its employes who can conceivably have a role in the leasing of property for school use, it board spokesman said last night.

title: CAR PRODUCTION OFF IN THE LATEST WEEK
description: DETROIT, May 30Newcar production fell 12.3 per cent this week from last week's level because of the Memorial Day holiday, according to the !trade newspaper Automotiv7 iNews.

title: St. Clair Challenges Panel Warning on Inferences
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The White House challenged today the warning by the House Judiciary Committee that the panel might draw adverse inferences from President INixon's refusal to turn over subpoenaed materials. Such an inference would not be proper or valid, the White House asserted.

title: French President Proposes Civil Rights Appeal Setup
description: PARIS, May 30 President rica Valery Giscard d'Estaing today proposed a series of basic political reforms that would include the establishment of an appeal system for citizens complaining about violations of their civil liberties.

title: Kodes Shoves a Linesman, Is Banned
description: ROME, May 30 (AP)Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, the Wimbledon champion, shoved a linesman today and was disqualified from the $134,000 Rome open tennis tournament.

title: Adm. Joseph P. Canty Dies; Mathematics Professor, 67
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., May 30 (AP)Rear Adm. Joseph P. Canty, U.S.N. retired, who taught mathematics at the University of Maine, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More Trains to Run to the Shore

title: Brookings Study Says Inflation Could Speed Surplus in Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Brookings Institution's annual analysis of the Federal budget found today that inflation was increasing the Government's revenues faster than its spending. As a result it said, there will soon be room again in the budget for new spending initiatives or tax cuts.

title: CONFEREES IN PACT ON AUTO EMISSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters)A SenateHouse conference committee reached agreement on a bill that will allow automobile emission standards fUr the 1975 model year to remain in effect through the 1976 model year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MOVE VOTED, 2810
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The House Judiciary Committee formally warned President Nixon today that his defiance of committee subpoenas might constitute a ground for impeachment.

title: LIBERTY LOAN TALKS ON ACQUISITION END
description: Liberty Loan Corporation and the First National Boston Corporation announced yesterday that discussions on a merger of the two companies were being terminated.

title: SESSION ADJOURNS AS WEE LOSES RENTLAW BATTLE
description: ALBANY, May 30The Republicancontrolled State Assembly today refused an urgent request from Governor Wilson to amend the new rentcontrol law as its leaders adjourned a twoday special session without allowing the Governor's amendments to come to a vote.

title: Baker. Eyes Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today that he expected he would have to go the primary route if he decides to run for President in 1976. He told a National Press Club audience that he doubted the American people, after the experiences of Watergate, would let the politicians choose the Presidential candidates next time.

title: Met Suspends Simon's Show of Asian Art
description: A planned exhibition of Asian art owned by the Norton Simon Foundation, Inc., has been suspended at the Metropolitan Museum of Art because of a disagreement between the foundation and Metropolitan officials.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who has been in frail health in recent months, took part yesterday in the dedication at the United States Military Academy of Eisenhower Hall, a $22.3million recreation facility named for the late President.

title: Contract Awards
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received orders valued at about $34million from the Gulf States Utilities Company for two 600megawatt controlledcirculation coalfired steam generators. The generators will be installed as units 5 and 6 at Gulf States Roy Nelson station near Lake Charles, La.

title: Muscovites Mark Death of Pasternak
Wisconsin, Penn Crews Gain Final at Syracuse
Garment Union Glum On Eve of Convention
description: As more than 1,000 delegates of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union were assembling in Miami for the start today of the organization's 35th convention, leaders here issue'I a woeful report yesterday.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial In Turner Fraud Charge
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 30 (AP)The ninemonth, mailfraud trial of Glenn W. Turner, the Florida businessman, seven former associates and three Turner controlled companies ended today when a Federal judge declared a mistrial.trial cost the Government and defendants about $1million.

title: ECONOMIC REFORM SET IN VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 30 (UPI)Venezuela's Governmentcontrolled Congress gave President Carlos Andres Perez extraordinary powers allowing hint to carry out a fullscale reform of the nation's oilrich economy.

title: WHEAT PRICES OFF ABOUT 5C A BUSHEL
description: Wheat futures prices declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade byi as much as 5 cents a bushel at the close for one delivery. There was a feeling among traders that the reported purchase here by India that caused a price rise Wednesday was not so large or so definite as indicated.

title: NIXON AIDES SCORE STRIPMINING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 30TWo top energy officials of thE Nixon Administration alignec themselves with the coal in. pastry today in a strong attacli on an attempt by Congress to curb environmental abuses of burface mining.

title: Byrne Appeals to Mayors For Support of Tax Plan He Promises Them at Conference That $750Million Package Will Result in Lower Property Levies
description: PRINCETON, May 30Governor Byrne appealed today to New Jersey's mayors and municipal authorities for their support of his proposed incometax program, promising them it would result in a reduction of local property taxes.

title: ERNEST L. BROTHERS
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 30Ernest Lynwood Brothers of 5 Manor Road, an interior decorator, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: 3 Captured and 8 Injured in Cleveland Police Battle

description: WASHINGTON, May 30Following is the text of the response filed in the Supreme Court today by President Nixon's attorneys urging the Court to reject the request of Leon Jaworshi, the special Watergate prosecutor, for expedited review of the Federal District Court ruling that the White House must surrender 64 tape recordings to the prosedutor:

title: Jackson Accuses Soviet Union Of Undermining Mideast Pact
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson decried here last night what he called Soviet efforts to undermine the willingness of some Arab governments to make peace with Israel. Senator Henry M. Jackson

title: Economic Storm
description: Contemplating the state of the American economy, which has been undergoing the worst inflation in its peacetime history, President Nixon finds encouraging signs today that the worst is behind us.... The storms are abating.

title: 2 Upsets in L.I. Tennis
description: ROSLYN, L. I., May 30Joe Bouquin of Danbury, Conn., and Doug Barrow of Bayside, Queens, scored upset victories today in the Long Island men's tennis championships at the Tower Tennis Club. Barrow defeated Mirk Moritz of Old Westbury, 1., 1., 62, 6.7, 63, to reach the quarterfinal round. Bou_quin, a University of Miami player, beat Tom Dughi of Essex Fells, N. J., 75, 57, 6.3, and gained the semifinals.

title: Schmidt to Ask Giscard's Cooperation
description: BONN, May 30  Seeking to case the deep crisis of the European Economic Community, chancellor Helmut Schmidt will nake an urgent proposal for coordination of West German and French economic policies when he goes to Paris tomorrow to meet President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, according to sigh officials here.

title: THING OF DARKNESS LACKS DANCE SPARK
description: Shakespeare's poetry saves his plots from tedium, but June Lewis's adaptation of Hamlet, called This Thing of Darkness, lacked poetic movement. In fact, virtually nothing happened Wednesday evening at the Theater of the Riverside Church as the work received its first performance.

title: Merrill Increases Salaries For 9,200 U.S. Employes
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner; & Smith, Inc., reported that it was granting 9,200 of its 16,500 domestic employes a onetime, acrosstheboard pay increase of 5 per cent.

title: Bean Ahead in Golf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., May 30 (AP)Andy Bean of the University of Florida shot a threeunderpar 69 today at Pensacola Country Club to take a fourstroke lead at 137 in the Amateur Golf Classic.

title: PHIL HOWSER DIES; HORNETS MANAGER
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C. May 30 (AP)Phil Howser, for 32 years general manager of the Charlotte Hornets baseball club, died today at Veterans Hospital in nearby Salisbury. He was 63 years old.

title: Aides Say Kissinger Was Close to Giving Up 3 Times During His Mideast Trip
description: CAIRO, May 30Three times during his grueling month of shuttle diplomacy, Secretary of State Kissinger was close to giving up and returning to Washington without an accord, American officials said today.

title: Market Place: Calgary Oilmen Upset on Future
description: GALGARY, Alberta, May 29  This Is a city that oil built. Some 450,000 people, including an estimated 50,000 Americans, live and work in this city of skyscrapers where major oil companies have their headquarters.

title: Kissinger Heads for Home Alter Tribute From Sadat
description: CAIRO, May 30Secretary of State Kissinger ended his monthlong mission to the Middle East today with assurances from President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that the American position in the area had been immeasurably strengthened as result of the IsraeliSyrian troopdisengagement agreement.

title: Court Bars Presumption That a Nude Is Lewd
description: Being nude in public is not being lewd in public, state appellate court declared yesterday, cutting through semantics and striking down the 1971 conviction of woman who went sunbathing in the nude at Indian Head Beach in Amagansett, L.I.

title: THE TIMES APPOINTS 3 FINANCIAL OFFICERS
description: Three new financial appointments at The New York Times Company were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and president. David L. Gorham was named controller of the company; 1Louis Lazar 3d was appointed the company's director of finance, and Thomas P. McVeigh will become chief finanIcial officer and controller of The New York Times newspaper division.

title: St. Clair's Letter to Judge Gesell in Plumber Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Following is the text of a letter sent today by James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's Watergate counsel, to Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of United States District Court, outlining Mr. Nixon's views on the release of personal White House files sought by Charles W. Colson and John D. Ehrlichman, two defendants in the plumbers case:

title: 3 of 5 in Jersey Poll Want to See Nixon Out
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 30 (AP)  Three out of five New Jerseyans want to see President Nixon out of office, either by resignation or through impeachment and conviction, the Eagleton Institute of Politics reported today.

title: Strikers Yield to Lisbon's Pleas and Return to Work
description: LISBON, May. 30The miltarybacked Government and top trade union leaders, including Communists, succeeded today in getting thousands of wildcat strikers back to work.

title: CONTROLS OPPOSED BY OIL COMPANIES
description: TRENTON, May 30  Representatives of the country's mai jor oil companies today strongI ly opposed two bills that would give New Jersey the power to regulate the petroleum industry within the state.

title: Jaworski Absolves I.T.T. Of Crime in Trust Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor,. said today that his office had found no evidence that executives of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation committed any criminal offenses in connection with the 1971 seltlement of Government antitrust suits against the conglomerate.

title: Article 2  No Title
