Wilson Signs Bill to create A Bond Agency for the City
description: ALBANY, May 30Governor Wilson today announced his approval of a measure authorizing New York City to establish a Stabilization Reserve Corporation with authority to sell $520million in bonds to help meet the city's financial needs.

title: PAN AM RANSOMED PILFERED TICKETS
description: Pan American World Airways secretly paid thousands of dollars to an organizedcrime ring to buy back blank flight tickets stolen from the airline.

title: I.M.F. OIL FACILITY SUPPORTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The United States threw its support today to the proposed oil facility in the International Monetary Fund to help nations cope with the adverse impact of the explosion of oil prices on their balances of payments.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES ON HUMAN TESTING
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Department of Health, Education and Welfare published today regulations codifying its policies for protecting the rights of human subjects of research.

title: Leif Hoegh, 78, Founded Norwegian Shipping Line
description: Leif Hoegh, founder and chairman of Leif Hoegh & Co., shipping company of Oslo, Norway, and former chairman of the Norwegian America Line, died May 23 in Oslo. His age was 78.

title: Airlines Drop Plan
description: Pan American World Airways has withdrawn its initial proposal that it and Trans World Airlines totally consolidate their services and revenues between eight cities in this country and five in Europe. Details on Page 45.

title: Goldman's Inactivity Is Assailed by Weisl
description: After months of deteriorating relations, the Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural 'Affairs, Edwin L. Weisl, said yesterday that Irving Goldman does not appear to be doing anything as Cultural Affairs Commissioner in his department.

title: Stock Prices Rise in Technical Rally
U.N. DELAYS PLAN FOR GOLAN FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30The United States sought unsuccessfully today to get quick Security Council approval for a United Nations observer force to supervise the flew SyrianIsraeli disengagement agreement in the Golan Heights.

title: R, KEITH KANE, 73, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: R. Keith Kane, a New York lawyer who held several posts in Washington, died yesterday of a stroke at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 73 years old and had lived, until his retirement last Dec. 31, at, 121 East 78th Street,

title: BLACK CATHOLICS SEEK LARGER ROLE
description: SAN DIEGO, May 30Black members of the Roman Catholic Church at a sixstate regional Conference have called for an affirmation of black power and commitment to increase their influence and authority within the church.

title: British Open Ulster Talks Amid Gloomy Predictions
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 30  The British Government set out today to seek new answer to the problem of how Northern Ireland can be governed with the consent of both the Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

title: McDonald's Files Suit Against United Airline
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (UPI)The might of a multibillionhamburger operation has been pitted against the power of a multitrillionairmile airline here in a law suit in which the McDonald's Corporation charges United Air Lines with pirating two trademarks.

title: BroadwayHale Stores Lifts Net 12%
It's Graduation Day for 400 in Centers for the Elderly
description: Joseph Schoenberger, a 100yearold retired diamond setter, is the oldest graduate of courses of the Institute of Study for Older Adults, a campus that reaches into 54 retirement homes and centers for the elderly around the city.

title: The Big Steak, Charred Just Perfectly
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire Damages Computer at Clinic

title: NIXON TO FURNISH 2 EXAIDES FILES
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 President Nixon agreed today to allow two Watergate defendants and their attorneys access to the defendants personal White House files.

title: Morgenthau Gets Backing
description: The Lexington Avenue Democratic Club last night voted overwhelmingly to endorse the candidacy of Robert M. Morgenthau for Manhattan District Attorney. The East Side Reform club also endorsed Mark Allan Siegal's campaign to fill the state Assembly seat to be vacated by Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri.

title: It's an American Dream, And It Still Comes True
Cabbie Who Fled Crime Slain on Coast
description: GLENDALE, Calif., May 30  Walter Bernard Strauss, was shot and killed during a holdup of his liquor store here early this week.

title: Italian Bombshell
description: The bomb explosion that killed six, wounded 94 and set off a fourhour nationwide general strike in Italy this week was part, of a continuing pattern of political violence that has been under way for more than five years. While extremists of the left as well as the right have been active, the initiative appears to be that neoFascist forces employing terrorism to undermine confidence, increase instability and provoke disorders of the kind that enabled Mussolini to seize power a halfcentury ago.

title: Sparkman Hopeful Of Becoming Head Of Fulbright Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP)Senator John J. SparkMan, Democrat of Alabama, said today that he would ask for the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee when J. W. Fulbright left that post.

title: Lloyd Heard in Rothko Case
description: Aspects of the operation of the worldwide network of Marlborough Art Galleries began to emerge yesterday as its head, Frank Lloyd, was questioned in Surrogate's Court.

title: Kissinger Heads for Home After Tribute From Sadat
description: CAIRO, May 30Secretary of State Kissinger ended his month long mission to the Middle East today with assurances from President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that the American position in the area had been immeasurably strengthened as result of the IsraeliSyrian troop disengagement agreement.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: CopenhagenJoe Bugner, 220 pounds, Britain knocked out Piermario Baruzzi, 231, Italy, rounds; Tom Boggs, Denmark, outpointed Bunny Sterling, Britain, 10, light heavyweights,

title: MILTON W. HOLDEN
description: Milton W. Holden, a former partner in the Wall Street brokerage firm of Bull, Holden & Co., died Wednesday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and also lived at 530 Park Avenue, and Southampton, LI.

title: AMERICAN ENKA TO RAISE PRICES
description: The American Enka Company, a unit of Akzona, Inc., announced yesterday that it would increase prices by 6 cents a pound on all grades of nylon staple, beginning July 1. A spokesman said that the increase would bring the price of regular grade nylon staple to 78 cents a pound.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.064billion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $933million. Total retail store sales were about 810:545billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $9.874billion.

title: Troubled Memorex Drops 125 of Management Staff
description: The Memorex Corporation, the most volatile and troubleplagued member of the computer industry, dropped 125 management level employes yesterday. The action was among a number of steps by a new chief executive to salvage a company whose losses last year almost caught up with its sales.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST WORRYING PENNCO
description: The Pennsylvania Company, the investment company subsidiary of the bankrupt Penn Cenltral Railroad, said in its 1973 annual report issued yesterday that one of its subsidiaries, the Great Southwest Corporation, might find itself in a critical fiInancial position if it could not come to an agreement with its creditors before the end of the year.

title: Five Testify They Heard Officer Shea Shoot Boy, 10
description: Five South Jamaica residents who live near the lot where Police Officer Thomas Shea shot and killed 10yearold Clifford Glover on April 28, 1973, testified yesterday at Officer Shea's inurder trial in. Supreme Court in Queens. All five said they had heard the shots.

title: Residential Building Contracts Dropped 13% in Value for April
description: The value of new residential building construction contracts last month declined by 13 per cent compared with April of last year, according to a report issued for release today by the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: STRAY DOG HUB LI. BOY AND FLEES
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 30A 5yearold boy was attacked and mauled by a stray dog here today as he waited outside his home for the mail, the Suffolk County police reported. The dog ran away after the attack.

title: White House Granted Delay On Data in Hoffa's Parole
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) A Federal judge today gave tehe White House until Monday to decide whether it will produce documents related to the parole of James R. Hoffa or argue that the material is privileged.

title: STATE APPROVES BLUE SHIELD RISE
description: The State Insurance DepartI ment yesterday announced the approval of an 18.9 per cent average increase in Blue Shield premiums affecting 2.5 million, subscribers. The increase is designed to yield the plan $14million a year.

title: Fifth Avenue, in Its 150th Year, Blooming Again as a Flower in City's Lapel
description: Fifth Avenue is a small dollar sign carved into the Gothic arch over the bride's chapel at St. Thomas's Church. It is an elderly lady ice skating at Rockefeller Center, It is a brigade of Italian and Jewish politicians leading the St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: U.S. Asks Withholding Of Lottery Prize Taxes.
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  The Administration proposed today legislation requiring states to deduct Federal income taxes automatically from any lottery prize money.

title: OUTFLOW SLOWS AT FRANKLIN BANK
description: The hardpressed Franklin National Bank continued to lose deposits in the last week, but the drain has slowed, according to the regular weekly report of the New York Clearing House.

title: Ulster's Big Loser: A Spirit of Compromise
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 30"Back to the womb was the despairing comment of a Roman Catholic leader today on the collapse of two years of efforts to construct the politics of consensus in Northern Ireland. My wife and Analysis were discussing our move at breakfast, said a moderate Protestant who is a highly successful lawyer. Out of the country.

title: ROBERT BRIDGMAN, GEOLOGIST, 58, DIES
description: Robert Ware Bridgman, a geologist and the president of the Mining and Metallurgical Society of America, died Wednesday in New Haven. He was 58 years old and lived in Wiltbn, Conn.

title: Goldman's Inactivity Is Assailed by Weisl
description: After months of deteriorating relations, the Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, Edwin L, Weisl, said yesterday that Irving Goldman does not appear to be doing anything as Cultural Affairs Commissioner in his department.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HAWTHORNE, May 30Lou Turco has thrown his last pitch for Fairleigh Dickinson University and all he can do now is wait for the major league baseball draft and hope that he's selected.

title: Strip Bill Offering Auctioned by Treasury
Yugoslav Party Names Tito as Its Head for Life
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30Yugoslav Communists ended their tenth party congress today with the election of President Tito as head of the party for life and with resolutions to strengthen party influence at every level of national life.

title: OSCAR DOOB, PIONEEA IN MOVIE PROMOTIOA
description: Oscar Doob, a pioneer in motionpicture advertising and promotion, died yesterday in Athens, Ohio, at the age of 83.

title: Anker Sets PaddlingInquiry Deadline
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker told officials of Community School District 9 in the Bronx yesterday that he wanted a full report by next Friday on the district's investigation into charges that students at junior high school had been beaten for bad behavior.

title: RaceFix Jury Goes Out For 5 HoursNo Verdict
description: Ordered to give separate personal study to each of 16 defendants, the jury in the racefixing trial of New York harness drivers deliberated for more than five hours yesterday without reaching a ierdict.

title: City Ballet Dances In the Night And Balanchine  Door and Sigh
description: Jerome Robbins's In the Night and George Balanchine's Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir, both given Wednesday night by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater, are ballets that include episodes treated elsewhere by their choreographers.

title: Trade Groups Acting Quietly to Aid Other Areas, Too
description: When a small manufacturer in Queens found, as one did last month, that trucks could not swing into his loading platform because neighberhood residents were parking too close to his driveway, he didn't go to the Traffic Department to get help. He went to the Queens Chamber of Commerce and the chamber took up his problem with the department.

title: EXTREMIST SUSPECT SHOT DEAD IN ITALY
description: ROME, May 30An alleged member of a rightwing extremist group was shot dead and two policemen were wounded this morning in an exchange of machinegun fire outside a tent in a remote wooded area in the Apennine Mountains.

title: Jipcho Mile Gives I.T.A. Some Hope
description: Ben Jipcho's magnificent mile at Madison Square Garden last Wednesday night (3 minutes 56.6 seconds) has provided fresh promotional ammunition for the International Track Association's professional tour next season.

title: Senate Votes to Ease Access to Federal Documents
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Despite warnings of a possible veto by President Nixon, the Senate approved today, 64 to 17, a bill increasing the public's access to Government information and documents.

title: People in Sports
description: As if being in last place in the National League's Eastern Division wasn't bad enough, the problems of the Pittsburgh Pirates and Manager Danny Murtaugh continued to mount yesterday.

title: NIXON BACKS. STANS ON PRIVACY OF FILES
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) President Nixon filed a formal claim today supporting the refusal of his chief fund raiser in 1972 to release evidence subpoenaed by a grand jury in its investigations of bribery and conspiracy in Mr. Nixon's reelection, campaign.

title: Limited Audit Bill On Reserve Board Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters)The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the Senate a bill calling for limited audit of the Federal Reserve Board by the General Accounting Office. It was a much weaker bill than sponsors of the measure hoped for.

title: REA Express Asks Stay Of C.A.B. Shipping Order
description: REA Express, Inc., whose stock is held by a small group of private investors, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to stay its May 6 orderi terminating the concern's smallshipments air express monopoly as of Aug. 1

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Musicians in Soviet Union Reported Asking Travel Permits
description: MOSCOW, May 30In the wake of the departure of the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich for a twoyear stay in Britain, similar travel requests by other renowned Soviet musicians, including the pianist Sviatoslav Richter, have come to light.

title: Three by Three Recital Offers Flutist, Pianist and a Violinist
description: Three by Three, the innovative recital series first put on last spring by the Carnegie Hall Corporation, is hardly meant to be a gladiatorial contest. But when three soloists (or chamber groups) appear for abhtreviated recitals within an offerall time span of less than three hours, it's difficult to avoid thinking about them in comparative terms. In the case of the second of this year's three grams, offered Wednesday evening, there was no obvious winner, but there was a loser.

title: From Homecoming Queen to New York Career Girl
description: Terry Points, who made history last fall when she became the first black homecoming queen at the University of Alabama, can be found these days toiling her way up the business ladder on East 42d Street.

title: ROBERT L. BEARD
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 30 (UPI)  Robert L. Beard, retired news picture editor for United Press International and ScrippsHoward Newspapers died here yesterday at the age of 76.

title: Outlook for Weekend Fishing
description: Striped bass, ranging from schoolsized fish to giants of more than 40 pounds, are being caught all along the coast from New Jersey to Cape Cod, and bluefish have been taken as far North as Montauk on Long Island. Between Montauk and Cape Cod, few or no bluefish are reported on the beaches, although Martha's Vineyard surf fishermen caught several of them a few days ago.

title: 2 AIRLINES DROP TALKS ON ROUTES
description: Pan American World Airways has withdrawn its initial proposal that it and Trans World Airlines totally consolidate their services and revenues between eight cities in this country and five in Europe, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: ExCity Aide is Named To Family Court Post
description: Joseph B. Williams, the administrator of the city's Model Cities program from 1970 to 1973, was named deputy administrative judge in charge of the city's Family Court yesterday.

title: Valiant Bret At 8 to 1 in Realization
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 Bettors with short memories may look over the field for tomorrow's $96,562.50 Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, see an 8.1 morning line on Valiant Bret, and yawn. For among the eight 4yearolds in the race is the imposing Armbro Nesbit, who this year set the track rceord of 1:56 45 at Yonkers, and has captured 8 of 11 starts in 1974, including 6 under 2 minutes.

title: Nations Vow No Protectionism
OUTFLOW SLOWS AT FRANKLIN BANK
description: The hardpressed Franklin ;National Bank continued to !lose deposits in the last week, but the drain has slowed, according to the regular weekly ;report of the New York Clearing House.

title: NIXON TO FURNISH 2 EXAIDES FILES
description: WASHINGTON, May 30i President Nixon agreed today to allow two Watergate de: fendants and their attorneys access to the defendants per1 sonal White House files.

title: Red Smith
description: Bud Harrelson expected to be booed when he made his first appearance of the year in Cincinnati last Monday, and he was not disappointed. Followers of the Reds had not forgotten how this 150pound brute had sprung upon the 200pound Pete Rose last October and struck him repeated blows. When Rose goes to bat for the first time in Shea Stadium next Monday night, admirers of the Mets will, no doubt, give him a piece of their mind, whether they can afford it or not. For Sparky Anderson's sake, not mention Rose's, it is hoped they stop there. Sparky gets upset when fans throw whisky bottles at his left fielder's skull, they did after his fight with Harrelson during the pennant playoff. The Reds manager never did care much for whisky.

title: Watson Leads by I As 67 Break Par
People and Business
description: Ridgeley P. Ware, president of Associated Advisers, Inc., suggested yesterday that real estate investment trusts might begin to stabilize themselves if they adopted a uniform code for accounting, taxes and public resorting.

title: Globetrotters Serious on Union
description: Why, someone asked Bobby Hunter, did the Harlem Globetrotters want to join janitors union?

title: Outlook for Weekend Fishing
description: Striped bass, ranging from schoolsized fish to giants of more than 40 pounds, are being caught all along the coast from New Jersey to Cape Cod, and bluefish have been taken as far North as Montauk on Long Island. Between Montauk and Cape Cod, few or no bluefish are reported on the ,beaches, although Martha's Vineyard surf fishermen caught several of them a few days ago.

title: TV: Sty of the Blind Pig
description: Hollywood Television Theater returned to public television this week with a production of Phillip Hayes Dean's The Sty of the Blind Pig. The Wednesday night broadcast will be repeated this evening at 10:30. The play had been presented on stage by New York's Negro Ensemble Company in 1971.

title: SCHOOL UNIT CHIDED ON PLEAS FOR FUNDS
description: Elected city officials took the Board of Education to task at a budget hearing yesterday for assertedly encouraging a parade of students, teachers, parents and schooldistrict representatives to plead for more money at a time when enrollment in, the public schools is declining. The criticism came the second day of joint hearings at City Hall by the Board of Estimate and the Finance Committee of the City Council on Mayor Beame's proposed $11.1billion expense budget for the 197475 fiscal year.

title: BANKERS OPPOSING SA VINGSBANKCHECKS
description: The New York State Bankers Association disclosed yesterday it was considering a lawsuit against one of the four leading savings banks that have introduced checking accounts. The association also said that it had asked the Governor for legislative relief.

title: Reid Halts His Campaign Amid Rumors of a Pullout
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid, who has been campaign ning intensively for the Democratic nomination for Governor, yesterday unexpectedly can celed his weekend campaign Appearances and an expensive television advertising campaign. His moves gave rise to speculation that he was pulling out of, the race, but a close aide warned against any such assumption. He had announced details of the television campaign only the day before.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 33 From WeekAgo Level
South Shore Wins P.S.A.L. Net Title
description: South Shore High School won its second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League tennis title yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. The South Shore team routed Madison, 50.

title: Vietcong Leave Meetings On Men Missing in Action
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Kay; 30The Vietcong withdrew today from talks designed to exchange information on men missing in action, a move apparently intended to bring pressure on the South Vietnarriese Government to restore the Communists access to the foreign press.

title: Japan to Lend to Petroperu
description: TOKYO, May 30 (UPI)The Japan Petroleum Development Corporation said today it had signed an agreement to extend a $330million loan to the Peruvian National Oil Company, Petroperu, in return for a stable oil supply to Japan over a 10year period beginning in 1978. Petroperu will use the loan to finance oil exploration and the installation of a 527mile oil pipeline linking oil fields in North Peruvian jungles to the Pacific Coast.

title: HAITI SUITE GIVEN WITH SOLO DANCES
description: Open Eye is a group of actors, dancers, musicians and singers who, on Wednesday at the Exchange Theater, joined their talents to create an event, Haitian Suite 74", directed by Teiji Ito.

title: Ballet: The Simplicity of Feld's Revival of Sephardic Song
A MISTRIAL RULED IN FOAM CASE
description: TRENTON, May 30  The bribery and conspiracy trial of tarmer State Treasurer Joseph McCrane Jr. and two other prominent New Jersey Republicans ended In a mistrial today, day after it started.

title: HOVE VOTED, 2810
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The House Judiciary Committee formally warned President Nixon today that his defiance of committee subpoenas might constitute a ground for impeachment.

title: In Colorado, Bad Days for a Cattleman
description: DENVERKen Monfort, whose Coloradobased company is the world's largest producer of grainfattened cattle, sold a steer one day recently and instead of making a profit he lost $125.

title: ERITREAN HOSPITALS CLOSED AS PROTEST
description: Two hospitals operated by British missionary groups have been closed in the Ethiopian province of Eritrea to protest the abduction of a 24yearold New Jersey nurse by guerrillas, it was reported here yesterday.

title: Head of the New School Is Lampooned
description: The New School for Social Research, which likes its anniversaries, brought the leaders Of New York's educational poli tical and cultural scene together at the Plaza Hotel last night to celebrate John R. Everett's first decade as presi dent.

title: Excerpts From Mrs, Meir's Speech to Israeli Parliament on the Accord With Syria
description: JERUSALEM, May 30Following are excerpts, in official translation, from Premier Golda Meir's speech to Israel's Parliament today on the disengagement agreeMent with Syria:

title: ENERGY TARGETS FOR EUROPE SET
Jaworski Absolves I.T.T. Of Crime in Trust Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, said today that his office had found no evidence that executives of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation committed any criminal offenses in connection with the 1971 settlement of Government antitrust suits against the conglomerate.

title: Text of the Agreement and a Protocol
description: CAIRO, May 30 (AP)Following are the texts of the disengagement agreement to be signed tomorrow by Israel and Syria and of a protocol on the United Nations observer force, as made public by American officials:

title: Article 1  No Title
Yanks Beat Mets In Mayor's Game
Slater Terms Cash the Best Investment
description: LONDON, May 30  Slater, Walker, Securities Ltd., the diversified investment banking concern, has been liquidating its assets because of a conviction that cash is the best investment in the uncertain economic climate of today, according to James D. Slater, chairman.

title: Music: Patches Recital
description: There are not many American singers who could or would devote an entire recital to music by Polish composers, but Elizabeth Patches did just that at Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Miss Patches has sung in. Poland and has developed a facility in the Polish language; her recital was presented under the auspices of Kazimierz H. Cias, the Polish consul here, and the Slavic Cultural Center of Port Jefferson, N.Y. The event celebrated the 30th anniversary of the Polish People's Republic.

title: $10Million Set for WNET by Ford
description: In closing out its involve meat with public television after some 23 years, the Eon Foundation has designates $10millionthe largest of it terminal grants  for WNET Channel 13, to help preserve the New York station's status as a leading force in the non commercial system, it was learned yesterday. The amount is to be disbursed over a perioc of tour years and Is conditiona mon the station's ability to raise a matching amount from the, public during that period, over and above its present 200,. 000 paid subscriptions.

title: A.T.&T. Ends Pay Inequity For Managerial Employes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The American Telephone and Tele1 graph Company agreed today to give back pay and future; pay adjustments totaling $30million to 25,000 of its managerial employes who have suffered discrimination in pay.

title: Body Exhumed in Inquiry on Wife's Honeymoon Death
description: TRENTON, May 30 (UF I) The body of Mrs. Patricia Ann Albanowski Giesick, formerly of Monmouth Junction, was removed from its grave today for a hair sample to be used in the murder investigation centering on her husband and a Texas massage parlor owner. The sealed metal coffin was removed from a concrete underground vault at St. Hedwig's Cemetery in Ewing Township and brought to a funeral home, where some 30 hairs were clipped.

title: SHARP GAIN IN NET REPORTED BY B.P.
description: LONDON, May 30The British Petroleum Company reported today that its earnings in the first quarter of 1974 had increased sharply from the yearearlier level, mainly because of a nonrecurring gain attributed to the impact of price increases on oil inventories.

title: PIANO CONSISTENCY IS SHOWN BY GARNER
description: Erroll Garner is one of those remarkable musicians who very early in their careers found their complete musical identities and have maintained them almost unchanged ever since. The Erroll Garner who is playing piano in the Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel for the next three weeks , has, in general, changed very little from the Erroll Garner who played in the small jazz rooms on 52d Street 30 years ago.

title: Owners Break Ice In N.F.L.
description: The National Football League owners, in an attempt to get the sticky negotiations with the N.F.L. Players Association off dead center, made a goodwill gesture this week by agreeing to pick up the players health insurance premiums for six weeks until July 15.

title: Paper Says Petersen Quotes Nixon on Job
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP)President Nixon asked Henry E. Petersen whether he would like to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the time Mr. Petersen was heading the Justice Department investigation of the Watergate scandal, The Evening Bulletin reported today.
